NYT Picture clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may download them from Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at 214-392-0888. Non-clients can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204.   (NYT22) BOULDER, Colo. -- November 3, 1994 -- RUN-NY-MARATHON-PRASAD, 11-3 -- Nadia Prasad, who finished third in last year's New York City Marathon, and her husband, Binesh, training near their home in Boulder, Colo. ``It felt like a knife poking me in the side,'' Mrs. Prasad said in regard to an agonizing pain she endured during the marathon. ``I had started too fast, then I didn't know how to grab the water bottles. I was scared of them. I was drinking too fast and I got a stitch.'' (William R. Sallaz/New York Times Photo)   (NYT21) HARDING HILL, West Virginia -- November 3, 1994 -- W.VA.-BYRD, 11-3 -- Projects financed by federal money that Sen. Robert C. Byrd has won for West Virginia are nothing new. Having brought thousands of federal jobs to the state, he has a good head start on transplanting the entire government to West Virginia. One such project was the building of a 12-mile stretch of highway where he presided at a ribbon-cutting ceremony last week. (Gary Truman/New York Times Photo)   (NYT20) LOS ANGELES -- November 3, 1994 -- MCA-MATSUSHITA, 11-3 -- Sidney J. Sheinberg, president of MCA, in his Universal City office. Sheinberg, along with MCA's 81-year-old chairman and chief executive, Lew R. Wasserman, had traveled to Osaka in September to propose that Matsushita - MCA's parent company - invest in and American television broadcast network. They were turned down and left for America feeling like they had been ``treated as children.'' (Steve Goldstein/New York Times Photo)   (NYT19) HAYWARD, Calif. -- November 3, 1994 -- POLITICS-PANIC, 11-3 -- TOP Kathleen Brown, who is trying to catch up with Gov. Pete Wilson in the hard-fought race in California, campaigned in Hayward, near San Francisco, on Wednesday. One of her senior advisers said: ``The formula changes by the hour. We change our messages all the time, every day.'' Bruce Benson, a Republican making a last-ditch effort to catch up to Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, has started running tougher ads. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photos)   (NYT18) BOISE, Idaho -- November 3, 1994 -- IDAHO-RABBI, 11-3 -- Rabbi Daniel B. Fink will be installed Friday night as the first full-time rabbi in Boise, Idaho. ``It is in a lot of ways a pioneering position,'' said Fink, 33, who was previously an associate rabbi at a synagogue in Omaha. ``It is a congregation that has a long history, a history of lay involvement, but no rabinic history. So, it offers a rabbi a chance to come in and not be bound by what previous rabbis have done.'' (Glenn Oakley/New York Times Photo)   (NYT17) WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. -- November 3, 1994 -- WILLIAMS-COLLEGE, 11-3 -- Dick Farley (center) is the coach of the unbeaten Williams football team Ephmen. The overall record of the school's varsity teams this autumn was 89-12-1. Williams has only 1,963 students, of whom half are women. But the Ephs' successes have been a constant, beyond the cyclical nature of sports. (Kevin Kennefick/New York Times Photo)   (NYT16) TOKYO -- November 3, 1994 -- JAPAN-BYPASS, 11-3 -- While many American companies are growing less interested in Japan, others keep pushing to penetrate a difficult market. ``Certainly a lot of American businessmen come through here and tell me that in terms of opportunity costs, they are increasingly of the view that they better spend more time elsewhere in the Asian market,'' said Walter Mondale, the U.S. ambassador to Japan. A Ford dealership in western Tokyo offered a selection of imported sedans. (Noboro Hashimoto/New York Times Photo)   (NYT15) ROME -- November 3, 1994 -- ITALY-ANTIQUITIES, 11-3 -- The Colosseum may be the symbol of the permanence of Rome, but 2,000 years have taken a heavy toll. Flower gardens are now being planted as Rome undertakes a $25 million restoration of the monument. The improvements are intended to quiet the vibrations caused by traffic and reduce the exhaust fumes that eat away its facade of travertine. (Carlo Lannutti/New York Times Photo)   (NYT14) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- NY-FASHION-BLASS, 11-3 -- FROM LEFT: New take on the sweater set by Bill Blass in pink and white checks with a bustier tank; Floral taffeta dress with checked bustle by Blass; Black taffeta ballerina-length dress with a bustier top by Oscar de la Renta; White satin short-sleeved jacket by de la Renta was shown with a navy bustle skirt. (Corina Lecca/New York Times Photo)   (NYT13) GLENDIVE, Montana -- November 3, 1994 -- WEST-DEMS, 11-3 -- Seeking the middle ground between the clashing interests of the old and new forces of the West, Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mt., sometimes travels 500 miles a day in his district, the largest in the lower 48 states. Last month the Congressman visited with customers barbershop in Glendive, Mont. (Larry Mayer/New York Times Photo)   (NYT12) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- NY-FASHION-SUI, 11-3 -- FROM LEFT: Anna Sui's black and blue rose-print wrap top, black satin bra and rose-print shorts; Sui's black leather jacket, red devil T-shirt and chartreuse satin slip skirt; Ghost's fuchsia beaded antique-lace cut-away dress with poppy beaded antique-lace bolero and cowboy hat; Finis' Laura Petrie look: a jacket with three-quarter-length-sleeves, marabou trim and plaid tweed cropped trousers. (Marilynn K. Yee/New York Times Photos)   (NYT11) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- DINOSAUR-EMBRYO, 11-3 -- In a discovery that should extend knowledge of the life cycle of dinosaurs, paleontologists exploring the Gobi Desert of Mongolia have found the first fossilized embryo of a meat-eating dinosaur. The 75-million-year-old specimen - the most exquisitely preserved embryo ever found - was discovered by Dr. Mark A. Norell, the associate curator of vertebrate paleontology at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. (Fred R. Conrad/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH HUGHES-INSTITUTE BY ROBERT D. HERSHEY   (NYT10) CHEVY CHASE, Maryland -- November 3, 1994 -- HUGHES-INSTITUTE, 11-3 -- ``I just try to orchestrate things,'' said C.F. Wolfe, installed May 1 as chief investment officer of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, the philanthropic legacy of the aviation pioneer, film maker and industrialist. ``I'm the conductor.'' LEFT TO RIGHT: Dr. Purnell W. Choppin, president, C.F. Wolfe, Nina Scherago, Lillian Blucher and Ellen Safir. (Stephen Crowley/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH JORDAN-PROFILE BY JOHN HOLUSHA   (NYT9) PITTSBURGH -- November 3, 1994 -- JORDAN-PROFILE, 11-3 -- Associates describe Westinghouse Electric Co. chairman Michael H. Jordan as an informal man, who insists on being called Mike, drives himself to work and often travels alone or with one or two other executives. ``This guy wants to get in tight with the people who are running the businesses,'' said one executive. ``It's not a game anymore.'' (Steve Mellon/New York Times Photo)   (NYT8) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- NY-LATAM-ARTISTS, 11-3 -- ``The Dinner,'' a mixed-media work on paper by Nahum Zenil, from the ``Cartographies'' show at the Bronx Museum of the Arts. The show, organized by the Winnipeg Art Gallery in Manitoba, Canada, brings together 14 Latin American artists, several of whom have shown in New York. But neither the specific works nor the essays in the show's vague, buzzword-filled catalogue suggest why they were deemed suitable company. (Chris Maynard/New York Times Photo)   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- KOOLHAAS, 11-3 -- New York City's most important architect lives in London, works in Rotterdam, and has yet to build a thing on the North American continent. But, for the next three months, Rem Koolhaas has the stage at the Museum of Modern Art, where New Yorkers can see how their city continues to shape the world even as their own architecture has become less than world-class. Bus-stop poster boxes guide visitors through the exhibition of Koolhaas' work. (Jose R. Lopez/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH HANRAHAN-MUSIC BY JASON WEISS   (NYT6) UNDATED -- November 3, 1993 -- HANRAHAN-MUSIC, 11-3 -- For 15 years as a composer and producer, Kip Hanrahan, right, has somehow kept fame at arm's length, yet many top musicians admire his work. A New Yorker to the bone and about to turn 40, Hanrahan has been making connections between musical styles long before pop stars were dabbling in world music. He works with Eric Schenkman. (Suzanne DeChillo/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH LASALLE-ER-TV BY ANDY MEISLER   (NYT5) LOS ANGELES -- November 3, 1994 -- LASALLE-ER-TV, 11-3 -- Eriq La Salle, the 32-year-old actor, who plays Dr. Peter Benton in NBC's new hit series, ``E.R.'' ``Where I grew up,'' La Salle says,'' the philosophy in my community was that you can't be as good as your white counterparts; you have to be better. And Benton, my character, I think, embodies what I've learned.'' (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH ONLINE-COMPUTATOES BY JAMES BARRON   (NYT4) UNDATED -- November 3, 1994 -- ONLINE-COMPUTATOES, 11-3 -- There is a special synergy between television and cyberspace, and how the two mediums overlap affects them both. Christopher Fusco, an active on-line user watching television with his computer monitor in the background. (Karin Anderson/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH SHOSTAKOVICH-OPERA BY RICHARD TARUSKIN   (NYT3) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- SHOSTAKOVICH-OPERA, 11-3 -- On Thursday evening the Metropolitan Opera will finally get around to Dmitri Shostakovich's second opera, ``Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk,'' 60 years after its first production. Maria Ewing will sing the title role in Graham Vick's production, with James Conlon conducting. Here the cast and crew of ``Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk'' rehearse at the Met. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH ELECTRONIC-CAFE BY WENDY SMITH   (NYT2) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- ELECTRONIC-CAFE, 11-3 -- Examples of the ``virtual stage,'' are created at various outposts of the Electronic Cafe International, a network of sites around the world linked by teleconferencing systems, videophones and computers. Testing part of the Electronic Cafe at the Kichen, a performance oriented club are, left, Ben Beill, a music curator; Lauren Amazeen, seated, the Kitchen's executive director; John Maxwell Hobbs, operations director, and DJ Spooky, a musician. (Fred R. Conrad/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH FOOTE-THEATER BY WILBORN HAMPTON   (NYT1) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- FOOTE-THEATER, 11-3 -- Anyone familiar with Horton Foote's work knows details are vital, and Hallie Foote's attention to them is one of the reasons she is the chief interpreter of her father's plays. Ms. Foote who is in her late 30s, stars in ``Night Season,'' written and directed by Horton Foote. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)   NEW YORK TIMES NEWS SERVICE  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941103.0384 type=story > <HEADLINE> 17 WARRANT EVADERS ARE ARRESTED IN RAIDS AT THEIR HOMES </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> NEW YORK  (BC-NY-WARRANT-SQUAD-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"
"8098"	"I"	"think"	" ``You'll notice robberies went way down in the subways,'' said Thomas Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941103.0385 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's New York Times Photo Full picture package moving: 11/3/94.   NYT Picture clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may download them from Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at 214-392-0888. Non-clients can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204.   (NYT22) BOULDER, Colo. -- November 3, 1994 -- RUN-NY-MARATHON-PRASAD, 11-3 -- Nadia Prasad, who finished third in last year's New York City Marathon, and her husband, Binesh, training near their home in Boulder, Colo. ``It felt like a knife poking me in the side,'' Mrs. Prasad said in regard to an agonizing pain she endured during the marathon. ``I had started too fast, then I didn't know how to grab the water bottles. I was scared of them. I was drinking too fast and I got a stitch.'' (William R. Sallaz/New York Times Photo)   (NYT21) HARDING HILL, West Virginia -- November 3, 1994 -- W.VA.-BYRD, 11-3 -- Projects financed by federal money that Sen. Robert C. Byrd has won for West Virginia are nothing new. Having brought thousands of federal jobs to the state, he has a good head start on transplanting the entire government to West Virginia. One such project was the building of a 12-mile stretch of highway where he presided at a ribbon-cutting ceremony last week. (Gary Truman/New York Times Photo)   (NYT20) LOS ANGELES -- November 3, 1994 -- MCA-MATSUSHITA, 11-3 -- Sidney J. Sheinberg, president of MCA, in his Universal City office. Sheinberg, along with MCA's 81-year-old chairman and chief executive, Lew R. Wasserman, had traveled to Osaka in September to propose that Matsushita - MCA's parent company - invest in and American television broadcast network. They were turned down and left for America feeling like they had been ``treated as children.'' (Steve Goldstein/New York Times Photo)   (NYT19) HAYWARD, Calif. -- November 3, 1994 -- POLITICS-PANIC, 11-3 -- TOP Kathleen Brown, who is trying to catch up with Gov. Pete Wilson in the hard-fought race in California, campaigned in Hayward, near San Francisco, on Wednesday. One of her senior advisers said: ``The formula changes by the hour. We change our messages all the time, every day.'' Bruce Benson, a Republican making a last-ditch effort to catch up to Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, has started running tougher ads. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photos)   (NYT18) BOISE, Idaho -- November 3, 1994 -- IDAHO-RABBI, 11-3 -- Rabbi Daniel B. Fink will be installed Friday night as the first full-time rabbi in Boise, Idaho. ``It is in a lot of ways a pioneering position,'' said Fink, 33, who was previously an associate rabbi at a synagogue in Omaha. ``It is a congregation that has a long history, a history of lay involvement, but no rabinic history. So, it offers a rabbi a chance to come in and not be bound by what previous rabbis have done.'' (Glenn Oakley/New York Times Photo)   (NYT17) WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. -- November 3, 1994 -- WILLIAMS-COLLEGE, 11-3 -- Dick Farley (center) is the coach of the unbeaten Williams football team Ephmen. But the Ephs' successes have been a constant, beyond the cyclical nature of sports. A Ford dealership in western Tokyo offered a selection of imported sedans. But neither the specific works nor the essays in the show's vague, buzzword-filled catalogue suggest why they were deemed suitable company. (Chris Maynard/New York Times Photo)   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- KOOLHAAS, 11-3 -- New York City's most important architect lives in London, works in Rotterdam, and has yet to build a thing on the North American continent. But, for the next three months, Rem Koolhaas has the stage at the Museum of Modern Art, where New Yorkers can see how their city continues to shape the world even as their own architecture has become less than world-class. Bus-stop poster boxes guide visitors through the exhibition of Koolhaas' work. (Jose R. Lopez/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH HANRAHAN-MUSIC BY JASON WEISS   (NYT6) UNDATED -- November 3, 1993 -- HANRAHAN-MUSIC, 11-3 -- For 15 years as a composer and producer, Kip Hanrahan, right, has somehow kept fame at arm's length, yet many top musicians admire his work. A New Yorker to the bone and about to turn 40, Hanrahan has been making connections between musical styles long before pop stars were dabbling in world music. He works with Eric Schenkman. (Suzanne DeChillo/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH LASALLE-ER-TV BY ANDY MEISLER   (NYT5) LOS ANGELES -- November 3, 1994 -- LASALLE-ER-TV, 11-3 -- Eriq La Salle, the 32-year-old actor, who plays Dr. Peter Benton in NBC's new hit series, ``E.R.'' ``Where I grew up,'' La Salle says,'' the philosophy in my community was that you can't be as good as your white counterparts; you have to be better. And Benton, my character, I think, embodies what I've learned.'' (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH ONLINE-COMPUTATOES BY JAMES BARRON   (NYT4) UNDATED -- November 3, 1994 -- ONLINE-COMPUTATOES, 11-3 -- There is a special synergy between television and cyberspace, and how the two mediums overlap affects them both. Christopher Fusco, an active on-line user watching television with his computer monitor in the background. (Karin Anderson/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH SHOSTAKOVICH-OPERA BY RICHARD TARUSKIN   (NYT3) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- SHOSTAKOVICH-OPERA, 11-3 -- On Thursday evening the Metropolitan Opera will finally get around to Dmitri Shostakovich's second opera, ``Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk,'' 60 years after its first production. Maria Ewing will sing the title role in Graham Vick's production, with James Conlon conducting. Here the cast and crew of ``Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk'' rehearse at the Met. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH ELECTRONIC-CAFE BY WENDY SMITH   (NYT2) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- ELECTRONIC-CAFE, 11-3 -- Examples of the ``virtual stage,'' are created at various outposts of the Electronic Cafe International, a network of sites around the world linked by teleconferencing systems, videophones and computers. Testing part of the Electronic Cafe at the Kichen, a performance oriented club are, left, Ben Beill, a music curator; Lauren Amazeen, seated, the Kitchen's executive director; John Maxwell Hobbs, operations director, and DJ Spooky, a musician. (Fred R. Conrad/New York Times Photo)   ADVANCE FOR SUN. NOV. 6 WITH FOOTE-THEATER BY WILBORN HAMPTON   (NYT1) NEW YORK -- November 3, 1994 -- FOOTE-THEATER, 11-3 -- Anyone familiar with Horton Foote's work knows details are vital, and Hallie Foote's attention to them is one of the reasons she is the chief interpreter of her father's plays. Ms. Foote who is in her late 30s, stars in ``Night Season,'' written and directed by Horton Foote. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)   NEW YORK TIMES NEWS SERVICE  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941103.0387 type=story > <HEADLINE> SHOTS ON VAN ARE RECALLED BY STUDENTS </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> NEW YORK  (BC-HASIDIC-SHOOTING-TRIAL-600&AMP;ADD-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"
"8118"	"you"	"think"	" If the allegations are true, the players should have been declared ineligible under NCAA rules. . </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941104.0069 type=multi > <HEADLINE> CAPSULE REVIEWS OF CURRENT FILMS </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(6takes)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> These brief reviews of current movies are written by Cox News Service movie critic Eleanor Ringel. They move weekly to clients of the New York Times News Service.   G: General audiences. Nothing that would offend parents if viewed by children.   PG: Parental guidance suggested. May contain some material parents consider inappropriate for young children.   PG-13: Parents strongly cautioned. Some material may be inappropriate for preteens.   R: Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. Parents are urged to learn more about the film before taking children.   NC-17: No one under 17 admitted. Replaces the X rating.   NR: Not rated.   Above the Rim R   A perfectly commendable above-average after-school special, except for one problem: It thinks it's a real movie, aimed, perhaps, at the ``New Jack City'' crowd. Duane Martin (a Knicks prospect-turned-actor) stars as a high school hotshot who sees a college athletic scholarship as his ticket out of Harlem and into the NBA. Directed by Jeff Pollack. Rated R for language, sexual innuendo and some violence.   The Adventures of Priscilla,   Queen of the Desert R   The boys on the bus would rather be thought of as the girls on the bus in this spirited Aussie froth about two drag queens (Hugo Weaving and Guy Pearce) and a transsexual ('60s stud Terence Stamp) on a cross-country jaunt through the Outback. The titular Priscilla is their vehicle -- a battered, unreliable bus that takes them from the sophistication of big-city Sydney to the wilds of Alice Springs where they've been asked to perform their act. Rated R for sex-related situations and language.   Andre PG   Predictable but sweet, this seal saga is a decent primer for kids learning some basic lesson about family and friendship. But be forewarned: Andre's best trick is to blow derogatory raspberries. Don't be surprised if your kids pick up the habit. Starring Keith Carradine. Rated PG for scenes of animal endangerment. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Angels in the Outfield PG   This kid-pleasing baseball fantasy about a lonely boy, a slumping baseball team and some divine intervention is a winged victory for Disney, thanks to a strong cast and heart- tugging plot. Think ``Free Willy'' with the California Angels instead of a whale. Starring Danny Glover and Christopher Lloyd. Directed by William Dear. Rated PG for mild adult themes.   Baby's Day Out PG   A very long day indeed, for Baby and for the audience. This John Hughes-ian spin on ``The Ransom of Red Chief'' is best recommended to die-hard slapstick fans who've always wanted to see a remake of ``Three Men and a Baby,'' starring the Three Stooges. Three bumbling crooks (Joe Mantegna, Joe Pantoliano, Brian Haley) kidnap a troublesome 9-month-old Bennington August Cottwell IV, a.k.a., Baby Bink. They learn that grabbing a curious tot is easier than holding onto him. Directed by Patrick Read Johnson. Rated PG for comic violence.   Barcelona PG-13   Set in Spain, Whit Stillman's literate, witty romantic comedy takes place within the socio-political context of ``the last decade of the Cold War.'' Starring Taylor Nichols and Chris Eigemann. Rated PG-13 for language and violence.   Black Beauty G   A beauty. This adaption of the classic 19th-century horse story offers a classy cast (headed by David Thewlis) and a sublime period setting, along with the expected equine enchantments. Directed by Caroline Thompson.   Blankman PG-13   Daman Wayans stars as a nerdy inventor who becomes a bargain-basement superhero. The movie has a few humorous moments, at least enough to fill a five-minute ``In Living Color'' sketch, but stretched out to feature-film length, the joke wears more than a bit thin. Directed by Mike Binder. Rated   PG-13 for profanity, some violence, and some sexual situations.   Bullets Over Broadway PG   It's as if Woody Allen decided to make a movie like the movie- within-the-movie in ``The Purple Rose of Cairo.'' Working in his Runyon-esque ``Broadway Danny Rose'' mode, he takes us back to the Great White Way of the Roaring '20s, for a theater-centric farce that ends up debating the artist vs. the man (something Woody's probably heard a lot of recently). John Cusack is the ardent young playwright who believes in Art and Jennifer Tilly is the no- talent moll whose gangster-boyfriend bankrolls his play so she can go onstage. The rest of the cast includes Dianne Wiest as a Norma Desmond-ish grand damme; Tracey Ullman as a chirpy, life-of-the-Green-Room type; and Chazz Palminteri as Tilly's thug-like bodyguard who turns out to have a playwright's soul. The disturbing thing about ``Bullets'' is how safe it is. How it presents a moral dilemma but tackles it in a blinkered wish-fulfillment style. That the uncouth Palminteri could be a better writer than the artsy Cusack is a surprise to NYC intelligentsia, but not to most of us. There are some great acting opportunities here (may both Wiest and Palminteri reap Best Supporting nominations), but as a Woody Allen film, this one is a bit disappointing.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941104.0070 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(2ndtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Cafe au Lait NR   A very strong cup of coffee might help you through this fumbling French romantic comedy, but I wouldn't bet on it. Writer/director/star Mathieu Kassovitz has a bad case of the Spike Lee wannabes. That he's white and French isn't the problem; that he doesn't have one-tenth of Spike's talent is. Kassovitz casts himself as one of two guys (the other is a Parisian Sidney Poitier-type played by Hubert Kounde) who learn, one, that their girlfried Lola (Julie Maudeuch) has been sleeping with both of them and, two, that she's pregnant, but doesn't know by whom. If this sounds a whole lot like ``She's Gotta Have It,'' it should.   Clear and Present Danger PG-13   Even when this new installment in the Tom Clancy film-adaptation franchise is far from clear, it's dangerously entertaining. Reteaming director Phillip Noyce and star Harrison Ford as CIA analyst Jack Ryan, it's more convoluted than ``Patriot Games.'' But also more gripping. Rated PG-13 for some intense action, violence and language. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Clerks R   Quirky, irreverent and about as off-the-cuff casual as a movie can be (even a $27,000 movie), this black-and-white no-budget-er has been a prize winner at Cannes and Sundance. Filmmaker Kevin Smith (who also appears in the picture as an enigmatic hanger-on named Silent Bob) gives us a day in the life of a couple of twentysomething Jersey guys named Dante (Brian O'Halloran) and Randal (Jeff Anderson). The two hold down dead-end jobs at, respectively, a Quick Stop convenience store and the neighboring hole-in-the-wall video store. Somewhere beyond slackers, they spend their days discussing the merits of ``The Empire Strikes Back'' vs. ``Return of the Jedi'' (``Justa bunch of Muppets'') while waiting on the usual eccentric crew of customers (like the guy who gets his hand stuck in a Pringle's potato chip can). The film looks just as raw as you'd expect, but it's also brimming with personality, humor and a genuine independent spirit. Absurdist, smutty and completely comfortable with itself, ``Clerks'' is grunge cinema at its best.   The Client PG-13   Susan Sarandon and Tommy Lee Jones are wonderful together in yet another John Grisham story. Unfortunately, they play supporting roles to a kid actor who's very impressive, but can't outshine them. Directed by Joel Schumacher. Rated PG-13 for violence and language.   Corrina, Corrina PG   In this beautifully acted, wonderfully perceptive comedy-drama, Whoopi Goldberg plays a '50s housekeeper who makes Mrs. Doubtfire look like W.C. Fields. Directed by Jessie Nelson. Rated PG for adult themes.   Crooklyn PG-13   Spike Lee's affectionate return to the Brooklyn of his youth is a sweet and funny change of pace. Starring Alfre Woodard, Delroy Lindo and Zelda Harris. Rated PG-13 for some profanity, scenes of neighborhood drug use, splintering family unit, kids pranks that include death of dog.   The Crow R   The true-life tragedy hanging over this action film -- a misfired prop gun that killed star Brandon Lee on the set -- is a lot creepier than anything in the movie itself. Still, it's more than a morbid curiosity, thanks to the young star himself. Lee plays a dead rock musician who rises from the grave to avenge the murders of himself and his fiancee. Directed by Alex Proyas. Rated R for violence and language.   I Don't Want to Talk About It PG-13   The ``It'' in this strangely affecting Argentinian film is the physicality of the daughter of a wealthy South American widow named Dona Leonor (Luisina Brando). Her teenager, Charlotte (Alejandra Podesta), is smart, loving, well-read, an accomplished pianist and a devoted daughter. She is also vertically challenged -- or, as they used to say, a dwarf. However, Dona Leonor won't say it (she also burns copies of ``Tom Thumb'') and she won't allow her neighbors to mention it either. The movie takes an odder-still twist when a mysterious roue (Marcello Mastroianni) comes to town and falls for Charlotte. The picture benefits from its bizarre set-up, a poetically Fellini-esque finale and Brando's chilling portrayal of a manipulative, overprotective parent. But director Maria Luisa Bemberg lets things go a bit flat in the middle and it's only thanks to Mastroianni's decades of expertise and innate courtly charisma that we remain interested during the slow spots. Still, the movie deserves points for acting, tone and originality; after all, how many movies try to mix psychotic denial and magic realism in one story?   Double Dragon PG-13   This film version of the popular video game is a cynical attempt at duping young fans into paying to watch a 93-minute commercial for the game and its inevitable sequels. Yet it's also surprisingly grim, considering the target audience. Set in the year 2007, the film blithely presents a nightmarish city ravaged by smog, earthquakes and marauding gangs straight out of ``The Warriors.'' The plot -- less complex than a Pong tournament -- involves a futuristic struggle for a magic Chinese talisman that grants its possessor vague powers over the ``body and soul.'' Half of the ``Double Dragon'' is being guarded by the wise- cracking, kick-boxing Lee brothers -- played in an interesting bit of casting by Mark Dacascos (who looks Asian) and TV's ``Party of Five'' star Scott Wolf (who looks like Tom Cruise). The evil tycoon who holds the other half is played by Robert Patrick, best known as the mighty morphin' cyborg in ``Terminator 2.'' Once again Patrick plays a character who shape-shifts, begging the question: Exactly what kind of typecasting is going on here? Can the guy do this in real life? -- Mark Binelli, free-lance writer   Drop Squad R   Drops a bombshell squarely in the middle of the African-American community. Produced by Spike Lee, directed by David Johnson and filmed in Atlanta, this fiercely engaging drama/satire looks at the highly- charged and often confusing issue of what it means to be African American. However, while it deals with the black experience in particular, the film has a tremendous universality. Daring and fall-down-funny, it ought to provoke a lot of debate, discussion and talk-show programs. The plot is part ``The Colored Museum,'' part ``Man From U.N.C.L.E'' episode. The Drop Squad, led by Vondie Curtis-Hall and Ving Rhames, is a secret militant group that specializes in Deprogramming and Restoration of Pride, i.e., working on blacks -- in this case, buppie Bruford Jamison (Eriq LaSalle) -- too willing to sell out. The film has its flaws -- the in-your-face deprogramming espoused by Rhames would work better on stage and the TV ad for ``GospelPak'' chicken dinners, while hilarious, is too broad; corporate America is far more insidious in its co- opting of ``Diversity,'' etc. This movie says out loud that being black is no longer a matter of being nonwhite (if, indeed, it ever was). Johnson and his expert cast tackle this disturbing reality head-on, with vividness and humor.   Eat Drink Man Woman NR   Master chef Chu (Sihung Lung) doesn't believe in fast food -- any more than the film's director Ang Lee believes in fast movies. As in his hit ``The Wedding Banquet,'' Lee brings an expansive humanist tone and leisurely pacing to familiar obsessions -- food, love and the idiosyncrasies of the heart. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Ed Wood R   Tim Burton's hilarious and superbly crafted tribute to Ed Wood, the filmmaker who was once named the worst director in film history. Tim Burton concentrates on Wood's (Johnny Depp) '50s career, when he turned out such beyond-bad opuses as ``Plan 9 From Outer Space.'' Rated R for language and adult themes.   Exit to Eden R   Exit FROM Eden. Better still, don't go anywhere near it in the first place. Based on Anne Rice's soft-core S&AMP;M novel about a kind of leather-bar Fantasy Island, the film version has been ``improved'' by director Garry Marshall who's turned it into a kind of ``The Story of O'' meets ``Police Academy III.'' Marshall leavens Rice's kinky stuff with a made-up comic subplot about a pair of cops (Rosie O'Donnell and Dan Aykroyd) on the trail of a handsome photographer (``Strictly Ballroom's'' Paul Mercurio) who's inadvertently snapped some jewel thieves. Rated R for adult themes and language.   The Flintstones PG   Hits rock bottom. The plot follows Fred's (John Goodman) precipitous ``Hudsucker Proxy''-ish rise from quarry worker to vice president of Slate and Co. when a villainous exec (Kyle Mac[DH] Lachlan) and his shapely assistant (Halle Berry) need a fall guy for their greedy schemes. Directed by Brian Levant. Rated PG for mild violence. .  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941104.0071 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(3rdtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Forrest Gump PG-13   Tom Hanks is clueless in America in Robert Zemeckis's half-baked fable about an idiot-savant of sorts, skimming through the last half of the 20th century and colliding ``Zelig''-like with history. Rated PG-13 for adult themes.   Fresh NR   The boy in this hood really is a boy -- a 12-year-old named Fresh (Sean Nelson) who divides his time between junior high and running drugs. The most important person in his life, however, is his near-derelict dad (Samuel L. Jackson) who passes along his passion for chess and, in doing so, teaches Fresh the strategy and mental agility he needs to pull off a revenge- scenario that Michael Corleone would envy. First-time director Boam Yakin has made a powerful and involving film. Not rated, but there is drug use, violence, profanity and adult themes.   Hoop Dreams PG-13   Three hours of basketball may sound like 21/2 hours too much for most movie-lovers. But trust me -- this extraordinary documentary is about much more than backboards and rebounds. Filmmakers Steve James, Frederick Marx and Peter Gilbert have delivered a richly observed, superbly nuanced slice of the American Dream -- a film that uses the particular arena of NBA-prospect high school and college basketball to explore and reflect a larger American experience.   I Like It Like That R   Not just another girl-in-the-hood flick. This is a smart, vivid comedy/drama about inner-city relationships under difficult circumstances. In her debut film, Darnell Martin has fashioned a knowing serio-comic look at a young woman who -- as they love to say on talk shows -- turns her life around. Rated R for language, adult themes and sex.   Imaginary Crimes PG   Almost all the crimes in this low-key affecting film are crimes of the heart. Harvey Keitel stars as a widower in the late '50s/early '60s, trying to make a life for himself and his two daughters (Fairuza Balk and Elisabeth Moss). Unfortunately, as the teenage Balk, a fledgling writer, notes, ``Never has a man so ill-equipped for parenthood tried so hard.'' The trouble with Harvey is he's a small-time con man who's always trying to sell somebody something. Though he's more a self-centered dreamer than a maliciously dishonest man, the result is the same: a family on the run from landlords and creditors and two daughters deeply embarrassed by their seemingly shameless dad. This is a refreshingly different female coming- of-age story; instead of being about the usual first love or lost virginity, it's about a girl who must grow up because her father can't. Director Anthony Drazan sometimes has trouble with pace and he could use more of a sense of humor, but Keitel and Balk save his skin. Eyeing each other with a mix of wariness and love, expectation and dismay, they remind us how rarely the punishment fits the crime, imaginary or not.   It Could Happen to You PG   This sweet nothing of a film pairs Nicolas Cage and Bridget Fonda in an appealing romantic fairy tale of love and the New York lottery. The film is too slight to be a grand romance, but it's definitely a winning one. Rated   PG for mild language, adult situations.   Jason's Lyric R   It starts with the promise of something invigorating and fresh. It's the story of an African-American family living outside the usual inner-city setting of gangsta flicks. But director Doug McHenry carries urban cliches with him into the suburbs: drugs, guns and a whore-madonna view of women that's not very different from a rap video. Rated R for violence, sex, language and drug use. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Little Giants PG   This time, the Bad News Bears . . . I mean, the Mighty Ducks . . . mean . . . Let's start over. This time, a gang of lovable kiddie misfits pull together and become a heck of a Pee Wee League football team. The only discernable twist is that the Giants' coach (Rick Moranis) and the coach (Ed O'Neill) of the all-star opposing team are brothers wtih a long- standing rivalry. Given a fourth-down-and-long situation, director Duwayne Dunham punts for formula and lets his cast fumble along as best they can. Rated PG for mild language.   Little Rascals PG   Rent the originals. The idea of turning Hal Roach's famed ``Our Gang'' shorts into a feature for '90s audiences is a dubious one at best. And it's been done in the worst possible way. Director Penelope Spheeris has found a remarkable cast of look-alikes who seem to have been cloned from some hidden source of Little Rascals DNA. But as well- trained and well-made-up as these kids are, they are pod-Rascals -- an artful semblance of the real thing but totally devoid of freshness, naturalness or spontaneity. Rated PG for smutty language.   Love Affair PG-13   If this timeless tale of true romance worked for Charles Boyer and Irene Dunne in 1939 (``Love Affair'') and for Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr in 1957 (``An Affair to Remember''), then why shouldn't it work in 1994 for Warren Beatty and Annette Bening? Well, it does. To a point. This is a first-class effort and while it isn't quite the heartbreaker one hopes for, it still manages to jerk a few tears. Maybe they don't make 'em like they used to, but as long as they keep making 'em for Bening, who is irresistible, they're on the right track.   The Mask PG-13   Forget the superhero plot of this live-action cartoon and focus on the Looney-Tunes special effects, the immensely likable Jim Carrey and Milo the mighty Jack Russell terrier. Directed by Chuck Russell. Rated PG-13 for mild violence.   Maverick PG-13   In the parlance of its poker-playing hero, this dumb-fun western draws a winning hand. A solid three-of-a-kind -- Mel Gibson, Jodie Foster and James Garner -- glide smoothly over the movie's rougher spots. Rated PG for mild violence and sexual innuendo.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941104.0072 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(4thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Mary Shelley's Frankenstein R   In Mary Shelley's classic 19th-century novel, medical student Victor Frankenstein learns that some things are better left to God. In this opulent, fever-pitched movie, director-star Kenneth Branagh learns that some thngs are better left to James Whale, the man who made the 1931 Karloff version. Not that Branagh's version is a total dud. But in its own way, it's as deliriously misguided as Shelley's mad-scientist protagonist. The problems begin with the casting of Robert De Niro as the Monster. His stitched-together mass of scar tissue may be closer to the novel than Karloff's plug-necked proletariat, but Karloff was an unknown and De Niro, well, is De Niro. Everytime he appears, you think, gee, Travis Bickle's been run over by his own taxi. Also, Branagh has chosen to return to the original's Gothic-romance roots by emphasizing the relationship between Victor (Branagh) and his beloved Elizabeth (Helena Bonham Carter). That's fine as far as it goes -- and in these actors' talented hands, it goes pretty far -- but it has the effect of reducing the Monster to a bothersome interruption. Brimming with talent and dedication, the Branagh version never bores, but it never truly chills either.   Natural Born Killers R   Oliver Stone is a natural born moviemaker and a natural born troublemaker and this anarchic, almost surreal film shows both sides at their best. As emblematic of the disaffected, media-overload '90s as ``Bonnie and Clyde'' was of the '60s, ``Killers'' celebrates sex, violence and celebrity with a vengeance that's both visual and visceral. Mickey (Woody Harrelson) and Mallory (Juliette Lewis) are young, in love and they kill people. About 52 people before they're put in Tommy Lee Jones' jail. Rated R for extreme violence, gore, language, nudity and sexuality.   The Next Karate Kid PG   The new ``kid'' is a sullen teenaged girl named Julie, played by newcomer Hilary Swank. It's not a bad idea to show that a teen can have lips like Claudia Schiffer's and still beat the stuffing out of a bothersome guy. Noriyuki ``Pat'' Morita returns as Mr. Miyagi. Rated PG for violence.   Only You PG   If only Hollywood would make more movies like this fanciful Roman holiday, starring Marisa Tomei as a bride-to-be on a quixotic romantic quest in Italy and Robert Downey Jr. as a gallant suitor who may or may not be her only one. Rated PG for mild sexual themes.   Princess Caraboo PG   A fascinating, fanciful and altogether delightful social satire/romance, lightly based on a true story. A gorgeous exotic (Phoebe Cates) shows up outside Bristol, England, in 1817. Speaking little English, she manages to convey to the wealthy gentry (Jim Broadbent and Wendy Hughes) who take her in that her name is Princess Caraboo and she has escaped from pirates who kidnapped her and took her away from her native land. Is she real or a fraud? Rated PG for adult themes.   Pulp Fiction R   Pop goes the pulp in this smashing sophomore effort by Quentin ``Reservoir Dogs'' Tarantino. Winner of the Golden Palm at Cannes and already subject to Oscar-time whispers, the picture is a gleefully lurid mix of hardboiled gangster-movie conventions and hip post-Warhol irony. It's an exceedingly violent genre flick with a twist -- everyone is in on the joke. Everyone, that is, except the characters on screen. The film consists of three expertly interwoven vignettes that take place before during and sometimes after one another (meaning, a major character in one story can turn up as a minor nobody in another). The first tale centers on a couple of hit men (beautifully played by John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson) and Travolta's job baby-sitting his big, bad boss's (Ving Rhames) babe-licious wife (Uma Thurman). The second focuses on a boxer (Bruce Willis) who's been asked to take a dive. The third goes back to Travolta and Jackson who need Harvey Keitel's help disposing a dead body. Flashy, smart, daring and full of itself, the movie sometimes suggests ``Short Cuts'' with shootouts. But it's very much an original -- from the second-chance career it gives Travolta to the bits of brain matter in Jackson's Jheri-curls. And when Travolta and Urman start a slo-mo dance, the film achieves a moment of pure pop culture/movies-in-our-mind madness. Let's twist again, like we did in another lifetime. Rated R for violence, language, nudity and drug use.   The Puppet Masters R   NASA scientist Dr. Mary Sefton (Julie Warner) has a unique test to determine whether a man is a full-blooded human or if he's possessed by an alien: She shows him her cleavage. This sexist device is one clue that ``The Puppet Masters'' originated as a 1951 Robert A. Heinlein novel. The premise is dated, the latest in a long line of sci-fi paranoia thrillers: Outer-space beasties leach onto human hosts and plot to overwhelm the world. Deduct points for freshness. But ``Masters'' bops with a brisk, nab-those-critters attitude. And the critters are a treat: gloppy manta rays that latch onto your back, jam a tether in your brain, and fuse with your nervous system. Like a good cigarette. Donald Sutherland and Eric Thal also star as estranged father-son federal agents, who with Warner find themselves menaced by dead-eyed townsfolk. Directed by Stuart Orme, ``Masters'' operates like a '50s automat. It's clean, straight-edged and impersonal. But it delivers some fun scenes, if you can get past the inconsistencies and an ending that's an FX letdown. -- Steve Murray   Quiz Show PG-13   Robert Redford's dazzlingly entertaining movie is set in the late '50s, when Americans were as hooked on quiz shows as later generations would be on Watergate or O.J.'s white Bronco. When the sponsor tires of ``Twenty-One's'' current wonder-boy, Herb Stempel (John Turturro), a schlemiel from Queens, he's replaced by Charles Van Doren (Ralph Fiennes), the handsome scion of an aristocratic, academic family. Van Doren becomes the nation's most adored egghead and Stempel spills the beans -- that the game is rigged -- to a congressional investigator (Rob Morrow). Rated PG-13 for adult themes.   Radioland Murders PG   Just plain murder to sit through. This fiasco is the latest missive from the hermit-like George Lucas. Produced and written by Lucas and directed by Mel Smith (``The Tall Guy''), the movie means to be a farcical murder mystery set in 1939 at the art deco studios of WBN, a radio station trying to go national. Running around the overcrowded halls are a bickering husband-and-wife team (headwriter Brian Benben and executive-assistant-turned-de-facto-producer, Mary Stuart Masterson); a femme-fatale radio star (the late, very talented Anita Morris); a philandering director (Jeffrey Tambor), a no-nothing executive president (Ned Beatty) and a libidious announcer (Corbin Bernsen) . . . among others. While the show goes on (and everything falls into chaos), someone behind-scenes is murdering the staff. The story, which Lucas has been sitting on for twenty years, has been turned into a screenplay by Willard Huyck and Gloria Katz (of ``Howard the Duck'' fame). Whatever affection or fun the filmmakers mean to have comes off as frenetic and witless. With all his power and money -- he could bankroll Julie Dash and a dozen like her -- this is what Lucas comes up with. Boy, what's the frequency George?  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941104.0073 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(5thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Renaissance Man PG-13   A bummer, man. Director Penny Marshall proves she can do predictable military schmaltz just as well (badly?) as the guys, with this Danny DeVito inspirational comedy that might well be subtitled ``Dead Poet's Platoon.''   Reservoir Dogs R   As in, one assumes, meaner than the junkyard variety. This is an electrifyingly vicious caper flick, soaked in blood, obscenity and incongruous black humor. Most of the movie takes place immediately before and after a robbery gone terribly wrong. Dressed in identical Blues Brothers suits and cloaked in the anonymity of color-coded aliases (Mr. Orange, Mr. Brown), the rattled crooks rd. Playing cereal czar and health nut John Harvey Kellogg, Hopkins creates a grand, blustery caricature. Unfortunately, Parker's adaptation of T. Coraghessan Boyle's novel has flurry in place of a plot. The welter of characters include a young cornflakes entrepreneur (John Cusack); Kellogg's prodigal son George (Dana Carvey); and Will and Eleanor Lightbody (Matthew Broderick and Bridget Fonda), whose physical ills cloak deeper marital problems. Fonda comes off as a mall rat in her great-grandma's clothes. Cusack goes over the top. Broderick gamely endures a lot of enema and bowel jokes, and shows off ab muscles more gym-developed than might be credible for a man of 1907. The movie blows its opportunities to score points about our own health- conscious age. It remains undernourished and dramatically anemic. -- Steve Murray   The Rocky Horror Picture Show R   Let's do the Time Warp again. . . . Barry Bostwick and Susan Sarandon are lost travelers at Tim Curry's castle. Rated R for adult themes and sexual innuendo.   Sankofa NR   Haile Gerima, one of the founding members of the New Black Cinema, has directed a uniquely powerful film about a modern-day African-American who learns to embrace her painful heritage when she's sent back to the 18th century to experience slavery firsthand. Not rated, but contains nudity and scenes of rape and torture.   The Shawshank Redemption R   There are two excellent reasons to see this involving movie and their names are Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. Based on a Stephen King novella, this is a stone-walls-do-not-a-prison-make story, in which hope flourishes in horrifying surroundings and a unique friendship is forged inside a human purgatory.   Silent Fall R   When a prosperous couple is found brutally murdered in the bedroom of their Maryland mansion, the only witness is their 9-year-old son (Ben Faulkner). Unfortunately, the boy is also autistic, which prompts the local sheriff and the boy's protective older sister (model Liv Tyler) to bring in a once-prominent child shrink (Richard Dreyfuss), who quit treating kids after a tragedy befell a patient. While the movie goes to great lengths to stress that autism isn't an easily understandable condition, it also uses the boy's state as a plot contrivance -- not only to get Dreyfuss involved, but also as a kind of freak circumstance that bestows everything from superhuman strength to an uncanny gift for mimicry. As suspense dramas go, this one is more solid than inspired. Still, director Bruce Beresford brings his usual quality treatment to the material and the autumn color on Maryland's Eastern Shore is so spectacular that you'll want to rush out to the area's nearest B&AMP;B.   The Specialist R   Sylvester Stallone's specialty has been to turn a one- note act into a multimillion-dollar career. But the specialist specified here is a former CIA explosives expert hired by a rich lovely (Sharon Stone) to wipe out the bad guys who killed her parents when she was just a kid. That means taking on Miami mobsters led by patriarch Rod Steiger (doing an embarrassing Jose Jimenez accent), his sleazy son (Eric Roberts) and his equally sleazy consigliere (James Woods, who used to be in the CIA with Sly until they had a falling out over innocent bystanders). At its best, the film is like ``Death Wish'' warmed-over, with hints of ``The Bodyguard.'' However, the expected sparks between the two stars never ignite and the clumsy double- entendre dialogue (Stone to Stallone in phone-sex whisper: ``I heard you control your explosions, that you shape your charges'') doesn't help. There's a glimmer of a good script here, with even a surprise or two. But onscreen, there's nothing but the same old explosions, the same old movie-star glistening skin and grunt-and-moan simulated sex.   Speed R   The perfect summer-movie rush. The gimmick is simple: A wacko (Dennis Hopper) has put a bomb on a city bus. When the bus hits 50 mph, the bomb goes on; if it slows below 50, the bomb goes off. And so the chase is on -- with a busload of terrified passengers, a hurt driver, a spunky civilian at the wheel (Sandra Bullock) and a very determined cop (Keanu Reeves) in pursuit. Directed by Jan De Bont. Rated R for violence and language.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941104.0074 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(6thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Stargate PG-13   An engaging sci-fi yarn with a flying pyramid, three moons and Jaye Davidson in a dress. Again. We start on Earth, where a linguist named Daniel (James Spader) deciphers Egyptian hieroglyphics on a circular mechanism unearthed near the Pyramids. It's the Stargate, a thingamajig that, when uncoded, becomes a portal to a twin gate on a sandy planet across the universe. Daniel gets enlisted for a space-jumping expedition, led by gruff Colonel Jack O'Neil (Kurt Russell), since he's the only one who can crack the code on that second Stargate. But first they have to face the sun god Ra (Davidson), a cosmic vampire. Like a Tintin adventure set in the cosmos, the movie has an enjoyable retro feel. But it's harder to get revved up by it. Director Roland Emmerich turns out serviceable action scenes, but it's Spielberg minus Spielberg. The movie's MVP is Spader, normally typecast as yuppie slime, here reinventing himself as an adorable egghead. The big letdown is Davidson's villain. He pouts prettily, but that's it; it's like finding out the universe is run by a waiter-slash-model. -- Steve Murray   Terminal Velocity PG-13   A free fall into silliness, this sky-diving thriller plays like Hitchcock Lite. It's preposterous. And a lot of fun. Charlie Sheen stars as Arizona sky-diver Ditch Brodie whose latest student, a blond airhead named Chris (Nastassja Kinski), takes an early tumble out the plane door, and makes like a pancake. Then again, is that really her body on the desert floor? Rated PG-13 for violence, language.   Timecop R   A good rule of thumb: the less sense a Jean-CLaude Van Damme movie makes, the more fun it is. Happily, this futuristic actioner is a welcome return to the sci-fi silliness of his most successful film to date, ``Universal Soldier.'' Van Damme plays a time-traveling cop who tries to stop a corrupt senator from changing history. Rated R for violence, language, brief sex and nudity.   True Lies R   True trash. Too long, too loud and too expensive, this action farce is a pointless exercise in abuse of power, Hollywood-style. Starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Jamie Lee Curtis. Directed by James Cameron. Rated R for violence and language.   The War PG- 13   A big-hearted bore from the maker of ``Fried Green Tomatoes.'' Director Jon Avnet returns to the South of a few years past, in this case small-town Mississippi, 1970. (It was mostly shot in Georgia.) Kevin Costner plays Stephen Simmons, a vet trying to hold a job while haunted by memories of 'Nam. We see him through the eyes of his kids, Stu (Elijah Wood) and Lidia (Lexi Randall), who spend the summer months building a treehouse -- and trying to avoid the white-trash Lipnicki clan. Unlike the plot-driven ``Tomatoes,'' ``War'' ambles with the humid sleepiness of one of its summer days. Somebody's always a- sittin' on a porch, talkin' about love and family and duty and dreams. Late in the movie, when a turf battle turns the kids' treehouse into an obvious anti- war allegory, you might have already tuned out due to the platitudes and melodrama. -- Steve Murray   Wes Craven's New Nightmare R   Wes Craven reclaims Freddy Krueger in this postmodern, Pirandellan funhouse of a movie -- a ``Player'' for the slasher set. When the execs at New Line (the actual makers of this movie) ask original ``Elm Street'' heroine Heather Langenkamp (as Herself) to reprise her role for the ``definitive `Nightmare,' '' she has doubts: She's been having these bad Freddy nightmares. So has her son (Miko Hughes, the scalpel baby from ``Pet Sematary''). Seems that the malevolent force behind the Krueger movies -- the real Freddy -- wants to cross into Real Life. Fun premise. Robert Englund, John Saxon and Craven pop up as Themselves. And it's nice to see Krueger returned to the roots of the first film -- a pre- wisecrack, hellish fiend. But writer-director Craven has turned into a Joseph Campbell-ite. He now takes the mythic archetypes that drive horror movies, and overstates them. (Here he turns ``Hansel and Gretel'' into holy writ.) He's followed his bliss and forgotten to give us good shocks (except for a couple of nasty bits reprised from the first ``Elm Street''). Rated R for gore, language. -- Steve Murray   Wolf R   Who's afraid of Big Bad Jack? You probably won't be, but you're likely to have a howlingly good time at this A-list treatment of old Lon Chaney Jr. werewolf movies. Starring Jack Nicholson and Michelle Pfeiffer. Directed by Mike Nichols. Rated R for sex, violence and language. .  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941104.0075 type=story > <HEADLINE> BOOKS: COFFEE TABLE GEMS: BOOKS ON SOUTHWEST DISPLAY DEPTH </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> PHOENIX  (BC-BOOKREVIEWS-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"
