They move weekly to clients of the New York Times News Service.   G: General audiences. Nothing that would offend parents if viewed by children.   PG: Parental guidance suggested. May contain some material parents consider inappropriate for young children.   PG-13: Parents strongly cautioned. Some material may be inappropriate for preteens.   R: Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. Parents are urged to learn more about the film before taking children.   NC-17: No one under 17 admitted. Replaces the X rating.   NR: Not rated.   The Adventures of Priscilla,   Queen of the Desert R   The boys on the bus would rather be thought of as the girls on the bus in this spirited Aussie froth about two drag queens (Hugo Weaving and Guy Pearce) and a transsexual ('60s stud Terence Stamp) on a cross-country jaunt through the Outback. Rated R for sex-related situations and language.   Andre PG   Predictable but sweet, this seal saga is a decent primer for kids learning some basic lesson about family and friendship. But be forewarned: Andre's best trick is to blow derogatory raspberries. Don't be surprised if your kids pick up the habit. Starring Keith Carradine. Rated PG for scenes of animal endangerment. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Angels in the Outfield PG   This kid-pleasing baseball fantasy about a lonely boy, a slumping baseball team and some divine intervention is a winged victory for Disney, thanks to a strong cast and heart-tugging plot. Think ``Free Willy'' with the California Angels instead of a whale. Starring Danny Glover and Christopher Lloyd. Directed by William Dear. Rated PG for mild adult themes.   Baby's Day Out PG   A very long day indeed, for Baby and for the audience. This John Hughes-ian spin on ``The Ransom of Red Chief'' is best recommended to die-hard slapstick fans who've always wanted to see a remake of ``Three Men and a Baby,'' starring the Three Stooges. Rated PG for comic violence.   Barcelona PG-13   Set in Spain, Whit Stillman's literate, witty romantic comedy takes place within the socio-political context of ``the last decade of the Cold War.'' Starring Taylor Nichols and Chris Eigemann. Rated PG- 13 for language and violence.   Blankman PG-13   Daman Wayans stars as a nerdy inventor who becomes a bargain-basement superhero. The movie has a few humorous moments, at least enough to fill a five-minute ``In Living Color'' sketch, but stretched out to feature-film length, the joke wears more than a bit thin. Directed by Mike Binder. Rated PG-13 for profanity, some violence, and some sexual situations.   Blue Sky PG-13   Tommy Lee Jones and Jessica Lange give Oscar-worthy performances in this riveting family drama set against a backdrop of military coverups and abuse of power. Directed by Tony Richardson. Rated PG- 13 for sex, brief nudity and adult themes.   Bullets Over Broadway R   It's as if Woody Allen decided to make a movie like the movie-within-the-movie in ``The Purple Rose of Cairo.'' Working in his Runyon-esque ``Broadway Danny Rose'' mode, he takes us back to the Great White Way of the Roaring '20s, for a theater-centric farce that ends up debating the artist vs. the man (something Woody's probably heard a lot of recently). John Cusack is the ardent young playwright who believes in art and Jennifer Tilly is the no-talent moll whose gangster-boyfriend bankrolls his play so she can go onstage. Rated R for language, adult themes.   Clear and Present Danger PG-13   Even when this new installment in the Tom Clancy film-adaptation franchise is far from clear, it's dangerously entertaining. Reteaming director Phillip Noyce and star Harrison Ford as CIA analyst Jack Ryan, it's more convoluted than ``Patriot Games.'' But also more gripping. Rated PG-13 for some intense action, violence and language. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Clerks R   Quirky, irreverent and about as off- the-cuff casual as a movie can be (even a $27,000 movie), this black-and-white no-budget-er has been a prize winner at Cannes and Sundance. Filmmaker Kevin Smith (who also appears in the picture as an enigmatic hanger-on named Silent Bob) gives us a day in the life of a couple of twentysomething Jersey guys named Dante (Brian O'Halloran) and Randal (Jeff Anderson). The two hold down dead-end jobs at, respectively, a Quick Stop convenience store and the neighboring hole-in-the-wall video store. Somewhere beyond slackers, they spend their days discussing the merits of ``The Empire Strikes Back'' vs. ``Return of the Jedi'' (``Justa bunch of Muppets'') while waiting on the usual eccentric crew of customers (like the guy who gets his hand stuck in a Pringle's potato chip can). The film looks just as raw as you'd expect, but it's also brimming with personality, humor and a genuine independent spirit. Absurdist, smutty and completely comfortable with itself, ``Clerks'' is grunge cinema at its best.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941111.0058 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(2ndtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The Client PG-13   Susan Sarandon and Tommy Lee Jones are wonderful together in yet another John Grisham story. Unfortunately, they play supporting roles to a kid actor who's very impressive, but can't outshine them. Directed by Joel Schumacher. Rated PG-13 for violence and language.   Corrina, Corrina PG   In this beautifully acted, wonderfully perceptive comedy-drama, Whoopi Goldberg plays a '50s housekeeper who makes Mrs. Doubtfire look like W.C. Fields. Directed by Jessie Nelson. Rated PG for adult themes.   Crooklyn PG-13   Spike Lee's affectionate return to the Brooklyn of his youth is a sweet and funny change of pace. Starring Alfre Woodard, Delroy Lindo and Zelda Harris. Rated PG-13 for some profanity, scenes of neighborhood drug use, splintering family unit, kids pranks that include death of dog.   Double Dragon PG-13   This film version of the popular video game is a cynical attempt at duping young fans into paying to watch a 93-minute commercial for the game and its inevitable sequels. Yet it's also surprisingly grim, considering the target audience. Set in the year 2007, the film blithely presents a nightmarish city ravaged by smog, earthquakes and marauding gangs straight out of ``The Warriors.'' The plot -- less complex than a Pong tournament -- involves a futuristic struggle for a magic Chinese talisman that grants its possessor vague powers over the ``body and soul.'' Half of the ``Double Dragon'' is being guarded by the wise-cracking, kick-boxing Lee brothers -- played in an interesting bit of casting by Mark Dacascos (who looks Asian) and TV's ``Party of Five'' star Scott Wolf (who looks like Tom Cruise). The evil tycoon who holds the other half is played by Marietta native Robert Patrick, best known as the mighty morphin' cyborg in ``Terminator 2.'' Once again Patrick plays a character who shape-shifts, begging the question: Exactly what kind of typecasting is going on here? Can the guy do this in real life? -- Mark Binelli, free-lance writer   Drop Squad R   Part ``The Colored Museum,'' part ``The Man From U.N.C.L.E.,'' this fiercely engaging drama/satire looks at the often confusing issue of what it means to be African American. Directed by David Johnson; produced by Spike Lee. Starring Eriq La Salle (NBC's ``E.R.''). Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   Ed Wood R   Tim Burton's hilarious and superbly crafted tribute to Ed Wood, the filmmaker who was once named the worst director in film history. Tim Burton concentrates on Wood's (Johnny Depp) '50s career, when he turned out such beyond-bad opuses as ``Plan 9 From Outer Space.'' Rated R for language and adult themes.   Exit to Eden R   Exit FROM Eden. Better still, don't go anywhere near it in the first place. Based on Anne Rice's soft-core S&AMP;M novel about a kind of leather-bar Fantasy Island, the film version has been ``improved'' by director Garry Marshall who's turned it into a kind of ``The Story of O'' meets ``Police Academy III.'' Marshall leavens Rice's kinky stuff with a made-up comic subplot about a pair of cops (Rosie O'Donnell and Dan Aykroyd) on the trail of a handsome photographer (``Strictly Ballroom's'' Paul Mercurio) who's inadvertently snapped some jewel thieves. Rated R for adult themes and language.   Forrest Gump PG-13   Tom Hanks is clueless in America in Robert Zemeckis's half-baked fable about an idiot-savant of sorts, skimming through the last half of the 20th century and colliding ``Zelig''-like with history. Rated PG-13 for adult themes.   Fresh NR   The boy in this hood really is a boy -- a 12-year-old named Fresh (Sean Nelson) who divides his time between junior high and running drugs. The most important person in his life, however, is his near-derelict dad (Samuel L. Jackson) who passes along his passion for chess and, in doing so, teaches Fresh the strategy and mental agility he needs to pull off a revenge-scenario that Michael Corleone would envy. Not rated, but there is drug use, violence, profanity and adult themes.   A Good Man in Africa R   A good deal of talent is wasted in this satire about the end of colonialism in a fictional African country. Starring Colin Friels and Sean Connery. Rated R for language, adult themes.   Hoop Dreams PG-13   Three hours of basketball may sound like 21/2 hours too many for most moviegoers, but this extraordinary documentary is about so much more than backboards and rebounds. It's a richly observed, superbly nuanced look at the American Dream through the eyes of two teenage NBA hopefuls. Directed by Steve James. Rated PG-13 for profanity and drug use.   I Don't Want to Talk About It PG-13   The ``It'' in this strangely affecting Argentinian film is the physicality of the daughter of a wealthy South American widow named Dona Leonor (Luisina Brando). Her teenager, Charlotte (Alejandra Podesta), is smart, loving, well-read, an accomplished pianist and a devoted daughter. She is also vertically challenged -- or, as they used to say, a dwarf. However, Dona Leonor won't say it (she also burns copies of ``Tom Thumb'') and she won't allow her neighbors to mention it either. The movie takes an odder-still twist when a mysterious roue (Marcello Mastroianni) comes to town and falls for Charlotte. The picture benefits from its bizarre set-up, a poetically Fellini-esque finale and Brando's chilling portrayal of a manipulative, overprotective parent. But director Maria Luisa Bemberg lets things go a bit flat in the middle and it's only thanks to Mastroianni's decades of expertise and innate courtly charisma that we remain interested during the slow spots. Still, the movie deserves points for acting, tone and originality; after all, how many movies try to mix psychotic denial and magic realism in one story?  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941111.0059 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(3rdtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> I Like It Like That R   A strong debut by young African-American filmmaker Darnell Martin, who deftly guides us through the mean streets of the Bronx and the complexities of the human heart. Rated R for language, adult themes and sex.   Interview With the Vampire R   As richly textured as a dark brocade, threaded with existential dread and drenched in plasma, Neil Jordan's film will disturb more viewers than just Oprah. It's filled with snapping necks, slit throats, rats and wrists draining crimson into goblets, and other bloody bits of necro-fun. But it's likely to thrill Anne Rice fans and seduce those unfamiliar with her books. Interviewed by a San Francisco journalist (Christian Slater), reluctant vampire Louis (Brad Pitt) goes back 200 years to torchlit New Orleans, recalling his role in the ultimate dysfunctional clan: himself, sadistic Lestat (Tom Cruise) who made him a vampire; and their ``child'' Claudia (Kirsten Dunst), whose golden curls mask a fierce hunger. Lestat is driven by appetite. Louis wants answers. His quest to find others of ``our kind'' drives the film into 19th- century Paris, introducing a clique of decadent undead (including Antonio Banderas and Stephen Rea). As a screenwriter, Rice doesn't hit her points as hard as she might, especially Louis' motivations. If you're unfamiliar with the book, you might find the going slow. And here's what you've been wondering: Cruise's Lestat is a dandy dandy; he could be more frightening, but the role hasn't been stretched into a vanity star turn. Pitt provides the eloquent heart of the movie. And Dunst, older than the novel's Claudia, conveys the character's anguish at being trapped in childhood. But the film's biggest triumph is its visual design, an opulent fusion of costumes (Sandy Powell), production design (Dante Ferretti) and cinematography (Philippe Rousselot). This ``Vampire'' has bite. -- Steve Murray   It Could Happen to You PG   This sweet nothing of a film pairs Nicolas Cage and Bridget Fonda in an appealing romantic fairy tale of love and the New York lottery. The film is too slight to be a grand romance, but it's definitely a winning one. Rated PG for mild language, adult situations.   Jason's Lyric R   It starts with the promise of something invigorating and fresh. It's the story of an African-American family living outside the usual inner-city setting of gangsta flicks. But director Doug McHenry carries urban cliches with him into the suburbs: drugs, guns and a whore-madonna view of women that's not very different from a rap video. Rated R for violence, sex, language and drug use. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Lassie PG   Lassie comes home to the big screen in an engaging family film directed by Daniel Petrie. Set in rural Virginia, this savvily updated version (by ``Paper House's'' Matthew Jacob) has a lot more in common with the TV series than the novel or the 1943 movie. But even after 50 years, it's still the same old story: a boy and his wonder-dog. The boy is Matt (Thomas Guiry), an angry adolescent who resents his new stepmom (Helen Slater) almost as much as he resents his dad's (Jon Tenney) relocating the family from Baltimore to a sheep farm. The wonder-dog, of course, is Lassie who latches onto Matt when her owner is killed. Rated PG for mild violence.   Little Giants PG   This time, the Bad News Bears . . . I mean, the Mighty Ducks . . . I mean . . . Let's start over. This time, a gang of lovable kiddie misfits pull together and become a heck of a Pee Wee League football team. The only discernable twist is that the Giants' coach (Rick Moranis) and the coach (Ed O'Neill) of the all- star opposing team are brothers with a long-standing rivalry. Given a fourth- down-and-long situation, director Duwayne Dunham punts for formula and lets his cast fumble along as best they can. Rated PG for mild language.   Little Rascals PG   Rent the originals. The idea of turning Hal Roach's famed ``Our Gang'' shorts into a feature for '90s audiences is a dubious one at best. And it's been done in the worst possible way. Director Penelope Spheeris has found a remarkable cast of look-alikes who seem to have been cloned from some hidden source of Little Rascals DNA. But as well-trained and well-made-up as these kids are, they are pod-Rascals -- an artful semblance of the real thing but totally devoid of freshness, naturalness or spontaneity. Rated PG for smutty language.   Love Affair PG-13   If this timeless tale of true romance worked for Charles Boyer and Irene Dunne in 1939 (``Love Affair'') and for Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr in 1957 (``An Affair to Remember''), then why shouldn't it work in 1994 for Warren Beatty and Annette Bening? Well, it does. To a point. This is a first-class effort and while it isn't quite the heartbreaker one hopes for, it still manages to jerk a few tears.   Mary Shelley's Frankenstein R   In Mary Shelley's classic 19th-century novel, medical student Victor Frankenstein learns that some things are better left to God. In this opulent, fever-pitched movie, director-star Kenneth Branagh learns that some things are better left to James Whale, the man who made the 1931 Karloff version. Not that Branagh's version is a total dud. But in its own way, it's as deliriously misguided as Shelley's mad-scientist protagonist. The problems begin with the casting of Robert De Niro as the Monster. His stitched-together mass of scar tissue may be closer to the novel than Karloff's plug-necked proletariat, but Karloff was an unknown and De Niro, well, is De Niro. Every time he appears, you think, gee, Travis Bickle's been run over by his own taxi. Also, Branagh has chosen to return to the original's Gothic-romance roots by emphasizing the relationship between Victor (Branagh) and his beloved Elizabeth (Helena Bonham Carter). That's fine as far as it goes -- and in these actors' talented hands, it goes pretty far -- but it has the effect of reducing the Monster to a bothersome interruption. Brimming with talent and dedication, the Branagh version never bores, but it never truly chills either.   The Mask PG-13   Forget the superhero plot of this live-action cartoon and focus on the Looney-Tunes special effects, the immensely likable Jim Carrey and Milo the mighty Jack Russell terrier. Directed by Chuck Russell. Rated PG-13 for mild violence.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941111.0060 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(4thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Natural Born Killers R Oliver Stone is a natural born moviemaker and a natural born troublemaker and this anarchic, almost surreal film shows both sides at their best. As emblematic of the disaffected, media-overload '90s as ``Bonnie and Clyde'' was of the '60s, ``Killers'' celebrates sex, violence and celebrity with a vengeance that's both visual and visceral. Mickey (Woody Harrelson) and Mallory (Juliette Lewis) are young, in love and they kill people. About 52 people before they're put in Tommy Lee Jones' jail. Rated R for extreme violence, gore, language, nudity and sexuality.   The Next Karate Kid PG   The new ``kid'' is a sullen teenaged girl named Julie, played by newcomer Hilary Swank. It's not a bad idea to show that a teen can have lips like Claudia Schiffer's and still beat the stuffing out of a bothersome guy. Noriyuki ``Pat'' Morita returns as Mr. Miyagi. Rated PG for violence.   Oleanna R   Cinematic saltpeter, it's a guaranteed date-night dampener. David Mamet's film of his off-Broadway power play can send men and women up the theater aisle, fuming for separate reasons. Charting a trio of disastrous meetings between a college professor (William H. Macy), and a student (Debra Eisenstadt) who's failing his class, the film is a paranoid reaction to the shifting sexual politics of the '90s: Patricia Bowman, Anita Hill, Tailhook, etc. We first meet Carol arriving sans appointment at John's office. The words that rain most often from her mouth are, ``I don't understand.'' But by their second encounter, she has morphed from a stammering coed to a coolly poised virago, equipped with a militantly drab wardrobe, a notably improved vocabulary, and the support of a student cabal whom she refers to as ``my group.'' The personality shift is abrupt, unexplained. Instead of a two-person, full-bodied drama, the movie turns into a symbolic standoff between an innocent man and a misogynist's nightmare. Sexless, anti-intellectual, tract-spouting, Carol becomes the sort of woman Rush Limbaugh and Camille Paglia would take turns hating. Mamet keeps the focus simple; he hardly ``opens up'' the play. And it's easy to admire the deft dialogue and the strong performances. Macy summons a natty self-satisfaction (you wouldn't mind seeing him deflated, but not crucified). Eisenstadt does as fine a job as possible with the role's limitations. In the end, Mamet comes up with Molotov cocktail that's almost too successful in making audiences see red. -- Steve Murray   Only You PG   If only Hollywood would make more movies like this fanciful Roman holiday, starring Marisa Tomei as a bride- to-be on a quixotic romantic quest in Italy and Robert Downey Jr. as a gallant suitor who may or may not be her only one. Rated PG for mild sexual themes.   Pulp Fiction R   Pop goes the pulp in this smashing sophomore effort by Quentin ``Reservoir Dogs'' Tarantino. Winner of the Golden Palm at Cannes and already subject to Oscar-time whispers, the picture is a gleefully lurid mix of hardboiled gangster-movie conventions and hip post-Warhol irony. It's an exceedingly violent genre flick with a twist -- everyone is in on the joke. Everyone, that is, except the characters on screen. The film consists of three expertly interwoven vignettes. The first tale centers on a couple of hit men (beautifully played by John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson) and Travolta's job babysitting his big, bad boss's (Ving Rhames) babe-licious wife (Uma Thurman). The second focuses on a boxer (Bruce Willis) who's been asked to take a dive. The third goes back to Travolta and Jackson who need Harvey Keitel's help disposing a dead body. Flashy, smart, daring and full of itself, the movie sometimes suggests ``Short Cuts'' with shootouts. Rated R for violence, language, nudity and drug use.   The Puppet Masters R   NASA scientist Dr. Mary Sefton (Julie Warner) has a unique test to determine whether a man is a full- blooded human or if he's possessed by an alien: She shows him her cleavage. This sexist device is one clue that ``The Puppet Masters'' originated as a 1951 Robert A. Heinlein novel. The premise is dated, the latest in a long line of sci-fi paranoia thrillers: Outer-space beasties leach onto human hosts and plot to overwhelm the world. Deduct points for freshness. But ``Masters'' bops with a brisk, nab-those-critters attitude. And the critters are a treat: gloppy manta rays that latch on to your back, jam a tether in your brain, and fuse with your nervous system. Like a good cigarette. -- Steve Murray   Quiz Show PG-13   Robert Redford's dazzlingly entertaining movie is set in the late '50s, when Americans were as hooked on quiz shows as later generations would be on Watergate or O.J.'s white Bronco. When the sponsor tires of ``Twenty-One's'' current wonder-boy, Herb Stempel (John Turturro), a schlemiel from Queens, he's replaced by Charles Van Doren (Ralph Fiennes), the handsome scion of an aristocratic, academic family. Van Doren becomes the nation's most adored egghead and Stempel spills the beans -- that the game is rigged -- to a congressional investigator (Rob Morrow). Rated PG-13 for adult themes.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941111.0061 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(5thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Radioland Murders PG   Just plain murder to sit through. This fiasco is the latest missive from the hermit-like George Lucas. Produced and written by Lucas and directed by Mel Smith (``The Tall Guy''), the movie means to be a farcical murder mystery set in 1939 at the art deco studios of WBN, a radio station trying to go national. Running around the overcrowded halls are a bickering husband-and-wife team (headwriter Brian Benben and executive-assistant-turned-de-facto-producer, Mary Stuart Masterson); a femme- fatale radio star (the late, very talented Anita Morris); a philandering director (Jeffrey Tambor), a no-nothing executive president (Ned Beatty) and a libidious announcer (Corbin Bernsen) . . . among others. While the show goes on (and everything falls into chaos), someone behindthe scenes is murdering the staff.   Red Rock West R   In this low-budget comic noir about greed, lust and cheatin' hearts, Nicholas Cage is a nice-guy drifter taught by the likes of Dennis Hopper and J.T. Walsh that no good deed ever goes unpunished. Directed by John Dahl. Rated R for violence, profanity and sex.   Renaissance Man PG-13   A bummer, man. Director Penny Marshall proves she can do predictable military schmaltz just as well (badly?) as the guys, with this Danny DeVito inspirational comedy that might well be subtitled ``Dead Poet's Platoon.''   Reservoir Dogs R   As in, one assumes, meaner than the junkyard variety. Quentin Tarentino's debut is an electrifyingly vicious caper flick, soaked in blood, obscenity and incongruous black humor. Most of the movie takes place immediately before and after a robbery gone terribly wrong. The ensemble cast -- headed by Harvey Keitel, Steve Buscemi, Chris Penn and Tim Roth -- is a marvel, worthy of a Mamet play (which this film's profane energy often evokes).   The River Wild PG-13   Meryl Streep is a former white-water river guide, who views a rafting excursion in her old splashing grounds as more than a family vacation. It's a chance to spend quality time and heal rifts with workaholic husband Tom (David Strathairn) and son Roarke (Joseph Mazzello). Slithering into the family's domestic Eden, Kevin Bacon is a fellow rafter who turns vacation into hell, taking the family hostage and forcing Streep to pilot him safely down the river. The actors and the scenery keep your mind off a predictable plot; this is a B-movie graced with members of the Hollywood A- list. But the trip is worth it. Rated PG-13 for violence. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   The Road to Wellville R   Paved with good intentions. Like that other road. Alan Parker's health-craze comedy is an art-design folly with little more going for it than spectacle: Edwardian clothes, Anthony Hopkins with buckteeth, and cruel spa machines Jules Verne might have forged. Playing cereal czar and health nut John Harvey Kellogg, Hopkins creates a grand, blustery caricature. Unfortunately, Parker's adaptation of T. Coraghessan Boyle's novel has flurry in place of a plot. The welter of characters include a young cornflakes entrepreneur (John Cusack); Kellogg's prodigal son George (Dana Carvey); and Will and Eleanor Lightbody (Matthew Broderick and Bridget Fonda), whose physical ills cloak deeper marital problems. Fonda comes off as a mall rat in her great-grandma's clothes. Cusack goes over the top. Broderick gamely endures a lot of enema and bowel jokes, and shows off ab muscles more gym-developed than might be credible for a man of 1907. The movie blows its opportunities to score points about our own health-conscious age. It remains undernourished and dramatically anemic. Rated R for nudity, sexual situations. -- Steve Murray   The Santa Clause PG   The movie's moral is a peculiar one, even by Hollywood standards: The best way for a father to gain his son's respect is to pack on 50 pounds, grow a white beard and consort with elves. Thus it goes with Scott Calvin (Tim Allen), a divorced dad whose 8-year-old, Charlie (Eric Lloyd), would rather spend Christmas Eve with Mom (Wendy Crewson) and her new therapist hubby (Judge Reinhold). That is, until Santa tumbles off the roof, Scott straps on St. Nick's suit, and goes across the globe popping in and out of chimneys (aided by some computer effects that aren't as special as you'd hope). Amiable Allen wisecracks his way past snarling mutts and spying moppets (``Do you want this doll or not?'' he asks one recalcitrant tot). Then, at the North Pole, he finds out from the rainbow-coalition elves that -- gulp -- once you put on Santa's suit, you're Santa. For good. From here, the movie unreels as a cross between ``Miracle on 34th Street'' and a paranoid delusion. As the new year unfolds, Scott bloats up and goes white-haired and bewhiskered. Call it Clausitis: Santa overcomes his nervous system like an incurable disease. Allen's normal-guy shtick is terrific, but once he disappears inside the fat-suit, the movie's personality goes with him. Cuteness happens, magic doesn't. And if you have kids, be prepared to tell them something the movie never explains: What the heck happened to the original Santa, who evaporates into thin air? Ho ho huh? -- Steve Murray   The Shawshank Redemption R   There are two excellent reasons to see this involving movie and their names are Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. Based on a Stephen King novella, this is a stone-walls-do-not-a-prison-make story, in which hope flourishes in horrifying surroundings and a unique friendship is forged inside a human purgatory.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941111.0062 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(6thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Silent Fall R   When a prosperous couple is found brutally murdered in the bedroom of their Maryland mansion, the only witness is their 9-year-old son (Ben Faulkner). Unfortunately, the boy is also autistic, which prompts the local sheriff and the boy's protective older sister (model Liv Tyler) to bring in a once-prominent child shrink (Richard Dreyfuss), who quit treating kids after a tragedy befell a patient. While this solid suspense drama goes to great lengths to stress that autism isn't an easily understandable condition, it also uses the boy's state as a plot contrivance to get Dreyfuss involved. Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   The Specialist R   Sylvester Stallone's specialty has been to turn a one-note act into a multimillion-dollar career. But the specialist specified here is a former CIA explosives expert hired by a rich lovely (Sharon Stone) to wipe out the bad guys who killed her parents when she was just a kid. That means taking on Miami mobsters led by patriarch Rod Steiger (doing an embarrassing Jose Jimenez accent), his sleazy son (Eric Roberts) and his equally sleazy consigliere (James Woods, who used to be in the CIA with Sly until they had a falling out over innocent bystanders). At its best, the film is like ``Death Wish'' warmed-over, with hints of ``The Bodyguard.'' However, the expected sparks between Stallone and Stone never ignite.   Speed R   The perfect summer- movie rush. The gimmick is simple: A wacko (Dennis Hopper) has put a bomb on a city bus. When the bus hits 50 mph, the bomb goes on; if it slows below 50, the bomb goes off. And so the chase is on -- with a busload of terrified passengers, a hurt driver, a spunky civilian at the wheel (Sandra Bullock) and a very determined cop (Keanu Reeves) in pursuit. Directed by Jan De Bont. Rated R for violence and language.   Stargate PG-13   An engaging sci-fi yarn with a flying pyramid, three moons and Jaye Davidson in a dress. Again. We start on Earth, where a linguist named Daniel (James Spader) deciphers Egyptian hieroglyphics on a circular mechanism unearthed near the pyramids. It's the Stargate, a thingamajig that, when uncoded, becomes a portal to a twin gate on a sandy planet across the universe. Daniel gets enlisted for a space-jumping expedition, led by gruff Colonel Jack O'Neil (Kurt Russell), since he's the only one who can crack the code on that second Stargate. But first they have to face the sun god Ra, (Davidson), a cosmic vampire. Like a Tintin adventure set in the cosmos, the movie has an enjoyable retro feel. But it's harder to get revved up by it. Director Roland Emmerich turns out serviceable action scenes, but it's Spielberg minus Spielberg. Rated PG-13 for violence. -- Steve Murray   Terminal Velocity PG-13   A free fall into silliness, this sky-diving thriller plays like Hitchcock Lite. It's preposterous. And a lot of fun. Charlie Sheen stars as Arizona sky diver Ditch Brodie whose latest student, a blond airhead named Chris (Nastassja Kinski), takes an early tumble out the plane door, and makes like a pancake. Then again, is that really her body on the desert floor? Rated PG-13 for violence, language.   Timecop R   A good rule of thumb: the less sense a Jean-Claude Van Damme movie makes, the more fun it is. Happily, this futuristic actioner is a welcome return to the sci-fi silliness of his most successful film to date, ``Universal Soldier.'' Van Damme plays a time-traveling cop who tries to stop a corrupt senator from changing history. Rated R for violence, language, brief sex and nudity.   Trial By Jury R   Jury tampering takes on a whole new dimension in this solid thriller- melodrama that replaces 12 angry men with one very angry woman. Juror Joanne Whalley-Kilmer doesn't start out mad; she feels jury duty is part of truth, justice and the American Way. However, when she's chosen by prosecutor Gabriel Byrne to sit in judgment on a smoothie mobster (Armande Assante), she learns otherwise. Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   True Lies R   True trash. Too long, too loud and too expensive, this action farce is a pointless exercise in abuse of power, Hollywood-style. Starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Jamie Lee Curtis. Directed by James Cameron. Rated R for violence and language.   The War PG-13 A big-hearted bore from the maker of ``Fried Green Tomatoes.'' Director Jon Avnet returns to the South of a few years past, in this case small-town Mississippi, 1970. (It was mostly shot in Georgia.) Kevin Costner plays Stephen Simmons, a vet trying to hold a job while haunted by memories of 'Nam. We see him through the eyes of his kids, Stu (Elijah Wood) and Lidia (Lexi Randall), who spend the summer months building a treehouse -- and trying to avoid the white-trash Lipnicki clan. Unlike the plot-driven ``Tomatoes,'' ``War'' ambles with the humid sleepiness of one of its summer days. Somebody's always a-sittin' on a porch, talkin' about love and family and duty and dreams. Late in the movie, when a turf battle turns the kids' treehouse into an obvious anti-war allegory, you might have already tuned out due to the platitudes and melodrama. -- Steve Murray   Wes Craven's New Nightmare R   Wes Craven reclaims Freddy Krueger in this postmodern, Pirandellan funhouse of a movie -- a ``Player'' for the slasher set. When the execs at New Line (the actual makers of this movie) ask original ``Elm Street'' heroine Heather Langenkamp (as Herself) to reprise her role for the ``definitive `Nightmare,' '' she has doubts: She's been having these bad Freddy nightmares. So has her son (Miko Hughes, the scalpel baby from ``Pet Sematary''). Seems that the malevolent force behind the Krueger movies -- the real Freddy -- wants to cross into Real Life. Fun premise. Robert Englund, John Saxon and Craven pop up as Themselves. And it's nice to see Krueger returned to the roots of the first film -- a pre-wisecrack, hellish fiend. Rated R for gore, language. -- Steve Murray .  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941111.0063 type=story > <HEADLINE> COMMENTARY: REAGAN GENIUS REBORN IN GOP CONTRACT </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> WACO, Texas  (BC-NETHAWAY-COLUMN-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"

"8932"	"you"	"think"	" Before the game, police cordoned off an area outside Pauley Pavilion because of a bomb threat. About an hour and a half before the game, the LAPD bomb squad found what was described as a ``prank bomb'' in a backpack near a soft-drink machine. It was determined to be harmless. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941118.0069 type=multi > <HEADLINE> CAPSULE REVIEWS OF CURRENT FILMS </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(6takes)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> These brief reviews of current movies are written by Cox News Service movie critic Eleanor Ringel. They move weekly to clients of the New York Times News Service.   G: General audiences. Nothing that would offend parents if viewed by children.   PG: Parental guidance suggested. May contain some material parents consider inappropriate for young children.   PG-13: Parents strongly cautioned. Some material may be inappropriate for preteens.   R: Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. Parents are urged to learn more about the film before taking children.   NC-17: No one under 17 admitted. Replaces the X rating.   NR: Not rated.   The Adventures of Priscilla,   Queen of the Desert R   The boys on the bus would rather be thought of as the girls on the bus in this spirited Aussie froth about two drag queens (Hugo Weaving and Guy Pearce) and a transsexual ('60s stud Terence Stamp) on a cross-country jaunt through the Outback. Rated R for sex-related situations and language.   Andre PG   Predictable but sweet, this seal saga is a decent primer for kids learning some basic lesson about family and friendship. But be forewarned: Andre's best trick is to blow derogatory raspberries. Don't be surprised if your kids pick up the habit. Starring Keith Carradine. Rated PG for scenes of animal endangerment. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Angels in the Outfield PG   This kid-pleasing baseball fantasy about a lonely boy, a slumping baseball team and some divine intervention is a winged victory for Disney, thanks to a strong cast and heart-tugging plot. Think ``Free Willy'' with the California Angels instead of a whale. Starring Danny Glover and Christopher Lloyd. Directed by William Dear. Rated PG for mild adult themes.   Baby's Day Out PG   A very long day indeed, for Baby and for the audience. This John Hughes-ian spin on ``The Ransom of Red Chief'' is best recommended to die-hard slapstick fans who've always wanted to see a remake of ``Three Men and a Baby,'' starring the Three Stooges. Rated PG for comic violence.   Barcelona PG-13   Set in Spain, Whit Stillman's literate, witty romantic comedy takes place within the socio-political context of ``the last decade of the Cold War.'' Starring Taylor Nichols and Chris Eigemann. Rated PG- 13 for language and violence.   Blankman PG-13   Daman Wayans stars as a nerdy inventor who becomes a bargain-basement superhero. The movie has a few humorous moments, at least enough to fill a five-minute ``In Living Color'' sketch, but stretched out to feature-film length, the joke wears more than a bit thin. Directed by Mike Binder. Rated PG-13 for profanity, some violence, and some sexual situations.   Blue Sky PG-13   Tommy Lee Jones and Jessica Lange give Oscar-worthy performances in this riveting family drama set against a backdrop of military coverups and abuse of power. Directed by Tony Richardson. Rated PG- 13 for sex, brief nudity and adult themes.   Bullets Over Broadway R   It's as if Woody Allen decided to make a movie like the movie-within-the-movie in ``The Purple Rose of Cairo.'' Working in his Runyon-esque ``Broadway Danny Rose'' mode, he takes us back to the Great White Way of the Roaring '20s, for a theater-centric farce that ends up debating the artist vs. the man (something Woody's probably heard a lot of recently). John Cusack is the ardent young playwright who believes in art and Jennifer Tilly is the no-talent moll whose gangster-boyfriend bankrolls his play so she can go onstage. Rated R for language, adult themes.   Clear and Present Danger PG-13   Even when this new installment in the Tom Clancy film-adaptation franchise is far from clear, it's dangerously entertaining. Reteaming director Phillip Noyce and star Harrison Ford as CIA analyst Jack Ryan, it's more convoluted than ``Patriot Games.'' But also more gripping. Rated PG-13 for some intense action, violence and language. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Clerks R   Quirky, irreverent and about as off- the-cuff casual as a movie can be (even a $27,000 movie), this black-and-white no-budget-er has been a prize winner at Cannes and Sundance. Filmmaker Kevin Smith (who also appears in the picture as an enigmatic hanger-on named Silent Bob) gives us a day in the life of a couple of twentysomething Jersey guys named Dante (Brian O'Halloran) and Randal (Jeff Anderson). The two hold down dead-end jobs at, respectively, a Quick Stop convenience store and the neighboring hole-in-the-wall video store. Somewhere beyond slackers, they spend their days discussing the merits of ``The Empire Strikes Back'' vs. ``Return of the Jedi'' (``Justa bunch of Muppets'') while waiting on the usual eccentric crew of customers (like the guy who gets his hand stuck in a Pringle's potato chip can). The film looks just as raw as you'd expect, but it's also brimming with personality, humor and a genuine independent spirit. Absurdist, smutty and completely comfortable with itself, ``Clerks'' is grunge cinema at its best.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941118.0070 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(2ndtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The Client PG-13   Susan Sarandon and Tommy Lee Jones are wonderful together in yet another John Grisham story. Unfortunately, they play supporting roles to a kid actor who's very impressive, but can't outshine them. Directed by Joel Schumacher. Rated PG-13 for violence and language.   Corrina, Corrina PG   In this beautifully acted, wonderfully perceptive comedy-drama, Whoopi Goldberg plays a '50s housekeeper who makes Mrs. Doubtfire look like W.C. Fields. Directed by Jessie Nelson. Rated PG for adult themes.   Crooklyn PG-13   Spike Lee's affectionate return to the Brooklyn of his youth is a sweet and funny change of pace. Starring Alfre Woodard, Delroy Lindo and Zelda Harris. Rated PG-13 for some profanity, scenes of neighborhood drug use, splintering family unit, kids pranks that include death of dog.   Double Dragon PG-13   This film version of the popular video game is a cynical attempt at duping young fans into paying to watch a 93-minute commercial for the game and its inevitable sequels. Yet it's also surprisingly grim, considering the target audience. Set in the year 2007, the film blithely presents a nightmarish city ravaged by smog, earthquakes and marauding gangs straight out of ``The Warriors.'' The plot -- less complex than a Pong tournament -- involves a futuristic struggle for a magic Chinese talisman that grants its possessor vague powers over the ``body and soul.'' Half of the ``Double Dragon'' is being guarded by the wise-cracking, kick-boxing Lee brothers -- played in an interesting bit of casting by Mark Dacascos (who looks Asian) and TV's ``Party of Five'' star Scott Wolf (who looks like Tom Cruise). The evil tycoon who holds the other half is played by Marietta native Robert Patrick, best known as the mighty morphin' cyborg in ``Terminator 2.'' Once again Patrick plays a character who shape-shifts, begging the question: Exactly what kind of typecasting is going on here? Can the guy do this in real life? -- Mark Binelli, free-lance writer   Drop Squad R   Part ``The Colored Museum,'' part ``The Man From U.N.C.L.E.,'' this fiercely engaging drama/satire looks at the often confusing issue of what it means to be African American. Directed by David Johnson; produced by Spike Lee. Starring Eriq La Salle (NBC's ``E.R.''). Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   Ed Wood R   Tim Burton's hilarious and superbly crafted tribute to Ed Wood, the filmmaker who was once named the worst director in film history. Tim Burton concentrates on Wood's (Johnny Depp) '50s career, when he turned out such beyond-bad opuses as ``Plan 9 From Outer Space.'' Rated R for language and adult themes.   Exit to Eden R   Exit FROM Eden. Better still, don't go anywhere near it in the first place. Based on Anne Rice's soft-core S&AMP;M novel about a kind of leather-bar Fantasy Island, the film version has been ``improved'' by director Garry Marshall who's turned it into a kind of ``The Story of O'' meets ``Police Academy III.'' Marshall leavens Rice's kinky stuff with a made-up comic subplot about a pair of cops (Rosie O'Donnell and Dan Aykroyd) on the trail of a handsome photographer (``Strictly Ballroom's'' Paul Mercurio) who's inadvertently snapped some jewel thieves. Rated R for adult themes and language.   Forrest Gump PG-13   Tom Hanks is clueless in America in Robert Zemeckis's half-baked fable about an idiot-savant of sorts, skimming through the last half of the 20th century and colliding ``Zelig''-like with history. Rated PG-13 for adult themes.   Fresh NR   The boy in this hood really is a boy -- a 12-year-old named Fresh (Sean Nelson) who divides his time between junior high and running drugs. The most important person in his life, however, is his near-derelict dad (Samuel L. Jackson) who passes along his passion for chess and, in doing so, teaches Fresh the strategy and mental agility he needs to pull off a revenge-scenario that Michael Corleone would envy. Not rated, but there is drug use, violence, profanity and adult themes.   A Good Man in Africa R   A good deal of talent is wasted in this satire about the end of colonialism in a fictional African country. Starring Colin Friels and Sean Connery. Rated R for language, adult themes.   Hoop Dreams PG-13   Three hours of basketball may sound like 21/2 hours too many for most moviegoers, but this extraordinary documentary is about so much more than backboards and rebounds. It's a richly observed, superbly nuanced look at the American Dream through the eyes of two teenage NBA hopefuls. Directed by Steve James. Rated PG-13 for profanity and drug use.   I Don't Want to Talk About It PG-13   The ``It'' in this strangely affecting Argentinian film is the physicality of the daughter of a wealthy South American widow named Dona Leonor (Luisina Brando). Her teenager, Charlotte (Alejandra Podesta), is smart, loving, well-read, an accomplished pianist and a devoted daughter. She is also vertically challenged -- or, as they used to say, a dwarf. However, Dona Leonor won't say it (she also burns copies of ``Tom Thumb'') and she won't allow her neighbors to mention it either. The movie takes an odder-still twist when a mysterious roue (Marcello Mastroianni) comes to town and falls for Charlotte. The picture benefits from its bizarre set-up, a poetically Fellini-esque finale and Brando's chilling portrayal of a manipulative, overprotective parent. But director Maria Luisa Bemberg lets things go a bit flat in the middle and it's only thanks to Mastroianni's decades of expertise and innate courtly charisma that we remain interested during the slow spots. Still, the movie deserves points for acting, tone and originality; after all, how many movies try to mix psychotic denial and magic realism in one story?  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941118.0071 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(3rdtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> I Like It Like That R   A strong debut by young African-American filmmaker Darnell Martin, who deftly guides us through the mean streets of the Bronx and the complexities of the human heart. Rated R for language, adult themes and sex.   Interview With the Vampire R   As richly textured as a dark brocade, threaded with existential dread and drenched in plasma, Neil Jordan's film will disturb more viewers than just Oprah. It's filled with snapping necks, slit throats, rats and wrists draining crimson into goblets, and other bloody bits of necro-fun. But it's likely to thrill Anne Rice fans and seduce those unfamiliar with her books. Interviewed by a San Francisco journalist (Christian Slater), reluctant vampire Louis (Brad Pitt) goes back 200 years to torchlit New Orleans, recalling his role in the ultimate dysfunctional clan: himself, sadistic Lestat (Tom Cruise) who made him a vampire; and their ``child'' Claudia (Kirsten Dunst), whose golden curls mask a fierce hunger. Lestat is driven by appetite. Louis wants answers. His quest to find others of ``our kind'' drives the film into 19th- century Paris, introducing a clique of decadent undead (including Antonio Banderas and Stephen Rea). As a screenwriter, Rice doesn't hit her points as hard as she might, especially Louis' motivations. If you're unfamiliar with the book, you might find the going slow. And here's what you've been wondering: Cruise's Lestat is a dandy dandy; he could be more frightening, but the role hasn't been stretched into a vanity star turn. Pitt provides the eloquent heart of the movie. And Dunst, older than the novel's Claudia, conveys the character's anguish at being trapped in childhood. But the film's biggest triumph is its visual design, an opulent fusion of costumes (Sandy Powell), production design (Dante Ferretti) and cinematography (Philippe Rousselot). This ``Vampire'' has bite. -- Steve Murray   It Could Happen to You PG   This sweet nothing of a film pairs Nicolas Cage and Bridget Fonda in an appealing romantic fairy tale of love and the New York lottery. The film is too slight to be a grand romance, but it's definitely a winning one. Rated PG for mild language, adult situations.   Jason's Lyric R   It starts with the promise of something invigorating and fresh. It's the story of an African-American family living outside the usual inner-city setting of gangsta flicks. But director Doug McHenry carries urban cliches with him into the suburbs: drugs, guns and a whore-madonna view of women that's not very different from a rap video. Rated R for violence, sex, language and drug use. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Lassie PG   Lassie comes home to the big screen in an engaging family film directed by Daniel Petrie. Set in rural Virginia, this savvily updated version (by ``Paper House's'' Matthew Jacob) has a lot more in common with the TV series than the novel or the 1943 movie. But even after 50 years, it's still the same old story: a boy and his wonder-dog. The boy is Matt (Thomas Guiry), an angry adolescent who resents his new stepmom (Helen Slater) almost as much as he resents his dad's (Jon Tenney) relocating the family from Baltimore to a sheep farm. The wonder-dog, of course, is Lassie who latches onto Matt when her owner is killed. Rated PG for mild violence.   The Last Seduction R   Probably the sleeper of the year. In the tradition of ``Double Indemnity'' and ``Body Heat,'' director John Dahl (``Red Rock West'') pairs a smart, sexy, no-good dame with a hunky sucker who's not half as smart as he thinks he is. Linda Fiorentino is a one-woman wrecking crew as a tough cookie with a lotta leg and even more nerve who easily gets nice-guy Peter Berg in her thrall. To reveal much more would spoil the movie's many twists, but let's just add that Bill Pullman plays one of her previous patsies and Bill Nunn is the private investigator Pullman puts on her trail. Thanks to their strong, steady work and Dahl's flashy direction, Steve Barancik's imaginative but far-fetched script gains considerable credibility. But the pivotal element here is Fiorentino whose portrayal of a master manipulator makes Sharon Stone look like a Girl Scout. Whether playing mind games or body games, she plays for keeps. Look for her name around Oscar-nomination time and go looking for this superbly entertaining picture immediately.   Little Giants PG   This time, the Bad News Bears . . . I mean, the Mighty Ducks . . . I mean . . . Let's start over. This time, a gang of lovable kiddie misfits pull together and become a heck of a Pee Wee League football team. The only discernable twist is that the Giants' coach (Rick Moranis) and the coach (Ed O'Neill) of the all- star opposing team are brothers with a long-standing rivalry. Given a fourth- down-and-long situation, director Duwayne Dunham punts for formula and lets his cast fumble along as best they can. Rated PG for mild language.   Little Rascals PG   Rent the originals. The idea of turning Hal Roach's famed ``Our Gang'' shorts into a feature for '90s audiences is a dubious one at best. And it's been done in the worst possible way. Director Penelope Spheeris has found a remarkable cast of look-alikes who seem to have been cloned from some hidden source of Little Rascals DNA. But as well-trained and well-made-up as these kids are, they are pod-Rascals -- an artful semblance of the real thing but totally devoid of freshness, naturalness or spontaneity. Rated PG for smutty language.   Love Affair PG-13   If this timeless tale of true romance worked for Charles Boyer and Irene Dunne in 1939 (``Love Affair'') and for Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr in 1957 (``An Affair to Remember''), then why shouldn't it work in 1994 for Warren Beatty and Annette Bening? Well, it does. To a point. This is a first-class effort and while it isn't quite the heartbreaker one hopes for, it still manages to jerk a few tears.   Mary Shelley's Frankenstein R   In Mary Shelley's classic 19th-century novel, medical student Victor Frankenstein learns that some things are better left to God. In this opulent, fever-pitched movie, director-star Kenneth Branagh learns that some things are better left to James Whale, the man who made the 1931 Karloff version. Not that Branagh's version is a total dud. But in its own way, it's as deliriously misguided as Shelley's mad-scientist protagonist. The problems begin with the casting of Robert De Niro as the Monster. His stitched-together mass of scar tissue may be closer to the novel than Karloff's plug-necked proletariat, but Karloff was an unknown and De Niro, well, is De Niro. Every time he appears, you think, gee, Travis Bickle's been run over by his own taxi. Also, Branagh has chosen to return to the original's Gothic-romance roots by emphasizing the relationship between Victor (Branagh) and his beloved Elizabeth (Helena Bonham Carter). That's fine as far as it goes -- and in these actors' talented hands, it goes pretty far -- but it has the effect of reducing the Monster to a bothersome interruption. Brimming with talent and dedication, the Branagh version never bores, but it never truly chills either.   The Mask PG-13   Forget the superhero plot of this live-action cartoon and focus on the Looney-Tunes special effects, the immensely likable Jim Carrey and Milo the mighty Jack Russell terrier. Directed by Chuck Russell. Rated PG-13 for mild violence.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941118.0072 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(4thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Miracle on 34th Street PG   It would be a miracle indeed if a John Hughes remake could come anywhere close to replicating the whimsical magic of the 1947 original starring Edmund Gwenn and Nathalie Wood. Alas, miracles don't happen every day and one certainly hasn't happened here. Despite a twinkly-eyed performance by Sir Richard Attenborough as The Man Who Would Be Santa and the gravelly voiced charm of little Mara Wilson as a non- believer ripe for conversion, this movie is staler than week-old fruitcake. Elizabeth Perkins plays a harried single mom who doesn't think her six-year-old daughter (Wilson) needs to believe in that ho-ho-ho stuff. Ironically, Perkins is the one who hires a mysterious gentleman named Kriss Kringle (Attenborough) to be her department store's seasonal Santa. As anyone who saw the original knows, Kringle ends up on trial, for claiming he really is Santa. Dylan McDermott is the lawyer who defends him and Robert Prosky is the judge with the hottest case this side of O.J. Though nominally directed by Les Mayfield, the film has the unmistakable Hughes imprint, meaning most of its charm is lost in the Hughesian overkill. This remake is as synthetic as a silver-foil Christmas tree. Harmless, perhaps, but hardly worth seeking out.   Natural Born Killers R Oliver Stone is a natural born moviemaker and a natural born troublemaker and this anarchic, almost surreal film shows both sides at their best. As emblematic of the disaffected, media-overload '90s as ``Bonnie and Clyde'' was of the '60s, ``Killers'' celebrates sex, violence and celebrity with a vengeance that's both visual and visceral. Mickey (Woody Harrelson) and Mallory (Juliette Lewis) are young, in love and they kill people. About 52 people before they're put in Tommy Lee Jones' jail. Rated R for extreme violence, gore, language, nudity and sexuality.   The Next Karate Kid PG   The new ``kid'' is a sullen teenaged girl named Julie, played by newcomer Hilary Swank. It's not a bad idea to show that a teen can have lips like Claudia Schiffer's and still beat the stuffing out of a bothersome guy. Noriyuki ``Pat'' Morita returns as Mr. Miyagi. Rated PG for violence.   Oleanna R   Cinematic saltpeter, it's a guaranteed date-night dampener. David Mamet's film of his off-Broadway power play can send men and women up the theater aisle, fuming for separate reasons. Charting a trio of disastrous meetings between a college professor (William H. Macy), and a student (Debra Eisenstadt) who's failing his class, the film is a paranoid reaction to the shifting sexual politics of the '90s: Patricia Bowman, Anita Hill, Tailhook, etc. We first meet Carol arriving sans appointment at John's office. The words that rain most often from her mouth are, ``I don't understand.'' But by their second encounter, she has morphed from a stammering coed to a coolly poised virago, equipped with a militantly drab wardrobe, a notably improved vocabulary, and the support of a student cabal whom she refers to as ``my group.'' The personality shift is abrupt, unexplained. Instead of a two-person, full-bodied drama, the movie turns into a symbolic standoff between an innocent man and a misogynist's nightmare. Sexless, anti-intellectual, tract-spouting, Carol becomes the sort of woman Rush Limbaugh and Camille Paglia would take turns hating. Mamet keeps the focus simple; he hardly ``opens up'' the play. And it's easy to admire the deft dialogue and the strong performances. Macy summons a natty self-satisfaction (you wouldn't mind seeing him deflated, but not crucified). Eisenstadt does as fine a job as possible with the role's limitations. In the end, Mamet comes up with Molotov cocktail that's almost too successful in making audiences see red. -- Steve Murray   Only You PG   If only Hollywood would make more movies like this fanciful Roman holiday, starring Marisa Tomei as a bride- to-be on a quixotic romantic quest in Italy and Robert Downey Jr. as a gallant suitor who may or may not be her only one. Rated PG for mild sexual themes.   The Professional R   French director Luc Besson (``La Femme Nikita'') goes American and his movie goes down the drain. Again, the stylish Frenchman dazzles us with explosions and massacres, killer babes and their world-weary mentors. But this time, the babe really is a babe -- a precocious 12-year-old (Natalie Portman) who takes up with a professional hitman (Jean Reno) after her family is wiped out by a crooked DEA agent (a hilariously hammy Gary Oldman). Initially, the bond formed between the pro and the preteen is tentative and touching; he may be the best killer in Manhattan, but his best friend is a house plant. She offers to clean house if he'll teach her to ``clean up,'' so she can avenge her family. Alas, Besson opts for a superfluous titillation factor, letting Portman walk around in budding-adolescent undershirts and do Madonna impersonations for Reno. He, in turn, stands around with his mouth hanging open, looking slightly stunned. Perhaps the most optimistic way to look at this film is as one exasperated Frenchman's attempt to circumvent the parasitical cycle of American remakes of French films. Besson probably figured that, if he'd made the film in Paris, some Hollywood producer would buy the remake rights, replace him as director and cast Clint Eastwood and one of the ``Full House'' twins.   Pulp Fiction R   Pop goes the pulp in this smashing sophomore effort by Quentin ``Reservoir Dogs'' Tarantino. Winner of the Golden Palm at Cannes and already subject to Oscar-time whispers, the picture is a gleefully lurid mix of hardboiled gangster-movie conventions and hip post-Warhol irony. It's an exceedingly violent genre flick with a twist -- everyone is in on the joke. Everyone, that is, except the characters on screen. The film consists of three expertly interwoven vignettes. The first tale centers on a couple of hit men (beautifully played by John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson) and Travolta's job babysitting his big, bad boss's (Ving Rhames) babe-licious wife (Uma Thurman). The second focuses on a boxer (Bruce Willis) who's been asked to take a dive. The third goes back to Travolta and Jackson who need Harvey Keitel's help disposing a dead body. Flashy, smart, daring and full of itself, the movie sometimes suggests ``Short Cuts'' with shootouts. Rated R for violence, language, nudity and drug use.   The Puppet Masters R   NASA scientist Dr. Mary Sefton (Julie Warner) has a unique test to determine whether a man is a full- blooded human or if he's possessed by an alien: She shows him her cleavage. This sexist device is one clue that ``The Puppet Masters'' originated as a 1951 Robert A. Heinlein novel. The premise is dated, the latest in a long line of sci-fi paranoia thrillers: Outer-space beasties leach onto human hosts and plot to overwhelm the world. Deduct points for freshness. But ``Masters'' bops with a brisk, nab-those-critters attitude. And the critters are a treat: gloppy manta rays that latch on to your back, jam a tether in your brain, and fuse with your nervous system. Like a good cigarette. -- Steve Murray   Quiz Show PG-13   Robert Redford's dazzlingly entertaining movie is set in the late '50s, when Americans were as hooked on quiz shows as later generations would be on Watergate or O.J.'s white Bronco. When the sponsor tires of ``Twenty-One's'' current wonder-boy, Herb Stempel (John Turturro), a schlemiel from Queens, he's replaced by Charles Van Doren (Ralph Fiennes), the handsome scion of an aristocratic, academic family. Van Doren becomes the nation's most adored egghead and Stempel spills the beans -- that the game is rigged -- to a congressional investigator (Rob Morrow). Rated PG-13 for adult themes.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941118.0073 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(5thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Radioland Murders PG   Just plain murder to sit through. This fiasco is the latest missive from the hermit-like George Lucas. Produced and written by Lucas and directed by Mel Smith (``The Tall Guy''), the movie means to be a farcical murder mystery set in 1939 at the art deco studios of WBN, a radio station trying to go national. Running around the overcrowded halls are a bickering husband-and-wife team (headwriter Brian Benben and executive-assistant-turned-de-facto-producer, Mary Stuart Masterson); a femme- fatale radio star (the late, very talented Anita Morris); a philandering director (Jeffrey Tambor), a no-nothing executive president (Ned Beatty) and a libidious announcer (Corbin Bernsen) . . . among others. While the show goes on (and everything falls into chaos), someone behindthe scenes is murdering the staff.   Red Rock West R   In this low-budget comic noir about greed, lust and cheatin' hearts, Nicholas Cage is a nice-guy drifter taught by the likes of Dennis Hopper and J.T. Walsh that no good deed ever goes unpunished. Directed by John Dahl. Rated R for violence, profanity and sex.   Renaissance Man PG-13   A bummer, man. Director Penny Marshall proves she can do predictable military schmaltz just as well (badly?) as the guys, with this Danny DeVito inspirational comedy that might well be subtitled ``Dead Poet's Platoon.''   Reservoir Dogs R   As in, one assumes, meaner than the junkyard variety. Quentin Tarentino's debut is an electrifyingly vicious caper flick, soaked in blood, obscenity and incongruous black humor. Most of the movie takes place immediately before and after a robbery gone terribly wrong. The ensemble cast -- headed by Harvey Keitel, Steve Buscemi, Chris Penn and Tim Roth -- is a marvel, worthy of a Mamet play (which this film's profane energy often evokes).   The River Wild PG-13   Meryl Streep is a former white-water river guide, who views a rafting excursion in her old splashing grounds as more than a family vacation. It's a chance to spend quality time and heal rifts with workaholic husband Tom (David Strathairn) and son Roarke (Joseph Mazzello). Slithering into the family's domestic Eden, Kevin Bacon is a fellow rafter who turns vacation into hell, taking the family hostage and forcing Streep to pilot him safely down the river. The actors and the scenery keep your mind off a predictable plot; this is a B-movie graced with members of the Hollywood A- list. But the trip is worth it. Rated PG-13 for violence. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   The Road to Wellville R   Paved with good intentions. Like that other road. Alan Parker's health-craze comedy is an art-design folly with little more going for it than spectacle: Edwardian clothes, Anthony Hopkins with buckteeth, and cruel spa machines Jules Verne might have forged. Playing cereal czar and health nut John Harvey Kellogg, Hopkins creates a grand, blustery caricature. Unfortunately, Parker's adaptation of T. Coraghessan Boyle's novel has flurry in place of a plot. The welter of characters include a young cornflakes entrepreneur (John Cusack); Kellogg's prodigal son George (Dana Carvey); and Will and Eleanor Lightbody (Matthew Broderick and Bridget Fonda), whose physical ills cloak deeper marital problems. Fonda comes off as a mall rat in her great-grandma's clothes. Cusack goes over the top. Broderick gamely endures a lot of enema and bowel jokes, and shows off ab muscles more gym-developed than might be credible for a man of 1907. The movie blows its opportunities to score points about our own health-conscious age. It remains undernourished and dramatically anemic. Rated R for nudity, sexual situations. -- Steve Murray   The Santa Clause PG   The movie's moral is a peculiar one, even by Hollywood standards: The best way for a father to gain his son's respect is to pack on 50 pounds, grow a white beard and consort with elves. Thus it goes with Scott Calvin (Tim Allen), a divorced dad whose 8-year-old, Charlie (Eric Lloyd), would rather spend Christmas Eve with Mom (Wendy Crewson) and her new therapist hubby (Judge Reinhold). That is, until Santa tumbles off the roof, Scott straps on St. Nick's suit, and goes across the globe popping in and out of chimneys (aided by some computer effects that aren't as special as you'd hope). Amiable Allen wisecracks his way past snarling mutts and spying moppets (``Do you want this doll or not?'' he asks one recalcitrant tot). Then, at the North Pole, he finds out from the rainbow-coalition elves that -- gulp -- once you put on Santa's suit, you're Santa. For good. From here, the movie unreels as a cross between ``Miracle on 34th Street'' and a paranoid delusion. As the new year unfolds, Scott bloats up and goes white-haired and bewhiskered. Call it Clausitis: Santa overcomes his nervous system like an incurable disease. Allen's normal-guy shtick is terrific, but once he disappears inside the fat-suit, the movie's personality goes with him. Cuteness happens, magic doesn't. And if you have kids, be prepared to tell them something the movie never explains: What the heck happened to the original Santa, who evaporates into thin air? Ho ho huh? -- Steve Murray   The Shawshank Redemption R   There are two excellent reasons to see this involving movie and their names are Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. Based on a Stephen King novella, this is a stone-walls-do-not-a-prison-make story, in which hope flourishes in horrifying surroundings and a unique friendship is forged inside a human purgatory.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941118.0074 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(6thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Silent Fall R   When a prosperous couple is found brutally murdered in the bedroom of their Maryland mansion, the only witness is their 9-year-old son (Ben Faulkner). Unfortunately, the boy is also autistic, which prompts the local sheriff and the boy's protective older sister (model Liv Tyler) to bring in a once-prominent child shrink (Richard Dreyfuss), who quit treating kids after a tragedy befell a patient. While this solid suspense drama goes to great lengths to stress that autism isn't an easily understandable condition, it also uses the boy's state as a plot contrivance to get Dreyfuss involved. Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   The Specialist R   Sylvester Stallone's specialty has been to turn a one-note act into a multimillion-dollar career. But the specialist specified here is a former CIA explosives expert hired by a rich lovely (Sharon Stone) to wipe out the bad guys who killed her parents when she was just a kid. That means taking on Miami mobsters led by patriarch Rod Steiger (doing an embarrassing Jose Jimenez accent), his sleazy son (Eric Roberts) and his equally sleazy consigliere (James Woods, who used to be in the CIA with Sly until they had a falling out over innocent bystanders). At its best, the film is like ``Death Wish'' warmed-over, with hints of ``The Bodyguard.'' However, the expected sparks between Stallone and Stone never ignite.   Speed R   The perfect summer- movie rush. The gimmick is simple: A wacko (Dennis Hopper) has put a bomb on a city bus. When the bus hits 50 mph, the bomb goes on; if it slows below 50, the bomb goes off. And so the chase is on -- with a busload of terrified passengers, a hurt driver, a spunky civilian at the wheel (Sandra Bullock) and a very determined cop (Keanu Reeves) in pursuit. Directed by Jan De Bont. Rated R for violence and language.   Stargate PG-13   An engaging sci-fi yarn with a flying pyramid, three moons and Jaye Davidson in a dress. Again. We start on Earth, where a linguist named Daniel (James Spader) deciphers Egyptian hieroglyphics on a circular mechanism unearthed near the pyramids. It's the Stargate, a thingamajig that, when uncoded, becomes a portal to a twin gate on a sandy planet across the universe. Daniel gets enlisted for a space-jumping expedition, led by gruff Colonel Jack O'Neil (Kurt Russell), since he's the only one who can crack the code on that second Stargate. But first they have to face the sun god Ra, (Davidson), a cosmic vampire. Like a Tintin adventure set in the cosmos, the movie has an enjoyable retro feel. But it's harder to get revved up by it. Director Roland Emmerich turns out serviceable action scenes, but it's Spielberg minus Spielberg. Rated PG-13 for violence. -- Steve Murray   Star Trek: Generations PG   This franchise boldly keeps going and going and going. In this incarnation, the torch is smoothly passed from one cast to the next as the aging members of the orginal '60s show are replaced by the ``Next Generation'' ensemble. Captains Picard (Patrick Stewart) and Kirk (William Shatner) join forces to defeat a mad scientist ('60s bad boy, Malcolm McDowell) who's willing to destroy whole galaxies in his frantic attempt to reach the Nexus, a place of illusionary contentment. In the ``Star Trek'' tradition, ``Generations'' offers a sprinkling of high-minded metaphysical musings along with a hearty dose of high-tech gimmickry (thus, the nature of mortality and Warp 4 come up in the same conversation). Scotty (James Doohan) and Chekov (Walter Koenig) turn up briefly, but most of the story is carried by Stewart's crew (Brent Spiner, LeVar Burton, Whoopi Goldberg, Michael Dorn, etc.). As for the battle of the starship captains, Stewart is patrician and compassionate, but Shatner's Hollywood-honed hamming steals every scene. Granted, the plot is incomprehensible and the logic nil; but the filmmakers have the proper respect for its characters and for the ongoing ``Star Trek'' mythos. They understand that, under the skin, we're all Trekkies.   The Swan Princess G   It's not Disney, but it's pretty decent. An animated musical from Richard Rich, who once worked for the Mouse, ``The Swan Princess'' tells of a true love that overcomes all obstacles. Prince Derek and Princess Odette, heirs to separate kingdoms, are brought together every summer by their parents, who hope the children's scrappy friendship will someday blossom into love. Nicely, ``Princess'' shows Derek and Odette mutually trying to find each other -- this isn't a damsel-in- distress scenario. The movie's pleasures come through amusing supporting characters (a turtle and frog, with voices by Steven Wright and John Cleese), some adult-friendly humor and songs propelled by clever lyrics that touch on everything from true love to political correctness. Though the animation varies between TV stiffness and Disney opulence, ``The Swan Princess'' is a pleasant holiday surprise that takes wing more often than not. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Terminal Velocity PG-13   A free fall into silliness, this sky-diving thriller plays like Hitchcock Lite. It's preposterous. And a lot of fun. Charlie Sheen stars as Arizona sky diver Ditch Brodie whose latest student, a blond airhead named Chris (Nastassja Kinski), takes an early tumble out the plane door, and makes like a pancake. Then again, is that really her body on the desert floor? Rated PG-13 for violence, language.   Timecop R   A good rule of thumb: the less sense a Jean-Claude Van Damme movie makes, the more fun it is. Happily, this futuristic actioner is a welcome return to the sci-fi silliness of his most successful film to date, ``Universal Soldier.'' Van Damme plays a time-traveling cop who tries to stop a corrupt senator from changing history. Rated R for violence, language, brief sex and nudity.   Trial By Jury R   Jury tampering takes on a whole new dimension in this solid thriller- melodrama that replaces 12 angry men with one very angry woman. Juror Joanne Whalley-Kilmer doesn't start out mad; she feels jury duty is part of truth, justice and the American Way. However, when she's chosen by prosecutor Gabriel Byrne to sit in judgment on a smoothie mobster (Armande Assante), she learns otherwise. Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   True Lies R   True trash. Too long, too loud and too expensive, this action farce is a pointless exercise in abuse of power, Hollywood-style. Starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Jamie Lee Curtis. Directed by James Cameron. Rated R for violence and language.   The War PG-13 A big-hearted bore from the maker of ``Fried Green Tomatoes.'' Director Jon Avnet returns to the South of a few years past, in this case small-town Mississippi, 1970. (It was mostly shot in Georgia.) Kevin Costner plays Stephen Simmons, a vet trying to hold a job while haunted by memories of 'Nam. We see him through the eyes of his kids, Stu (Elijah Wood) and Lidia (Lexi Randall), who spend the summer months building a treehouse -- and trying to avoid the white-trash Lipnicki clan. Unlike the plot-driven ``Tomatoes,'' ``War'' ambles with the humid sleepiness of one of its summer days. Somebody's always a-sittin' on a porch, talkin' about love and family and duty and dreams. Late in the movie, when a turf battle turns the kids' treehouse into an obvious anti-war allegory, you might have already tuned out due to the platitudes and melodrama. -- Steve Murray   Wes Craven's New Nightmare R   Wes Craven reclaims Freddy Krueger in this postmodern, Pirandellan funhouse of a movie -- a ``Player'' for the slasher set. When the execs at New Line (the actual makers of this movie) ask original ``Elm Street'' heroine Heather Langenkamp (as Herself) to reprise her role for the ``definitive `Nightmare,' '' she has doubts: She's been having these bad Freddy nightmares. So has her son (Miko Hughes, the scalpel baby from ``Pet Sematary''). Seems that the malevolent force behind the Krueger movies -- the real Freddy -- wants to cross into Real Life. Fun premise. Robert Englund, John Saxon and Craven pop up as Themselves. And it's nice to see Krueger returned to the roots of the first film -- a pre-wisecrack, hellish fiend. Rated R for gore, language. -- Steve Murray .  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941118.0075 type=story > <HEADLINE> TARA FANTASYLAND CLOSER TO REALITY NEAR VILLA RICA </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> VILLA RICA, Ga.
