I hunted all over for meanings of any kind -- not, I think, simply out of grief or anger at their deaths, but also because the stuff they saved implied that there must have been a reason for saving it.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"
"9158"	"I"	"think"	" ``I do not believe we should do unto Republicans as they have done unto us in the last session of Congress,'' said Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, chief sponsor of the proposal. ``To do that, I think, will further frustrate the American people ... will lead to gridlock and will diminish this place in the eyes of the American public.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"
"9159"	"I"	"think"	" He takes a snow shower of Parmesan cheese on his pasta. He and Gene Roddenberry, the creator of ``Star Trek,'' never got along, did they? ``Our relationship was cool,'' he agrees. ``It was summed up, I think, by one of the statements made to me by his wife after his death. I said, `I never understood why Gene didn't like me.' And she said: `Oh, but he did. He thought of all of you as his children.' And I don't need anyone to think of me as a child.'' Though right about now he sounds suspiciously like one. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"
"9288"	"you"	"think"	" Many others are just as curious to see if Grgurich will be able to win at UNLV and run a clean program at the same time. Changing people's perception may be his most formidable challenge of all. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941125.0046 type=multi > <HEADLINE> CAPSULE REVIEWS OF CURRENT FILMS </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(6takes)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> These brief reviews of current movies are written by Cox News Service movie critic Eleanor Ringel. They move weekly to clients of the New York Times News Service.   G: General audiences. Nothing that would offend parents if viewed by children.   PG: Parental guidance suggested. May contain some material parents consider inappropriate for young children.   PG-13: Parents strongly cautioned. Some material may be inappropriate for preteens.   R: Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. Parents are urged to learn more about the film before taking children.   NC-17: No one under 17 admitted. Replaces the X rating.   NR: Not rated.   The Adventures of Priscilla,   Queen of the Desert R   The boys on the bus would rather be thought of as the girls on the bus in this spirited Aussie froth about two drag queens (Hugo Weaving and Guy Pearce) and a transsexual ('60s stud Terence Stamp) on a cross-country jaunt through the Outback. Rated R for sex-related situations and language.   Andre PG   Predictable but sweet, this seal saga is a decent primer for kids learning some basic lesson about family and friendship. But be forewarned: Andre's best trick is to blow derogatory raspberries. Don't be surprised if your kids pick up the habit. Starring Keith Carradine. Rated PG for scenes of animal endangerment. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Angels in the Outfield PG   This kid-pleasing baseball fantasy about a lonely boy, a slumping baseball team and some divine intervention is a winged victory for Disney, thanks to a strong cast and heart-tugging plot. Think ``Free Willy'' with the California Angels instead of a whale. Starring Danny Glover and Christopher Lloyd. Directed by William Dear. Rated PG for mild adult themes.   Baby's Day Out PG   A very long day indeed, for Baby and for the audience. This John Hughes-ian spin on ``The Ransom of Red Chief'' is best recommended to die-hard slapstick fans who've always wanted to see a remake of ``Three Men and a Baby,'' starring the Three Stooges. Rated PG for comic violence.   Barcelona PG-13   Set in Spain, Whit Stillman's literate, witty romantic comedy takes place within the socio-political context of ``the last decade of the Cold War.'' Starring Taylor Nichols and Chris Eigemann. Rated PG- 13 for language and violence.   Blankman PG-13   Daman Wayans stars as a nerdy inventor who becomes a bargain-basement superhero. The movie has a few humorous moments, at least enough to fill a five-minute ``In Living Color'' sketch, but stretched out to feature-film length, the joke wears more than a bit thin. Directed by Mike Binder. Rated PG-13 for profanity, some violence, and some sexual situations.   Blue Sky PG-13   Tommy Lee Jones and Jessica Lange give Oscar-worthy performances in this riveting family drama set against a backdrop of military coverups and abuse of power. Directed by Tony Richardson. Rated PG- 13 for sex, brief nudity and adult themes.   Bullets Over Broadway R   It's as if Woody Allen decided to make a movie like the movie-within-the-movie in ``The Purple Rose of Cairo.'' Working in his Runyon-esque ``Broadway Danny Rose'' mode, he takes us back to the Great White Way of the Roaring '20s, for a theater-centric farce that ends up debating the artist vs. the man (something Woody's probably heard a lot of recently). John Cusack is the ardent young playwright who believes in art and Jennifer Tilly is the no-talent moll whose gangster-boyfriend bankrolls his play so she can go onstage. Rated R for language, adult themes.   Clear and Present Danger PG-13   Even when this new installment in the Tom Clancy film-adaptation franchise is far from clear, it's dangerously entertaining. Reteaming director Phillip Noyce and star Harrison Ford as CIA analyst Jack Ryan, it's more convoluted than ``Patriot Games.'' But also more gripping. Rated PG-13 for some intense action, violence and language. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Clerks R   Quirky, irreverent and about as off- the-cuff casual as a movie can be (even a $27,000 movie), this black-and-white no-budget-er has been a prize winner at Cannes and Sundance. Filmmaker Kevin Smith (who also appears in the picture as an enigmatic hanger-on named Silent Bob) gives us a day in the life of a couple of twentysomething Jersey guys named Dante (Brian O'Halloran) and Randal (Jeff Anderson). The two hold down dead-end jobs at, respectively, a Quick Stop convenience store and the neighboring hole-in-the-wall video store. Somewhere beyond slackers, they spend their days discussing the merits of ``The Empire Strikes Back'' vs. ``Return of the Jedi'' (``Justa bunch of Muppets'') while waiting on the usual eccentric crew of customers (like the guy who gets his hand stuck in a Pringle's potato chip can). The film looks just as raw as you'd expect, but it's also brimming with personality, humor and a genuine independent spirit. Absurdist, smutty and completely comfortable with itself, ``Clerks'' is grunge cinema at its best.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941125.0047 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(2ndtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The Client PG-13   Susan Sarandon and Tommy Lee Jones are wonderful together in yet another John Grisham story. Unfortunately, they play supporting roles to a kid actor who's very impressive, but can't outshine them. Directed by Joel Schumacher. Rated PG-13 for violence and language.   Corrina, Corrina PG   In this beautifully acted, wonderfully perceptive comedy-drama, Whoopi Goldberg plays a '50s housekeeper who makes Mrs. Doubtfire look like W.C. Fields. Directed by Jessie Nelson. Rated PG for adult themes.   Crooklyn PG-13   Spike Lee's affectionate return to the Brooklyn of his youth is a sweet and funny change of pace. Starring Alfre Woodard, Delroy Lindo and Zelda Harris. Rated PG-13 for some profanity, scenes of neighborhood drug use, splintering family unit, kids pranks that include death of dog.   Double Dragon PG-13   This film version of the popular video game is a cynical attempt at duping young fans into paying to watch a 93-minute commercial for the game and its inevitable sequels. Yet it's also surprisingly grim, considering the target audience. Set in the year 2007, the film blithely presents a nightmarish city ravaged by smog, earthquakes and marauding gangs straight out of ``The Warriors.'' The plot -- less complex than a Pong tournament -- involves a futuristic struggle for a magic Chinese talisman that grants its possessor vague powers over the ``body and soul.'' Half of the ``Double Dragon'' is being guarded by the wise-cracking, kick-boxing Lee brothers -- played in an interesting bit of casting by Mark Dacascos (who looks Asian) and TV's ``Party of Five'' star Scott Wolf (who looks like Tom Cruise). The evil tycoon who holds the other half is played by Marietta native Robert Patrick, best known as the mighty morphin' cyborg in ``Terminator 2.'' Once again Patrick plays a character who shape-shifts, begging the question: Exactly what kind of typecasting is going on here? Can the guy do this in real life? -- Mark Binelli, free-lance writer   Drop Squad R   Part ``The Colored Museum,'' part ``The Man From U.N.C.L.E.,'' this fiercely engaging drama/satire looks at the often confusing issue of what it means to be African American. Directed by David Johnson; produced by Spike Lee. Starring Eriq La Salle (NBC's ``E.R.''). Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   Ed Wood R   Tim Burton's hilarious and superbly crafted tribute to Ed Wood, the filmmaker who was once named the worst director in film history. Tim Burton concentrates on Wood's (Johnny Depp) '50s career, when he turned out such beyond-bad opuses as ``Plan 9 From Outer Space.'' Rated R for language and adult themes.   Exit to Eden R   Exit FROM Eden. Better still, don't go anywhere near it in the first place. Based on Anne Rice's soft-core S&AMP;M novel about a kind of leather-bar Fantasy Island, the film version has been ``improved'' by director Garry Marshall who's turned it into a kind of ``The Story of O'' meets ``Police Academy III.'' Marshall leavens Rice's kinky stuff with a made-up comic subplot about a pair of cops (Rosie O'Donnell and Dan Aykroyd) on the trail of a handsome photographer (``Strictly Ballroom's'' Paul Mercurio) who's inadvertently snapped some jewel thieves. Rated R for adult themes and language.   Forrest Gump PG-13   Tom Hanks is clueless in America in Robert Zemeckis's half-baked fable about an idiot-savant of sorts, skimming through the last half of the 20th century and colliding ``Zelig''-like with history. Rated PG-13 for adult themes.   Fresh NR   The boy in this hood really is a boy -- a 12-year-old named Fresh (Sean Nelson) who divides his time between junior high and running drugs. The most important person in his life, however, is his near-derelict dad (Samuel L. Jackson) who passes along his passion for chess and, in doing so, teaches Fresh the strategy and mental agility he needs to pull off a revenge-scenario that Michael Corleone would envy. Not rated, but there is drug use, violence, profanity and adult themes.   A Good Man in Africa R   A good deal of talent is wasted in this satire about the end of colonialism in a fictional African country. Starring Colin Friels and Sean Connery. Rated R for language, adult themes.   Hoop Dreams PG-13   Three hours of basketball may sound like 21/2 hours too many for most moviegoers, but this extraordinary documentary is about so much more than backboards and rebounds. It's a richly observed, superbly nuanced look at the American Dream through the eyes of two teenage NBA hopefuls. Directed by Steve James. Rated PG-13 for profanity and drug use.   I Don't Want to Talk About It PG-13   The ``It'' in this strangely affecting Argentinian film is the physicality of the daughter of a wealthy South American widow named Dona Leonor (Luisina Brando). Her teenager, Charlotte (Alejandra Podesta), is smart, loving, well-read, an accomplished pianist and a devoted daughter. She is also vertically challenged -- or, as they used to say, a dwarf. However, Dona Leonor won't say it (she also burns copies of ``Tom Thumb'') and she won't allow her neighbors to mention it either. The movie takes an odder-still twist when a mysterious roue (Marcello Mastroianni) comes to town and falls for Charlotte. The picture benefits from its bizarre set-up, a poetically Fellini-esque finale and Brando's chilling portrayal of a manipulative, overprotective parent. But director Maria Luisa Bemberg lets things go a bit flat in the middle and it's only thanks to Mastroianni's decades of expertise and innate courtly charisma that we remain interested during the slow spots. Still, the movie deserves points for acting, tone and originality; after all, how many movies try to mix psychotic denial and magic realism in one story?  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941125.0048 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(3rdtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> I Like It Like That R   A strong debut by young African-American filmmaker Darnell Martin, who deftly guides us through the mean streets of the Bronx and the complexities of the human heart. Rated R for language, adult themes and sex.   Interview With the Vampire R   As richly textured as a dark brocade, threaded with existential dread and drenched in plasma, Neil Jordan's film will disturb more viewers than just Oprah. It's filled with snapping necks, slit throats, rats and wrists draining crimson into goblets, and other bloody bits of necro-fun. But it's likely to thrill Anne Rice fans and seduce those unfamiliar with her books. Interviewed by a San Francisco journalist (Christian Slater), reluctant vampire Louis (Brad Pitt) goes back 200 years to torchlit New Orleans, recalling his role in the ultimate dysfunctional clan: himself, sadistic Lestat (Tom Cruise) who made him a vampire; and their ``child'' Claudia (Kirsten Dunst), whose golden curls mask a fierce hunger. Lestat is driven by appetite. Louis wants answers. His quest to find others of ``our kind'' drives the film into 19th- century Paris, introducing a clique of decadent undead (including Antonio Banderas and Stephen Rea). As a screenwriter, Rice doesn't hit her points as hard as she might, especially Louis' motivations. If you're unfamiliar with the book, you might find the going slow. And here's what you've been wondering: Cruise's Lestat is a dandy dandy; he could be more frightening, but the role hasn't been stretched into a vanity star turn. Pitt provides the eloquent heart of the movie. And Dunst, older than the novel's Claudia, conveys the character's anguish at being trapped in childhood. But the film's biggest triumph is its visual design, an opulent fusion of costumes (Sandy Powell), production design (Dante Ferretti) and cinematography (Philippe Rousselot). This ``Vampire'' has bite. -- Steve Murray   It Could Happen to You PG   This sweet nothing of a film pairs Nicolas Cage and Bridget Fonda in an appealing romantic fairy tale of love and the New York lottery. The film is too slight to be a grand romance, but it's definitely a winning one. Rated PG for mild language, adult situations.   Jason's Lyric R   It starts with the promise of something invigorating and fresh. It's the story of an African-American family living outside the usual inner-city setting of gangsta flicks. But director Doug McHenry carries urban cliches with him into the suburbs: drugs, guns and a whore-madonna view of women that's not very different from a rap video. Rated R for violence, sex, language and drug use. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Lassie PG   Lassie comes home to the big screen in an engaging family film directed by Daniel Petrie. Set in rural Virginia, this savvily updated version (by ``Paper House's'' Matthew Jacob) has a lot more in common with the TV series than the novel or the 1943 movie. But even after 50 years, it's still the same old story: a boy and his wonder-dog. The boy is Matt (Thomas Guiry), an angry adolescent who resents his new stepmom (Helen Slater) almost as much as he resents his dad's (Jon Tenney) relocating the family from Baltimore to a sheep farm. The wonder-dog, of course, is Lassie who latches onto Matt when her owner is killed. Rated PG for mild violence.   The Last Seduction R   Probably the sleeper of the year. In the tradition of ``Double Indemnity'' and ``Body Heat,'' director John Dahl (``Red Rock West'') pairs a smart, sexy, no-good dame with a hunky sucker who's not half as smart as he thinks he is. Linda Fiorentino is a one-woman wrecking crew as a tough cookie with a lotta leg and even more nerve who easily gets nice-guy Peter Berg in her thrall. To reveal much more would spoil the movie's many twists, but let's just add that Bill Pullman plays one of her previous patsies and Bill Nunn is the private investigator Pullman puts on her trail. Thanks to their strong, steady work and Dahl's flashy direction, Steve Barancik's imaginative but far-fetched script gains considerable credibility. But the pivotal element here is Fiorentino whose portrayal of a master manipulator makes Sharon Stone look like a Girl Scout. Whether playing mind games or body games, she plays for keeps. Look for her name around Oscar-nomination time and go looking for this superbly entertaining picture immediately.   Little Giants PG   This time, the Bad News Bears . . . I mean, the Mighty Ducks . . . I mean . . . Let's start over. This time, a gang of lovable kiddie misfits pull together and become a heck of a Pee Wee League football team. The only discernable twist is that the Giants' coach (Rick Moranis) and the coach (Ed O'Neill) of the all- star opposing team are brothers with a long-standing rivalry. Given a fourth- down-and-long situation, director Duwayne Dunham punts for formula and lets his cast fumble along as best they can. Rated PG for mild language.   Little Rascals PG   Rent the originals. The idea of turning Hal Roach's famed ``Our Gang'' shorts into a feature for '90s audiences is a dubious one at best. And it's been done in the worst possible way. Director Penelope Spheeris has found a remarkable cast of look-alikes who seem to have been cloned from some hidden source of Little Rascals DNA. But as well-trained and well-made-up as these kids are, they are pod-Rascals -- an artful semblance of the real thing but totally devoid of freshness, naturalness or spontaneity. Rated PG for smutty language.   Love Affair PG-13   If this timeless tale of true romance worked for Charles Boyer and Irene Dunne in 1939 (``Love Affair'') and for Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr in 1957 (``An Affair to Remember''), then why shouldn't it work in 1994 for Warren Beatty and Annette Bening? Well, it does. To a point. This is a first-class effort and while it isn't quite the heartbreaker one hopes for, it still manages to jerk a few tears.   Mary Shelley's Frankenstein R   In Mary Shelley's classic 19th-century novel, medical student Victor Frankenstein learns that some things are better left to God. In this opulent, fever-pitched movie, director-star Kenneth Branagh learns that some things are better left to James Whale, the man who made the 1931 Karloff version. Not that Branagh's version is a total dud. But in its own way, it's as deliriously misguided as Shelley's mad-scientist protagonist. The problems begin with the casting of Robert De Niro as the Monster. His stitched-together mass of scar tissue may be closer to the novel than Karloff's plug-necked proletariat, but Karloff was an unknown and De Niro, well, is De Niro. Every time he appears, you think, gee, Travis Bickle's been run over by his own taxi. Also, Branagh has chosen to return to the original's Gothic-romance roots by emphasizing the relationship between Victor (Branagh) and his beloved Elizabeth (Helena Bonham Carter). That's fine as far as it goes -- and in these actors' talented hands, it goes pretty far -- but it has the effect of reducing the Monster to a bothersome interruption. Brimming with talent and dedication, the Branagh version never bores, but it never truly chills either.   The Mask PG-13   Forget the superhero plot of this live-action cartoon and focus on the Looney-Tunes special effects, the immensely likable Jim Carrey and Milo the mighty Jack Russell terrier. Directed by Chuck Russell. Rated PG-13 for mild violence.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941125.0049 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(4thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Miracle on 34th Street PG   It would be a miracle indeed if a John Hughes remake could come anywhere close to replicating the whimsical magic of the 1947 original starring Edmund Gwenn and Nathalie Wood. Alas, miracles don't happen every day and one certainly hasn't happened here. Despite a twinkly-eyed performance by Sir Richard Attenborough as The Man Who Would Be Santa and the gravelly voiced charm of little Mara Wilson as a non- believer ripe for conversion, this movie is staler than week-old fruitcake. Elizabeth Perkins plays a harried single mom who doesn't think her six-year-old daughter (Wilson) needs to believe in that ho-ho-ho stuff. Ironically, Perkins is the one who hires a mysterious gentleman named Kriss Kringle (Attenborough) to be her department store's seasonal Santa. As anyone who saw the original knows, Kringle ends up on trial, for claiming he really is Santa. Dylan McDermott is the lawyer who defends him and Robert Prosky is the judge with the hottest case this side of O.J. Though nominally directed by Les Mayfield, the film has the unmistakable Hughes imprint, meaning most of its charm is lost in the Hughesian overkill. This remake is as synthetic as a silver-foil Christmas tree. Harmless, perhaps, but hardly worth seeking out.   Natural Born Killers R Oliver Stone is a natural born moviemaker and a natural born troublemaker and this anarchic, almost surreal film shows both sides at their best. As emblematic of the disaffected, media-overload '90s as ``Bonnie and Clyde'' was of the '60s, ``Killers'' celebrates sex, violence and celebrity with a vengeance that's both visual and visceral. Mickey (Woody Harrelson) and Mallory (Juliette Lewis) are young, in love and they kill people. About 52 people before they're put in Tommy Lee Jones' jail. Rated R for extreme violence, gore, language, nudity and sexuality.   The Next Karate Kid PG   The new ``kid'' is a sullen teenaged girl named Julie, played by newcomer Hilary Swank. It's not a bad idea to show that a teen can have lips like Claudia Schiffer's and still beat the stuffing out of a bothersome guy. Noriyuki ``Pat'' Morita returns as Mr. Miyagi. Rated PG for violence.   Oleanna R   Cinematic saltpeter, it's a guaranteed date-night dampener. David Mamet's film of his off-Broadway power play can send men and women up the theater aisle, fuming for separate reasons. Charting a trio of disastrous meetings between a college professor (William H. Macy), and a student (Debra Eisenstadt) who's failing his class, the film is a paranoid reaction to the shifting sexual politics of the '90s: Patricia Bowman, Anita Hill, Tailhook, etc. We first meet Carol arriving sans appointment at John's office. The words that rain most often from her mouth are, ``I don't understand.'' But by their second encounter, she has morphed from a stammering coed to a coolly poised virago, equipped with a militantly drab wardrobe, a notably improved vocabulary, and the support of a student cabal whom she refers to as ``my group.'' The personality shift is abrupt, unexplained. Instead of a two-person, full-bodied drama, the movie turns into a symbolic standoff between an innocent man and a misogynist's nightmare. Sexless, anti-intellectual, tract-spouting, Carol becomes the sort of woman Rush Limbaugh and Camille Paglia would take turns hating. Mamet keeps the focus simple; he hardly ``opens up'' the play. And it's easy to admire the deft dialogue and the strong performances. Macy summons a natty self-satisfaction (you wouldn't mind seeing him deflated, but not crucified). Eisenstadt does as fine a job as possible with the role's limitations. In the end, Mamet comes up with Molotov cocktail that's almost too successful in making audiences see red. -- Steve Murray   Only You PG   If only Hollywood would make more movies like this fanciful Roman holiday, starring Marisa Tomei as a bride- to-be on a quixotic romantic quest in Italy and Robert Downey Jr. as a gallant suitor who may or may not be her only one. Rated PG for mild sexual themes.   The Professional R   French director Luc Besson (``La Femme Nikita'') goes American and his movie goes down the drain. Again, the stylish Frenchman dazzles us with explosions and massacres, killer babes and their world-weary mentors. But this time, the babe really is a babe -- a precocious 12-year-old (Natalie Portman) who takes up with a professional hitman (Jean Reno) after her family is wiped out by a crooked DEA agent (a hilariously hammy Gary Oldman). Initially, the bond formed between the pro and the preteen is tentative and touching; he may be the best killer in Manhattan, but his best friend is a house plant. She offers to clean house if he'll teach her to ``clean up,'' so she can avenge her family. Alas, Besson opts for a superfluous titillation factor, letting Portman walk around in budding-adolescent undershirts and do Madonna impersonations for Reno. He, in turn, stands around with his mouth hanging open, looking slightly stunned. Perhaps the most optimistic way to look at this film is as one exasperated Frenchman's attempt to circumvent the parasitical cycle of American remakes of French films. Besson probably figured that, if he'd made the film in Paris, some Hollywood producer would buy the remake rights, replace him as director and cast Clint Eastwood and one of the ``Full House'' twins.   Pulp Fiction R   Pop goes the pulp in this smashing sophomore effort by Quentin ``Reservoir Dogs'' Tarantino. Winner of the Golden Palm at Cannes and already subject to Oscar-time whispers, the picture is a gleefully lurid mix of hardboiled gangster-movie conventions and hip post-Warhol irony. It's an exceedingly violent genre flick with a twist -- everyone is in on the joke. Everyone, that is, except the characters on screen. The film consists of three expertly interwoven vignettes. The first tale centers on a couple of hit men (beautifully played by John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson) and Travolta's job babysitting his big, bad boss's (Ving Rhames) babe-licious wife (Uma Thurman). The second focuses on a boxer (Bruce Willis) who's been asked to take a dive. The third goes back to Travolta and Jackson who need Harvey Keitel's help disposing a dead body. Flashy, smart, daring and full of itself, the movie sometimes suggests ``Short Cuts'' with shootouts. Rated R for violence, language, nudity and drug use.   The Puppet Masters R   NASA scientist Dr. Mary Sefton (Julie Warner) has a unique test to determine whether a man is a full- blooded human or if he's possessed by an alien: She shows him her cleavage. This sexist device is one clue that ``The Puppet Masters'' originated as a 1951 Robert A. Heinlein novel. The premise is dated, the latest in a long line of sci-fi paranoia thrillers: Outer-space beasties leach onto human hosts and plot to overwhelm the world. Deduct points for freshness. But ``Masters'' bops with a brisk, nab-those-critters attitude. And the critters are a treat: gloppy manta rays that latch on to your back, jam a tether in your brain, and fuse with your nervous system. Like a good cigarette. -- Steve Murray   Quiz Show PG-13   Robert Redford's dazzlingly entertaining movie is set in the late '50s, when Americans were as hooked on quiz shows as later generations would be on Watergate or O.J.'s white Bronco. When the sponsor tires of ``Twenty-One's'' current wonder-boy, Herb Stempel (John Turturro), a schlemiel from Queens, he's replaced by Charles Van Doren (Ralph Fiennes), the handsome scion of an aristocratic, academic family. Van Doren becomes the nation's most adored egghead and Stempel spills the beans -- that the game is rigged -- to a congressional investigator (Rob Morrow). Rated PG-13 for adult themes.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941125.0050 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(5thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Radioland Murders PG   Just plain murder to sit through. This fiasco is the latest missive from the hermit-like George Lucas. Produced and written by Lucas and directed by Mel Smith (``The Tall Guy''), the movie means to be a farcical murder mystery set in 1939 at the art deco studios of WBN, a radio station trying to go national. Running around the overcrowded halls are a bickering husband-and-wife team (headwriter Brian Benben and executive-assistant-turned-de-facto-producer, Mary Stuart Masterson); a femme- fatale radio star (the late, very talented Anita Morris); a philandering director (Jeffrey Tambor), a no-nothing executive president (Ned Beatty) and a libidious announcer (Corbin Bernsen) . . . among others. While the show goes on (and everything falls into chaos), someone behindthe scenes is murdering the staff.   Red Rock West R   In this low-budget comic noir about greed, lust and cheatin' hearts, Nicholas Cage is a nice-guy drifter taught by the likes of Dennis Hopper and J.T. Walsh that no good deed ever goes unpunished. Directed by John Dahl. Rated R for violence, profanity and sex.   Renaissance Man PG-13   A bummer, man. Director Penny Marshall proves she can do predictable military schmaltz just as well (badly?) as the guys, with this Danny DeVito inspirational comedy that might well be subtitled ``Dead Poet's Platoon.''   Reservoir Dogs R   As in, one assumes, meaner than the junkyard variety. Quentin Tarentino's debut is an electrifyingly vicious caper flick, soaked in blood, obscenity and incongruous black humor. Most of the movie takes place immediately before and after a robbery gone terribly wrong. The ensemble cast -- headed by Harvey Keitel, Steve Buscemi, Chris Penn and Tim Roth -- is a marvel, worthy of a Mamet play (which this film's profane energy often evokes).   The River Wild PG-13   Meryl Streep is a former white-water river guide, who views a rafting excursion in her old splashing grounds as more than a family vacation. It's a chance to spend quality time and heal rifts with workaholic husband Tom (David Strathairn) and son Roarke (Joseph Mazzello). Slithering into the family's domestic Eden, Kevin Bacon is a fellow rafter who turns vacation into hell, taking the family hostage and forcing Streep to pilot him safely down the river. The actors and the scenery keep your mind off a predictable plot; this is a B-movie graced with members of the Hollywood A- list. But the trip is worth it. Rated PG-13 for violence. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   The Road to Wellville R   Paved with good intentions. Like that other road. Alan Parker's health-craze comedy is an art-design folly with little more going for it than spectacle: Edwardian clothes, Anthony Hopkins with buckteeth, and cruel spa machines Jules Verne might have forged. Playing cereal czar and health nut John Harvey Kellogg, Hopkins creates a grand, blustery caricature. Unfortunately, Parker's adaptation of T. Coraghessan Boyle's novel has flurry in place of a plot. The welter of characters include a young cornflakes entrepreneur (John Cusack); Kellogg's prodigal son George (Dana Carvey); and Will and Eleanor Lightbody (Matthew Broderick and Bridget Fonda), whose physical ills cloak deeper marital problems. Fonda comes off as a mall rat in her great-grandma's clothes. Cusack goes over the top. Broderick gamely endures a lot of enema and bowel jokes, and shows off ab muscles more gym-developed than might be credible for a man of 1907. The movie blows its opportunities to score points about our own health-conscious age. It remains undernourished and dramatically anemic. Rated R for nudity, sexual situations. -- Steve Murray   The Santa Clause PG   The movie's moral is a peculiar one, even by Hollywood standards: The best way for a father to gain his son's respect is to pack on 50 pounds, grow a white beard and consort with elves. Thus it goes with Scott Calvin (Tim Allen), a divorced dad whose 8-year-old, Charlie (Eric Lloyd), would rather spend Christmas Eve with Mom (Wendy Crewson) and her new therapist hubby (Judge Reinhold). That is, until Santa tumbles off the roof, Scott straps on St. Nick's suit, and goes across the globe popping in and out of chimneys (aided by some computer effects that aren't as special as you'd hope). Amiable Allen wisecracks his way past snarling mutts and spying moppets (``Do you want this doll or not?'' he asks one recalcitrant tot). Then, at the North Pole, he finds out from the rainbow-coalition elves that -- gulp -- once you put on Santa's suit, you're Santa. For good. From here, the movie unreels as a cross between ``Miracle on 34th Street'' and a paranoid delusion. As the new year unfolds, Scott bloats up and goes white-haired and bewhiskered. Call it Clausitis: Santa overcomes his nervous system like an incurable disease. Allen's normal-guy shtick is terrific, but once he disappears inside the fat-suit, the movie's personality goes with him. Cuteness happens, magic doesn't. And if you have kids, be prepared to tell them something the movie never explains: What the heck happened to the original Santa, who evaporates into thin air? Ho ho huh? -- Steve Murray   The Shawshank Redemption R   There are two excellent reasons to see this involving movie and their names are Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. Based on a Stephen King novella, this is a stone-walls-do-not-a-prison-make story, in which hope flourishes in horrifying surroundings and a unique friendship is forged inside a human purgatory.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941125.0053 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MINI-REVIEWS-(6thtake)-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Silent Fall R   When a prosperous couple is found brutally murdered in the bedroom of their Maryland mansion, the only witness is their 9-year-old son (Ben Faulkner). Unfortunately, the boy is also autistic, which prompts the local sheriff and the boy's protective older sister (model Liv Tyler) to bring in a once-prominent child shrink (Richard Dreyfuss), who quit treating kids after a tragedy befell a patient. While this solid suspense drama goes to great lengths to stress that autism isn't an easily understandable condition, it also uses the boy's state as a plot contrivance to get Dreyfuss involved. Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   The Specialist R   Sylvester Stallone's specialty has been to turn a one-note act into a multimillion-dollar career. But the specialist specified here is a former CIA explosives expert hired by a rich lovely (Sharon Stone) to wipe out the bad guys who killed her parents when she was just a kid. That means taking on Miami mobsters led by patriarch Rod Steiger (doing an embarrassing Jose Jimenez accent), his sleazy son (Eric Roberts) and his equally sleazy consigliere (James Woods, who used to be in the CIA with Sly until they had a falling out over innocent bystanders). At its best, the film is like ``Death Wish'' warmed-over, with hints of ``The Bodyguard.'' However, the expected sparks between Stallone and Stone never ignite.   Speed R   The perfect summer- movie rush. The gimmick is simple: A wacko (Dennis Hopper) has put a bomb on a city bus. When the bus hits 50 mph, the bomb goes on; if it slows below 50, the bomb goes off. And so the chase is on -- with a busload of terrified passengers, a hurt driver, a spunky civilian at the wheel (Sandra Bullock) and a very determined cop (Keanu Reeves) in pursuit. Directed by Jan De Bont. Rated R for violence and language.   Stargate PG-13   An engaging sci-fi yarn with a flying pyramid, three moons and Jaye Davidson in a dress. Again. We start on Earth, where a linguist named Daniel (James Spader) deciphers Egyptian hieroglyphics on a circular mechanism unearthed near the pyramids. It's the Stargate, a thingamajig that, when uncoded, becomes a portal to a twin gate on a sandy planet across the universe. Daniel gets enlisted for a space-jumping expedition, led by gruff Colonel Jack O'Neil (Kurt Russell), since he's the only one who can crack the code on that second Stargate. But first they have to face the sun god Ra, (Davidson), a cosmic vampire. Like a Tintin adventure set in the cosmos, the movie has an enjoyable retro feel. But it's harder to get revved up by it. Director Roland Emmerich turns out serviceable action scenes, but it's Spielberg minus Spielberg. Rated PG-13 for violence. -- Steve Murray   Star Trek: Generations PG   This franchise boldly keeps going and going and going. In this incarnation, the torch is smoothly passed from one cast to the next as the aging members of the orginal '60s show are replaced by the ``Next Generation'' ensemble. Captains Picard (Patrick Stewart) and Kirk (William Shatner) join forces to defeat a mad scientist ('60s bad boy, Malcolm McDowell) who's willing to destroy whole galaxies in his frantic attempt to reach the Nexus, a place of illusionary contentment. In the ``Star Trek'' tradition, ``Generations'' offers a sprinkling of high-minded metaphysical musings along with a hearty dose of high-tech gimmickry (thus, the nature of mortality and Warp 4 come up in the same conversation). Scotty (James Doohan) and Chekov (Walter Koenig) turn up briefly, but most of the story is carried by Stewart's crew (Brent Spiner, LeVar Burton, Whoopi Goldberg, Michael Dorn, etc.). As for the battle of the starship captains, Stewart is patrician and compassionate, but Shatner's Hollywood-honed hamming steals every scene. Granted, the plot is incomprehensible and the logic nil; but the filmmakers have the proper respect for its characters and for the ongoing ``Star Trek'' mythos. They understand that, under the skin, we're all Trekkies.   The Swan Princess G   It's not Disney, but it's pretty decent. An animated musical from Richard Rich, who once worked for the Mouse, ``The Swan Princess'' tells of a true love that overcomes all obstacles. Prince Derek and Princess Odette, heirs to separate kingdoms, are brought together every summer by their parents, who hope the children's scrappy friendship will someday blossom into love. Nicely, ``Princess'' shows Derek and Odette mutually trying to find each other -- this isn't a damsel-in- distress scenario. The movie's pleasures come through amusing supporting characters (a turtle and frog, with voices by Steven Wright and John Cleese), some adult-friendly humor and songs propelled by clever lyrics that touch on everything from true love to political correctness. Though the animation varies between TV stiffness and Disney opulence, ``The Swan Princess'' is a pleasant holiday surprise that takes wing more often than not. -- Steve Murray, staff writer   Terminal Velocity PG-13   A free fall into silliness, this sky-diving thriller plays like Hitchcock Lite. It's preposterous. And a lot of fun. Charlie Sheen stars as Arizona sky diver Ditch Brodie whose latest student, a blond airhead named Chris (Nastassja Kinski), takes an early tumble out the plane door, and makes like a pancake. Then again, is that really her body on the desert floor? Rated PG-13 for violence, language.   Timecop R   A good rule of thumb: the less sense a Jean-Claude Van Damme movie makes, the more fun it is. Happily, this futuristic actioner is a welcome return to the sci-fi silliness of his most successful film to date, ``Universal Soldier.'' Van Damme plays a time-traveling cop who tries to stop a corrupt senator from changing history. Rated R for violence, language, brief sex and nudity.   Trial By Jury R   Jury tampering takes on a whole new dimension in this solid thriller- melodrama that replaces 12 angry men with one very angry woman. Juror Joanne Whalley-Kilmer doesn't start out mad; she feels jury duty is part of truth, justice and the American Way. However, when she's chosen by prosecutor Gabriel Byrne to sit in judgment on a smoothie mobster (Armande Assante), she learns otherwise. Rated R for violence, language and adult themes.   True Lies R   True trash. Too long, too loud and too expensive, this action farce is a pointless exercise in abuse of power, Hollywood-style. Starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Jamie Lee Curtis. Directed by James Cameron. Rated R for violence and language.   The War PG-13 A big-hearted bore from the maker of ``Fried Green Tomatoes.'' Director Jon Avnet returns to the South of a few years past, in this case small-town Mississippi, 1970. (It was mostly shot in Georgia.) Kevin Costner plays Stephen Simmons, a vet trying to hold a job while haunted by memories of 'Nam. We see him through the eyes of his kids, Stu (Elijah Wood) and Lidia (Lexi Randall), who spend the summer months building a treehouse -- and trying to avoid the white-trash Lipnicki clan. Unlike the plot-driven ``Tomatoes,'' ``War'' ambles with the humid sleepiness of one of its summer days. Somebody's always a-sittin' on a porch, talkin' about love and family and duty and dreams. Late in the movie, when a turf battle turns the kids' treehouse into an obvious anti-war allegory, you might have already tuned out due to the platitudes and melodrama. -- Steve Murray   Wes Craven's New Nightmare R   Wes Craven reclaims Freddy Krueger in this postmodern, Pirandellan funhouse of a movie -- a ``Player'' for the slasher set. When the execs at New Line (the actual makers of this movie) ask original ``Elm Street'' heroine Heather Langenkamp (as Herself) to reprise her role for the ``definitive `Nightmare,' '' she has doubts: She's been having these bad Freddy nightmares. So has her son (Miko Hughes, the scalpel baby from ``Pet Sematary''). Seems that the malevolent force behind the Krueger movies -- the real Freddy -- wants to cross into Real Life. Fun premise. Robert Englund, John Saxon and Craven pop up as Themselves. And it's nice to see Krueger returned to the roots of the first film -- a pre-wisecrack, hellish fiend. Rated R for gore, language. -- Steve Murray .  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941125.0054 type=story > <HEADLINE> : BUMPER '94 CORN HARVEST </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> RANDALL, Iowa  (BC-CORN-CORNUCOPIA-ART-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199411.gz"

She is Elizabeth McCaughey, the Republican lieutenant governor-elect of New York; he is Wilbur Ross Jr., an investment banker who has been a fund-raiser and financial contributor to Democratic campaigns.   Ms. McCaughey, 46, an academic from the Manhattan Institute think tank, earned a spot on the ticket last November for her published attacks on the Clinton health care plan.   Ross, 55, senior managing director with Rothschild Inc., has a spot of his own, on President Clinton's Fund for Large Enterprises in Russia.   The two became engaged discreetly a couple of weeks ago when she gave him a birthday party at La Cote Basque. ``It was a small gathering and Wilbur was swept away, I think, by the wonderful party she threw for him,'' said Lisa Linden, a spokeswoman for Ms. McCaughey (the name is pronounced McCoy).   The official engagement party is set for Feb. 8 -- exactly one year after their first date. ``It will be a big bash,'' Ms. Linden said, ``with all their friends and family.''   The first marriages of both Ms. McCaughey and Ross ended in divorce. No date has been set for the wedding, but the couple said it would take place sometime next year. Since she has three children enrolled in schools in Manhattan, Ms. McCaughey, known as Betsy, plans to divide her time between New York and Albany after she is sworn in.   Asked if Ms. McCaughey planned to keep her name after the marriage, Ross said he did not know, but he rather thought so.   Otherwise, she'd be Betsy Ross.   NEW YORK -- Catherine Dickens will be in the Winter Garden at the World Financial Center this weekend, contemplating Christmas past. Really past. The one of 151 years ago, when her great-great-great grandfather Charles Dickens wrote ``A Christmas Carol.''   She won't be cooking a prize goose, but she and her parents, Christopher Charles Dickens and Jeanne-Marie Dickens, who live in England, will be signing and selling paperback copies of the book.   Proceeds of the sale will go to New York Downtown Hospital's pediatric division, she said.   The family will wax Dickensian in the indoor garden Saturday and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. They will also discuss the Charles Dickens Heritage Foundation, which was founded three years ago by Jeanne-Marie Dickens, a Hungarian countess by birth.   The foundation is supported by the sale of American-made Dickensiana. There's a replica of a Dickens desk and a ceramic village with electrified Pickwickian inns and such. One-third of the royalties from the sales will go to the foundation, the family said.   When not keeping Christmas, Catherine Dickens manages a small hotel in the British Virgin Islands with her husband, Jonathan Charles Dickens.   ``Before we got married,'' she recalled, ``I said, `Jon, you'll have to take my name.'   He looked up from his Heineken and said, `Sure, OK.' ''  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941216.0322 type=story > <DATELINE>  (BC-COMPANIES-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199412.gz"

"10866"	"I"	"think"	" -- ``Cooking for Good Health,'' edited by Jean Rogers, editor of ``Prevention'' Magazine Health Books (Rodale Press, $27.95). ``Prevention'' magazine cookbooks are always good. This one, I think, is perhaps the best. It is set up in the most practical style I've seen in cookbooks. It is, I think, the way all cookbooks should be done. On each left-hand page is a brief description of a dish and a full-color photograph. On the facing, right-hand page is the recipe and additional ``Chef's Notes,'' as well as the ``Nutrition at a Glance'' column. The book includes easy-to-understand symbols that indicate the recipe is low-cholesterol, low-calorie or low-salt. There are guides in the back of the book to help you with selecting just the right spices, berries, cheeses, greens and oils. I can't imagine having just one cookbook, but if I had to throw everything else out, I would consider keeping this one. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199412.gz"

By Steven Erlanger.   YUGOSLAVIA-BOSNIA (Belgrade) -- Bomb kills two in Sarajevo market; The day's developments. By Roger Cohen.   ITALY-RESIGN (Rome) -- Brought low by rebellion within his own coalition, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi resigns after 226 turbulent days in office. By Alan Cowell.   NEWT-BOOK (Washington) -- Reaction to Newt Gingrich's acceptance of a reported $4 million book advance from Rupert Murdoch's media empire.   ARBITRATE (Washington) -- Reversing what had been a trend in federal courts, a California appeals court rules that workers may not be forced to submit discrimination and sexual harassment claims against their employers to binding arbitration unless the employee knowingly waives a claim to a jury trial. By Stephen Holmes.   KING-MUSEUM (Atlanta, Ga.) -- The family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is feuding with the National Parks Service over the Atlanta sites that are linked with his memory.   KOREA-PILOT (Brookville, Fla.) -- Neighbors and friends of captured helicopter pilot await his return from North Korea.   NY-EXPLOSION (New York) -- Unemployed computer expert arrested in subway firebomb. By John Kifner.   OFFICE-PARTIES (Undated) -- The office party as prom night, and social test. By Trip Gabriel. PESO (Mexico City) -- The peso floats; Washington steps in with credit line. By Anthony DePalma.   PESO-NAFTA (Washington) -- What are the implications for the trade pact from the big currency shift between the U.S. and Mexico. BAT-ANTITRUST (Undated) -- The Federal Trade Commission has dropped its charges of anti-trust violations against BAT Industries, reaching an out-of-court settlement that will permit the London-based tobacco giant's $1-billion acquisition of the American Tobacco Company.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19941222.0166 type=multi > <DATELINE> MOSCOW (NYT)  (BC-WORLD-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Russian bombing raids intensified Thursday over Grozny, the capital of the breakaway Chechen republic, as signs of strong dissent continued to emerge from within the Russian military command.   At least 24 people were reported to have died Thursday in Grozny as bombs and shells hit apartment blocks and strategic targets like the Lenin oil refinery, causing panic in the streets.   Some missiles and bombs, the first heavy daylight air attacks on Grozny, hit crowds of people who were working to clear away the debris from nighttime bombing.   Russian officials said the intense bombing raids over Grozny would continue through the night as a prelude to ``resolute steps'' to try to end what has become a full-blown military and political crisis in Moscow.   BETHLEHEM (NYT) -- It was supposed to be a different Christmas season here this year, brimming with the spirit of peace and hopes for the expansion of Palestinian autonomy to the entire West Bank.   But preparations in this town of 50,000 seem joyless during this holiday season, the first since the start of Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho.   The Israeli army still controls security and access to the Manger Square and the Church of the Nativity, venerated as the site of Jesus's birth. The thousands of pilgrims attending Christmas Eve services here will see little change this year aside from the Palestinian flags added to decorations put up by the municipality. The red, green, black and white banners, once outlawed by Israel, were hoisted this week above city hall.   TOKYO (NYT) -- In what could be another step toward reducing its isolation, North Korea announced Thursday that it is planning to allow commercial airlines from other countries to fly over its territory and land at its airports.   The government controlled Korean Central News Agency said that North Korea would offer ``the facilities and services for appropriate airline operation without discrimination'' to foreign aircraft. It said North Korea in particular wants to establish an air route linking Tokyo and Beijing through Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.   Analysts said the move could improve North Korea's international economic relations, but cautioned that it is unclear how far the Communist nation is willing to go.   ROME -- Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi resigned Thursday in the face of a revolt within his ruling alliance, leaving the country in deep confusion only seven months after he took office promising a new era of stability and prosperity.   Italians facing confusion, possible elections and the near-certainty that, whatever their next government, it will not survive for long.   Berlusconi handed his resignation to President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, who, in turn ''reserved judgement'' on whether to accept it - a formality designed to allow Berlusconi to stay on as caretaker while the president seeks a way out of the impasse.   UNITED NATIONS (NYT) -- About to be stripped of their military protection as the Somalia peacekeeping operation winds down, the international relief agencies working in the country appealed Thursday for $70.3 million in emergency funds to keep Somalis from slipping back into starvation and disease, for at least the next six months.   ``The U.N. agencies are committed to remaining in Somalia during and after the withdrawal of Unosom,'' Peter Hansen, under secretary general for Humanitarian Affairs, told reporters Thursday, referring to the U.N. mission.   But he acknowledged that there were no guarantees that relief and rehabilitation work will be able to continue in all parts of the country and warned that increased fighting was possible. He said that the U.N. agencies -- denied international police support or aircraft for evacuation by the Security Council -- were planning for the worst.   TOKYO (NYT) -- Japan's electronics industry, creeping back from a long slump, registered an increase in production in 1994 for the first time in three years, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said Thursday.   The gain resulted from a slight improvement in demand for electronics products in Japan, but mainly from strong shipments to the United States and Asia of computer chips and flat panel displays to be made into personal computers and other products.   But production of consumer electronics equipment in Japan fell by nearly 9.7 percent in 1994 as Japanese companies shifted their manufacturing of television sets, video recorders and stereo systems to countries with lower wages, in part to escape the effects of the strong Japanese yen.   MEXICO CITY (NYT) -- On Wall Street and other financial capitals, they told a wonderful tale called ``The Mexico Story:'' Closed, quasi-socialist economy is thrown open by bold, Ivy-trained technocrats. Nationalists embrace privatization and free trade. Investment pours in, inflation is vanquished, democracy takes root. Billionaires proliferate; the poor look up.   Then, in what seemed an instant, the story changed.   After the government's announcement Wednesday night that it would abandon its defense of the peso and let the currency trade freely against the dollar, Mexicans awoke to a country that most of them had consigned to a dark past. It is a place of surging inflation, recession and myriad uncertainties.   The sudden collapse is in fact neither so sudden nor so complete. In the longer run, investors with stakes in Mexico were quick to point out, the economy will have a more solid foundation if the peso can now be wrestled down to a more stable, if weaker level.   WASHINGTON (NYT) -- , Dec. 22 -- With North Korea having released the body of one American pilot, the White House Thursday voiced regret that his heliocpter crossed into North Korea and urged that country to release a second pilot who survived the crash.   ``I think certainly he regrets the incident,'' the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said of the surviving pilot. ``It was unnecessary, I think, in our view. Because I think the process of making something that hasn't been there before, or trying to reform something that has, has got to get much worse, otherwise you can't figure out how to put it together.''   -- Media mogul   For the traveler to whom a vacation without a best friend seems unthinkable, the San Ysidro Ranch in Montecito, Calif., offers its Privileged Pet Program, which has accommodated dogs, cats, birds and other portable fauna.   The human guests occupying one of the resort's $475-a-day freestanding cottages -- where JFK and Jackie honeymooned -- may be accompanied by a pet for an extra fee of $45. What's in it for the dog?:   -- The animal's name (along with its master's) will be burned into a wooden plaque that hangs outside the cottage.   -- Upon arrival, a gift basket of peanut butter dog biscuits awaits.   -- A foam bed shaped like a steak is provided.   -- A personalized bowl has been filled with squeaky toys, cookies and rawhide chews.   -- The room service pet menu includes dog biscuits and entrees ranging from canned Alpo ($3.95 per serving) to ground sirloin ($6.50) to New York steak ($17). Calorie-conscious dogs may choose Science Diet ($4.25).   -- Off-premises day care is available, at extra cost. Arrangements may be made to taxi the dog to the sitter.   P.S. More on the four-legged: Mirabella says the trendiest way to get away from it all is agricultural. The line forms behind the barn for ``the exurbanite fantasy of the moment,'' six-month apprenticeships at Barnum-Goodfriend goat farms in New York's Catskill Mountains.   The lucky apprentice gets a room, meals, a little pin money and on-the-job lessons in milking, breeding, cheese-making and financial planning.  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950221.0349 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-LEAH-PERSONALS-SFCHRON) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Tossing aside those lawyer and health care advocate labels, the first lady told U.S. News &AMP; World Report this week that at heart, she's a husband-centric cookie-baking wifey.   ``My first responsibility, I think, is to do whatever my husband would want me to do that he thinks would be helpful to him. "16123"	"we"	"think"	" The more difficult question in this case is whether the Curtiss-Wright reservation clause contains a ``procedure for amending (the) plan.'' To recall, the reservation clause says in effect that the plan may be amended ``by the Company.'' Curtiss-Wright is correct, we think, that this states an amendment procedure and one that, like the identification procedure, is more substantial than might first appear. It says the plan may be amended by a unilateral company decision to amend, and only by such a decision and not, for example, by the unilateral decision of a third-party trustee or upon the approval of the union. Moreover, to the extent that this procedure is the barest of procedures, that is because the CurtissWright plan is the simplest of plans: a voluntarily maintained single-employer health plan that is administered by the employer and funded by the employer. More complicated plans, such as multiemployer plans, may have more complicated amendment procedures, and s402(b)(3) was designed to cover them as well. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199503.gz"

"19883"	"I"	"think"	" But there is other indication, of the most weighty sort: the widespread and longstanding traditions of our people. Principles of liberty fundamental enough to have been embodied within constitutional guarantees are not readily erased from the Nation's consciousness. A governmental practice that has become general throughout the United States, and particularly one that has the validation of long, accepted usage, bears a strong presumption of constitutionality. And that is what we have before us here. Section 3599.09(A) was enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Ohio almost 80 years ago. See Act of May 27, 1915, 1915 Ohio Leg. Acts 350. Even at the time of its adoption, there was nothing unique or extraordinary about it. The earliest statute of this sort was adopted by Massachusetts in 1890, little more than 20 years after the Fourteenth Amendment was ratified. No less than 24 States had similar laws by the end of World War I, (footnote 1) and today every State of the Union except California has one, (footnote 2) as does the District of Columbia, see D. C. Code Ann. s1-1420 (1992), and as does the Federal Government where advertising relating to candidates for federal office is concerned, see 2 U. S. C. s441d(a). Such a universal (footnote 3) and long established American legislative practice must be given precedence, I think, over historical and academic speculation regarding a restriction that assuredly does not go to the heart of free speech. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199504.gz"

"24467"	"I"	"think"	" Time and time again the feathered world went out of its way to welcome us as friends and confidants. A tiny goldfinch hopped onto Jessie's front steps to show us, I think, how a baby bird discovers it can fly. Chickadees built nests in the eaves above our back porch so that whenever I went outside, I heard the song of hungry baby birds. A cardinal startled me one morning by flinging herself against the window of my living room, over and over and over again. Another time, I was astounded to come across a large gull wing in perfect condition on the beach. I took it as a gift from the goddess and added a black-tipped 15-inch feather to our collection. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"

By Josh Barbanel. (Scheduled to move by 8 p.m. ET in ``a'' news file.)  BOTTOM  NY-NUCLEAR-STING (New York) _ Three businessmen from Queens and Long Island, in collusion with a Russian general, smuggled seven metric tons of nuclear material from a military stockpile in Ukraine, stored most of it in a warehouse in Queens and conspired to sell it to Iraq, U.S. Customs Service officials say. The businessmen were arrested after a year-long sting operation in which customs agents posed as Iraqi foreign ministry officials and European arms dealers planning to buy zirconium, a material used in nuclear reactors. By Pam Belluck. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``a'' news file.)  MANTLE-LIVER (Dallas) _ Surgeons replace Mickey Mantle's liver, ravaged by cancer, hepatitis and decades of heavy drinking, in a bid to save his life. As Mantle's health deteriorated, with organ failure spreading from his liver to his kidneys, a liver donor was suddenly found overnight. By Allen R. Myerson. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``a'' and ``s'' news files.)  With graphic. By Robert Pear. (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in ``w'' news file.) Times News Service  For FRIDAY PMs  Here are the top news stories from The New York Times News Service for PMs of Friday, June 9.  The PMs news desk, 212-556-1927, opens at 7 a.m. Eastern Time. To get story repeats before this hour call 212-621-1595 for reruns on AP DataFeatures or 214-980-8305 or 8367 for repeats on UPI DataNews.  INTERNATIONAL _ (Moved in ``i'' category)  YUGOSLAVIA-PILOT-PROFILE _ Capt. Scott F. O'Grady: By all accounts, the 29-year-old pilot is a tough, resilient man, modest and unassuming _ an ideal companion, except in a car. ``Scott has a need for speed, I think,'' his sister, Stacey, said. In a day full of talk about answered prayers and old-fashioned, manly virtues, the most telling remark about O'Grady's survival may have been uttered by Adm. Leighton Smith, commander of NATO forces in Southern Europe: ``He maintained his cool,'' Smith said. By David Stout.  RUSSIAN-BELLY-DANCERS (Cairo) _ Egyptian belly dancers, condemned by Islamic militants as licentious and scorned by the general public as disreputable, face a new onslaught from Russian rivals, who have invaded the nightclubs that line the road to the pyramids and crowd the banks of the Nile. By Chris Hedges.  GERMANY-STUDENTS (Bonn, Germany) _ In the tranquillity of the Konrad Adenauer High School, no one has to fret about the kinds of things that worry Americans on campus, like guns or drugs, because such things do not happen here, said Heinz Wilms, a history teacher. Since January, though, he has been nudging his 10th-grade class of 16-year-olds to confront something much more momentous than school-yard discipline: the historical progression from Hitler's rise to power in 1933 to the Holocaust. By Alan Cowell.  (ART ADV: Photo [NYT17) of students in Bad Godesberg has been sent to NYT photo clients.)  NATIONAL _ GENERAL (Moved in ``a'' category)  HARTFORD-SCHOOLS (Hartford, Conn.) _ A private education company that gained national attention after signing a contract last year to manage this city's entire troubled public school system now expects to concentrate on just five of the system's 32 schools this fall. By Kirk Johnson.  HARVARD-COMMENCE (Cambridge, Mass.) _ At the end of an annus horribilis, the reassuring routines of commencement, including John Kenneth Galbraith's afternoon party, the 25th and 50th reunions and the stream of notables. A National Journal by Fox Butterfield.  (ART ADV: Photo [NYT15) of celebrating Harvard graduates has been sent to NYT photo clients.)  OKLA-BOMB-TIGAR-LAW (Undated) _ Over the last three decades, Michael E. Tigar, a law professor in Austin, Texas, has represented many of the most vilified of criminal defendants. So his assignment last month to represent Terry L. Nichols, one of two men accused of blowing up the Federal Building in Oklahoma, is hardly novel. A profile of a lawyer who says that the measure of the American legal system is how it treats society's pariahs. By Stephen Labaton.  (ART ADV: Photo [NYT13) of Michael Tigar has been sent to NYT photo clients.)  DELLINGER-LAW (Washington) _ Walter Dellinger, an assistant attorney general and the head of the Office of Legal Counsel, has the optimal job for a former constitutional law professor: It combines pontificating on legal issues _ not in the academy but at the top levels of government. By Neil A. Lewis.  WASHINGTON _ (Moved in ``w'' category)  WELFARE-CHAFEE (Washington) _ John Chafee, a moderate Republican, finds himself between a rock and a hard place as his party plans to slash social welfare spending. By Robin Toner.  (ART ADV: Photo [NYT12) of Sen. John Chafee has been sent to NYT photo clients.)  BUSINESS DAY _ (Moved in ``f'' category)  INSIDER-MARKETPLACE (New York) _ The daily Market Place colum: The frenzy of merger deals on Wall Street is looking like old times in more ways than one. Securities regulators say they are opening investigations into insider trading at a pace not seen since the 1980s. By Susan Antilla.  (ART ADV: Chart to illustrate story has been sent to NYT graphics clients.)  BULL-MARKET-ASSESS (New York) _ Economic Analysis: This year's bull market has actually added more than twice as much to the wealth of America's households as all the money families painstakingly salted away in savings last year. So now that signs of an economic slowdown are multiplying, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan is acknowledging the possibility of a brief downturn this summer, and anxiety is starting to well up, shouldn't all that freshly minted wealth help make the economy safe from recession? By Sylvia Nasar.  (ART ADV: Two charts to illustrate story have been sent to NYT graphics clients.)  NETWORKS-ADS-MEDIA (New York) _ Don't be surprised if the next broadcast network television executive you see is sporting a goofy grin and chanting an old cigarette slogan: ``It's what's upfront that counts.'' The four broadcast networks are booking a record-breaking amount of advance sales of commercial time for the 1995-96 season. By Stuart Elliott.  (ART ADV: Chart to illustrate story has been sent to NYT graphics clients.) Rosenthal on the indictment of 3 former federal prosecutors on drug charges. "24763"	"I"	"think"	" Vinogradov said that the Kirov corps dancers received $70 a month, with principals earning $150. ``So it's only natural that people are living only on what they manage to earn on tour,'' he said. ``In addition, many of the companies have fallen apart and many artists have gone to the West. The most important thing, and the most complicated thing, is what is missing right now in our economy and our country. We have no discipline. Or law. And what we're trying to create in our company right now is exactly those things. Discipline, law and fairness.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950611.0116 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-LEAH-PERSONALS-SFCHRON) </DATELINE> <TEXT> (Eds: This story also moved in the ``l'' lifestyle category) By LEAH GARCHIK c.1995 San Francisco Chronicle  EVERY GESTURE HAS A MEANING  In his new book, ``Bodytalk,'' behavioral scientist Desmond Morris has cataloged and analyzed more than 600 gestures from all over the world. Applying Morris' scholarship to the gestures of three would-be Republican presidential nominees:  _ Pete Wilson's Thumb Up means ``Long Live the Basques!''  This, writes Morris, is ``the emblem of the Basque Separatist Movement,'' and if Wilson were in Spain, he would be in serious trouble.  _ Phil Gramm's Hands (Creating a Certain Aperture) gesture is a sexual insult in Neapolitan Italy.  Gramm's gesture, in Morris' description, describes the size of the part to which the gesture refers.  _ Bob Dole's stylish rendition of the Forefinger Suck signifies regret.  ``This is a relic gesture,'' writes Morris, ``in which the finger-sucker reverts momentarily to the childhood comfort of oral contact. It is, in effect, an adult version of thumb-sucking.''  SECURITY ADVISER SQUEALS WITH JOY  White House National Security Adviser Anthony Lake told Newsweek that he was so excited last week when he learned of the rescue of fighter pilot Scott O'Grady in Bosnia that he just couldn't contain the news.  After learning that the mission had been successful, said Lake, he left the White House to drive home, stopping at a 7-Eleven at 2:30 a.m. to buy a few celebratory cupcakes.  A policemen pouring himself a cup of coffee was an irresistible confidante. ``Can I tell you something that no one else in the world knows?'' asked Lake.  The cop looked up at him. ``You know that pilot that was shot down over Bosnia?''  ``Yeah?'' said the cop.  ``We just got him home,'' said Lake, on his way out of the store. ``Who are you?'' asked the cop. ``I just work for the government,'' said Lake.  STEVE YOUNG HAS PROBLEMS  When posed the question, ``What is your greatest fashion challenge?'' Steve Young, 49er quarterback, Most Valuable Player of the Super Bowl and Macy's poster boy, was reflective:  ``I think,'' he said, ``to me, people expect now that I'll be able to put some kind of ensemble together _ things that go together, things that make sense. ... The problem now is that as I try to get into nicer suits I ask, `Does this really go?' And I have the confidence that, you know what, I think, but I'm not sure.''  BRYANT GUMBEL ON HIS COLLEAGUES AND HIMSELF  ``Today'' show host Bryant Gumbel tells TV Guide this week that he thinks CBS was right to fire Connie Chung from her job as co-anchor of the ``CBS Evening News.''  ``I'm a big Dan Rather fan,'' said Gumbel. ``It's a better program with him alone. He's the one with credibility.''  Gumbel took a slap at critics who have said he has a big ego. ``I find it odd,'' he said, ``that the charge is never leveled at Ted Koppel or Peter Jennings or anybody else in the business. At that point, you have to start to wonder, why is it only coming at me.''  He went on to speculate. ``I think for a lot of people it's race. To suggest there's no racial aspects to judgment about me is naive. ... There are a lot of people who are uncomfortable with the idea of a black man being their intellectual or economic or social equal or superior.'' </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950611.0117 type=story > <HEADLINE> IBM'S LOTUS ACQUISITION SEEN AS FIRST SHOT IN WAR ON MICROSOFT </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> Armonk, New York, June 11 (Bloomberg) (BC-IBM-MICROSOFT-AIM-BLOOM) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"
"24870"	"we"	"think"	" As Judge Friendly observed, the Declaratory Judgment Act ``does not speak,'' on its face, to the question whether discretion to entertain declaratory judgment actions is vested in district courts alone or in the entire judicial system. Friendly, Indiscretion about Discretion, 31 Emory L. J. 747, 778 (1982). The Court of Appeals reviewed the District Court's decision to stay London Underwriters' action for abuse of discretion, and found none. London Underwriters urge us to follow those other Courts of Appeals that review decisions to grant (or to refrain from granting) declaratory relief de novo. See, e. g., Genentech, Inc. v. Eli Lilly &AMP; Co., 998 F. 2d, at 936; Cincinnati Ins. Co. v. Holbrook, 867 F. 2d, at 1333. We decline this invitation. We believe it more consistent with the statute to vest district courts with discretion in the first instance, because facts bearing on the usefulness of the declaratory judgment remedy, and the fitness of the case for resolution, are peculiarly within their grasp. Cf. First Options of Chicago, Inc. v. Kaplan, 514 U. S. ---, --- (1995) (slip op., at 10) (``(T)he reviewing attitude that a court of appeals takes toward a district court decision should depend upon `the respective institutional advantages of trial and appellate courts''') (citation omitted); Miller v. Fenton, 474 U. S. 104, 114 (1985) (``(T)he fact/law distinction at times has turned on a determination that, as a matter of the sound administration of justice, one judicial actor is better positioned than another to decide the issue in question''). Whileit may be true that sound administration of the Declaratory Judgment Act calls for the exercise of ``judicial discretion, hardened by experience into rule,'' Borchard, Declaratory Judgments, at 293, proper application of the abuse of discretion standard on appellate review can, we think, provide appropriate guidance to district courts. In this regard, we reject London Underwriters' suggestion, Brief for Petitioners 14, that review for abuse of discretion ``is tantamount to no review'' at all. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"
"24892"	"I"	"think"	" ``The main theme, I think, is that persons with high quadriplegia (high-up spinal injuries) are active, involved people who are satisfied with their existence and happy to be alive,'' said Gale Whiteneck, director of research for Craig Hospital in Colorado. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"
"24921"	"I"	"think"	" ``Retail real estate values are measurably better than just 12 months ago,'' said Daniel O'Conn </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950612.0579 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-LEAH-PERSONALS-SFCHRON) </DATELINE> <TEXT> (Eds: This story also moved in the ``a'' national news file) By LEAH GARCHIK c.1995 San Francisco Chronicle  EVERY GESTURE HAS A MEANING  In his new book, ``Bodytalk,'' behavioral scientist Desmond Morris has cataloged and analyzed more than 600 gestures from all over the world. Gramm's gesture, in Morris' description, describes the size of the part to which the gesture refers.  _ Bob Dole's stylish rendition of the Forefinger Suck signifies regret.  ``This is a relic gesture,'' writes Morris, ``in which the finger-sucker reverts momentarily to the childhood comfort of oral contact. It is, in effect, an adult version of thumb-sucking.'' It was, I think, by all that I read last week, a healthy price for the company, highly valued. What I told all the employees is that IBM had just paid all of them a nice compliment by paying $3.5 billion for what they have built. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"
