(EDITORS: This material is NOT available to clients in Canada except to The Toronto Globe &AMP; Mail.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950620.0162 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-SYLVESTER-STALLONE-JUDGE-DREDD-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> SYLVESTER STALLONE HAS SEEN THE FUTURE _ AND IT'S VIOLENT (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Sylvester Stallone as Judge Dredd. By CINDY PEARLMAN Distributed by New York Times Special Features  Sylvester Stallone likes to call himself the Hiroshima of love.  ``When I fall in love, it is always a big catastrophic explosion. No one is left standing,'' he says. ``My private life is almost a theatrical event. And it's not a comedy.''  It's 9 a.m. at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Marina Del Rey, Calif., and Stallone _ the man who played Rambo and Rocky _ has decided to show his vulnerable side. As he discusses his recent breakup with his fiance, model Angie Everhardt, Sly is wearing his heart on his well-muscled sleeve.  ``I tend to live life to the fullest,'' Stallone says, putting on his dark Ray-Ban sunglasses in the dimly lit hotel ballroom where he has come to do interviews for his newest film, ``Judge Dredd.''  ``I believe in that `Mame' song, `Life is a banquet. Live it every day.' I will spare you and not sing. ...  ``I live life too hard, with too much muscle and gusto. I tend to accelerate things. Everything is real fast with me. Relationships go much faster than they should. Sometimes they burn out much faster than they should.''  Is that what happened to his relationship with Everhardt?  ``Angie's a wonderful girl. I think she will go far,'' Stallone says. ``Some of the best-laid plans just don't work out. My motto is, `If it feels right, you give it a shot. If it doesn't, no regrets. You still did it.'  ``My biggest fear is waking up someday and thinking, `I didn't do it.'''  He won't ever have to think that about ``Judge Dredd,'' the futuristic action film based on the popular British comic-book series. Stallone knew right away that he wanted to play the title character, a helmeted lawman who is sort of a cop, a judge and a jury rolled into one.  ``I like to do things that are larger than life,'' he says. ``With this movie, I knew I wouldn't have to play it normal.''  Stallone, a ``big believer'' in the authority of the law, says he liked the fact that his character has the power to dispense instant justice _ or punishment.  ``We're heading toward a much more accelerated process of law,'' he says. ``In fact, I hope punishment is much more intensified in the future. I'm sick of these prolonged appeals year after year. If you're caught red-handed you should just go away.''  Sometimes Stallone would like to go away himself _ away from all the media attention and hype, that is. He says the reporters who chronicle his comings and goings make it impossible for him to live a normal life. He can't even go to the grocery store without being monitored.  ``Every move I make is under a microscope. My life is examined. If my collar is up, the tabloids write, `He's a pig.' The next guy could be standing there naked and it's no big deal.''  It's this sort of scrutiny and reporting, Stallone says, that has made it hard for him to trust members of the opposite sex.  ``People know everything about me. I know nothing about them. I am at the distinct disadvantage,'' he explains.  ``I need the time to get to know women. But then again, do I walk around for my entire life skeptical or do I give women the benefit of the doubt until proven unworthy or guilty?''  And just where does Stallone meet these women? It's not like he can just go to a bar to pick up dates. Or can he?  ``I do go to nightclubs and Planet Hollywood openings,'' Stallone says, referring to the restaurant chain of which he is a part-owner.  ``The women who have the nerve to come over and talk to me are usually so drunk that you can't understand what they're saying. And the other women are afraid to cross over that little barrier and talk to me.''  Stallone did manage to establish a relationship with Everhardt. The two had dated for just a few months when they announced their engagement this spring. Then, in mid-June, they broke it off with no explanation.  It's the latest in a series of failed romances for Stallone. His past includes a divorce from his first wife, Sasha, a brief, rocky marriage to Brigitte Nielsen and a long relationship with model Jennifer Flavin.  Part of the problem, Stallone says, is that it's hard to be his significant other.  ``My dates are scrutinized. That's the really unfair part.''  So when he begins a relationship with a woman, he makes sure she is prepared for what's ahead.  ``I tell them up front, `If you have any skeletons in your life, the tabloids will find them. They will tear your life apart. They will go after your teachers and your old boyfriends. They got all of my past already.'''  Stallone's personal history has been told over and over.  ``I'm like bleached bones out there,'' he says, laughing.  Yes, it's been a long, strange trip since he began writing the script for the first ``Rocky'' movie almost 20 years ago. At the time, he was an unemployed actor living in New York City.  ``I sat down to write Rocky on December 5, 1975,'' Stallone recalls. ``Now I look back and everything seems real quick.  ``But I don't look back in too much anger. Whatever mistakes I've made there seemed to be a reason for it at the time. Now to be here 20 years later and, I think, doing better than ever ... I'm a very lucky man.''  His career has had its ups (the ``Rocky'' films, the ``Rambo'' series, 1993's ``Cliffhanger'') and its downs (1984's ``Rhinestone,'' 1991's ``Oscar'' and other attempts at comedy).  Now he has a new policy about films.  ``I'm sticking to action,'' he says. ``I've learned all you get from stretching is stretch marks.''  Does he still have the eye of the tiger?  ``It's still there. I'm more hungry now than ever. I believe in chasing time. Time moves fast, so you must move fast.''  When he is reminded that his 50th birthday is approaching, Stallone groans. Loudly. And with fury.  ``That definitely bothers me,'' he says. ``You sit there and go, `Oh man. This is it. We're definitely heading into the home stretch here. This is not a rehearsal.'  ``Now I'm living in what I like to call a `controlled spinout.' It's a racing term. It means that you just slide into the future and try not to be too out of control.''  To regain some stability, Stallone moved from Hollywood to Miami, where he tries to live a quiet life in between Planet Hollywood openings and making movies.  In Florida, no one judges him, he says.  ``I think it's an exotic place. I blend in.''  He recently left Miami, however, to join Antonio Banderas and director Richard Donner on the set of ``Assassins'' in Seattle. It's another action film, with Stallone playing a trained killer.  This will certainly provide more fodder for the debate about violence in movies. What is Stallone's position on this issue?  ``I think there is a responsibility there, but I don't agree with (Bob) Dole's comments,'' he says. ``You should allow any film to be made. Sure, some junk will get in there. But it's about freedom.''  Stallone knows all about freedom _ especially freedom of expression. He is reminded of this when he's shown a copy of the 1993 Vanity Fair magazine for which he chose to pose nude.  ``Gee, I wish you didn't show me that,'' he moans as he looks at his incredibly muscular body in the photos. ``That's a lot of work.''  Looking lean and taut in beige pants and a wheat-colored sweater, Stallone says he still works out four and a half days a week. He rises at 5 a.m. and heads straight for his home gym.  But it's not always easy.  ``Some days I get out of bed and think, `Oh man, do I have to work out?' Actually, I think this all the time.''  What does going the distance mean for Stallone these days?  ``It's getting out of bed without my knees cracking. I believe in that Nike ad, `There is no finish line.'''  When it comes to his professional life, he seems to know no boundaries. He says he's thinking of bringing ``Rocky'' to Broadway as a musical.  And as far as his love life goes, there's no finish line there either. He says he really, really wants to get married again someday.  ``Oh yeah, definitely. But I'm very happy right now.''  Above all, Stallone says, he is a hopeless romantic.  ``It beats the alternative. I'd hate to be a hopeless cynic.'' c.1995 Cindy Pearlman  (Cindy Pearlman is a Chicago-based free-lance writer.) ------------------------------------------------- (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950620.0163 type=story > <HEADLINE> LONE-WOLF CLINTON: I AM A ROCK, I AM AN ISLAND </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-DYSFUNCTIONAL-DEMOCRATS-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"

"25838"	"we"	"think"	" But this argument, we think, fails in the face of the statutory language itself. The term ``such interception'' is part of the intent requirement in the second clause; the defendant must intend to obstruct the interception made pursuant to the application or authorization of which he has the knowledge required by the first clause. The phrase ``possible interception'' is found in the third clause, which describes the act which offends the statute. A defendant intending to disclose the existence of a pending application would ordinarily have no way of knowing whether the application or authorization had resulted in an interception, and that is doubtless why the third clause uses the term ``possible'' interception. It was not intended to limit the offense to cases where the interception based upon the application or authorization was factually possible, but to recognize the fact that at the time the prohibited notice was given it very likely could not be known whether or not there would be an interception. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"
"25841"	"I"	"think"	" The Court apparently adds to its ``natural and probable effect'' requirement the requirement that the defendant know of that natural and probable effect. See ante, at 6 (``(I)f the defendant lacks knowledge that his actions are likely to affect the judicial proceeding, he lacks the requisite intent to obstruct''). Separate proof of such knowledge is not, I think, required for the orthodox use of the ``natural and probable effect'' rule discussed in Pettibone: Where the defendant intentionally commits a wrongful act that in fact has the ``natural and probable consequence'' of obstructing justice, ``the unintended wrong may derive its character from the wrong that was intended.'' 148 U. S., at 207. Or, as we would put the point in modern times, the jury is entitled to presume that a person intends the natural and probable consequences of his acts. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"
"25843"	"they"	"think"	" The jumbled rock containing pterosaur bones scattered every which way, they think, was deposited by a giant flash flood that roared through the valley. Perhaps a landslide had dammed a river, Bell speculates, and then suddenly the dam burst. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"

"26400"	"we"	"think"	" As to the efficacy of this means for addressing the problem: It seems to us self-evident that a drug problem largely fueled by the ``role model'' effect of athletes' drug use, and of particular danger to athletes, is effectively addressed by making sure that athletes do not use drugs. Respondents argue that a ``less intrusive means to the same end'' was available, namely, ``drug testing on suspicion of drug use.'' Brief for Respondents 45-46. We have repeatedly refused to declare that only the ``least intrusive'' search practicable can be reasonable under the Fourth Amendment. Skinner, supra, at 629, n. 9 (collecting cases). Respondents' alternative entails substantial difficulties if it is indeed practicable at all. It may be impracticable, for one thing, simply because the parents who are willing to accept random drug testing for athletes are not willing to accept accusatory drug testing for all students, which transforms the process into a badge of shame. Respondents' proposal brings the risk that teachers will impose testing arbitrarily upon troublesome but not drug-likely students. It generates the expense of defending lawsuits that charge such arbitrary imposition, or that simply demand greater process before accusatory drug testing is imposed. And not least of all, it adds to the ever-expanding diversionary duties of schoolteachers the new function of spotting and bringing to account drug abuse, a task for which they are ill prepared, and which is not readily compatible with their vocation. Cf. Skinner, supra, at 628 (quoting 50 Fed. Reg. 31526 (1985)) (a drug impaired individual ``will seldom display any outward `signs detectable by the lay person or, in many cases, even the physician.'''); Goss, 419 U. S., at 594 (Powell, J., dissenting) (``There is an ongoing relationship, one in which the teacher must occupy many roles educator, adviser, friend, and, at times, parentsubstitute. It is rarely adversary in nature . . .'') (footnote omitted). In many respects, we think, testing based on ``suspicion'' of drug use would not be better, but worse. (footnote 3) </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"
"26405"	"we"	"think"	" As to the efficacy of this means for addressing the problem: It seems to us self-evident that a drug problem largely fueled by the ``role model'' effect of athletes' drug use, and of particular danger to athletes, is effectively addressed by making sure that athletes do not use drugs. Respondents argue that a ``less intrusive means to the same end'' was available, namely, ``drug testing on suspicion of drug use.'' Brief for Respondents 45-46. We have repeatedly refused to declare that only the ``least intrusive'' search practicable can be reasonable under the Fourth Amendment. Skinner, supra, at 629, n. 9 (collecting cases). Respondents' alternative entails substantial difficulties if it is indeed practicable at all. It may be impracticable, for one thing, simply because the parents who are willing to accept random drug testing for athletes are not willing to accept accusatory drug testing for all students, which transforms the process into a badge of shame. Respondents' proposal brings the risk that teachers will impose testing arbitrarily upon troublesome but not drug-likely students. It generates the expense of defending lawsuits that charge such arbitrary imposition, or that simply demand greater process before accusatory drug testing is imposed. And not least of all, it adds to the ever-expanding diversionary duties of schoolteachers the new function of spotting and bringing to account drug abuse, a task for which they are ill prepared, and which is not readily compatible with their vocation. Cf. Skinner, supra, at 628 (quoting 50 Fed. Reg. 31526 (1985)) (a drug impaired individual ``will seldom display any outward `signs detectable by the lay person or, in many cases, even the physician.'''); Goss, 419 U. S., at 594 (Powell, J., dissenting) (``There is an ongoing relationship, one in which the teacher must occupy many roles educator, adviser, friend, and, at times, parentsubstitute. It is rarely adversary in nature . . .'') (footnote omitted). In many respects, we think, testing based on ``suspicion'' of drug use would not be better, but worse. (footnote 3) </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"

The commissioner knows he could not get the team owners to vote for expansion right now. The owners are more concerned about franchises jumping all over the place and want to see how it all unfolds before even thinking about adding two more teams. The Seahawks, for example, are working behind the scenes to slip into Los Angeles, which has always been a pro football bust-out. After the Raiders and Rams both bailed, broadcaster Pat Haden, a former Ram, probably put it best: ``It's not a cultural loss in Los Angeles. There isn't a passion, I think, for the hometown team, because this isn't a lot of people's hometown. I don't think most people are terribly concerned. It's nice to have a team, but there isn't the passion for athletics here that there is in a lot of towns.'' Pro football, especially ... INTERNATIONAL (i)  NAGASAKI-PROTEST (Nagasaki, Japan) _ Anger abounds at ceremony commemorating the 50th anniversary of the dropping of the second atomic bomb. By Charles Radin. 900 wors.  SERBS-EXODUS (Glina, Croatia) _ On road from Zagreb toward Serbia, 35,000 rebel Serb refugees are jeered, booed, spat at by Croats. By Elizabeth Neuffer.  WASHINGTON (w)  WHITEWATER-NUSSBAUM (Washington) _ Former White House counsel Bernard Nussbaum says his handling of the search of Vincent Foster's office balanced the interests of the president and the police. By John A. Farrell.  NATIONAL (a)  HEROIN-TREND (New York) _ More people are using heroin, which has become cheaper, for recreational use, and some, including a New York stockbroker, are dying. Officials fear a trend. By Fred Kaplan.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e)  GARCIA-OBIT (Undated) _ Jerry Garcia, Grateful Dead guitarist, dies at 53 at a drug treatment center in California, apparently of a heart attack. By Steve Morse. (a and e coding)  w/  DEAD-FUTURE (Undated) _ Jerry Garcia's legacy and the Dead's future. By Matthew Gilbert.  FINANCIAL (f)  NETSCAPE-IPO (Undated) _ Initial investors in Netscape Communications, with about $17 million in sales this year, drive up its stock price to 2 1/2 times higher than its offering price, valuing the company at an astounding $3.5 billion. By Beppi Crosariol. 1000 words.  w/  NETSCAPE-TRADING (Undated) _ Chances are that no one you know made money on Netscape's wild first day of trading. Underwriters typically leave the best IPOs to their best customers. By Charles Jaffe. 500 words.  AMERICANMED-AMBULANCE (Undated) _ American Medical Response, the leading ambulance service provider, will acquire Ambulance Systems of America in a bid to create a $100 million nationwide company. By Alex Pham. 700 words.  SPORTS (s)  BBA-REDSOX (Boston) _ Cleveland Indians at Boston Red Sox. By Nick Cafardo.  BKN-NBA (Undated) _ The NBA agreement came in the nick of time. By Peter May.  FBN-PATRIOTS (Smithfield, R.I.) _ With rookie Curtis Martis, the Patriots may resurrect the trap play. By Ron Borges.  FBC-BCSEASON (Newton, Mass.) _ This year's BC football players have high expectations _ and a higher standard. Just ask Justice Smith. By Frank Dell'Apa. Aug. 9 (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor. Contribute to NYLite and get a NYT rolling-writer style pen.)  DAVID-LETTERMAN LATE SHOW TOP TEN  ''Items on the Westinghouse `To Do' List''  10. Learn difference between a network and a hole in the ground.  9. Review pay package of TV host David Letterman.  8. Rehire Connie Chung to sell toasters door-to-door.  7. Lead story on every CBS newscast: ``Westinghouse appliances still dependable and affordably priced!''  6. Six words: ``Dr. Quinn Totally Nude Medicine Woman.''  5. Find out who the hell this ``Johnny Carwash'' is.  4. Have Anna Nicole Smith keep marrying rival network executives until they're all dead.  3. See if Westinghouse engineers can fix Fran Drescher's voice.  2. Assemble all employees for a huge party followed by massive layoffs.  1. ``The Late Show with Dick Assman.''  QUOTABLES FROM AMERICA'S TALKING  ``The secret to all of my success last fall was that I suddenly unleashed all of my blinding charisma.''  _California Governor Pete Wilson jokes about how he won the election to his current office, on the America's Talking program ``Straight Forward with Roger Ailes.''  ``Let's start building prisons in the Alaskan Tundra. When I send your butt to jail, you're going to jail. Do your time!''  _Talk show host Montel Williams tells how he would carry out prison reform if he were president, on ``Straight Forward With Roger Ailes.''  AU REVOIR, `SEEKER OF THE FRENCH SOUL' By BILL TAMMEUS A famous retired Harvard professor, of whom, I sadly admit, I had never even heard, died the other day.  I suppose it was not unexpected. Laurence Wylie was, after all, 85 years old, having lived a full and charming existence, according to The New York Times, which keeps pretty fair track of famous retired Harvard professors.  So what struck me wasn't Wylie's actual demise but the wonderful headline on the obituary. It called Wylie ``Seeker of the French Soul.''  Ah, my friends, what a glorious _ if ultimately frustrating _ vocation. It did, of course, make me wonder why you never see a ``Seeker of National Souls'' booth at high school career days, but I have been around long enough to know that you shouldn't tell high school kids everything.  I was so taken with the ``Seeker of the French Soul'' appellation that I am now driven to suggest we live our lives in such a way that, on our passing, newspapers (assuming they themselves aren't all dead by then) will place similarly engaging epitaphs over our obituaries.  It will be hard to top the delicious feel of ``Seeker of the French Soul,'' probably, but surely we can give it a go. (Where, by the way, does one seek for the French soul? In ((blank))? There will be a $5 reward for the best French soul joke or pun. In case of a tie, the judge will keep the dough.)  For instance, wouldn't you love to know someone of whom it could be written, ``Cornerer of the Marketplace of Ideas''? I do not know anyone at the moment to whom such a grandiloquent title could be accurately applied, but I would like to know such a person, if only to see how his or her children are putting up with this condition.  I also would like to know about (though maybe not know personally) people whose obituaries could carry these headlines: ``Titillater of the Greek Libido,'' ``Launcher of New Eras,'' ``Dancer with Wolves,'' ``Keeper of Cosmic Secrets,'' ``Ponderer of Brazilian Mysteries,'' ``E-Mailer to the Cheesemakers'' and ``Sailor of the Brain's Waves.''  The problem, I think, is that our vision of our roles in the ultimate scheme of things is so pinched. We talk about self-esteem and complain that politicians and Hollywood stars (to say nothing of heavyweight journalists) are loaded with ego. But when we think of ourselves, we almost never imagine a memorable phrase of cosmic proportions by which we'd like to be remembered.  Quite simply, we lack vision. And without vision, the people perish. Or, in the alternative, as Laurence Wylie might have said, they go to Paris.  Wylie himself, from what I can tell, did not spend a lifetime in Paris. Indeed, he was born in Indianapolis, which may not be as far from Paris, culturally, as you can get but in Indianapolis the left bank has drive-up windows. And after getting degrees from such non-French places as Brown University and the University of Pennsylvania, Wylie wound up at Harvard for 21 years.  Yet somehow he was able to construct his life so that no less a chronicler of human foibles and achievements than The New York Times was willing to call him ``Seeker of the French Soul.'' Bravo! I say, and I say it because I can't think of the French equivalent for Bravo! right now, despite my having made it through an advanced French reading class in college (no more about that later).  My point is that each of us, Walter Mitty-like (or Laurence Wylie-like), is capable of imagining a life for ourselves that would cause us, at the moment of our departure, to be hailed effusively as, say, ``Launderer of the Canadian Underwear.'' And wouldn't that make our mothers proud?  (Bill Tammeus is a columnist for The Kansas City Star. This article was distributed by The New York Times News Service.)  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) (BC-MIDWEST-COMMODITIES-KAN) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199508.gz"
"30684"	"I"	"think"	" The volume in the Kansas City wheat pit was estimated at 25.6 million bushels. In wheat options, 132 lots traded. In the Kansas City Value Line, about 125 contracts traded. In the Mini Value Line, about 200 contracts traded. In Western Natural Gas, about 800 contracts traded. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950809.0446 type=other > <DATELINE>  (BC-NYLITE(SMILE)-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> c.1995 N.Y. AU REVOIR, `SEEKER OF THE FRENCH SOUL' By BILL TAMMEUS A famous retired Harvard professor, of whom, I sadly admit, I had never even heard, died the other day.  I suppose it was not unexpected. Laurence Wylie was, after all, 85 years old, having lived a full and charming existence, according to The New York Times, which keeps pretty fair track of famous retired Harvard professors.  So what struck me wasn't Wylie's actual demise but the wonderful headline on the obituary. It called Wylie ``Seeker of the French Soul.''  Ah, my friends, what a glorious _ if ultimately frustrating _ vocation. It did, of course, make me wonder why you never see a ``Seeker of National Souls'' booth at high school career days, but I have been around long enough to know that you shouldn't tell high school kids everything.  I was so taken with the ``Seeker of the French Soul'' appellation that I am now driven to suggest we live our lives in such a way that, on our passing, newspapers (assuming they themselves aren't all dead by then) will place similarly engaging epitaphs over our obituaries.  It will be hard to top the delicious feel of ``Seeker of the French Soul,'' probably, but surely we can give it a go. (Where, by the way, does one seek for the French soul? In ((blank))? There will be a $5 reward for the best French soul joke or pun. In case of a tie, the judge will keep the dough.)  For instance, wouldn't you love to know someone of whom it could be written, ``Cornerer of the Marketplace of Ideas''? I do not know anyone at the moment to whom such a grandiloquent title could be accurately applied, but I would like to know such a person, if only to see how his or her children are putting up with this condition.  I also would like to know about (though maybe not know personally) people whose obituaries could carry these headlines: ``Titillater of the Greek Libido,'' ``Launcher of New Eras,'' ``Dancer with Wolves,'' ``Keeper of Cosmic Secrets,'' ``Ponderer of Brazilian Mysteries,'' ``E-Mailer to the Cheesemakers'' and ``Sailor of the Brain's Waves.''  The problem, I think, is that our vision of our roles in the ultimate scheme of things is so pinched. We talk about self-esteem and complain that politicians and Hollywood stars (to say nothing of heavyweight journalists) are loaded with ego. But when we think of ourselves, we almost never imagine a memorable phrase of cosmic proportions by which we'd like to be remembered.  Quite simply, we lack vision. And without vision, the people perish. Or, in the alternative, as Laurence Wylie might have said, they go to Paris.  Wylie himself, from what I can tell, did not spend a lifetime in Paris. Indeed, he was born in Indianapolis, which may not be as far from Paris, culturally, as you can get but in Indianapolis the left bank has drive-up windows. And after getting degrees from such non-French places as Brown University and the University of Pennsylvania, Wylie wound up at Harvard for 21 years.  Yet somehow he was able to construct his life so that no less a chronicler of human foibles and achievements than The New York Times was willing to call him ``Seeker of the French Soul.'' Bravo! I say, and I say it because I can't think of the French equivalent for Bravo! right now, despite my having made it through an advanced French reading class in college (no more about that later).  My point is that each of us, Walter Mitty-like (or Laurence Wylie-like), is capable of imagining a life for ourselves that would cause us, at the moment of our departure, to be hailed effusively as, say, ``Launderer of the Canadian Underwear.'' And wouldn't that make our mothers proud?  (Bill Tammeus is a columnist for The Kansas City Star. This article was distributed by The New York Times News Service.)  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!! DAVID-LETTERMAN LATE SHOW TOP TEN  ''Items on the Westinghouse `To Do' List''  10. Learn difference between a network and a hole in the ground.  9. Review pay package of TV host David Letterman.  8. Rehire Connie Chung to sell toasters door-to-door.  7. Lead story on every CBS newscast: ``Westinghouse appliances still dependable and affordably priced!''  6. Six words: ``Dr. Quinn Totally Nude Medicine Woman.''  5. Find out who the hell this ``Johnny Carwash'' is.  4. Have Anna Nicole Smith keep marrying rival network executives until they're all dead.  3. See if Westinghouse engineers can fix Fran Drescher's voice.  2. Assemble all employees for a huge party followed by massive layoffs.  1. ``The Late Show with Dick Assman.''  QUOTABLES FROM AMERICA'S TALKING  ``The secret to all of my success last fall was that I suddenly unleashed all of my blinding charisma.''  _California Governor Pete Wilson jokes about how he won the election to his current office, on the America's Talking program ``Straight Forward with Roger Ailes.''  ``Let's start building prisons in the Alaskan Tundra. When I send your butt to jail, you're going to jail. Do your time!''  _Talk show host Montel Williams tells how he would carry out prison reform if he were president, on ``Straight Forward With Roger Ailes.'' "30795"	"I"	"think"	" This may not be a cure, but it's the only way you can try to get them back down and stay down. The tiles are tongued and grooved, so they are locked in place. Ideally, all tiles should be taken up and relaid with new adhesive. But instead, try this: draw a utility knife straight down a seam between two rows of tile; this will cut the tongue so you can lift that row of tiles. The whole row may lift up intact, if you're lucky. Then try to lift the other buckled rows to expose the concrete floor, which is covered with a black mastic. This mastic is a tar emulsion, which holds the tiles in place by staying sticky; it never dries out, or shouldn't. Your mastic has dried out, I think, so scrape it off the concrete and apply more mastic (sold at tile and building supply stores), as thin as practicable, press the tiles back in place and hope for the best. If you can't get the tar emulsion mastic, use any tile mastic and it should work. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199508.gz"

Unless otherwise noted, they are for use at any time.  Stories are moving in category shown at end of each budget item.  Entertainment/Lifestyle  GOURMET _ For a cool Labor Day celebration Beverlie Rabinow has a do-ahead, expandable buffet menu that can grow if the guest list expands. Early preparations revolve around a chilled smoked or canned salmon mousse that can be accompanied by a vegetable mold, orzo salad, cheese dilly bread, mandel bread and cherry tarts. To expand this menu, add one or more of the following: chilled shrimp, sliced roast beef or fillet at room temperature, a garnish of asparagus wrapped in prosciutto for the vegetable salad mold, a fruit platter, a bowl of large green and black olives marinated in French dressing and-or a batch of chocolate madeleines. (Harwood).  BRUNSWICK-STEW _ ATLANTA _ In one of those North vs. South food conversations, the question arose about how Northern food differs from Southern food. Someone asserted that one of the big distinctions was that Southerners are not inclined to mix food together, cook it in a casserole and serve as a one-dish meal. ``Macaroni and cheese is as close as we come to those tuna-noodle dishes you all cook up North,'' said one woman. If I hadn't been so busy wrinkling my nose at the thought of tuna-noodle, I would have offered Brunswick stew as an example of a Southern mixture that satisfies as a meal, wholly. And, with the summer's last holiday just around the weekend, the stew, which complements barbecue and benefits from having it as an ingredient, will be filling a lot of bowls and bellies one more time. (May, Two Takes).  RIDES _ Fear is good _ when you want it and especially when you pay for it. Case in point: Orlando. Theme park mecca. Home to Walt Disney World, Disney-MGM Studios and Universal Studios Florida. Orlando offers attractions aplenty for folks who desire dread. So in a sort of Academy Awards for Anxiety, we went on a hunt for manufactured horror. Here are the winners and the number of screams they rated. (Grantham).  MAGIC-BUS _ Now, if you have not heard of the Friz and have never been inside Arnold's stomach, this will be meaningless. But if you're with me on this one, here's a Magic School Bus secret: On the last page of every book, the world's kookiest science teacher wears a dress that hints at the next book's topic. Take the newest edition of the Magic School Bus series, written by Joanna Cole and illustrated by Bruce Degan. On the final page of ``The Magic School Bus Inside a Hurricane'' (Scholastic Inc., $14.95), Ms. Frizzle is wearing a dress decorated with bees. Heck, there are even bees on her shoes. The next book, due out next year: ``The Magic School Bus Inside a Beehive.'' (Minor).  WILSON _ Brian Wilson's music was made for these times. If only the man behind the music was as durable. In the disposable world of pop music, Beach Boys songs such as ``Good Vibrations,'' ``In My Room,'' ``California Girls'' and ``Caroline, No'' are as fresh today as when Wilson created them 30 years ago. The documentary ``Brian Wilson: I Just Wasn't Made For These Times'' attempts to answer the question: Why is Wilson considered a musical genius on a level with Duke Ellington and George Gershwin by many of his peers? For all his genius, Wilson, 53, seems on good days extremely fragile, contradictory and vulnerable in this 72-minute documentary directed by Grammy award-winning record producer Don Was (Bonnie Raitt, Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan). (Lomartire).  LEWIS _ NEW YORK _ These days, Jerry Lewis is shuttling between heaven and hell. He's either a devil or an angel _ the havoc-wreaking hellion Applegate of the musical ``Damn Yankees'' or the Muscular Dystrophy telethonmeister who has raised hundreds of millions of dollars over the past 40 years. Earlier this month, he closed up the revival of the Washington Senators-meet-the-devil baseball musical that he kept running on Broadway, virtually single-handedly, since February. Off with the horns, on with the halo. Since then, Lewis has concentrated on the Labor Day Telethon, getting himself ready for the 20 1-2-hour fund-raising institution to be carried by nearly 200 stations in the United States and Canada. (Erstein, Two Takes).  National  TICKETS _ LAWTEY, Fla. _ The men in blue in this north Florida hamlet take the first three letters of their town's name seriously. Very seriously. Don't mess with the law in Lawtey _ or nearby Hampton or Waldo, either _ unless you want to find yourself at the business end of a gun. A radar gun. The three towns dotting U.S. 301 between Jacksonville and Gainesville have been singled out by the American Automobile Association as ``traffic traps'' _ the first time in seven years AAA has meted out the designation. The association is warning its 37 million members to detour around the towns _ or take the pedal off the metal if they decide to drive down 301. Between April and July of this year, officers in the three towns have written nearly 5,000 speeding tickets. (Williams).  ABORTION-DRUGS _ ATLANTA _ Two drugs already approved for use in the United States may be as effective as the controversial RU-486 for inducing an abortion without surgery, a study suggests. The drugs, methotrexate and misoprostol, administered within five to seven days of each other, caused abortions in 171 of 178 women treated at a New York hospital. Methotrexate is an approved cancer treatment, and misoprostol is an ulcer drug. RU-486, widely available in Europe for more than 10 years, is undergoing testing in the United States as a step toward possible approval by the Food and Drug Administration. Abortion opponents have threatened to boycott any U.S. company that manufactures or distributes it. (Husted).  Sports  OLY-SPORTS _ ATLANTA _ Part of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution's weekly Olympic report is a roundup, comprising a page of copy, on developments in each Olympic sport in 1996. It moves Friday mornings and is slugged OLY-SPORTS. We're trying to gauge interest papers have in running this. If you're picking this up, or plan to, please call Paul Foutch at 404-526- 5429. Mac-generated sigs are available. (Seven Takes).  OLY-BRIEFS _ News briefs on matters related to the upcoming 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution staff).  OLY-ARTS _ ATLANTA _ ``On Translation'' by the Barcelona-born, New York-based artist Antonio Muntadas, next June 7-Aug. 4 at the Atlanta College of Art Gallery, will be an interactive multimedia installation created for and keying to the Olympics. The installation ``promises to shed new light on our notions of public access, cross-cultural conversation and the very nature of mass experience at `international events,' '' said Annette Carlozzi, the Olympiad visual arts producer. The piece, which is still being conceived, will include six ``education stations'' showing nonstop video, a ``translator's booth'' and audio. The Atlanta International Museum of Art and Design will mount ``Ways of Welcoming: Greeting Rituals From Around the World,'' May 24-Nov. 8. (Pousner).  OLY-ROUGHTON-COLUMN _ ATLANTA _ Like a hapless nomadic tribe that keeps camping in the path of civilization, the homeless can't seem to stay out of the way of the Olympics. Having ceded their old turf in Atlanta's downtown Woodruff Park and the blocks of old buildings that have been leveled for the new Centennial Olympic Park, many of them have taken refuge in the stoops and alleys of the elegant old buildings in the city's long-forlorn Fairlie-Poplar District. It's clearly the most life the ``Heart of Downtown'' has seen in years, even if it consists mostly of thin, raggedy men hanging on corners raving and/or drinking from brown lunchbags. But now even the sidewalks in Fairlie-Poplar are filling with remodelers' trucks. The squeeze is on again. (Roughton).  OLY-RENT _ ATLANTA _ Despite highly publicized accounts of local renters getting gouged for the Olympics, hundreds more are likely to pocket some extra cash by subleasing their apartments. Atlanta's biggest landlords are making Olympic sublease plans optional for their residents. Most tenants are staying put for the Games, but some tenants, usually just a handful per complex, are taking them up on the deal. With most of the major apartment companies promising their vacant units to the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games' private lodging operation, Private Housing 1996, neither the landlords nor the tenants are going to get rich. (Turner).  OLY-TAXIS _ ATLANTA _ In Germany, they drive Mercedes Benzes. In Finland, their cars are equipped to take credit cards. And in England, cabdrivers never get lost because they complete two years of training before they're allowed behind the wheel. And each country can bet its reputation that the taxis are immaculate. So what will Atlanta cab drivers be remembered for after they chauffeur the world during the Olympics? It won't be credit card machines, because many local taxis don't have them. ``I think people are going to be very upset with the (lack of) cleanliness and the lack of knowledge of the city,'' said Anne Hansen, executive director of the Georgia Council for International Visitors and a critic of local hacks. (Hill).  OLY-TICKETS _ ATLANTA _ More than 326,000 people across America have ordered tickets to the Atlanta Games, far exceeding Olympic organizers' expectations and breaking all records previously set by the 1984 Los Angeles Games. ``We're delighted with the results,'' Scott Anderson, ticket chief for the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, said Thursday. He should be. With orders averaging $1,100 for 17 tickets each, ACOG collected a whopping $358 million. It won't be keeping all of it, of course. Some will have to be refunded once ticket confirmations go out this month and folks find out what they've won _ and lost _ in the ticket lottery. The committee is budgeting $290 million from ticket sales. (Turner).  OLY-MARATHON _ ATLANTA _ Many marathon runners and experts say the Olympic race in the dead of an Atlanta summer could become a trek through hell. That's just what Manuela Machado wants to hear. Jot down the Portuguese woman as an early favorite. With her solid victory at the World Championships last month, run in mid-80s temperatures and under sunny Swedish skies, Machado furthered her reputation as someone who can deal with warm weather. ``I like very much to run in a hot climate,'' Machado said through an interpreter. ``It is more difficult to run in humidity, but I have already done it in the Barcelona Olympics. (Fish).  OLY-TRAFFIC _ ATLANTA _ In the heart of downtown Atlanta, these are the times that try one's soles. When Olympic visitors breeze into town next year, city officials promise that traffic-choked intersections like Peachtree Street and International Boulevard will be pedestrian-friendly corridors with wider sidewalks, new street lights and sheltering trees. But since last week, downtown has been a place only a shoemaker could love. It's a sprawling war zone of hard hats and construction machinery where casualties are measured in scuffed loafers, broken heels and lost patience. The sidewalks have been transformed into minefields of bright orange netting, wobbly plywood planks and muddy gravel that has office worker Bernard Rolax hopping mad. (Harris).  OLY-DIVE _ ATLANTA _ Kent Ferguson was 11 when he bounced from the trampoline to the diving board. He was 29 when he made the Olympic diving team. Now, at 32, he is an elder statesman in a sport usually dominated by younger athletes. He will lead the U.S. contingent into the IX Diving World Cup, the year's biggest meet, beginning Tuesday at the Georgia Tech Aquatic Center. Ferguson earned a spot on the World Cup squad by defeating a slew of younger men on the 3-meter springboard at the U.S. Championships in August. And if he realizes his dream of winning an Olympic medal next year, he would be the oldest U.S. diver in memory to do so. (Walston).  Commentary  MINTER-COLUMN _ The Georgia-Auburn football rivalry, oldest in the South at the age of 103, remains much as it began. A game between friends. When Dr. Charles Herty introduced football to Athens and the South in 1892, he needed an opponent. He called on Auburn professor Dr. George Petrie, an old friend and classmate from Johns Hopkins University, who got a team together and brought it to Atlanta, where the game was played for 10 years before moving to Macon, Montgomery and Savannah. When a Georgia fan says he, or she, pulls for Georgia Tech except when Tech plays Georgia, that person is either a liar or not a real Georgia fan. The same is true of Auburn fans in regard to Alabama. Most Georgia fans, I think, like to see Auburn win, except when Auburn is the opponent. I suspect Auburn fans feel the same way about Georgia. (Minter).  MINTER-COLUMN _ Unlike many of my chauvinist friends I was disappointed to see Shannon Faulkner's Citadel career come to such an early and ignominious end. I'm all for women in the military. Women shouldn't be denied the right to bear arms and fight for their country if that's what they want to do. The truth is misguided males, having read too many stories about chivalrous knights in shining armor, have allowed women to shirk their duties for far too long. I was pleased when our womenfolk decided to shoulder their share of responsibility for the national defense. I've never had any particular desire to sleep on the ground in rain and cold, wade snake-infested rivers and run five miles before a breakfast of whatever on a shingle. I'm generally not anxious to shoot at people and specifically not anxious to be shot at. (Minter).  For questions and resends, contact:  Andrew Alexander, 202-887-8334.  Matt Vita, 202-887-8309. The Boston Globe </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19951017.0436 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-SPOT-BUDGET-COX COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Cox News Service budget for Wednesday, Oct. 18, 1995.  OKINAWA-LIFE _ KIN, Japan _ For the 27,000 men and women posted here for the U.S. armed services, life on sun-washed Okinawa is a contrasting mix of grueling combat exercises and spectacular recreational opportunities. (Deans 1130). MOVED.  WASHINGTON  SCHOOL-BREAKFAST _ WASHINGTON _ The Food Research and Action Center holds a news conference to release national and state participation numbers in the School Breakfast Program, which serves nutritious morning meals to children who are unable to eat breakfast at home. State-by-state figures are included, with Georgia and Florida receiving relatively high marks. (Shaffer).  SUGAR _ WASHINGTON _ American Sugar Farmers holds a news conference to announce a campaign against the Hershey candy firm discuss the recent actions taken by opponents of federal sugar subsidies. The AMS, which represents both sugar cane and sugar beet growers, will release ``specific examples of misleading information'' on U.S. sugar policy. (Dart). MOVED.  DOLE-POWELL _ WASHINGTON _ If Colin Powell decides to run for president, the retired general's popularity will begin to plummet the moment he declares his candidacy, Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole predicted Tuesday. ``He'll discover, I think, you're the most popular in politics the day you get in and the day you get out,'' the Kansas Republican said. ``It's one thing on a book tour, it's something else going out to the Iowa caucuses one by one or stumping across Ohio.'' (Price). MOVED.  DOLE-GAYS _ WASHINGTON _ Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole said Tuesday that his campaign finance officials should not have rejected a $1,000 contribution from an organization of homosexual Republicans. But the declaration did not mend his fences with the organization, the Log Cabin Democrats. ``We have to question Mr. Dole's sincerity,'' said David Greer, the organization's public affairs director. (Price).  For more information, call:  Night News Editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316.  News Editor Art Dalglish 202-887-8338.  Deputy Bureau Chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334.  Foreign Editor Matt Vita, 202-887-8309. (White also has information on subscribing to Ivor Davis' in-depth and revealing ``Hollywood Stars'' column regularly.) (1,200 words) World rights except Boston, Great Britain and Australia. Color slides of the Beatles in 1964 and 1969 available. B&AMP;W photos of the Beatles in the 1960s and on the set of ``A Hard Day's Night'' also available. By IVOR DAVIS Distributed by New York Times Special Features  Hollywood-based journalist Ivor Davis was one of the handful of reporters assigned to travel with the Beatles during their 1964 American tour. This fascinating, funny backstage memoir is packed with behind-the-scenes anecdotes, including John's encounter with gossip writer Hedda Hopper, George's battle with a photographer at a Los Angeles nightclub and the band's ``summit meeting'' with Elvis Presley. Also included: an interview with former Beatles press officer Derek Taylor and a report on ABC's ``The Beatles Anthology'' miniseries, which airs Nov. l9, 22 and 23. Times News Service  No. 1727 Fri., Nov. 10 (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor. Contribute to NYLite and get a NYT rolling-writer style pen.)  ROLE MODEL OF THE WEEK  Dick Bell, coach of Cardinal Gibbons High in Raleigh, N.C., whose team scored 100 points against the Eastern North Carolina School for the Deaf. Said Bell: ``Once we got to 70, I said `what the heck, let's go for 100!''  _Sports Illustrated.  AND SPEAKING OF CHARACTER ...  O.J. Simpson told The Associated Press that people have supported rather than shunned him since his acquittal, and that he has learned that fame and wealth are illusions: ``The only thing that endures is character.''  VETERANS DAY  ``I always thought it was so artisctic the way the Army makes their fatigues and their food the same color.  _Joey Adams  DAVID LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Least Popular Stripper Names''  10. Ginger Vitis.  9. Stripper Gore.  8. Mrs. Charlie Sheen.  7. Stanley Cupps.  6. Lois the Letterman Look-A-Like.  5. H. Rose Perot.  4. Sue Dafed.  3. Yogi Bare-Ass.  2. Nude Gingrich.  1. Tammy Lasorda.  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  There's now serious talk of a government shutdown in the federal budget fight. Who'd run such an outfit? The Cabinot?  The Postal Service plans to issue 93 new stamps in 1996, it's reported. But as far as we know no ``O.J. Trial Commemorative'' is in the works.  There are about 1.7 million more births than deaths each year in the U.S., new figures show. You've got to feel good about the future of a country in which baby showers outnumber funerals.  Officials expect the U.S. population to grow to 392 million by 2050. Or 391,999,999 if we don't make it to age 105.  A new survey shows most Americans say they're too busy to eat three square meals a day. We may have to go from just fast to fantastically fleet food.  If our national forests are properly preserved, says Mr. Clinton, they can ``promise future generations continued benefits.'' Knock on wood.  ``We have tried to give the American people a more modern government,'' the president says. It's worked. When this administration began, our IRS forms said 1993. Now they say 1995.  A new poll shows 63 percent of Americans would support creation of a new political party. The other 37 percent probably would, too _ as long as they didn't have to bring the bean dip.  ``Each of us,'' Mr. Clinton says, ``has a sacred obligation to pass on a clean planet to future generations.'' Even if it's not Earth.  ``Protecting our environment,'' the president says, ``is a fundamental community value for all Americans.'' As long, of course, as it doesn't require us to change the way we live.  Experts say Colin Powell lacked fire in his belly. Apparently the road to the White House goes through a Tex-Mex restaurant.  Powell's decision not to run for president disappointed Aunt Ilse from Oelwein, who hoped he'd come to Iowa to judge her bridge group's annual Christmas centerpiece decoration contest.  With Powell out of the race, there's talk Newt Gingrich may jump in. Makes sense. They have a lot in common. For instance, neither is Bill Clinton.  Powell agonized a long time about his decision. Maybe not as long as Bill Clinton and Bob Dole agonized about Powell's decision, but long enough.  Another question is whether Powell will be asked to be the GOP's vice presidential candidate. Maybe, but why would a guy want to be busted from general to, in effect, assistant buck private?  Powell may have future political options. For instance, he could decide not to run for president again in 2000.  Powell's wife Alma was said to be strongly against his running. So it's just as well he decided not to. The U.S. probably doesn't need a First Delady.  Air pollution is so bad in Mexico City that authorities may forbid residents from driving their cars two days a week. Noneday and Shoesday?  Overheard on our bus: ``Just to see if anyone notices, I think this year I'll put storm windows on the car and snow tires on the house.''  Our minister, Pastor Deluge, says newly donated costumes for the children's annual Christmas pageant should be fine _ as long as people remember Bethlehem had no Power Rangers.  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) Stories are moving in category shown at end of each budget item.  Lifestyle, Entertainment  JULIE-HARRIS-2takes _ MIAMI _ She is a sparrow of a woman, almost frail. But onstage, Julie Harris is towering, an unforgettable creature of steel and strength. With a record five Tony Awards, close to 30 Broadway appearances over the past 50 years and handfuls of stunning one-woman shows of literary figures to her credit, Harris is the reigning actress of the American stage. (e)  GORE-VIDAL _ undated _ BOOKS: You will be relieved to know that Gore Vidal remains a sly, haughty old puss of Mandarin malice and gleeful sarcasm, a minor glory of the republic and a major glory of American letters. That Vidal is America's best essayist and, I think, literary critic, is universally acknowledged. (e)  REAL-LIFE _ undated _ What the heck is morphing? Why do I care? (l)  KEATING-COLUMN _ undated _ FASHION: Surprise, surprise: Designers try on new styles. (l)  MERV _ undated _ Merv Griffin is in no jeopardy of slowing down. (l)  EYMAN-ON-BOOKS _ undated _ BOOKS COMMENTARY: A sterling book about animals is ``The Encyclopedia of the Dog'' (Dorling Kindersley, $39.95). This is an exhaustive _ but never exhausting _ overview of more than 400 breeds, at least 100 of which I had never seen nor heard of, including some breeds that either are or have been on the verge of extinction (the Polish Hound?). (e)  KINGSOLVER _ undated _ BOOKS: Since intimacy is a distinguishing characteristic of the personal essay, readers should be ready for a nice, long visit with Barbara Kingsolver when they pick up her latest book, ``High Tide In Tucson: Essays From Now Or Never.'' (e)  KLEMPERER _ undated _ Thirty years ago this month, Hogan's Heroes completed its assault on the Nielsen's ratings, thus becoming the only top-rated new show of the 1965-66 TV season. (e)  National  NEWS-QUESTIONS-4takes _ undated _ Do you have a question about the news? Then ask it, and the Atlanta Journal- Constitution's Colin Bessonette will try to find the answer and publish it in this weekly column. (a)  Sports  OLY-WRESTLING _ undated _ They helped lead the United States to its finest hour in the sport, and now Joe Seay and Greg Strobel have been chosen by USA Wrestling to top that. They have been nominated as head and assistant coach of the U.S. Olympic Freestyle Team. (s)  OLY-STEED _ ATLANTA _ A year ago, Munson Steed was an obscure jazz promoter and T-shirt vendor, a maverick- in-the-making with his eyes peeled for the deal of lifetime. Then, he found it. (s)  Business  SUCCESSION _ ATLANTA _ Corporate succession often provides insight into a company's philosophy. (f)  Commentary  NETHAWAY-COLUMN _ undated _ If Americans had the opportunity to go to the polls right now, the Republicans would have to stop bragging about the great Republican revolution. Polls show Americans overwhelmingly blame the Republicans for the faux-shutdown of government. A real government shutdown, of course, would have sent the entire 2.1 million civilians in the federal work force home, rather than only 840,000 ``nonessential'' workers. But the polls also don't let President Clinton off the hook. (k)  EZZARD-COLUMN _ ATLANTA _ `Citizen solutions' to Superfund fall on deaf ears. (k)  MORGAN-COLUMN _ NACOGDOCHES, Texas _ The attendant at the car wash waved and flapped his arms, guiding me to the exact spot where the cleaning process would begin. He wanted me to move closer. Closer still. He wasn't going to be happy until I hit him in the knees with my front bumper. (k)  For answers or resends, call the Cox News Service at 202-331-0900. (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) By LISA COLLIER COOL c.1995 Child magazine (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  If you think you know all you need to know about babyproofing your home, think again.  Even second-time parents can benefit from a refresher course, especially if you've relaxed your standards or simply forgotten how curious babies are. They eat aspirin, chew on extension cords and pull hot pots and their contents onto themselves.  While nothing can substitute for being extra-vigilant, ``The best way to prevent accidents is to plan ahead,'' says Dr. Mark Widome, a pediatrician in Hershey, Penn. who is chairman of the American Academy of Pediatrics' Council on Child and Adolescent Health.  Test your babyproofing IQ with this 10-question quiz. -0- BABYPROOFING QUIZ  +_ 1. The safest way to secure electrical outlets to prevent your baby from sticking fingers or toes into them is to:  a) Insert a plastic outlet cap in each one.  b) Replace outlet covers with safety plates that will snap shut when the outlet is not being used.  c) Block access to outlets with furniture.  Answer: b) Safety plates that snap shut, instead of having caps that must be reinserted after each use, are best, especially for outlets you use frequently. Plastic caps are easily forgotten or misplaced once they're removed. Blocking outlets with furniture is risky, since your baby may be able to squeeze through anyway.  +_ 2. The most dangerous cleaning apparatus in your home is probably:  a) The vacuum cleaner, because a baby could get an arm or leg stuck in the hose.  b) A string mop, because babies love to put things in their mouths and might be able to pull off a piece of string from the mop, which can cause choking.  c) A small bucket, because an infant might lean over the edge to see what's inside, fall in and possibly drown.  Answer: c) Each year approximately 40 babies drown in five-gallon plastic buckets, according to The National Safe Kids Campaign in Washington, D.C. Before using a pail, put your baby in a safe spot such as a play yard. Empty the bucket immediately after using it. When storing buckets outdoors, turn them upside down to prevent rain from collecting in them. Vacuum cleaners and string mops are not as dangerous, but all cleaning equipment and chemicals should be kept on a top shelf or locked away.  +_ 3. You should install toilet latches in all of your bathrooms because:  a) Your baby might flush toys down the toilet and damage your pipes.  b) Toilet water isn't clean.  c) Babies can drown in just one inch of water.  Answer: c) Unlike adults, babies are top-heavy. A standing baby, leaning forward while holding onto an open toilet, can tumble in and drown. Toilet latches can also keep babies from flushing toys down the toilet or playing with water.  +_ 4. To prevent your infant from rolling off a changing table, you should:  a) Never leave your baby unattended on the changing table, even for a second.  b) Secure your baby with the table's safety strap.  c) Get a changing table with a 2-inch-high guardrail around the sides.  Answer: a) Falling from the height of a changing table could seriously injure your baby, so constant vigilance is essential. Safety straps and guardrails help to prevent falls, but don't guarantee safety.  +_ 5. To keep your baby from falling out of a window, you should:  a) Install a window guard that keeps your windows from opening more than three inches wide.  b) Move away any furniture which your child could use to climb to the window.  c) Be sure that the window has a sturdy screen.  Answer: a) Window guards or plastic stops are the only sure way to prevent a baby from falling out a window. Moving furniture isn't reliable, since in your absence a baby sitter or relative could shift it around. And screens aren't strong enough to keep a baby inside.  Caution: Window guards should not be installed in a window that's also an emergency fire exit. Instead, use a window stop or be sure to keep the window closed and latched.  +_ 6. A hand-me-down crib is safe to use only if:  a) It was made after 1974, when manufacturers stopped producing lead paint.  b) It was made after 1974, when crib slats spaced more than 2 3/8 inches apart (which can trap an infant's head) were banned.  c) It was made after 1991, when corner posts (which can cause strangulation if a baby's clothes get caught on them) were banned.  Answer: c) A crib made after 1991 will meet all current safety standards, according to the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission in Washington, D.C. If you are unsure if a hand-me-down crib has been recalled, call the CPSC's hot line at (800) 638-2772 for details. Older cribs have several potential hazards.  Beware especially of cribs from the '70s, which may have been repainted with lead-based paint, which was allowable prior to 1977. Consider using a Lead Check swab, available at hardware stores or by calling (800) 262-LEAD, to check for lead in paint.  +_ 7. Once your baby starts to crawl, you should secure the top and bottom of staircases with:  a) Pressure gates.  b) Wall-mounted gates with horizontal slats no more than 2 3/8 inches apart.  c) Wall-mounted, accordion-style gates to stairs.  Answer: b) Wall-mounted gates with narrowly spaced horizontal slats give greater protection than pressure gates, which your baby may be able to push over. Accordion-style gates should not be used, because your baby's neck or arm could get caught in the openings.  +_ 8. As soon as your baby can get up on hands and knees in the crib, you should remove:  a) Crib bumpers.  b) A crib gym.  c) Large stuffed animals.  Answer: b) Once your baby can steady him/herself on all fours, remove the crib gym. Babies can fall forward on gyms and become entangled. A cushioned crib bumper or large stuffed animals can remain in cribs until babies can stand or at least pull up, after which they might use them as steps to climb out of cribs, according to the AAP.  +_ 9. Any drawers or cabinets that are off-limits should be secured with:  a) Latches that automatically lock when you close the door or drawers.  b) Baby-safe hooks and eyes.  c) A sturdy lock that can only be opened with a key.  Answer: a) Latches are the most reliable and convenient way to safeguard cabinets and drawers, because you don't have to remember to reclose them, as you do with babyproof hooks and eyes. But although it may be less convenient, keeping really hazardous materials such as strong cleansers, dishwasher soap, furniture polish and other household chemicals not only in high cabinets but also under lock and key may bring extra peace of mind. Your baby might be capable of climbing higher than you thought.  +_ 10. The most important thing you can do to keep your baby safe in the bathtub, besides watching at all times, is to:  a) Set your water heater at 120 degrees Fahrenheit or below to prevent scalding.  b) Place nonskid strips on the bottom of the tub.  c) Cover the faucet with a soft vinyl guard to protect against head bumps.  Answer: a) Water hotter than 120 degrees Fahrenheit can burn a baby in seconds. Lowering the temperature on the water heater or installing an anti-scald device, available in hardware stores and babyproofing catalogs, drastically reduces your baby's risk of being scalded. Nonskid strips and a faucet cover can help avert less serious slips, falls and bumps.  (Lisa Collier Cool is a free-lance writer in Pelham, N.Y.) ------------------------------------------------- (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19951120.0464 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-EARN-BIG-BUCKS-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> EARN $1,000 AN HOUR _ AND IT'S EASY! (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) By TOBY McERLEAN c.1995 Pensacola Magazine (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  I know better. Really, I do.  But still I answer a direct-mail invitation to attend a home-based business conference, absolutely free of charge and with no obligation whatsoever. The printed come-on is meant to be irresistible, and it is.  Do I want to retire in a couple of years? Not necessarily, but I certainly would like the option.  Do I want to be relieved of money concerns for the rest of my life? Who doesn't?  Can I imagine making more money in a day than most people earn in a week? I can! I can!  Although a relatively Puritanical upbringing and basic good sense convince me that huge sums of money aren't easy to come by, I'm intrigued _ but not convinced. Someone probably gets rich quick at these conferences, I think, but it's probably the conference sponsors.  A few days before the conference, a barrage of TV infomercials hits the airwaves. Programming reaches a crescendo in an advertising blitz during which the word ``free'' is prominently featured.  The half-hour TV spot is saturated with testimonials of the ``I used to be a typical wage slave, but now I'm my own boss'' variety. Not only does the ecstatic witness make vastly more dollars _ tax-free of course _ but her once-dull hair gleams thick and glossy, her plump body has become lean and trim, her age goes backward instead of forward and she's looking ahead to a luxurious retirement at age 29.  The morning of the conference dawns sunny and chilly. When I arrive at the appointed hotel, its parking lot is overflowing with vehicles. Inside, I am flabbergasted to find a huge room filled to overflowing with people, 300 or more, dressed in everything from formal business attire to Bermuda shorts.  The wannabe-wealthies are young to late middle age, with skins ranging in color from palest white to deepest black. There are a surprising number of couples, and perhaps a slight preponderance of males. One woman even has a baby in tow.  All are listening with rapt attention to a young, bland-faced man who is telling them that they don't need charm or intelligence to make a bundle _ only know-how. Easy Money?  It's barely 8 a.m., but already the lecturer has the audience deeply involved, raising hands and shouting responses in a manner reminiscent of a religious revival. ``How many people are interested in learning how to make $1,000 an hour?'' Every hand in the audience shoots up. ``I'm going to teach you how to do that today!'' he promises.  His speech is larded with platitudes: There's something here for everyone in this room. Change your life by learning something and acting on it. Getting rich is a choice _ choose to be rich or by default you'll be poor. Successful people are decisive people _ they see an opportunity and they act. Don't work for money _ let money work for you. Believe you can be successful. And so on. He delivers the kind of short-sentence, punchy platitudes that defy logic.  He explains that the average start-up investment for a small business is $27,000, and that the five-year success rate is under 10 percent. Then he says that 30 million people are involved in home-based businesses, and 30 million can't be wrong.  His shtick is getting us involved in an affordable home business. Minimum effort for maximum reward. Sounds good. But what, I keep wondering, what is he selling?  You need a plan, he explains, one that will provide immediate cash flow plus a continuing income of tax-free dollars. He shares with us the fact that he's a poor Carolina farm boy, not terribly bright, with no college education. If he can do it, he says, anyone can.  Why is he wasting precious time talking to us? Why isn't he out working deals and pulling in millions by the minute? Despite these obvious questions, the audience is on the edge of their seats, ears pricked up attentively. We're going to find out how to make a bundle!  Reduce risk, he tells us, through the sacred principle of using ``O.P.M.'' _ other people's money. Take action! If we apply what we learn, it will surely change our lives.  He offers us ``win/win'' situations, revealing in the most candid and confidential of tones that he makes money by entering into partnership with his audiences.  Our task is to find and secure suitable properties. His part is to close the deal and pay out the money. The audience positively gasps in gleeful anticipation.  He doesn't mention, at least not initially, either the cost of the sign-up or what we would be letting ourselves in for and, astonishingly, nobody asks. We simply listen, hungry for more talk about how we, too, can get rich quick.  After a brief sojourn in real-estate heaven, the lecturer proceeds to auctions where, once again, he brilliantly manages to tell us very little about how to make a lot of money. But, interspersed with numerous success stories, he certainly whets our appetites with promises of further ``insider'' hints. We are panting to know more.  He drops a few possibly practical but innocuous tips: Bring jumper cables to automobile auctions. Look for risk-free, tax-free investments conferring 18 percent to 50 percent interest. Keep the term ``state tax certificates'' in mind. Buy real estate at discount. Subdivide property. Sell things before they're actually paid for. He gives us just enough information, it seems, to keep most people satisfied and asking for more. Getting to the Pitch  After 3 1/2 hours, my attention is beginning to flag, although the instructor's energy level remains at a constant high. At this point, we finally find out what he's selling: membership in his company.  The cost, wrote large in numbers on the projection screen, is almost $3,000. But wait! For us, he can make it a mere $995. Ah, we're so special he'll practically give it away for $599.  But don't think he's charging because he wants to make money. No, sir _ he's charging because otherwise people won't take the program seriously. And anyway, he says, there's a money-back guarantee.  Along with several others, I decline the offer. But a feeding frenzy sweeps through the crowd. Audience members race to the back of the room, practically pushing each other over to get to the tables where a number of young men wait, pens at the ready.  Lest some fear being shut out, the lecturer, as energetic as ever, leaps upon a chair, assuring every individual that they will indeed be allowed to sign up. Why am I not surprised?  At the close of the morning session, I ask other participants what they found most impressive about the conference. With little hesitation, most say, ``The success stories!'' Maybe we deserve what we get.  One annoyed young man likens the conference to a carrot dangled just out of a donkey's reach. Another, a 60-year-old woman who takes care of elderly people in her home, came because she was told everything would be free.  ``And now,'' she complains, ``they're saying it will be $599. 1 don't think it's fair. I wouldn't have come if I'd known I'd have to pay. I thought I'd get the course, and then I'd go on and they would be lending me their money.''  A 43-year-old woman, who is a full-time college student and also holds a full-time job, speaks for many when she says that she wouldn't hesitate to sign up if only she could get the money together.  Sad to tell, I still don't know how to make $1,000 an hour.  But I do know you don't have to go to Las Vegas to gamble. Caveat emptor, folks _ and how!  (Toby McErlean is a free-lance writer based in Gulf Breeze, Fla.) ------------------------------------------------- (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) WHY? </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-SHOPPING-DIFFERENCES-2TAKES-KAN) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199512.gz"
"42808"	"I"	"think"	" In the title role, Julia Ormond takes on the toughest acting assignment of the year. How could she possibly compete with the ghost of a woman who was born to play gossamer princesses? The key word here, I think, is born. Ormond plays Sabrina _ the chauffeur's daughter contended for by the two rich scions of the family for which her father works _ with a great deal of heart, beauty and, on occasion, the kind of deep glances any man with any sense would plunge into without looking back. In short, Ormond plays Sabrina with the considerable resources of a star in the initial stage of a brilliant career, able to hold the screen against any costar Hollywood in its wisdom might throw against her. Hepburn played Sabrina as if she was born to play her. That's the difference. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199512.gz"

By John Ellement. 700 words.  LEAD-BEHAVIOR (Undated) _ New study linking lead in children's bodies to their propensity for aggressive and delinquent behavior adds urgency to the need get lead out of the environment. By Richard Saltus. 700 words.  BRATTON-BOOK (New York) _ Police Commissioner William Bratton is about to sign a six-figure contract with Random House to write a book about his life as a crime fighter. By Fred Kaplan. "50689"	"I"	"think"	" Best Director: Mel Gibson. Many Academy members are industry workers who recognize and respect craft more than most. ``Braveheart'' is a conventional film, but a thoroughly well-crafted and extremely handsome one. Gibson wasn't named in the best-actor category, but with 10 nominations ``Braveheart'' isn't going to go away empty-handed. This, I think, will be its big prize. Although Mike Figgis' ``Leaving Las Vegas'' and Tim Robbins' ``Dead Man Walking'' represent greater daring and reach, the freeze out of each in the best-picture category suggests that Oscar is thinking conservatively again, regarding them as ``bummer films'' because of their respective subject matter. Chris Noonan (``Babe'') and Michael Radford (``The Postman'') got their prizes when they were nominated. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199603.gz"
