"51009"	"I"	"think"	" Notes: The Dodgers defeated the Florida Marlins 6-2 on Wednesday afternoon. Their exhibition record is 4-1. In his second exhibition start, Tom Candiotti pitched four scoreless innings. Closer Todd Worrell pitched a scoreless eighth inning.... Mark Davis, the 1989 Cy Young Award winner with the San Diego Padres whose career fizzled after that, is attempting to earn a place in the Marlins' bullpen. He pitched the third inning and allowed two runs on four hits. He is 35.... The Dodgers play the Houston Astros today at Holman Stadium. Right-hander Ramon Martinez is expected to start, followed by left-hander Joey Eischen. Eischen, who pitched well in his first appearance, said he has been told he will start Monday's game against the New York Mets. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960306.0791 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's New York Times Photo Full picture package, moving 03/06/96.  NYT Picture clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at 214-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on NewsCom at 305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling 212-556-4204.  (NYT23) LOS ANGELES -- March 6, 1996 -- KIDS-CLOTHING, 3-06 -- Serina Magner, 17, shops at a Rampage store in Los Angeles. The popular Southern California clothing chain matches merchandise with regional tastes. ``In each market we learn about the psychographic mix,'' says Nancy Mamann, the marketing director for Rampage. ``Like in Texas, those are meat-and-potato girls. We're not going to give them mini T-shirts.'' (Marissa Roth/New York Times Photo)  (NYT22) TENAFLY, N.J. -- March 6, 1996 -- SCHOOLS-INTERNET-CLR, 3-06 -- A growing number of elementary schools are linking to the Internet. A third-grade class in Tenafly, in northern New Jersey, is participating in a program aimed at helping 500 schools in the state go on line; Marianne Denner guides some of the program's students in proper internet usage. (Dith Pran/New York Times Photo)  (NYT21) ALBANY, N.Y. -- March 6, 1996 -- FORBES, 3-06 -- Jack F. Kemp, left, endorsing Steve Forbes on Wednesday in Albany. ``What encouraged me to get into the campaign,was the fear that the Republican Party was going into 96-slash-97 without the vigor, dynamism, growth, inclusiveness issue I believe Steve stands for,'' he says. (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT20) TAMPA, Fla. -- March 6, 1996 -- BUCHANAN, 3-06 -- Patrick J. Buchanan's presidential aspirations suffered a big setback this week, but in a hot tent in Tampa on Wednesday Robert Hallowell, Joe Mullane and Charles White are among those reaffirming their support. ``We're going to fight until hell freezes over,'' says Buchanan. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)  (NYT19) CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- March 1, 1996 -- BOOK-MCCAULEY-BOS-CLR, 3-6 -- Author Stephen McCauley is a master of the art of the first-person narrative, filtering his stories through male voices that are as wry and comic as they are well-defended. McCauley says he hopes his novels will usher people beyond gay stereotypes, but he is not writing with a political agenda: ``I think that's just deadly. When I pick up a book and see that, I think, 'I'm not wasting my time.''' (John Blanding/Boston Globe Staff Photo)  (NYT18) SANTA FE, N.M. -- March 6, 1996 -- SANTA-FE-DESIGN, 3-06 -- His city may be growing more conventional by the day, but just a few blocks from the city's historic plaza, Ford Ruthling - whose own paintings and assemblages play off the folk art he collects - has carved out a genre all his own. ``It's Santa Fe in a very different way than vigas and adobe,'' his friend Robert Ewing, a former director of the Fine Arts Museum here, says of the house. In Ruthling's bedroom, an altarlike frame surrounds his bull painting. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT17) MAPUTO ELEPHANT RESERVE, Mozambique -- March 6, 1996 -- MOZAMBIQUE-ECOTOURISM-CLR, 3-06 -- Where an $800 million ecotourist paradise has been proposed in Mozambique, the project's representative there, John R. Perrott, right, talks with Mateus Chambol, director of the Maputo Elephant Reserve. ``My budget is $50,000 U.S.,'' he says, acknowledging that the funds will run out in June. ``If we don't get more, we will have to abandon the reserve.'' (Donald G. McNeil Jr./New York Times Photo)  (NYT16) MILAN, Italy -- March 6, 1996 -- GUCCI-FASHION, 3-06 -- Dolce &AMP; Gabbana's chiffon dress with a cherry print and a nude corset underneath, right; tweed skirt, crocheted top and fake fur at Dolce &AMP; Gabbana, left. It was as if Tom Ford, the designer of Gucci, had pumped happy gas into the room: some of fashion's most famous poker faces were smiling, and many found their feet for the first time in the Milan season, which opened Friday, to give him a standing ovation at the end. (Corina Lecca/New York Times Photo)  (NYT15) LONDON -- March 6, 1996 -- BRITAIN-THEATER, 3-06 -- Trevor Nunn, outside the National Theater in London, has been chosen as its new director. He rose to fame in the 1960s as the Wunderkind of the Royal Shakespeare Company and then struck bountiful commercial success in the West End with a parade of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musicals. ``I spent 18 years being responsible for an organization of similar scale,'' he says. (Jonathan Player/New York Times Photo)  (NYT14) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- SPAIN-BALLET-REVIEW-CLR, 3-06 -- The National Ballet of Spain performing ``Bolero'' at City Center. George Balanchine once said that if you didn't like his ballets there was always the music to close your eyes and listen to. And that is just as well, for dance is the least interesting part of the evening. But the production is so filled with beautiful faces and handsomely arched upper bodies that it almost doesn't matter what the dancers are doing. (Sara Krulwich/New York Times Photo)  (NYT13) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- SOROS-DESIGN-CLR, 3-06 -- Susan Soros, wife of the financier George Soros, at her duplex on Fifth Avenue. ``Our mission is to elevate the approval and recognition of the decorative arts as an academic discipline as worthy of attention as painting, music and literature,'' she says of the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, of which she is founder and director. (Fred R. Conrad/New York Times Photo)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- BRIGID-BERLIN-ARTIST-CLR-2, 3-06 -- Brigid Berlin, 57, is a spirited survivor of the famously decadent Andy Warhol Factory years. Her makeup drawer is an example of her increased focus on organization, and contains her cache of meticulously hand-labeled cosmetics. ``Oh, I don't wear makeup,'' Ms. Berlin says. ``I just love that it looks so neat in my closet.'' Next Tuesday, she will be at Stubbs Books and Prints in Manhattan for the opening of an exhibition of her recent art. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)  (NYT11) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- BRIGID-BERLIN-ARTIST-CLR-1, 3-06 -- Brigid Berlin at home with pugs, both real and stuffed. A spirited survivor of the famously decadent Andy Warhol Factory years, Ms. Berlin, now 57, enjoys the life of a recluse. But she is planning to emerge for one night at least. Next Tuesday, she will be at Stubbs Books and Prints, a gallery cum salon in Manhattan, for the opening of an exhibition of her recent art. ``I use my breasts as a paint brush,'' she says, by way of explaining her craft. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)  (NYT10) UNDATED -- March 6, 1996 -- HOME-IMPROVEMENT, 3-6 -- In order to understand tool quality, one should understand steel. Steel is basically an alloy of iron and carbon. The addition of carbon makes the metal harder, but also more brittle, less malleable and less able to withstand stress and shock. Manufacturers recognize that different tools are subjected to different amounts of stress and shock, so they match steel with a suitable carbon content for each tool. (Edward R. Lipinski/New York Times Photo)  The following photos are with part five of the New York Times' Jobs Series:  (NYT9) LEWISBURG, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-STUDENTS-CLR-3, 3-6 -- At Bucknell, corporate recruiters connect with sophomores and even freshmen pushing them to identify goals earlier. Psychology major, Priscilla Stack, 21, is distinctly lacking in career focus. ``Everyone has a direction,'' she says during a walk around Bucknell's campus. ``I feel like I have to make some kind of decision and pounce into it, but I just don't know.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT8) LEWISBURG, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-STUDENTS-CLR-2, 3-6 --  ``We're a little more realistic about our goals than our parents were,'' says Karim Abdul-Matin, 21, a biology major from New York City, as he works in the lab. Abdul-Matin, who is planning on a medical career says, ``We can't become anything we want anymore. We have a set number of options.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT7) LEWISBURG, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-STUDENTS-CLR-1, 3-6 -- Management major, Mike Wickerham, 22, has an American flag hanging over his bed. He holds a firm belief that capitalism is a struggle in which he will prevail. `` I don't know where the country is going as a whole,'' Wickerham says. ``But if there are only so many places, I'll have one of them.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT6) LITTLETON, Colo. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-6, 3-6 -- At home, Richard A. Baumbusch, an electrical engineering major at Bucknell, plays with his dog, Charlie. Baumbusch, who has been laid off twice, is now an executive director at U.S. West Communications, a unit of the telecommunications corporation U.S. West. ``I'm more aware of the pain involved in layoffs and relocations than I was.'' he admits. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT5) ASPEN, Colo. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-5, 3-6 -- Peter Louthis, who dropped out college two months before graduation to avoid being drafted, is now a construction superintendent for a small company in Aspen that specializes in multimillion-dollar mountainside mansions. ``I know I've become part of the system I rejected, to an extent,'' he says from a job site. ``But I feel that I have still kept my individuality.'' (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT4) UNDATED -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-4, 3-6 -- In her office at home, Shelby H. Diefenbach takes a break with Mighty, her greyhound. After getting laid off, Ms. Diefenbach set up shop as an independent marketing research consultant and found herself on the winning end of a downsizing trend. With no benefits, and her husband now working as a consultant too, she is happy and confident of herself and her abilities. ``I have a great personality now. I never had a personality before,'' she jokes. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT3) SELINSGROVE, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-3, 3-6 -- Dr. Christine Dotterer, examining a patient, points out that her autonomy as a physician is being whittled down as insurers second-guess her treatment decisions. Dr. Dottererdesired the autonomy of a small-town family practice and the ability to run it a woman's sensibility. ``It's not hierarchical,'' she says ``It's a female-oriented office, just me and two nurses, and we're all soft touches.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT2) GOLDEN, Colo. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-2, 3-6 -- Bucknell graduate, Glen B. Maynard drove west in 1975 after graduating from Boston University Law School. He found his way to Golden, Colo. and set up a practice above the Silverheels Grill. Maynard simplified his life long before it became trendy. ``My choice is that I don't like to take direction from other people, I like to do things my way.'' he says while walking his dog down Golden's main street. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT1) CANANDAIGUA, N.Y. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-1, 3-6 -- After graduating Bucknell, Gerald M. Brown took job in his hometown at Eastman Kodak. He is still in the information services department where he started out as a programmer. Having risen in the hierarchy, to senior systems analyst, he feels lost. ``When I have lunch with my peers, we all have the same sense of hollowness,'' he says looking out on Canandaigua Lake. (Michael J. Okoniewski/New York Times Photo)  N. Y. Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960306.0792 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's New York Times Photo Full picture package, moving 03/06/96.  NYT Picture clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at 214-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on NewsCom at 305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling 212-556-4204.  (NYT23) LOS ANGELES -- March 6, 1996 -- KIDS-CLOTHING, 3-06 -- Serina Magner, 17, shops at a Rampage store in Los Angeles. The popular Southern California clothing chain matches merchandise with regional tastes. ``In each market we learn about the psychographic mix,'' says Nancy Mamann, the marketing director for Rampage. ``Like in Texas, those are meat-and-potato girls. We're not going to give them mini T-shirts.'' (Marissa Roth/New York Times Photo)  (NYT22) TENAFLY, N.J. -- March 6, 1996 -- SCHOOLS-INTERNET-CLR, 3-06 -- A growing number of elementary schools are linking to the Internet. A third-grade class in Tenafly, in northern New Jersey, is participating in a program aimed at helping 500 schools in the state go on line; Marianne Denner guides some of the program's students in proper internet usage. (Dith Pran/New York Times Photo)  (NYT21) ALBANY, N.Y. -- March 6, 1996 -- FORBES, 3-06 -- Jack F. Kemp, left, endorsing Steve Forbes on Wednesday in Albany. ``What encouraged me to get into the campaign,was the fear that the Republican Party was going into 96-slash-97 without the vigor, dynamism, growth, inclusiveness issue I believe Steve stands for,'' he says. (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT20) TAMPA, Fla. -- March 6, 1996 -- BUCHANAN, 3-06 -- Patrick J. Buchanan's presidential aspirations suffered a big setback this week, but in a hot tent in Tampa on Wednesday Robert Hallowell, Joe Mullane and Charles White are among those reaffirming their support. ``We're going to fight until hell freezes over,'' says Buchanan. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)  (NYT19) CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- March 1, 1996 -- BOOK-MCCAULEY-BOS-CLR, 3-6 -- Author Stephen McCauley is a master of the art of the first-person narrative, filtering his stories through male voices that are as wry and comic as they are well-defended. McCauley says he hopes his novels will usher people beyond gay stereotypes, but he is not writing with a political agenda: ``I think that's just deadly. When I pick up a book and see that, I think, 'I'm not wasting my time.''' (John Blanding/Boston Globe Staff Photo)  (NYT18) SANTA FE, N.M. -- March 6, 1996 -- SANTA-FE-DESIGN, 3-06 -- His city may be growing more conventional by the day, but just a few blocks from the city's historic plaza, Ford Ruthling - whose own paintings and assemblages play off the folk art he collects - has carved out a genre all his own. ``It's Santa Fe in a very different way than vigas and adobe,'' his friend Robert Ewing, a former director of the Fine Arts Museum here, says of the house. In Ruthling's bedroom, an altarlike frame surrounds his bull painting. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT17) MAPUTO ELEPHANT RESERVE, Mozambique -- March 6, 1996 -- MOZAMBIQUE-ECOTOURISM-CLR, 3-06 -- Where an $800 million ecotourist paradise has been proposed in Mozambique, the project's representative there, John R. Perrott, right, talks with Mateus Chambol, director of the Maputo Elephant Reserve. ``My budget is $50,000 U.S.,'' he says, acknowledging that the funds will run out in June. ``If we don't get more, we will have to abandon the reserve.'' (Donald G. McNeil Jr./New York Times Photo)  (NYT16) MILAN, Italy -- March 6, 1996 -- GUCCI-FASHION, 3-06 -- Dolce &AMP; Gabbana's chiffon dress with a cherry print and a nude corset underneath, right; tweed skirt, crocheted top and fake fur at Dolce &AMP; Gabbana, left. It was as if Tom Ford, the designer of Gucci, had pumped happy gas into the room: some of fashion's most famous poker faces were smiling, and many found their feet for the first time in the Milan season, which opened Friday, to give him a standing ovation at the end. (Corina Lecca/New York Times Photo)  (NYT15) LONDON -- March 6, 1996 -- BRITAIN-THEATER, 3-06 -- Trevor Nunn, outside the National Theater in London, has been chosen as its new director. He rose to fame in the 1960s as the Wunderkind of the Royal Shakespeare Company and then struck bountiful commercial success in the West End with a parade of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musicals. ``I spent 18 years being responsible for an organization of similar scale,'' he says. (Jonathan Player/New York Times Photo)  (NYT14) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- SPAIN-BALLET-REVIEW-CLR, 3-06 -- The National Ballet of Spain performing ``Bolero'' at City Center. George Balanchine once said that if you didn't like his ballets there was always the music to close your eyes and listen to. And that is just as well, for dance is the least interesting part of the evening. But the production is so filled with beautiful faces and handsomely arched upper bodies that it almost doesn't matter what the dancers are doing. (Sara Krulwich/New York Times Photo)  (NYT13) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- SOROS-DESIGN-CLR, 3-06 -- Susan Soros, wife of the financier George Soros, at her duplex on Fifth Avenue. ``Our mission is to elevate the approval and recognition of the decorative arts as an academic discipline as worthy of attention as painting, music and literature,'' she says of the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, of which she is founder and director. (Fred R. Conrad/New York Times Photo)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- BRIGID-BERLIN-ARTIST-CLR-2, 3-06 -- Brigid Berlin, 57, is a spirited survivor of the famously decadent Andy Warhol Factory years. Her makeup drawer is an example of her increased focus on organization, and contains her cache of meticulously hand-labeled cosmetics. ``Oh, I don't wear makeup,'' Ms. Berlin says. ``I just love that it looks so neat in my closet.'' Next Tuesday, she will be at Stubbs Books and Prints in Manhattan for the opening of an exhibition of her recent art. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)  (NYT11) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- BRIGID-BERLIN-ARTIST-CLR-1, 3-06 -- Brigid Berlin at home with pugs, both real and stuffed. A spirited survivor of the famously decadent Andy Warhol Factory years, Ms. Berlin, now 57, enjoys the life of a recluse. But she is planning to emerge for one night at least. Next Tuesday, she will be at Stubbs Books and Prints, a gallery cum salon in Manhattan, for the opening of an exhibition of her recent art. ``I use my breasts as a paint brush,'' she says, by way of explaining her craft. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)  (NYT10) UNDATED -- March 6, 1996 -- HOME-IMPROVEMENT, 3-6 -- In order to understand tool quality, one should understand steel. Steel is basically an alloy of iron and carbon. The addition of carbon makes the metal harder, but also more brittle, less malleable and less able to withstand stress and shock. Manufacturers recognize that different tools are subjected to different amounts of stress and shock, so they match steel with a suitable carbon content for each tool. (Edward R. We're not going to give them mini T-shirts.'' A third-grade class in Tenafly, in northern New Jersey, is participating in a program aimed at helping 500 schools in the state go on line; Marianne Denner guides some of the program's students in proper internet usage. (Dith Pran/New York Times Photo)  (NYT21) ALBANY, N.Y. -- March 6, 1996 -- FORBES, 3-06 -- Jack F. Kemp, left, endorsing Steve Forbes on Wednesday in Albany. ``What encouraged me to get into the campaign,was the fear that the Republican Party was going into 96-slash-97 without the vigor, dynamism, growth, inclusiveness issue I believe Steve stands for,'' he says. (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT20) TAMPA, Fla. -- March 6, 1996 -- BUCHANAN, 3-06 -- Patrick J. Buchanan's presidential aspirations suffered a big setback this week, but in a hot tent in Tampa on Wednesday Robert Hallowell, Joe Mullane and Charles White are among those reaffirming their support. ``We're going to fight until hell freezes over,'' says Buchanan. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)  (NYT19) CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- March 1, 1996 -- BOOK-MCCAULEY-BOS-CLR, 3-6 -- Author Stephen McCauley is a master of the art of the first-person narrative, filtering his stories through male voices that are as wry and comic as they are well-defended. McCauley says he hopes his novels will usher people beyond gay stereotypes, but he is not writing with a political agenda: ``I think that's just deadly. When I pick up a book and see that, I think, 'I'm not wasting my time.''' (John Blanding/Boston Globe Staff Photo)  (NYT18) SANTA FE, N.M. -- March 6, 1996 -- SANTA-FE-DESIGN, 3-06 -- His city may be growing more conventional by the day, but just a few blocks from the city's historic plaza, Ford Ruthling - whose own paintings and assemblages play off the folk art he collects - has carved out a genre all his own. ``It's Santa Fe in a very different way than vigas and adobe,'' his friend Robert Ewing, a former director of the Fine Arts Museum here, says of the house. In Ruthling's bedroom, an altarlike frame surrounds his bull painting. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT17) MAPUTO ELEPHANT RESERVE, Mozambique -- March 6, 1996 -- MOZAMBIQUE-ECOTOURISM-CLR, 3-06 -- Where an $800 million ecotourist paradise has been proposed in Mozambique, the project's representative there, John R. Perrott, right, talks with Mateus Chambol, director of the Maputo Elephant Reserve. ``My budget is $50,000 U.S.,'' he says, acknowledging that the funds will run out in June. ``If we don't get more, we will have to abandon the reserve.'' (Donald G. McNeil Jr./New York Times Photo)  (NYT16) MILAN, Italy -- March 6, 1996 -- GUCCI-FASHION, 3-06 -- Dolce &AMP; Gabbana's chiffon dress with a cherry print and a nude corset underneath, right; tweed skirt, crocheted top and fake fur at Dolce &AMP; Gabbana, left. It was as if Tom Ford, the designer of Gucci, had pumped happy gas into the room: some of fashion's most famous poker faces were smiling, and many found their feet for the first time in the Milan season, which opened Friday, to give him a standing ovation at the end. (Corina Lecca/New York Times Photo)  (NYT15) LONDON -- March 6, 1996 -- BRITAIN-THEATER, 3-06 -- Trevor Nunn, outside the National Theater in London, has been chosen as its new director. He rose to fame in the 1960s as the Wunderkind of the Royal Shakespeare Company and then struck bountiful commercial success in the West End with a parade of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musicals. ``I spent 18 years being responsible for an organization of similar scale,'' he says. (Jonathan Player/New York Times Photo)  (NYT14) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- SPAIN-BALLET-REVIEW-CLR, 3-06 -- The National Ballet of Spain performing ``Bolero'' at City Center. George Balanchine once said that if you didn't like his ballets there was always the music to close your eyes and listen to. And that is just as well, for dance is the least interesting part of the evening. But the production is so filled with beautiful faces and handsomely arched upper bodies that it almost doesn't matter what the dancers are doing. (Sara Krulwich/New York Times Photo)  (NYT13) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- SOROS-DESIGN-CLR, 3-06 -- Susan Soros, wife of the financier George Soros, at her duplex on Fifth Avenue. ``Our mission is to elevate the approval and recognition of the decorative arts as an academic discipline as worthy of attention as painting, music and literature,'' she says of the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, of which she is founder and director. (Fred R. Conrad/New York Times Photo)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- BRIGID-BERLIN-ARTIST-CLR-2, 3-06 -- Brigid Berlin, 57, is a spirited survivor of the famously decadent Andy Warhol Factory years. Her makeup drawer is an example of her increased focus on organization, and contains her cache of meticulously hand-labeled cosmetics. ``Oh, I don't wear makeup,'' Ms. Berlin says. ``I just love that it looks so neat in my closet.'' Next Tuesday, she will be at Stubbs Books and Prints in Manhattan for the opening of an exhibition of her recent art. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)  (NYT11) NEW YORK -- March 6, 1996 -- BRIGID-BERLIN-ARTIST-CLR-1, 3-06 -- Brigid Berlin at home with pugs, both real and stuffed. A spirited survivor of the famously decadent Andy Warhol Factory years, Ms. Berlin, now 57, enjoys the life of a recluse. But she is planning to emerge for one night at least. Next Tuesday, she will be at Stubbs Books and Prints, a gallery cum salon in Manhattan, for the opening of an exhibition of her recent art. ``I use my breasts as a paint brush,'' she says, by way of explaining her craft. (Stephanie Berger/New York Times Photo)  (NYT10) UNDATED -- March 6, 1996 -- HOME-IMPROVEMENT, 3-6 -- In order to understand tool quality, one should understand steel. Steel is basically an alloy of iron and carbon. The addition of carbon makes the metal harder, but also more brittle, less malleable and less able to withstand stress and shock. Manufacturers recognize that different tools are subjected to different amounts of stress and shock, so they match steel with a suitable carbon content for each tool. (Edward R. Lipinski/New York Times Photo)  The following photos are with part five of the New York Times' Jobs Series:  (NYT9) LEWISBURG, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-STUDENTS-CLR-3, 3-6 -- At Bucknell, corporate recruiters connect with sophomores and even freshmen pushing them to identify goals earlier. Psychology major, Priscilla Stack, 21, is distinctly lacking in career focus. ``Everyone has a direction,'' she says during a walk around Bucknell's campus. ``I feel like I have to make some kind of decision and pounce into it, but I just don't know.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT8) LEWISBURG, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-STUDENTS-CLR-2, 3-6 --  ``We're a little more realistic about our goals than our parents were,'' says Karim Abdul-Matin, 21, a biology major from New York City, as he works in the lab. Abdul-Matin, who is planning on a medical career says, ``We can't become anything we want anymore. We have a set number of options.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT7) LEWISBURG, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-STUDENTS-CLR-1, 3-6 -- Management major, Mike Wickerham, 22, has an American flag hanging over his bed. He holds a firm belief that capitalism is a struggle in which he will prevail. `` I don't know where the country is going as a whole,'' Wickerham says. ``But if there are only so many places, I'll have one of them.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT6) LITTLETON, Colo. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-6, 3-6 -- At home, Richard A. Baumbusch, an electrical engineering major at Bucknell, plays with his dog, Charlie. Baumbusch, who has been laid off twice, is now an executive director at U.S. West Communications, a unit of the telecommunications corporation U.S. West. ``I'm more aware of the pain involved in layoffs and relocations than I was.'' he admits. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT5) ASPEN, Colo. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-5, 3-6 -- Peter Louthis, who dropped out college two months before graduation to avoid being drafted, is now a construction superintendent for a small company in Aspen that specializes in multimillion-dollar mountainside mansions. ``I know I've become part of the system I rejected, to an extent,'' he says from a job site. ``But I feel that I have still kept my individuality.'' (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT4) UNDATED -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-4, 3-6 -- In her office at home, Shelby H. Diefenbach takes a break with Mighty, her greyhound. After getting laid off, Ms. Diefenbach set up shop as an independent marketing research consultant and found herself on the winning end of a downsizing trend. With no benefits, and her husband now working as a consultant too, she is happy and confident of herself and her abilities. ``I have a great personality now. I never had a personality before,'' she jokes. (Jim Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT3) SELINSGROVE, Pa. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-3, 3-6 -- Dr. Christine Dotterer, examining a patient, points out that her autonomy as a physician is being whittled down as insurers second-guess her treatment decisions. Dr. Dottererdesired the autonomy of a small-town family practice and the ability to run it a woman's sensibility. ``It's not hierarchical,'' she says ``It's a female-oriented office, just me and two nurses, and we're all soft touches.'' (Keith Meyers/New York Times Photo)  (NYT2) GOLDEN, Colo. -- March 6, 1996 -- JOBS-V-CLR-2, 3-6 -- Bucknell graduate, Glen B. Maynard drove west in 1975 after graduating from Boston University Law School. He found his way to Golden, Colo. and set up a practice above the Silverheels Grill. Maynard simplified his life long before it became trendy. ``My choice is that I don't like to take direction from other people, I like to do things my way.'' he says while walking his dog down Golden's main street. Having risen in the hierarchy, to senior systems analyst, he feels lost. ``When I have lunch with my peers, we all have the same sense of hollowness,'' he says looking out on Canandaigua Lake. They will move in the ``e'' entertainment news file. For questions, contact Jimmy Johnson at the Daily News, (818) 713-3695. . HELEN-OSCARS (Los Angeles) _ Before Susan Sarandon played a Catholic nun giving spiritual counseling on Louisiana's death row in Dead Man Walking, Sister Helen Prejean walked death row. Prejean, whose bestselling anti-execution tract Dead Man Walking formed the basis of the Oscar-nominated Tom Robbin's movie, hopes to use any spotlight she grabs at Monday's Academy Awards to focus attention on her campaign against the death penalty. The movie, which stars Sean Penn as a condemned man whose character is a blend of two men Prejean counseled, has rejuvenated sales of her book and thrust the 56-year-old nun into fame, if not fortune. (She is giving the $300,000 share of the film and book proceeds to her order.) Over the next few months, translations of her book will hit the stores in Japan, Latin America, France, Germany and Italy, in time for the film's distribution in those countries. It's no surprise, then, that the 56-year-old crusading nun is booked solid through August, with some speaking engagements scheduled for 1997 and beyond. And the calls keep coming. The message she hopes to bring to the Oscar show? ``The death penalty is not an isolated little peripheral issue of maybe knocking off a few of these criminals,'' she says. ``It has to do, I think, with the three deepest wounds of American society, and that's our racism, our assault on the poor and our penchant for trying to solve social problems through violence.'' By Sara Catania  . BOSTON-COMMON (Los Angeles) Anthony Clark thought he had reached the top when he became the first person in his family to leave the state of Virginia and the first to graduate from college. But these days, those accomplishments pale when compared to Clark's success in the entertainment business: the actor and standup comic has landed his own sitcom. ``It's just thrilling,'' says Clark. ``But I'm also scared. I'm just so incredibly kind of shy.'' ``Boston Common'' is based on Clark's experiences as a fish-out-of-water Southerner attending Emerson College in Boston. It debuts tonight on NBC. By Janet Weeks. . ROSENTHAL-COLUMN _ To see Chita Rivera, at age 63 no less, kick and dance and strut and stride, reprising her 1993 Tony-winning role in the musical ``Kiss of the Spiderwoman'' through April 21 at the Ahmanson Theater downtown, you would never realize how seriously she was injured in a Manhattan car accident 10 years ago next month. Doctors originally weren't sure she would ever walk again, let alone dance. Times News Service  COMPUTER HACKER PLEADS GUILTY  (NYT) _ Kevin Mitnick, once the country's most notorious computer hacker until he was tracked down and arrested in a high-tech manhunt last year, pleaded guilty Tuesday in Los Angeles to a charge that he used stolen mobile telephone numbers.  Mitnick, who was a fugitive from the law for three years before his capture in February 1995, had been charged with nearly two dozen crimes, including the possession of millions of dollars worth of corporate software, trade secrets, credit card numbers and other electronic information taken from hundreds of supposedly secure computers.  The plea agreement with federal prosecutors appeared to dismiss all but two of the many charges against Mitnick, now 32, who started breaking into computer and telephone systems as an overweight, lonely teen-ager with a talent for manipulating both electronics and people.  HIGH COURT ISSUES PATENT RULING  WASHINGTON (NYT) _ In one of the most important patent decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously Tuesday that in a patent infringement suit it is up to judges, rather than juries, to resolve the crucial issue of what a patent means.  While the decision does not completely oust juries from patent cases, it may have that effect as a practical matter in many infringement suits. The determination of the patent claim _ the precise definition of the scope of the patent over which the patent owner exercises a lawful monopoly _is often the most important aspect of the case, and once a judge has decided this question, there is often nothing left for the jury to do.  The decision is likely to strengthen the position of people accused of infringing on a patent, because juries are known for favoring patent holders and for being impressed by expert trial testimony that portrays the scope of a patent in the broadest possible way.  JOBS REPORT RELEASED  WASHINGTON (NYT) _ In a report intended to defuse some of the anxieties surging through the workplace, the Clinton administration Tuesday released a study that refutes a stereotype about the American economy, concluding that most of the new jobs created in the service industries are relatively high-paying executive and management positions.  That conclusion was part of a politically delicate report that the administration released as part of its election year effort to take credit for the growth of 8.5 million jobs, but also to focus new attention on workers caught in transition.  The report also suggests that in the early 1990s, older workers, above age 55, were more likely to be laid off than any other age group, a reversal from the 1980s.  SENATE PASSES HEALTH INSURANCE LEGISLATION  WASHINGTON (NYT) _ The Senate on Tuesday passed legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job, on a 100-0 vote that masked months of uncertainties, compromises and difficult persuasion.  The legislation sponsored by Sens. Nancy Kassebaum and Edward Kennedy still faces a difficult conference with the House, but it appears to have acquired irresistible political momentum.  The core of the bill _ common to both House and Senate versions _ is a provision that requires insurers to cover workers under a new employer's plan if their last job carried insurance. It would also sharply limit any exclusions for pre-existing conditions.  If that core becomes law, it will be at once the palest shadow of President Clinton's failed universal health insurance plan of 1994 and the most sweeping federal health legislation since Medicare and Medicaid were established in 1965.  SALES OF U.S. SERVICE ABROAD SHRINKS TRADE DEFICIT  WASHINGTON (NYT) _ Erasing about half of a huge increase in January, the nation's trade deficit shrank to $8.2 billion in February with record sales of American services abroad, the Commerce Department reported Tuesday.  Exports overall climbed 2 percent to the second-highest total on record while imports fell 0.5 percent, the first time since November that the deficit was narrowed.  Although the deficit was about $400 million less than expected _ and was accompanied by a downward revision of that amount for January _ private analysts noted two main reasons for the contraction, neither of them likely to be soon repeated.  One was a big drop in the nation's bill for imported oil, which tumbled $800 million, to $3 billion. The other was a surge in exports of civilian aircraft in the aftermath of the strike at Boeing Co., which was settled in December.  HEALTH AGENCY: DOCTORS SHOULD TELL PATIENTS TO STOP SMOKING  CHICAGO (NYT) _ Doctors should routinely ask patients about their tobacco use and actively work to get those who smoke, chew or sniff tobacco to quit, according to new guidelines released Tuesday by the U.S. Agency for Health Care Policy and Research.  ``I wouldn't say it's malpractice not to inquire about tobacco, but it is now a standard of care doctors should meet,'' said Dr. Randolph Smoak, secretary treasurer of the American Medical Association, which will publish the new guidelines Wednesday in a special issue of the weekly Journal of the American Medical Association devoted entirely to tobacco. ``It's a whole cultural change for someone to quit smoking and doctors should try to help them.''  SPECIALIST: SOME KEVORKIAN PATIENTS COULD HAVE BEEN TREATED  PONTIAC, Mich. (NYT) _ A nationally recognized specialist on suicide testified Tuesday that two patients of Dr. Jack Kevorkian might not have wanted to take their own lives if they had been treated for clinical depression.  ``Dr. Kevorkian's medical treatment, I think, is improper because he did not make sure they had a full course of treatment for depression,'' Dr. Jan Fawcett, chairman of the department of psychiatry at Rush Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago, said. He took the witness stand as prosecutors in Oakland County finished their case against the retired pathologist, who is on trial for violating Michigan's common law by assisting the suicides of Marjorie Wantz, 58, and Sherry Miller, 43, who died together on Oct. 23, 1991.  Under cross-examination by Geoffrey Fieger, Kevorkian's lead attorney, Dr. Fawcett admitted that he had never examined the women nor seen their complete medical records, but he added ``I think I know enough about depression to know it when I see it.'' </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960423.0581 type=story > <HEADLINE> THARP IS GEM ON `DANCE IN AMERICA' </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-TV-THARP-REVIEW-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199604.gz"

"58538"	"I"	"think"	" Pedaling up muddy mountains and through streams proved romantic for professional mountain bikers Susan DeMattei, 33, and David Wiens, 31, members of the U.S. team. They met while riding for the Diamondback team and plan to wed Sept. 28, the weekend after the world championships in Australia. DeMattei is the world's third-ranked woman in cross country mountain biking, behind Alison Sydor of Canada and Julia Furtado of the United States. DeMattei hopes to represent the U.S. on Conyers' Olympic course, which Wiens helped design. Meeting Wiens was ``the best thing to come out of my cycling career, I think,'' DeMattei said. "62917"	"I"	"think"	" Accordingly, the remedy should not necessarily require either the admission of women to VMI, or the creation of a VMI clone for women. An adequate remedy in my opinion might be a demonstration by Virginia that its interest in educating men in a single-sex environment is matched by its interest in educating women in a singlesex institution. To demonstrate such, the State does not need to create two institutions with the same number of faculty PhD's, similar SAT scores, or comparable athletic fields. See ante, at 34-35. Nor would it necessarily require that the women's institution offer the same curriculum as the men's; one could be strong in computer science, the other could be strong in liberal arts. It would be a sufficient remedy, I think, if the two institutions offered the same quality of education and were of the same overall calibre. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199606.gz"

"62985"	"I"	"think"	" It says something, I think, that though the outskirts of town are getting crowded with motels, in the village itself the bed-and-breakfast rules, often in 19th-century homes. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199606.gz"
"62994"	"I"	"think"	" Pro Stock drag racing champion Warren Johnson says a race car is nothing more than a tool. Based on his victory Sunday at the Pennzoil Nationals in Millington, Tenn., Johnson's latest GM Performance Parts Pontiac Firebird appears ready to hammer the National Hot Rod Association competition. Johnson's second NHRA victory of 1996 came at the expense of Jim Yates, a four-time winner who has led the points chase since the season opener. Yates, who drives the McDonald's Firebird owned by Joe Gibbs, leads Johnson by 139 points, or slightly more than one race. But Johnson, a three-time NHRA Pro Stock world champion, has advanced to the final round in four consecutive events, winning two of them. That indicates that Johnson, who won NHRA Pro Stock titles in 1992, 1993 and 1995 in an Oldsmobile Cutlass, is finally coming to terms with the Firebird. ``Powerwise, we have exactly the same motors we ended last season with,'' said Johnson, who is using a 1,200 horsepower//500 cubic-inch GM Drag Race Competition Engine. ``It's trying to figure this car out.'' Here is the short course on the differences between the Cutlass and the Firebird, as delivered by Johnson: ``The Firebird is about an inch lower than the Cutlass, as far as ground to maximum height of the roof. It has a 6-inch-shorter wheelbase and a wider track width. The center of gravity is considerably different. And we run a completely different shock setup, spring rate and weight distribution than in the previous car.'' Johnson said that although the Firebird appears to be a ``slipperier car'' aerodynamically than the Cutlass, wind-tunnel tests indicate otherwise. ``Because we've got a different racehorse, it's a stimulus to our team,'' Johnson said. ``And the championship is definitely not out of the question.''  Lapping in Las Vegas Indianapolis 500 champion Buddy Lazier had never lapped on a 1.5-mile oval until Tuesday. On Wednesday afternoon, Lazier toured the new Las Vegas Motor Speedway at 217.383 mph to pace a handful of Indy Racing League teams testing as part of the track's ``National Media Day.'' Lazier, who drives for Hemelgarn Racing, bumped Mark Dismore of Team Menard off the practice ``pole.'' Dismore turned a lap at 213.532 mph Wednesday morning. Richie Hearn, who finished third in the Indy 500, posted a lap at 212.816 mph. The league's fifth and final race of 1996 is scheduled for Sept. 15 in Las Vegas. Three-time Indy 500 champion Johnny Rutherford of Fort Worth also toured the track, but in a passenger car. ``The track is deceiving because it looks like it has some bumps. But it's smooth as glass and the transitions are nice,'' said Rutherford, the league's special-projects coordinator. ``It looks like it's going to develop a character of its own with the (12-degree) banking. It's big and fast.''  De Ferran to F1? Second-year IndyCar driver Gil de Ferran, who drives for team owner Jim Hall of Midland, has been dousing rumors that he is contemplating a jump to Formula One. De Ferran was spotted at dinner with former Formula One champion Jackie Stewart during the IndyCar Detroit Grand Prix weekend. Stewart and his son, Paul, are assembling an Formula One team for 1997 that will be backed by Ford Motor Company. De Ferran, whose stock rose last weekend with a second-place finish on the road course in Portland, Ore., is fifth in IndyCar points. He won the season finale in Monterey, Calif., and was rookie of the year in 1995. De Ferran's ties to Stewart, Ford's worldwide ambassador, stem from a four-year association with Paul Stewart Racing in Europe. That is where de Ferran, who grew up in Brazil, cut his open-wheel racing teeth. ``It's natural people would connect us. Certainly I have a lot of respect for what Jackie is doing,'' said de Ferran, 28, who has two second-place finishes this season. ``I don't think it's a matter of if they're going to be successful; it's a matter of when. They have shown some interest in myself as a driver. But from there to have a signed contract is a long way. ``I'll certainly consider any formal approaches from them. But there has not been a formal offer. I'm happy here in America. I wouldn't have a problem if I spent the rest of my career racing here.'' De Ferran returns to the Grand Prix of Cleveland this weekend as the defending pole-winner.  Schroeder shreds 'em With victories in three of the past four events and two in a row, road-racing specialist Dorsey Schroeder is the hottest driver in the Sports Car Club of America's Trans-Am Championship. Schroeder, who has completed every lap in seven 1996 races, has opened a 17-point lead on Chevrolet's Jamie Galles. Round No.8 is scheduled for Saturday afternoon in Cleveland, and Schroeder would like to repeat some personal history. Schroeder's run to the 1989 Trans-Am title included a victory on the wide-open Burke Lakefront Airport course, which definitely suits his attack-at-all-angles style. ``I'm optimistic because we have a really, really good race car right now, better than I've had going into a race anywhere,'' Schroeder, 43, said of the Raybestos Ford Mustang owned by former series champion Tom Gloy. ``This car is doing an awfully good job of getting the power down. I've been playing this `inverted five' thing. But I can tell you for sure we're going to go for the outright pole for the first time in a long time at Cleveland.'' Schroeder was referring to a quirky SCCA rule that inverts the top five qualifiers. In other words, the fastest qualifier earns one bonus point for the pole, but has to start fifth and try to work to the front. Schroeder said that on a tight street course such as Detroit, it was smart to lay back and try to qualify fourth- or fifth-fastest in order to sit on the inverted pole. ``But this is an airport course, so you can be a little more aggressive and not worry about wrecking the car, because there's not much to hit,'' he said. ``The gamble's worth it. ``I haven't had a pole in about three years, and you kind of get the reputation you can't do it. I guarantee you, I can do it.''  Truckin' to please At the request of his boss, former NASCAR Winston Cup champion Rusty Wallace plans to work on his ``day off'' Sunday. The Cup series is idle for a weekend, and Wallace has accepted an invitation from business partner Roger Penske to compete in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series event at Penske's one-mile Nazareth (Pa.) Speedway. Although this is a one-shot deal, Wallace said he is not taking his truck-racing debut lightly. ``We're going to do it first-class,'' said Wallace, winner of the Winston Cup Miller 400 on Sunday at Penske's Michigan International Speedway. ``We're not going there just to make an appearance.'' Wallace said most of his Winston Cup pit crew will accompany him to Nazareth. And the meticulous Wallace said his black No. 2 Miller Beer Ford pickup has a killer paint job. ``Looks better than on the race car,'' he said. Wallace anticipates continued growth for the second-year truck series because it reaches an audience heretofore ignored by NASCAR. The series has been limited to tracks of one mile or less, mainly because of concerns about the lack of rear down force and stability of the trucks on super speedways, including the under-construction 1.5-mile Texas Motor Speedway in far north Fort Worth. ``I'm not saying they can't do it,'' Wallace said. ``If they go to Texas and run trucks, they (NASCAR) might say instead of running a 5-inch-tall rear spoiler, let's put a 61/2-inch spoiler on it like the Cup cars. And maybe we'll get all the down force we need, and the trucks will be stable. ``NASCAR can always change the rules. They'd have to, I think, to run the faster tracks.'' "63355"	"I"	"think"	" It's possible, of course, that Symington would save McCain the trouble and resign on his own. "63378"	"I"	"think"	" The Government's remaining arguments are, I think, readily rejected. The scope and force of the ``reserved powers'' and ``express delegation'' defenses which the plurality thinks inapplicable based on its view of the nature of the contracts at issue here, see ante, at 49-51 have not been well defined by our prior cases. The notion of ``reserved powers'' seems to stand principally for the proposition that certain core governmental powers cannot be surrendered, see, e.g., Stone v. Mississippi, 101 U. S. 814 (1880); thus understood, that doctrine would have no force where, as here, the private party to the contract does not seek to stay the exercise of sovereign authority, but merely requests damages for breach of contract. To the extent this Court has suggested that the notion of ``reserved powers'' contemplates, under some circumstances, nullification of even monetary governmental obligations pursuant to exercise of ``the federal police power or some other paramount power,'' Lynch v. United States, 292 U. S. 571, 579 (1934), I do not believe that regulatory measures designed to minimize what are essentially assumed commercial risks are the sort of ``police power'' or ``paramount power'' referred to. And whatever is required by the ``express delegation'' doctrine is to my mind satisfied by the statutes which the plurality identifies as conferring upon the various federal bank regulatory agencies involved in this case authority to enter into agreements of the sort at issue here, see ante, at 51-52. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199607.gz"
"63379"	"I"	"think"	" Finally, in my view the Government cannot escape its obligations by appeal to the so-called ``sovereign acts'' doctrine. That doctrine was first articulated in Court of Claims cases, and has apparently been applied by this Court in only a single case, our 3-page opinion in Horowitz v. United States, 267 U. S. 458, decided in 1925 and cited only once since, in a passing reference, see Nortz v. United States, 294 U. S. 317, 327 (1935). Horowitz holds that ``the United States when sued as a contractor cannot be held liable for an obstruction to the performance of (a) particular contract resulting from its public and general acts as a sovereign.'' 267 U. S., at 461. In my view the ``sovereign acts'' doctrine adds little, if anything at all, to the ``unmistakability'' doctrine, and is avoided whenever that one would be i.e., whenever it is clear from the contract in question that the Government was committing itself not to rely upon its sovereign acts in asserting (or defending against) the doctrine of impossibility, which is another way of saying that the Government had assumed the risk of a change in its laws. That this is the correct interpretation of Horowitz is made clear, I think, by our two principal cases of this century holding that the Government may not simply repudiate its contractual obligations, Lynch v. United States, 292 U. S. 571 (1934), and Perry v. United States, 294 U. S. 330 (1935). Those cases, which are barely discussed by the plurality's opinion, failed even to mention Horowitz. In both of them, as here, Congress specifically set out to abrogate the essential bargain of the contracts at issue and in both we declared such abrogation to amount to impermissible repudiation. See Lynch, supra, at 578-580; Perry, supra, at 350-354. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199607.gz"
"63402"	"I"	"think"	" ``It's the kind of thing that's sort of off to the side of our brains, I think,'' said Doug Hurst, a travel agent who, like many of those interviewed, said that security in his office building has been strengthened since federal authorities moved the bombing case to Denver. ``But the awareness of what could happen, it's definitely there, and you can't help but wonder ... anytime you hear a siren or an alarm or anything like that.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199607.gz"

Times News ServiceNo. 1863 Mon, July 8:  (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor.)  MUG OF THE WEEK !!!!!!  We will now be awarding a mug every Friday for the best joke, story, anecdote, whatever, of the week. (C'mon, admit it, you're excited!) Send by fax (212-556-3535) or via e-mail:  Dr. NYlite can now be reached by e-mail: nylite(at)nytimes.com (use ``at'' sign sted (at)).  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  The U.S. unemployment rate is at a six-year low. The issue voters must decide is whether the right people are out of work.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ``Earlier today, the blockbuster movie of the summer, Independence Day,' opened all over the country. As you know, the movie is about space aliens -- space aliens come to Earth and destroy the White House. Fortunately, at the time, President Clinton is shacked up at the Marriott, so he's o.k.''  ``If you're like me, do what I do. If you want to spend eight dollars to see a hostile alien...take a New York City cab ride.''  ``All I need I an apron, oven mitts and a spatula, and I'm telling you, I'm ready for sex!''  ``Do you like New York City when it's a little sleepy, when it's kind of empty? Yeah, I enjoy it. As a matter of fact, you know the guy who stands out in front of the Ed Sullivan Theater every day screaming obscenities at me? Well, he's not there today, but early this morning, he faxed me the finger from the Hamptons.''  ``I had a pretty good weekend. I hosted up at my Brentwood estate my anti-speeding fundraiser benefit.''  ``The New York Yankees announced earlier today that they have resigned slugger Daryl Strawberry. If you think about it in terms of baseball, it makes perfect sense because now with Steve Howe gone, on the roster there is room for a designated felon.''  ``Yesterday, Daryl Strawberry, they moved him up from AA to AAA, and he played a minor league baseball game yesterday in Columbus, hit two home runs...and despite the fact that the night before he only got one hour of sleep. Gosh! I wonder how he managed to stay awake?''  ``Earlier this week, Boris Yeltsin was re-elected President of Russia...And you know, I think, by re-electing Yeltsin, the Russian people are sending a very strong message. And that message is, We want a drunk guy in charge!'''  ``Yesterday, Bob Dole was in town here in New York City. He went over to see our good friends, Regis and Kathie Lee...Bob Dole told some stories about Cody...No, no, no, I'm talking about Buffalo Bill Cody.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, today is the 133rd anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg. A lot of people don't know this: this is the battle that made a war hero of Bob Dole.''  ``The one thing I think that people don't understand about the Fourth of July, when John Hancock was getting ready to sign the Declaration of Independence, Bob Dole said, Here, use my pen.'''  ``Bob Dole is now looking for a running mate. Bob Dole says he wants a running mate who is a ``10.'' Well, that's a very easy number for Bob Dole to remember because it also happens to be his Social Security number.''  ``Bob Dole is looking for a Vice President that is a ``10.'' When President Clinton is looking for a ``10,'' he's talking about a cocktail waitress at Hooters.''  ``People said that Bob Dole when he was on the Today' show continued to be a little cranky. In all fairness, I think I know what happened. He was on the Today' show -- yeah, he was cranky, he was upset. You know what happened -- Willard Scott forgot to wish him a happy 100th birthday.''  ``Here locally, it's a very festive day, Fourth of July. They have, Nathan's, out there in Coney Island, every year, has the hot dog eating competition. And this year's winner meets next week in the finals President Clinton.''  ``Do you know about the book that former FBI agent Gary Aldrich has written? It's just unbelievable! It's an insider look at the White House and the Clintons. And Hillary Clinton is being a little defensive about the book. She's saying that the book is a complete fabrication, should not be taken seriously -- you know, like her account of the Whitewater billing records.''  ``The book claims that Bill Clinton would sneak out of the White House at night to meet women. Right here you have the difference between Bill Clinton and Bob Dole: the only thing Bob Dole has ever been in bed with is the tobacco industry.''  ``This raises an interesting question: what has become of the FBI? A couple of weeks ago, we find out they let the White House have 700 confidential, personal files...And then a former agent, Gary Aldrich, writes the tell-all book about the Clintons. I'm telling you something, J. Edgar Hoover must be turning over in his dress.''  DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Ways Bob Dole Celebrated the Fourth of July''  10. While watching fireworks, was so overwhelmed with emotion he almost had a facial expression.  9. Requested moment of silence for friends he lost at Battle of Bunker Hill.  8. Marched in parade wearing Joe Camel costume.  7. Got confused, spent all morning hiding Easter eggs for the grandkids.  6. Smoked a joint and nailed a campaign worker -- I'm sorry, that's how President Clinton celebrated.  5. Every time Newt Gingrich looked the other way, spit watermelon seeds at his head.  4. Gathered everyone around the microwave to watch his pacemaker spark.  3. Played ``George and Martha'' with Elizabeth.  2. After having a few beers, took out his teeth and played them like castanets.  1. Same as always: kegs n' babes.  (MORE!) DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Fourth of July Movies Playing in Times Square''  10. ``Picnic in My Pants.''  9. ``George, Martha, Thomas and Ernesto.''  8. ``The Cable-Laying Guy.''  7. ``Washington's Other Monument.''  6. ``The British Are Coming! The British Are Coming!''  5. ``The Fondling Fathers.''  4. ``One if By Land, Two if Bisexual.''  3. ``The Slutty Professor.''  2. ``Don't Shoot Until You See the Whites of Their Thighs.''  1. ``Star-Spangled Hookers.''  (AND MORE STILL!) DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Signs Bob Dole is in Bed with the Tobacco Industry''  10. Posters for his rallies include the line, ``Free Marlboros for the kids!''  9. During speeches, pauses every few minutes to hit the ol' spittoon.  8. Named his cocker spaniels ``Philip'' and ``Morris.''  7. Claims there's no connection between cigarettes and cigarette burns.  6. His choice for new head of National Council on Physical Fitness: Keith Richards.  5. Campaign ads show him holding a beach ball with caption, ``Bob Dole: Alive with Pleasure.''  4. He's requested FBI files on everyone who uses ``The Patch.''  3. In the latest Marlboro billboards, check out the cranky old cowboy in the background.  2. His new campaign slogan: ``Fogies for Stogies.''  1. Has a Joe Camel tattoo on his ass.  YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS STUFF UP  Edward B. Ward, a truck driver from Richmond, Mich., said he came up with his ``combined urine guard and toilet trainer with target'' after his son had trouble toilet-training his children.  ``The boys just soaked the walls and ruined the bathroom,'' Ward said.  Ward's invention, which he designed with his daughter, Deborah A. Lucido, is a horseshoe-shaped piece of plastic, about 7 inches high, which attaches by suction cups to the inside of the toilet bowl. A target on the back of the guard hangs down about 4 inches into the toilet.  ``This gives them something to aim at and if they miss the toilet it stays in and goes in the toilet instead of the walls and the floors,'' Ward said.  Ward, who is looking to license his invention, received design patent 369,856.  _THE NEW YORK TIMES  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) Times News ServiceNo. 1863 Mon, July 8:  (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor.)  MUG OF THE WEEK !!!!!!  We will now be awarding a mug every Friday for the best joke, story, anecdote, whatever, of the week. (C'mon, admit it, you're excited!) Send by fax (212-556-3535) or via e-mail:  Dr. NYlite can now be reached by e-mail: nylite(at)nytimes.com (use ``at'' sign sted (at)).  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  The U.S. unemployment rate is at a six-year low. The issue voters must decide is whether the right people are out of work.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ``Earlier today, the blockbuster movie of the summer, Independence Day,' opened all over the country. As you know, the movie is about space aliens -- space aliens come to Earth and destroy the White House. Fortunately, at the time, President Clinton is shacked up at the Marriott, so he's o.k.''  ``If you're like me, do what I do. If you want to spend eight dollars to see a hostile alien...take a New York City cab ride.''  ``All I need I an apron, oven mitts and a spatula, and I'm telling you, I'm ready for sex!''  ``Do you like New York City when it's a little sleepy, when it's kind of empty? Yeah, I enjoy it. As a matter of fact, you know the guy who stands out in front of the Ed Sullivan Theater every day screaming obscenities at me? Well, he's not there today, but early this morning, he faxed me the finger from the Hamptons.''  ``I had a pretty good weekend. I hosted up at my Brentwood estate my anti-speeding fundraiser benefit.''  ``The New York Yankees announced earlier today that they have resigned slugger Daryl Strawberry. If you think about it in terms of baseball, it makes perfect sense because now with Steve Howe gone, on the roster there is room for a designated felon.''  ``Yesterday, Daryl Strawberry, they moved him up from AA to AAA, and he played a minor league baseball game yesterday in Columbus, hit two home runs...and despite the fact that the night before he only got one hour of sleep. Gosh! I wonder how he managed to stay awake?''  ``Earlier this week, Boris Yeltsin was re-elected President of Russia...And you know, I think, by re-electing Yeltsin, the Russian people are sending a very strong message. And that message is, We want a drunk guy in charge!'''  ``Yesterday, Bob Dole was in town here in New York City. He went over to see our good friends, Regis and Kathie Lee...Bob Dole told some stories about Cody...No, no, no, I'm talking about Buffalo Bill Cody.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, today is the 133rd anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg. A lot of people don't know this: this is the battle that made a war hero of Bob Dole.''  ``The one thing I think that people don't understand about the Fourth of July, when John Hancock was getting ready to sign the Declaration of Independence, Bob Dole said, Here, use my pen.'''  ``Bob Dole is now looking for a running mate. Bob Dole says he wants a running mate who is a ``10.'' Well, that's a very easy number for Bob Dole to remember because it also happens to be his Social Security number.''  ``Bob Dole is looking for a Vice President that is a ``10.'' When President Clinton is looking for a ``10,'' he's talking about a cocktail waitress at Hooters.''  ``People said that Bob Dole when he was on the Today' show continued to be a little cranky. In all fairness, I think I know what happened. He was on the Today' show -- yeah, he was cranky, he was upset. You know what happened -- Willard Scott forgot to wish him a happy 100th birthday.''  ``Here locally, it's a very festive day, Fourth of July. They have, Nathan's, out there in Coney Island, every year, has the hot dog eating competition. And this year's winner meets next week in the finals President Clinton.''  ``Do you know about the book that former FBI agent Gary Aldrich has written? It's just unbelievable! It's an insider look at the White House and the Clintons. And Hillary Clinton is being a little defensive about the book. She's saying that the book is a complete fabrication, should not be taken seriously -- you know, like her account of the Whitewater billing records.''  ``The book claims that Bill Clinton would sneak out of the White House at night to meet women. Right here you have the difference between Bill Clinton and Bob Dole: the only thing Bob Dole has ever been in bed with is the tobacco industry.''  ``This raises an interesting question: what has become of the FBI? A couple of weeks ago, we find out they let the White House have 700 confidential, personal files...And then a former agent, Gary Aldrich, writes the tell-all book about the Clintons. I'm telling you something, J. Edgar Hoover must be turning over in his dress.''  DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Ways Bob Dole Celebrated the Fourth of July''  10. While watching fireworks, was so overwhelmed with emotion he almost had a facial expression.  9. Requested moment of silence for friends he lost at Battle of Bunker Hill.  8. Marched in parade wearing Joe Camel costume.  7. Got confused, spent all morning hiding Easter eggs for the grandkids.  6. Smoked a joint and nailed a campaign worker -- I'm sorry, that's how President Clinton celebrated.  5. Every time Newt Gingrich looked the other way, spit watermelon seeds at his head.  4. Gathered everyone around the microwave to watch his pacemaker spark.  3. Played ``George and Martha'' with Elizabeth.  2. After having a few beers, took out his teeth and played them like castanets.  1. Same as always: kegs n' babes.  (MORE!) DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Fourth of July Movies Playing in Times Square''  10. ``Picnic in My Pants.''  9. ``George, Martha, Thomas and Ernesto.''  8. ``The Cable-Laying Guy.''  7. ``Washington's Other Monument.''  6. ``The British Are Coming! The British Are Coming!''  5. ``The Fondling Fathers.''  4. ``One if By Land, Two if Bisexual.''  3. ``The Slutty Professor.''  2. ``Don't Shoot Until You See the Whites of Their Thighs.''  1. ``Star-Spangled Hookers.''  (AND MORE STILL!) DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Signs Bob Dole is in Bed with the Tobacco Industry''  10. Posters for his rallies include the line, ``Free Marlboros for the kids!''  9. During speeches, pauses every few minutes to hit the ol' spittoon.  8. Named his cocker spaniels ``Philip'' and ``Morris.''  7. Claims there's no connection between cigarettes and cigarette burns.  6. His choice for new head of National Council on Physical Fitness: Keith Richards.  5. Campaign ads show him holding a beach ball with caption, ``Bob Dole: Alive with Pleasure.''  4. He's requested FBI files on everyone who uses ``The Patch.''  3. In the latest Marlboro billboards, check out the cranky old cowboy in the background.  2. His new campaign slogan: ``Fogies for Stogies.''  1. Has a Joe Camel tattoo on his ass.  YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS STUFF UP  Edward B. Ward, a truck driver from Richmond, Mich., said he came up with his ``combined urine guard and toilet trainer with target'' after his son had trouble toilet-training his children.  ``The boys just soaked the walls and ruined the bathroom,'' Ward said.  Ward's invention, which he designed with his daughter, Deborah A. Lucido, is a horseshoe-shaped piece of plastic, about 7 inches high, which attaches by suction cups to the inside of the toilet bowl. A target on the back of the guard hangs down about 4 inches into the toilet.  ``This gives them something to aim at and if they miss the toilet it stays in and goes in the toilet instead of the walls and the floors,'' Ward said.  Ward, who is looking to license his invention, received design patent 369,856.  _THE NEW YORK TIMES  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  The U.S. unemployment rate is at a six-year low. The issue voters must decide is whether the right people are out of work.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ``Earlier today, the blockbuster movie of the summer, Independence Day,' opened all over the country. Yeah, I enjoy it. As a matter of fact, you know the guy who stands out in front of the Ed Sullivan Theater every day screaming obscenities at me? Well, he's not there today, but early this morning, he faxed me the finger from the Hamptons.''  ``I had a pretty good weekend. I hosted up at my Brentwood estate my anti-speeding fundraiser benefit.''  ``The New York Yankees announced earlier today that they have resigned slugger Daryl Strawberry. If you think about it in terms of baseball, it makes perfect sense because now with Steve Howe gone, on the roster there is room for a designated felon.''  ``Yesterday, Daryl Strawberry, they moved him up from AA to AAA, and he played a minor league baseball game yesterday in Columbus, hit two home runs...and despite the fact that the night before he only got one hour of sleep. Gosh! I wonder how he managed to stay awake?''  ``Earlier this week, Boris Yeltsin was re-elected President of Russia...And you know, I think, by re-electing Yeltsin, the Russian people are sending a very strong message. It's an insider look at the White House and the Clintons. And Hillary Clinton is being a little defensive about the book. She's saying that the book is a complete fabrication, should not be taken seriously -- you know, like her account of the Whitewater billing records.''  ``The book claims that Bill Clinton would sneak out of the White House at night to meet women. I'm telling you something, J. Edgar Hoover must be turning over in his dress.''  DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Ways Bob Dole Celebrated the Fourth of July''  10. BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  The U.S. unemployment rate is at a six-year low. The issue voters must decide is whether the right people are out of work.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ``Earlier today, the blockbuster movie of the summer, Independence Day,' opened all over the country. As you know, the movie is about space aliens -- space aliens come to Earth and destroy the White House. Fortunately, at the time, President Clinton is shacked up at the Marriott, so he's o.k.''  ``If you're like me, do what I do. Well, he's not there today, but early this morning, he faxed me the finger from the Hamptons.''  ``I had a pretty good weekend. Gosh! A couple of weeks ago, we find out they let the White House have 700 confidential, personal files...And then a former agent, Gary Aldrich, writes the tell-all book about the Clintons. I'm telling you something, J. Edgar Hoover must be turning over in his dress.''  DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Ways Bob Dole Celebrated the Fourth of July''  10. The British Are Coming!''  5. ``The Fondling Fathers.''  4. ``One if By Land, Two if Bisexual.''  3. ``The Slutty Professor.''  2. ``Don't Shoot Until You See the Whites of Their Thighs.''  1. ``Star-Spangled Hookers.'' Claims there's no connection between cigarettes and cigarette burns.  6. His choice for new head of National Council on Physical Fitness: Keith Richards.  5. Campaign ads show him holding a beach ball with caption, ``Bob Dole: Alive with Pleasure.''  4. He's requested FBI files on everyone who uses ``The Patch.''  3. In the latest Marlboro billboards, check out the cranky old cowboy in the background.  2. His new campaign slogan: ``Fogies for Stogies.''  1. Has a Joe Camel tattoo on his ass.  YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS STUFF UP  Edward B. Ward, a truck driver from Richmond, Mich., said he came up with his ``combined urine guard and toilet trainer with target'' after his son had trouble toilet-training his children.  ``The boys just soaked the walls and ruined the bathroom,'' Ward said.  Ward's invention, which he designed with his daughter, Deborah A. Lucido, is a horseshoe-shaped piece of plastic, about 7 inches high, which attaches by suction cups to the inside of the toilet bowl. A target on the back of the guard hangs down about 4 inches into the toilet.  ``This gives them something to aim at and if they miss the toilet it stays in and goes in the toilet instead of the walls and the floors,'' Ward said.  Ward, who is looking to license his invention, received design patent 369,856.  _THE NEW YORK TIMES  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) WASHINGTON (w)  GUNS-CLINTON (Washington) _ President unveils pilot program to trace guns used in crimes through a computer database in an effort to crack down on illegal gun sales to minors. By Brian McGrory. 700 words.  MINIMUM-WAGE (Washington) _ Senate opens debate on 90-cent minimum wage increase that faces Clinton veto if Republicans succeed in exempting small businesses. By Chris Black. 850 words.  POLITICS (p)  POWELL-ROLE (Washington) _ Colin Powell says he does not plan to campaign for Bob Dole or any other GOP candidates and does not want a major role at the convention. By Michael Kranish.  REFORM-PARTY (Washington) _ Reform Party establishes ground rules for selecting its presidential candidate. Richard Lamm, former Colorado governor, expected to make bid. By Michael Rezendes. 750 words.  NATIONAL (a)  AIDS-VIRUS (Vancouver, B.C.) _ Evidence mounts that the number of AIDS virus particles in the blood determines a patient's chance for survival. By Richard Knox. 600 words.  LEWIS-SUIT (Boston) _ Prominent Boston cardiologist, who directed care for Henry Kissinger, to represent the medical profession in a tribunal that will decide whether Donna Harris Lewis can sue the doctors who treated her late husband, Celtics star Reggie Lewis. By John Ellement. 600 words.  FINANCIAL (f)  BANKS-MERGER (Undated) _ When Bank of Boston and BayBanks complete their merger, the new entity will be known as BankBoston. By Charles Stein.  PERSEPTIVE-SMITH (Undated) _ Jack Smith, second in command at Digital Equipment before retiring in 1993, to become president of Perseptive Biosystems. By Ronald Rosenberg.  SPORTS (s)  BBA-ALLSTARS (Philadelphia) _ Charles Nagy is a very good pitcher, perhaps, the best you'll see in the 67th All-Star baseball game. By Larry Whiteside.  w/  BBA-VAUGHN (Philadelphia) -- There is a natural charisma about Mo Vaughn that follows him everywhere he goes. Even among a team of All-Stars, he can make his presence felt. By Larry Whiteside.  BBA-REDSOX (Philadelphia) _ Dan Duquette is not at the All-Star game to touch the Liberty Bell, but to ring out a few deals. By Nick Cafardo.  BKN-CELTICS (Undated) _ The greatest talent contest in NBA history begins Tuesday. Within 48 to 72 hours, teams will likely have committed hundreds of millions of dollars to a handful of players. By Peter May.  RYAN-COLUMN (Undated) _ This is Phase II of the grand experiment known as The NBA Represents You And Me At The Olympics and You still are uncomfortable. By Bob Ryan.
