Times News ServiceNo. 1863 Mon, July 8:  (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor.)  MUG OF THE WEEK !!!!!!  We will now be awarding a mug every Friday for the best joke, story, anecdote, whatever, of the week. (C'mon, admit it, you're excited!) Send by fax (212-556-3535) or via e-mail:  Dr. NYlite can now be reached by e-mail: nylite(at)nytimes.com (use ``at'' sign sted (at)).  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  The U.S. unemployment rate is at a six-year low. The issue voters must decide is whether the right people are out of work.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ``Earlier today, the blockbuster movie of the summer, Independence Day,' opened all over the country. As you know, the movie is about space aliens -- space aliens come to Earth and destroy the White House. Fortunately, at the time, President Clinton is shacked up at the Marriott, so he's o.k.''  ``If you're like me, do what I do. If you want to spend eight dollars to see a hostile alien...take a New York City cab ride.''  ``All I need I an apron, oven mitts and a spatula, and I'm telling you, I'm ready for sex!''  ``Do you like New York City when it's a little sleepy, when it's kind of empty? Yeah, I enjoy it. As a matter of fact, you know the guy who stands out in front of the Ed Sullivan Theater every day screaming obscenities at me? Well, he's not there today, but early this morning, he faxed me the finger from the Hamptons.''  ``I had a pretty good weekend. I hosted up at my Brentwood estate my anti-speeding fundraiser benefit.''  ``The New York Yankees announced earlier today that they have resigned slugger Daryl Strawberry. If you think about it in terms of baseball, it makes perfect sense because now with Steve Howe gone, on the roster there is room for a designated felon.''  ``Yesterday, Daryl Strawberry, they moved him up from AA to AAA, and he played a minor league baseball game yesterday in Columbus, hit two home runs...and despite the fact that the night before he only got one hour of sleep. Gosh! I wonder how he managed to stay awake?''  ``Earlier this week, Boris Yeltsin was re-elected President of Russia...And you know, I think, by re-electing Yeltsin, the Russian people are sending a very strong message. And that message is, We want a drunk guy in charge!'''  ``Yesterday, Bob Dole was in town here in New York City. He went over to see our good friends, Regis and Kathie Lee...Bob Dole told some stories about Cody...No, no, no, I'm talking about Buffalo Bill Cody.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, today is the 133rd anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg. A lot of people don't know this: this is the battle that made a war hero of Bob Dole.''  ``The one thing I think that people don't understand about the Fourth of July, when John Hancock was getting ready to sign the Declaration of Independence, Bob Dole said, Here, use my pen.'''  ``Bob Dole is now looking for a running mate. Bob Dole says he wants a running mate who is a ``10.'' Well, that's a very easy number for Bob Dole to remember because it also happens to be his Social Security number.''  ``Bob Dole is looking for a Vice President that is a ``10.'' When President Clinton is looking for a ``10,'' he's talking about a cocktail waitress at Hooters.''  ``People said that Bob Dole when he was on the Today' show continued to be a little cranky. In all fairness, I think I know what happened. He was on the Today' show -- yeah, he was cranky, he was upset. You know what happened -- Willard Scott forgot to wish him a happy 100th birthday.''  ``Here locally, it's a very festive day, Fourth of July. They have, Nathan's, out there in Coney Island, every year, has the hot dog eating competition. And this year's winner meets next week in the finals President Clinton.''  ``Do you know about the book that former FBI agent Gary Aldrich has written? It's just unbelievable! It's an insider look at the White House and the Clintons. And Hillary Clinton is being a little defensive about the book. She's saying that the book is a complete fabrication, should not be taken seriously -- you know, like her account of the Whitewater billing records.''  ``The book claims that Bill Clinton would sneak out of the White House at night to meet women. Right here you have the difference between Bill Clinton and Bob Dole: the only thing Bob Dole has ever been in bed with is the tobacco industry.''  ``This raises an interesting question: what has become of the FBI? A couple of weeks ago, we find out they let the White House have 700 confidential, personal files...And then a former agent, Gary Aldrich, writes the tell-all book about the Clintons. I'm telling you something, J. Edgar Hoover must be turning over in his dress.''  DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Ways Bob Dole Celebrated the Fourth of July''  10. While watching fireworks, was so overwhelmed with emotion he almost had a facial expression.  9. Requested moment of silence for friends he lost at Battle of Bunker Hill.  8. Marched in parade wearing Joe Camel costume.  7. Got confused, spent all morning hiding Easter eggs for the grandkids.  6. Smoked a joint and nailed a campaign worker -- I'm sorry, that's how President Clinton celebrated.  5. Every time Newt Gingrich looked the other way, spit watermelon seeds at his head.  4. Gathered everyone around the microwave to watch his pacemaker spark.  3. Played ``George and Martha'' with Elizabeth.  2. After having a few beers, took out his teeth and played them like castanets.  1. Same as always: kegs n' babes.  (MORE!) DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Fourth of July Movies Playing in Times Square''  10. ``Picnic in My Pants.''  9. ``George, Martha, Thomas and Ernesto.''  8. ``The Cable-Laying Guy.''  7. ``Washington's Other Monument.''  6. ``The British Are Coming! The British Are Coming!''  5. ``The Fondling Fathers.''  4. ``One if By Land, Two if Bisexual.''  3. ``The Slutty Professor.''  2. ``Don't Shoot Until You See the Whites of Their Thighs.''  1. ``Star-Spangled Hookers.''  (AND MORE STILL!) DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Signs Bob Dole is in Bed with the Tobacco Industry''  10. Posters for his rallies include the line, ``Free Marlboros for the kids!''  9. During speeches, pauses every few minutes to hit the ol' spittoon.  8. Named his cocker spaniels ``Philip'' and ``Morris.''  7. Claims there's no connection between cigarettes and cigarette burns.  6. His choice for new head of National Council on Physical Fitness: Keith Richards.  5. Campaign ads show him holding a beach ball with caption, ``Bob Dole: Alive with Pleasure.''  4. He's requested FBI files on everyone who uses ``The Patch.''  3. In the latest Marlboro billboards, check out the cranky old cowboy in the background.  2. His new campaign slogan: ``Fogies for Stogies.''  1. Has a Joe Camel tattoo on his ass.  YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS STUFF UP  Edward B. Ward, a truck driver from Richmond, Mich., said he came up with his ``combined urine guard and toilet trainer with target'' after his son had trouble toilet-training his children.  ``The boys just soaked the walls and ruined the bathroom,'' Ward said.  Ward's invention, which he designed with his daughter, Deborah A. Lucido, is a horseshoe-shaped piece of plastic, about 7 inches high, which attaches by suction cups to the inside of the toilet bowl. A target on the back of the guard hangs down about 4 inches into the toilet.  ``This gives them something to aim at and if they miss the toilet it stays in and goes in the toilet instead of the walls and the floors,'' Ward said.  Ward, who is looking to license his invention, received design patent 369,856.  _THE NEW YORK TIMES  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) I'm telling you something, J. Edgar Hoover must be turning over in his dress.''  DAVID-LETTERMAN ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  ``Ways Bob Dole Celebrated the Fourth of July''  10. The NYT frontpage advisory, with layout description, will move by 7:30 p.m. ET. The NYT News Service Night Supervisor is Pat Ryan (212-556-1927).  NY-SCHOOLS-PRESIDENT (New York) _ The mayor hints he might be leaning toward backing Board of Education member William Thompson Jr. to take over the panel's top job overseeing the million-student school system.  NY-SCHOOLS-MAYOR (Albany, N.Y.) _ By mounting a successful coup against the president of the Board of Education, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani achieved a victory through backroom politicking.  PETITION-GATHERERS (Woodstock, Ga.) _ At one time, political volunteers collected signatures to get an issue or an insurgent candidate on the ballot. They acted out of ideology, party loyalty, the expectation of a patronage reward or a commitment to a particular candidate. That breed isn't extinct, but it is endangered, as more and more are paid to collect signatures. By Ernest Tollerson.  ISRAEL-GAZA (Gaza) _ In Jerusalem and Washington, people ask whether Benjamin Netanyahu will withdraw from the Golan Heights, share Jerusalem or permit the Palestinians a state. In the teeming Jabaliya refugee camp here, the men squatting by the side of an unpaved and cluttered street ask only one thing: Will he lift the ``closure?'' By Serge Schmemann.  With map.  YUGO-SERBIA-ECON (Belgrade, Serbia) _ The deep economic and political crisis brewing in Yugoslavia: The break-up of Yugoslavia in 1991 destroyed its industrial sector, and now the central bank's hard currency is almost gone. If things do not improve soon _ and there are few signs they will _ the president of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, could face ``serious political unrest within six to nine months,'' according to U.S. intelligence reports. By Chris Hedges.  Reefers:  TURKEY-POLITICS (Undated) _ In a break with Turkey's 73-year record of zealous secularism, the Turkish Parliament gives narrow approval to a coalition government led by an Islamic party that has campaigned to restore the country's Muslim identity. By Celestine Bohlen.  NAACP (Charlotte, N.C.) _ Addressing an organization that has been embroiled in internal strife, Kweisi Mfume, the new leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, says he will ``fight like hell'' any attempts to sow discord within the civil rights organization. By Steven A. Holmes. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960708.0560 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-SPOT-BUDGET-BOS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> For Release TUESDAY AMs, July 9, 1996  The Boston Globe plans to move the following stories for use by NYTimes News Service clients. "64188"	"I"	"think"	" ``Plus, there aren't many times in your life when you get to turn a page to a brand new chapter. If you keep trying to write the same old chapter, how much headway are you making? And here we are, each of us with an opportunity to do things we've always wanted to do but never had the time or focus to get around to. We would be remiss, I think, to blow an opportunity like this.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199607.gz"

Miramax is distributing the film in the United States. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199607.gz"

"64416"	"they"	"think"	" ``Everyone will always be fascinated by women who will go the distance,'' Michael Kors says. ``Most people have their tail between their legs and have less nerve. "65330"	"I"	"think"	" A. You could insulate the chimney in the attic, but it won't do much good because its heat is insignificant. Your problem is, I think, the soffit vents; those two-inch holes do almost no good. What you need is a continuous opening two inches wide going the full length of each soffit, and covered with a louvered cover. And, make sure the ridge vent is actually venting. There should be a two-inch-wide opening in the roof on each side of the ridge board. If that isn't done, the vent will not vent. Sounds silly, but it has happened. To check, inspect the ridge from inside the attic; you may not see daylight, but you should see where the cut in the roof was made on each side of the ridge board. Or, light a match, blow it out and hold it near the ridge; the air ciruclation should move that smoke quickly. Naturally, the usual caveat: Be careful using matches in the house, attic or anyplace else. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199607.gz"

If you have questions, call Judy Holland or Eric Rosenberg at 202-298-6320.  (Slugline includes the ``HNS'' tag.)  NATIONAL NEWS (``a'' category)  GAY-FAMILY (San Francisco) _ Assemblyman Pete Knight, leader of the state Legislature's battle to outlaw gay marriage, revealed this week that he has a gay son and lost a gay brother to AIDS. By CAROL NESS.  CENSUS-CHANGES (San Francisco) _ With Census 2000 just four years away, a war is raging over whether to subject a nation of 250 million mobile people to an old-fashioned nose count or try the more newfangled idea of statistical sampling. By VICKI HADDOCK.  PRIMATE-CARETAKER (San Antonio) _ Since 1978, Wallace Swett has devoted his life to 359 cast-off chimps, orangutans, monkeys and apes at Primarily Primates, which he says is the first and largest sanctuary of its kind, set in the hills of far northwestern Bexar County near Leon Springs, Texas. By ROY BRAGG. (A photo is available in the Hearst folder on the Weick photo data base.)  IMMIGRANTS-CITIZENSHIP (San Francisco) _ Many immigrants are worried that federal and state welfare overhaul _ as well as growing xenophobia _ will cost them benefits and make it harder for noncitizens to live comfortably. Increasing numbers of them are becoming citizens. By JULIAN GUTHRIE.  POLITICAL NEWS (``p'' category)  CLINTON-CALIFORNIA (San Francisco) _ This Thursday marks Clinton's 27th trip to California as president _ surpassing the number of visits made by former California Gov. Ronald Reagan during his eight years in the White House. By CARA MARINUCCI.  BUSINESS &AMP; FINANCE (``f'' category)  PHOTO-SOFTWARE (San Francisco) _ Live Picture Inc. of Soquel, Calif., has developed software that lets computer users view, edit and print photographs on their home computers. By LOUIS TRAGER.  KENWOOD-KORBEL (San Francisco) _ Defying the adage ``Never mix drinks,'' the owner of Korbel Champagne Cellars is getting closer to buying half of Kenwood Vineyards for a price estimated as high as $24 million. By WENDY TANAKA.  TRAVEL (``t'' category)  RUSSIA-TRAVEL (Moscow) _ Perhaps no other country has affected Americans so directly _ and been as misunderstood _ as Russia and the former Soviet Union. RUSSIA-CZAR'S-PALACE (St. Petersburg, Russia) _ Just outside St. Petersburg, in a village alternately called Pushkin and Czarskoe Selo, sits a pale yellow palace that stands as a monument to both the glory and the shame of Russia's past. By JOE STINEBAKER. (Goes with: RUSSIA-TRAVEL.)  TRAVEL-DRINKING (San Francisco) _ The last thing I want to do here is glamorize, or even condone, drinking to excess. It's bad for your health, it's too easy to make a world-class fool of yourself and it's no fun to view the world the next day through bloodshot, hungover eyes. But most of us, I think, have found ourselves being swept up in this situation while traveling. "72754"	"I"	"think"	" You might take several approaches to this problem. The worst, I think, is to position the 403(b) portfolio more aggressively. For example, you might swap the annuity for more stock exposure _ hoping to exceed that 10 percent growth. But with the market sky-high right now, and with you so close to retirement, that is a very risky approach _ in fact, at your age most people are realigning their portfolios in the opposite direction, moving down from growth to growth and income funds, from growth and income to balanced, or from balanced to fixed-income funds. I think you should take that approach. I suggest you move about 40 percent of the 403(b) account to funds in the growth and income, equity income, and balanced category, leaving 20 percent in growth, 10 percent in balanced, and leaving the annuity (and your ongoing contributions to it) as is. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199609.gz"

The gap between the two, a gauge of investor confidence in the U.S. financial system, was unchanged at 54 basis points. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19961002.0565 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-LEAH-PERSONALS-SFCHRON) </DATELINE> <TEXT> (Eds: This story also moved in the ``a'' national news file) By LEAH GARCHIK c.1996 San Francisco Chronicle  MICHAEL MILKEN, THE MUSICAL  Karole Armitage's ``The Predator's Ball,'' a multimedia show based on the life of Michael Milken, will be performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's New Wave Festival this month.  The work, which W calls ``a hyper-stylized synthesis of ballet, fashion, music, video and classic Greek drama,'' describes Milken's rise to the top of the financial world.  It incorporates music by Philip Johnston, David Shea and DJ Ski of Jazzmatazz; stage design by David Salle with Jeff Koons; costumes by Hugo Boss, Debra Moises and Pilar Limosner; and a 44-member cast that includes actors playing Carl Icahn, Ted Turner, T. Boone Pickens, Henry Kravis, Ronald Perelman, Stephen Wynn, Oscar Wyatt, Irwin Jacobs, Victor Posner, Nelson Peltz, Rupert Murdoch and Kirk Kerkorian. Armitage interviewed many of them in preparing the work.  She says the play's structure is modeled after ``Bacchae'' by Euripides, including the use of a Greek chorus of hip-hop rappers.  ``In the end,'' says Armitage, ``it's the archetypal story of a young, arrogant character who wants to change the world, but is taught by fate that, unlike the gods, man is not limitless.''  Armitage says Milken's story ``is what America is all about: Who's going to make the most money with the newest ideas in the fastest possible way. Let's face it. America is the '80s. And the '80s are back.''  WHO SAID WHAT  ``If you live in Hollywood and all you see is pregnant people around here, and really narcissistic pregnant people, that are convinced they're going to have this majestic child ... it's just hideous. And I know if I were fertile, I'd be just like them. Furthermore, these people don't even raise their babies out here. They have some Third World woman teaching their kid how to walk for four bucks an hour while they're here pitching me story ideas. We're all in hell, baby.''  _ ``Grace Under Fire'' star Brett Butler, on ``Access Hollywood.''  ``I need to do publicity to promote my films. The usual stuff is fine, but when the interviewers start getting into my opinions, I think, Oh, I'm 26, what the hell do I know? It's ridiculous. And it bothers me when I read articles about young actors and athletes who have these opinions about various things. They say things that are so stupid. I'm sure I've said a lot of dumb things in a lot of interviews. As far as politics and stuff go, I've got thoughts, but they're just things I think. I don't have what I consider to be well-formed ideas.''  _ Actor Chris O'Donnell in Playboy.  LUXURY TAX  A survey taken by Fodor Travel Publications has determined that the worst restaurant grievance of American travelers is air hand dryers in the bathroom. Twenty percent of 500 respondents were more peeved about this than anything else. Rounding out the top five: room temperatures too high or too low, waiters paying more attention to other diners, waiting too long for water refills, and too-small portions.  _ Damien Hirst, the British artist whose controversial works include a Plexiglas box containing a whole dead cow preserved in formaldehyde, has announced plans to open a restaurant in North London with chef Marco Pierre White.  l  HOW TO HAVE SOME PERFECTLY WONDERFUL TIMES  Behavioral Health Consultants sounds like the name of an outfit that teaches you how to floss your teeth, but in reality, its counselors are professional daters. They are employed to go out with clients and then make honest evaluations of their dating skills.  Company head Bart Ellis, a social worker, told Marie Claire magazine that he's fussy about his staff. ``We prefer people at university level, able to impartially judge a client's social abilities and give an assessment our psychologists can work with.''  After several dates, the psychologists sit down with the clients and give them some straightforward advice. The average customer is a person who has no trouble getting first dates but rarely gets beyond that.  Among the most common findings for male clients: They talk too much about past dates; they talk too much about themselves; they're too needy or desperate; they try too hard to impress.  Among the most common findings for female clients: They mentally march every man up the aisle; they tend to burst into tears; they dress inappropriately; they trash their ex-boyfriends.  ``It's scary being assessed by someone while you're ordering dinner,'' said Dawn, a client. ``But my date was like a regular guy you'd meet at the grocery store. And my assessment wasn't about what a horrible human being I am. It was all really positive.'' </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19961002.0566 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-SPOT-BUDGET-COX ) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The Cox News Service budget for Wednesday, October 2, 1996.  MIDEAST SUMMIT  MIDEAST-SUMMIT _ WASHINGTON _ The Middle East summit ended Wednesday with Israeli and Palestinian leaders failing to settle their differences, though President Clinton announced the two sides had agreed to step up peace talks beginning Sunday. (Deans).  EDs: Cox photos will move to illustrate this story.  MIDEAST-ISRAEL _ MEVASSERET ZION, Israel _ The enduring political rift among Israeli Jews resurfaced after the sudden violence that left 56 Palestinians and 15 Israeli soldiers dead last week. As he returns from the Washington summit, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is under renewed pressure to fulfill two seemingly contradictory pledges: no concessions to Yasser Arafat and the Palestinians, but a continuation of the peace process. An overwhelming majority of Israelis want the peace process with the Palestinians to continue and an increasing number are questioning Netanyahu's performance. (Holmes).  WASHINGTON  FLAGS _ WASHINGTON _ A nasty fight has broken out over who will get the business of selling the U.S. government millions of dollars worth of American flags to be used honoring deceased veterans of the Armed Forces. (Nesmith 860). MOVED.  EDs: Photos, COX1-COX2, have MOVED to illustrate this story.  COMMENTARY  MURRAY-COLUMN _ KILKENNY, Ireland _ Danville House, just a mile outside the medieval town of Kilkenny in Southeast Ireland, looks like something out of a movie, picturesque as it is. (Murray 500). MOVED.  STEIN-COLUMN _ When Israel signed peace treaties with Egypt and Jordan, those agreements did not require finding formulas for sharing land. Now, with Israel and the Palestinians seekings ways to share portions of the same land, more political will, courage, and vision is required than emerged in past breakthroughs toward peace. By Kenneth Stein, professor of Middle Eastern History and Political Science at Emory University in Atlanta. MOVED.  For more information, call:  Night news editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316. COMMENTARY  MURRAY-COLUMN _ LUFKIN, Texas _ Most all of us have a book in us. The problem is getting it out of us. Rick Pezdirtz, I think, has found the perfect inspiration. He knew that if he didn't get his book finished God was going to get him. So it is, just in time for Christmas, that we have ``Promises Kept _ Memoirs of a Missionary Priest,'' the autobiography of Father Fred Julien as told to Rick Pezdirtz. The book has been almost 15 years in the making _ ever since Pezdirtz, a fallen-away sportswriter, made a promise to Father Julien, his priest since boyhood, that he would write his life story. Be careful what you promise a man of God. God is listening. (Murray). MOVED.  There are no stories scheduled out of the Cox Washington Bureau at this time. The following is a checklist of COX enterprises stories MOVED in advance for the weekend, Dec. 14-16:  Moved Tuesday:  NUNN  NUNN-POLITICS  NUNN-PERSONAL  NUNN-Q&AMP;A  Moved Wednesday:  NUNN-TIMELINE  NUNN-ACCOMPLISHMENTS  Moved Thursday:  GLASS-COLUMN  TEEPEN-COLUMN  KLEINBERG-COLUMN  POLMONEY-LIST  Moved Friday:  BETHLEHEM-BLUES  POLMONEY-AMEND  Checklist of COX photos that moved to illustrate these stories:  COX4 of Friday. With BETHLEHEM-BLUES.  For more information, contact:  Weekend duty editor Rick Christie, (301) 352-8313. "81329"	"I"	"think"	" ``The talks are at a critical juncture, I think,'' Clinton said, adding that the ``situation is full of tension and full of frustration.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81340"	"I"	"think"	" Thomas said the court had adopted, in Griffin vs. Illinois and similar cases, ``an equalizing notion of the Equal Protection Clause that would, I think, have startled the 14th Amendment's Framers.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81369"	"I"	"think"	" ``This, I think, is a breakthrough of great significance for China,'' Bottelier. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81512"	"I"	"think"	" ``I don't think I would be a very good elected politician, because I'm too interested in a private life,'' Nye says. ``I admire the people who are willing to do it, but when I look at friends who neglect their families for the sake of rising to higher levels, I think, `This is a tragedy.' To rise to the top you have to be ruthless.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81623"	"I"	"think"	" ``So many things could have gone wrong,'' she said. ``When I was trying to get out of the plane, with the injury to my back, I could have made some bad move and paralyzed myself. Just the impact from the plane, I think, `Wow, I could have lost my vision.' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81648"	"I"	"think"	" ``It's a form of informal learning, and that, I think, has diminished substantially,'' he said. ``When informal learning declines, formal learning must take its place.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81869"	"I"	"think"	" ``The main issue for gay people is the closet _ 60 percent of our readers want the magazine delivered in a dark wrapper,'' Ms. Petit said. ``The idea of reaching any mass audience of gay people with any kind of information, I think, is a radical thing to do.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81923"	"I"	"think"	" But whenever I see things like that, I think, ``Seriously, who can afford it?'' (Actually, first I think, ``Cool! Wish I had one.'' Then I move on to more pressing concerns.) </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81939"	"you"	"think"	" ``One of the charges leveled against the play is that she's mean to these students,'' says Dunaway. ``At one point in rehearsal, Terrence said if she doesn't set high enough standards for these students, she's going to make them mediocre. So, on one level, you think, `God, isn't she mean.' But you have to go higher and be firm and be strong and I think she has all this.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"81953"	"I"	"think"	" ``The story of this book is how artists get pulled away from their art and whatever makes their art. Joffrey Ballet was often overlooked, in part, I think, because it was so American. Little was known about Bob Joffrey. That is why it took 6{ years to write this book.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"82003"	"I"	"think"	" Asked if some of the hostages have succumbed to a type of ``Stockholm Syndrome,'' in which hostages begin to identify with their captors, Kieren Metcalfe, who spoke during a press conference at the Canadian embassy, said: ``I'm not sure if anybody necessarily took sides with the people involved, but I think many people developed some respect for these people .... While nobody, I think, could support what they're trying to do, and certainly not the methods they used, they conducted themselves very well.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"82036"	"we"	"think"	" Three actors play Helfgott as a boy, a fragile adolescent and a grown man, respectively. It's Geoffrey Rush who'll be remembered as the adult Helfgott. He delivers what not only is the performance of the year, but one of the great picking-up-the-pieces performances, period. Mind and mouth racing, he lurches out of the rain into a restaurant late one rainy night, sputtering, we think, incoherently. We quickly realize, however, that he's making perfect sense, delivering a running commentary not only on what he's seeing and thinking, but on himself. Mordant and ironic, shaky after years inside the institution into which he collapsed under the strain of rejection by his tyrannical father, his scattered state actually represents a turnaround, a rejoining of the world. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
"82081"	"I"	"think"	" One more thing, said Clay, the veteran of a playoff disaster that few Patriots even could imagine, ``I haven't talked to the guys yet about last year, but I will. Just to let 'em know what can happen when you're not at that next level.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19961224.0680 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's N.Y. Times Photo Full picture package, moving 12/24/96.  NYT Picture clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on NewsCom at 305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling 212-556-4204.  (NYT21) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NY-HOMELESS-PROFILE, 12-24 -- Lamont McClam carries his found cardboard to a site on Fifth Avenue where he spends his nights. At right, MClam puts a lot of effort into constructing his ``bed'' every night in a corner of the entrance to the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. McClam commutes to a regular, minimum-wage job in Long Island City. He doesn't absolutely have to live in the box. But he has a clear goal: to save $50 a week so he can reunite with his estranged wife and two daughters who moved to Florida. (Edward Keating/New York Times Photo)  (NYT20) VILLA EL SALVADOR, Peru -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- PERU-HOSTAGES-POOR-2, 12-24 -- Felicita Fuentes Torres hunts through a garbage dump for empty cans and bottles to resell. ``God knows, we don't need more violence,'' says the 44-year-old Indian woman, who says she was trying to earn a few extra centavos to put together a decent Christmas dinner for her family. ``I don't have the education to understand if the guerrillas or the government help us or not. All I know is we need food, water and light.'' (New York Times Photo)  (NYT19) VILLA EL SALVADOR, Peru -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- PERU-HOSTAGES-POOR-1, 12-24 -- In Villa el Salvador, an impoverished shantytown not far from downtown Lima, Ernesto Somoza Meza roasts a pig. While people here voiced little if any sympathy for the rebels, they also expressed little empathy for the well-heeled coterie of hostages, all of whom have wealth unimaginable by Peruvian standards. (New York Times Photo)  (NYT18) CLARK, N.J. -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- KINDERCARE-KKR-CLR, 12-24 -- The chain that operates this Kindercare day care center in Clark, says it promotes ``industry-leading education and quality standards.'' But how many parents can afford it? While more money to subsidize day care is clearly necessary to meet the needs of lower-income families, no level of government is likely to aim much money in the direction of Kindercare and other centers that cater to the middle class. (Laura Pedrick/New York Times Photo)  (NYT17) FOUNTAIN VALLEY, Calif. -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- KINGSTON-BONUS-CLR, 12-24 -- Employees of Kingston Technology, who will share $100 million in bonuses, celebrate at a holiday party. ``What makes or breaks a company is not one or two people, it's a team,'' says John Tu, a founder of Kingston Technology, the world's biggest independent maker of computer memory boards. ``So you have to share. They work just as hard as you do, probably harder. It's simple. It's common sense.'' (Davis Barber/New York Times Photo)  (NYT16) CANTON, Ohio -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- CANTON-CHRISTMAS-CLR, 12-24 -- Keeping a holiday tradition in Canton, a volunteer cast ended the final scene of ``A Christmas Carol'' last Sunday at the Cultural Center, with Jimmy Jeffries playing Tiny Tim, and Nick Berry as Scrooge. At the Hoover vacuum cleaner factory in North Canton, left, a glowing Christmas tree signals the company's longtime commitment. (Scott Heckel/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT15) NEW ORLEANS -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NEW-ORLEANS-GROCERY-CLR, 12-24 -- ``New Orleans won't be New Orleans without Schwegmann's, `` Wilda Anthony says on a shopping trip with her husband, Willie. For 127 years, the family-owned Schwegmann supermarket chain has been a part of real life in New Orleans, a part of the city's vocabulary, its politics, even its fashion. But now the chain's owner, John Schwegmann, has apparently cut a deal to sell the struggling business. (Lee Celano/New York Times Photo)  (NYT14) TEXUIXTLA, Mexico -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- MEXICO-CHRISTMAS-VILLAGE-CLR, 12-24 -- At Christmas, Tehuixtla comes to life because many residents who have moved to the New York area return, like Juan Ramon Palafox, his wife, Elvira, and their children, Ulises, 6, and Jenny, 2, who live in Newburgh. Reflecting this annual cycle, Mexico's highways, airports and bus terminals have become jammed in recent weeks with homeward-bound travelers.(Keith Dannemiller/New York Times Photo)  (NYT13) WASHINGTON -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- PELL-RETIRE-EDUC, 12-24 -- Senator Claiborne Pell, seated before a portrait of himself as a boy with his father, was the impetus behind the Pell educational grants. After 36 years in the Senate, the Rhode Island democrat who wrote the legislation creating national endowments for arts and humanities is retiring. (Stephen Crowley/New York Times Photo)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- LORING-XMAS-CLR, 12-24 -- John Loring, Tiffany's design director, lights candles on a table set for Christmas entertaining. ``Cooking is a gift you give to other people,'' says Loring. His Christmas Eve supper party has become a tradition. As with most traditions, it simply grew from a nice idea - looking after stray friends who might otherwise celebrate the holiday in impersonal restaurants or grazing on takeout food. (Philip Greenberg/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT11) SEATTLE -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NATIONS-TABLE-CLR-2, 12-24 -- It's easy to spot the regular diners at the Flying Fish Restaurant, Bar and Grill in Seattle. They're the ones diving into platters of Dungeness crab. Christine Keff, the owner and chef, has made Flying Fish into one of the most non-traditional, yet popular, new area restaurants. By specializing in fresh seafood with a Pan-Asian flavor, she has set herself apart. (Doug Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT10) CHICAGO -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NATIONS-TABLE-CLR-1, 12-24 -- Francios Kwaku-Dongo with the brick oven style pizza that Spago is known for. Wolfgang Puck has brought his Spago restaurant concept to Chicago. Kwaku-Dongo, who had been the executive chef at the Spago in Los Angeles for five years, says in the opening weeks the restaurant has had to revise the size of its portions. ``Maybe it's the cold weather, but here we have had to increase the amount of pasta on the plates.'' (Todd Buchanan/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT9) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- MEXICAN-FEAST-CLR, 12-24 -- While speaking on the phone, Christy Haubegger, coordinates a tamale assembly line for her annual Mexican Christmas party. ``It's like a labor of love,'' says Ms. Haubegger, 28. ``And by the time Christmas rolls around again next year, you have forgotten how labor-intensive it was last year.''(Edward Keating/New York Times Photo)  (NYT8) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- HOSPITAL-DOGS-2-CLR, 12-24 -- Destiny, a golden retriever visits Monsarriti Maldonado, a patient at St. Vincent's hospital. Destiny is volunteering in St. Vincent's new research project, in which visits to geriatric patients from human and dog teams are monitored to see whether they decrease depression, isolation and loneliness. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT7) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- HOSPITAL-DOGS-1-CLR, 12-24 -- Destiny, a golden retriever, works in animal-assisted therapy programs in nursing homes and rehabilitation centers. Here she sits patiently while getting her picture taken for a St. Vincent's Hospital identification card. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)  (NYT6) BOSTON -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- BOND-FUNDS-BOS-CLR, 12-24 -- The action on the floor of the Fidelity Investments bond trading operation. In the 1990s, stock funds have consistently outperformed bond funds, often by a wide margin. Bonds and bond funds make particularly good sense for investors who may need access to their money in a few years and for older people approaching retirement age. (John Tlumacki/Boston Globe Photo)  (NYT5) BRETTON, N.H. -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TRAVEL-BRITISH-SKIERS-CLR, 12-24 -- ``Skiers in the Alps struggle with the concept of a queue,'' says Christine Roberts, a resident of a London suburb. ``They don't appear to understand that there's another way to reach a ski lift than over the skis or bodies of others.'' Ms. Roberts skiing at Bretton Woods last Monday. (Boston Globe Photo)  (NYT4) SEATTLE -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- BALLET-JOFFREY-SPI-CLR, 12-24 -- Los Angeles dance critic Sasha Anawalt talks about her book ``The Joffrey Ballet,'' during a recent interview. ``The story of this book is how artists get pulled away from their art and whatever makes their art,'' explains Ms. Anawalt. ``Joffrey Ballet was often overlooked, in part, I think, because it was so American.'' (Philip Webber/Seattle Post-Intelligencer Photo)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TOOLS-SPI-2-CLR, 12-24 -- Dave Englund has the world's largest collection of fine finishing planes made 250 years ago by the earliest known toolmakers in Anglo-America. He polishes one of his most recent purchases, a $4000 Nicholson molding plane. Part of Englund's collection, right, includes a brace and bit set fashioned from a revolutionary war American Brown Bess musket bayonet. The set sits atop a wooden chest dated 1776. (Mike Urban/Seattle Post-Intelligencer Photo) *LITE  (NYT2) UNDATED -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TOOLS-SPI-1-CLR, 12-24 -- Coachmakers were the elite woodworkers of the colonial era. Their tools, like this plane, most of which were made by the craftsman, were designed to fit the tight compound curves of a coach. ``These tools are works of art themselves,'' says Dave Englund, 54, a former industrial-arts teacher, now has the world's largest collection of such tools. (Mike Urban/Seattle Post-Intelligencer Photo)  (NYT1) PHOENIX -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TEMPS-BACKLASH-AZR-CLR, 12-23 -- At Mesa Community College, temporary, or adjunct staff members outnumber the permanent employees. The college has 788 adjunct instructors and a permanent staff of 239. Wendy Perkins, who is a ``contract instructor'' at the college, stands in front of a bulletin board in the hallway of one of the college's buildings. (Arizona Republic Photo)  N.Y. Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19961224.0681 type=story > <HEADLINE> JAPAN'S BONDS FALL AFTER CENTRAL BANK CUTS BACK BOND PURCHASES </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> Tokyo, Dec. 25 (Bloomberg) (BC-JAPAN-BONDS-BLOOM) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"

While more money to subsidize day care is clearly necessary to meet the needs of lower-income families, no level of government is likely to aim much money in the direction of Kindercare and other centers that cater to the middle class. (Laura Pedrick/New York Times Photo)  (NYT17) FOUNTAIN VALLEY, Calif. -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- KINGSTON-BONUS-CLR, 12-24 -- Employees of Kingston Technology, who will share $100 million in bonuses, celebrate at a holiday party. ``What makes or breaks a company is not one or two people, it's a team,'' says John Tu, a founder of Kingston Technology, the world's biggest independent maker of computer memory boards. ``So you have to share. They work just as hard as you do, probably harder. It's simple. It's common sense.'' (Davis Barber/New York Times Photo)  (NYT16) CANTON, Ohio -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- CANTON-CHRISTMAS-CLR, 12-24 -- Keeping a holiday tradition in Canton, a volunteer cast ended the final scene of ``A Christmas Carol'' last Sunday at the Cultural Center, with Jimmy Jeffries playing Tiny Tim, and Nick Berry as Scrooge. At the Hoover vacuum cleaner factory in North Canton, left, a glowing Christmas tree signals the company's longtime commitment. (Scott Heckel/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT15) NEW ORLEANS -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NEW-ORLEANS-GROCERY-CLR, 12-24 -- ``New Orleans won't be New Orleans without Schwegmann's, `` Wilda Anthony says on a shopping trip with her husband, Willie. For 127 years, the family-owned Schwegmann supermarket chain has been a part of real life in New Orleans, a part of the city's vocabulary, its politics, even its fashion. But now the chain's owner, John Schwegmann, has apparently cut a deal to sell the struggling business. (Lee Celano/New York Times Photo)  (NYT14) TEXUIXTLA, Mexico -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- MEXICO-CHRISTMAS-VILLAGE-CLR, 12-24 -- At Christmas, Tehuixtla comes to life because many residents who have moved to the New York area return, like Juan Ramon Palafox, his wife, Elvira, and their children, Ulises, 6, and Jenny, 2, who live in Newburgh. Reflecting this annual cycle, Mexico's highways, airports and bus terminals have become jammed in recent weeks with homeward-bound travelers.(Keith Dannemiller/New York Times Photo)  (NYT13) WASHINGTON -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- PELL-RETIRE-EDUC, 12-24 -- Senator Claiborne Pell, seated before a portrait of himself as a boy with his father, was the impetus behind the Pell educational grants. After 36 years in the Senate, the Rhode Island democrat who wrote the legislation creating national endowments for arts and humanities is retiring. (Stephen Crowley/New York Times Photo)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- LORING-XMAS-CLR, 12-24 -- John Loring, Tiffany's design director, lights candles on a table set for Christmas entertaining. ``Cooking is a gift you give to other people,'' says Loring. His Christmas Eve supper party has become a tradition. As with most traditions, it simply grew from a nice idea - looking after stray friends who might otherwise celebrate the holiday in impersonal restaurants or grazing on takeout food. (Philip Greenberg/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT11) SEATTLE -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NATIONS-TABLE-CLR-2, 12-24 -- It's easy to spot the regular diners at the Flying Fish Restaurant, Bar and Grill in Seattle. They're the ones diving into platters of Dungeness crab. Christine Keff, the owner and chef, has made Flying Fish into one of the most non-traditional, yet popular, new area restaurants. By specializing in fresh seafood with a Pan-Asian flavor, she has set herself apart. (Doug Wilson/New York Times Photo)  (NYT10) CHICAGO -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NATIONS-TABLE-CLR-1, 12-24 -- Francios Kwaku-Dongo with the brick oven style pizza that Spago is known for. Wolfgang Puck has brought his Spago restaurant concept to Chicago. Kwaku-Dongo, who had been the executive chef at the Spago in Los Angeles for five years, says in the opening weeks the restaurant has had to revise the size of its portions. ``Maybe it's the cold weather, but here we have had to increase the amount of pasta on the plates.'' (Todd Buchanan/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT9) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- MEXICAN-FEAST-CLR, 12-24 -- While speaking on the phone, Christy Haubegger, coordinates a tamale assembly line for her annual Mexican Christmas party. ``It's like a labor of love,'' says Ms. Haubegger, 28. ``And by the time Christmas rolls around again next year, you have forgotten how labor-intensive it was last year.''(Edward Keating/New York Times Photo)  (NYT8) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- HOSPITAL-DOGS-2-CLR, 12-24 -- Destiny, a golden retriever visits Monsarriti Maldonado, a patient at St. Vincent's hospital. Destiny is volunteering in St. Vincent's new research project, in which visits to geriatric patients from human and dog teams are monitored to see whether they decrease depression, isolation and loneliness. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo) *LITE  (NYT7) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- HOSPITAL-DOGS-1-CLR, 12-24 -- Destiny, a golden retriever, works in animal-assisted therapy programs in nursing homes and rehabilitation centers. Here she sits patiently while getting her picture taken for a St. Vincent's Hospital identification card. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)  (NYT6) BOSTON -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- BOND-FUNDS-BOS-CLR, 12-24 -- The action on the floor of the Fidelity Investments bond trading operation. In the 1990s, stock funds have consistently outperformed bond funds, often by a wide margin. Bonds and bond funds make particularly good sense for investors who may need access to their money in a few years and for older people approaching retirement age. (John Tlumacki/Boston Globe Photo)  (NYT5) BRETTON, N.H. -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TRAVEL-BRITISH-SKIERS-CLR, 12-24 -- ``Skiers in the Alps struggle with the concept of a queue,'' says Christine Roberts, a resident of a London suburb. ``They don't appear to understand that there's another way to reach a ski lift than over the skis or bodies of others.'' Ms. Roberts skiing at Bretton Woods last Monday. (Boston Globe Photo)  (NYT4) SEATTLE -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- BALLET-JOFFREY-SPI-CLR, 12-24 -- Los Angeles dance critic Sasha Anawalt talks about her book ``The Joffrey Ballet,'' during a recent interview. ``The story of this book is how artists get pulled away from their art and whatever makes their art,'' explains Ms. Anawalt. ``Joffrey Ballet was often overlooked, in part, I think, because it was so American.'' (Philip Webber/Seattle Post-Intelligencer Photo)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TOOLS-SPI-2-CLR, 12-24 -- Dave Englund has the world's largest collection of fine finishing planes made 250 years ago by the earliest known toolmakers in Anglo-America. He polishes one of his most recent purchases, a $4000 Nicholson molding plane. Part of Englund's collection, right, includes a brace and bit set fashioned from a revolutionary war American Brown Bess musket bayonet. The set sits atop a wooden chest dated 1776. (Mike Urban/Seattle Post-Intelligencer Photo) *LITE  (NYT2) UNDATED -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TOOLS-SPI-1-CLR, 12-24 -- Coachmakers were the elite woodworkers of the colonial era. Their tools, like this plane, most of which were made by the craftsman, were designed to fit the tight compound curves of a coach. ``These tools are works of art themselves,'' says Dave Englund, 54, a former industrial-arts teacher, now has the world's largest collection of such tools. (Mike Urban/Seattle Post-Intelligencer Photo)  (NYT1) PHOENIX -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- TEMPS-BACKLASH-AZR-CLR, 12-23 -- At Mesa Community College, temporary, or adjunct staff members outnumber the permanent employees. The college has 788 adjunct instructors and a permanent staff of 239. Wendy Perkins, who is a ``contract instructor'' at the college, stands in front of a bulletin board in the hallway of one of the college's buildings. (Arizona Republic Photo)  N.Y. Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19961224.0685 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's N.Y. Times Photo Full picture package, moving 12/24/96.  NYT Picture clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on NewsCom at 305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling 212-556-4204.  (NYT21) NEW YORK -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- NY-HOMELESS-PROFILE, 12-24 -- Lamont McClam carries his found cardboard to a site on Fifth Avenue where he spends his nights. At right, MClam puts a lot of effort into constructing his ``bed'' every night in a corner of the entrance to the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. McClam commutes to a regular, minimum-wage job in Long Island City. He doesn't absolutely have to live in the box. But he has a clear goal: to save $50 a week so he can reunite with his estranged wife and two daughters who moved to Florida. (Edward Keating/New York Times Photo)  (NYT20) VILLA EL SALVADOR, Peru -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- PERU-HOSTAGES-POOR-2, 12-24 -- Felicita Fuentes Torres hunts through a garbage dump for empty cans and bottles to resell. ``God knows, we don't need more violence,'' says the 44-year-old Indian woman, who says she was trying to earn a few extra centavos to put together a decent Christmas dinner for her family. ``I don't have the education to understand if the guerrillas or the government help us or not. All I know is we need food, water and light.'' (New York Times Photo)  (NYT19) VILLA EL SALVADOR, Peru -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- PERU-HOSTAGES-POOR-1, 12-24 -- In Villa el Salvador, an impoverished shantytown not far from downtown Lima, Ernesto Somoza Meza roasts a pig. While people here voiced little if any sympathy for the rebels, they also expressed little empathy for the well-heeled coterie of hostages, all of whom have wealth unimaginable by Peruvian standards. (New York Times Photo)  (NYT18) CLARK, N.J. -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- KINDERCARE-KKR-CLR, 12-24 -- The chain that operates this Kindercare day care center in Clark, says it promotes ``industry-leading education and quality standards.'' But how many parents can afford it? While more money to subsidize day care is clearly necessary to meet the needs of lower-income families, no level of government is likely to aim much money in the direction of Kindercare and other centers that cater to the middle class. (Laura Pedrick/New York Times Photo)  (NYT17) FOUNTAIN VALLEY, Calif. -- Dec. 24, 1996 -- KINGSTON-BONUS-CLR, 12-24 -- Employees of Kingston Technology, who will share $100 million in bonuses, celebrate at a holiday party. ``What makes or breaks a company is not one or two people, it's a team,'' says John Tu, a founder of Kingston Technology, the world's biggest independent maker of computer memory boards. ``So you have to share. If you have questions, please call Chuck Lewis at 202-298-6920 or Elizabeth Schwinn or Mark Helm at 202-298-6320.  (EDs: Adds MOM-MURDER-TRIAL; TEX-BUSH; BMC-COMPUTERS; SUPER-BOWL-SEXISM; TRAVEL-COTSWOLD; TRAVEL-LOUVRE)  (The ``HNS'' tag appears in all sluglines.)  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  MEXICO-DRUGS (Washington) _ The Clinton administration applauded Mexican Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar for appointing military officials to oversee efforts to combat narcotics cultivation and trafficking. Civilians previously held the posts. By GARY MARTIN.  ENTITLEMENTS-COMMISSION (Washington) _ During the election campaign, President Clinton talked about the need for a bi-partisan commission to look at federal benefit programs. While the White House tends to other business, two Democrats and two Republican members of Congress have gone ahead and formed one on their own to look at Social Security and pensions. By DAN FREEDMAN.  NATIONAL NEWS (``a'' category)  MOM-MURDER-TRIAL (Kerrville, Texas) _ Darlie Routier, accused of stabbing her 5- and 6-year-old sons to death, takes the witness stand in her capital murder trial. By JOHN W. GONZALEZ.  TEX-BUSH (Austin, Texas) _ Texas Gov. George W. Bush begins a series of meetings to push his proposed $2.8 billion property tax cut and on Thursday begins a road trip to try to sell the plan. He proposes an $84.7 billion budget. By CLAY ROBISON.  BUSINESS &AMP; FINANCIAL (``f'' category)  BMC-COMPUTERS (Houston) _ Three years ago, industry pundits labeled the mainframe computer a technology dinosaur. Companies such as BMC Software that had tied their fortunes to ``big iron'' were warned to get out or die. It turned out there was plenty of life left in those dinosaurs. BMC has not only survived. It has thrived. By DWIGHT SILVERMAN.  SPORTS (``s'' category)  SUPER-BOWL-SEXISM (Midland, Mich.) _ Try as I might, I cannot understand the silence surrounding what I took to be a serious case of sexism in the National Football League during the halftime show of Super Bowl XXXI in New Orleans Sunday. By RALPH E. WIRTZ.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  FRENCH-CULTURE (Paris) _ already filed _ As some of us uncouth Americans have long suspected, French culture has seen better days. Confirmation now comes from no less a person than Edouard Balladur, a former prime minister and one-time French presidential candidate. By BERNARD D. KAPLAN.  FOR SUNDAY:  THOMPSON-COLUMN (Washington) _ After his pity-poor-Newtie routine before the faithful in his Georgia congressional district last week, the speaker of the House can best be described as Richard Milhaus Gingrich. He sounded eerily like the 37th president defending himself when disappointment and deceit interrupted his political journey. By ROBERT E. THOMPSON. (``k'' category)  TRAVEL-COTSWOLD (Wortley, England) _ The Cotswold Way winds 102 miles from Chipping Camden to Bath, meandering down tree-lined country lanes, through the backyards of lavish country manors, along the banks of millstreams and over hillsides with sweeping views of not-so-distant Wales. By JOHN FLINN. (``t'' category)  TRAVEL-LOUVRE (Paris) _ I have a confession to make. Although I've been to Paris three times, I have never set foot in the Louvre. I mention this not to impress upon you what an uncultured lout I am, but to make a point: In travel, and particularly, I think, in European travel, we've each got to follow our own path. By JOHN FLINN. "85674"	"I"	"think"	" Shares of the U.S. company traded in Paris closed up 0.59 percent at 406. Its American depository receipts were recently unchanged at 73 1/8. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19970130.0194 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-TRAVEL-ADVISORY-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> (ATTN: Managing editors, travel editors, feature editors)  The New York Times News Service calls your attention to the following travel features and columns.  The articles, which moved within the last week, are from The New York Times (NYT), Boston Globe (BOS), Los Angeles Daily News (LADN), Hearst News Service (HNS), Fort Worth Star-Telegram (TEX) and Cox News Service (COX).  Photos, where indicated, have been sent to NYT photo clients. Graphics, where indicated, have been sent to NYT graphic clients. Nonsubscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204.  For retransmissions of these stories, please call 212-556-1927.  PLACES/DESTINATIONS  TRAVEL-COTSWOLD-$ADV02-HNS (Wortley, England) _ A traveling tour of the Cotswolds. By John Flinn. Moved 1-30 for release 2-2.  BABBIT-GRAND-CANYON-HNS (Berkeley, Calif.) _ At sunrise and sunset, tourists from around the world flock to the rims of the Grand Canyon to see the incredible colors on the layers of stones that rise thousands of feet above the Colorado River. It's a unique moment on Earth. By Carl Irving. Moved 1-28.  BORDER-TOUR-HNS (Tijuana) _ They paid $450 each to be ushered along a rocky, garbage-strewn path. And when they reached their destination _ the steel wall bisecting the border _ they joined a circle of men who regarded them with curiosity. Introductions began. But suddenly, a helicopter with a blinding spotlight burst out of the night. Were these desperate migrants hoping to cross the border? Not exactly. They were American tourists on a ``reality tour'' of the Mexico-California border sponsored by San Francisco's Global Exchange. By Susan Ferriss. Moved 1-27.  EXCLUSIVE-WOODSTOCK-LEGACY-ART-NYT (Bethel, N.Y.) _ Every summer, tens of thousands of pilgrims come to this Catskills town to gaze at what seems to be an ordinary cow pasture but to them is hallowed ground. Now Sullivan County officials have decided that rather than fight the invading hordes, they will acquire the 37-acre field and turn it into a shrine to Woodstock. By Joseph Berger. W/photo. Moved 1-26.  TRAVEL-TEXAS-NYT (Undated) _ There is perhaps no place in the continental United States where one can feel quite as blissfully small as one does in Big Bend National Park in West Texas. By Sam Howe Verhovek.Moved 1-24.  WINE-TRAVEL-LADN (Los Angeles) _ Forgetting to taste and encountering the occasional poseur is only a minor annoyance on the wine-tasting circuit in and around the rustic epicenter of California's Central Coast wine country, Los Olivos, a paltry 100 miles from Los Angeles up highways 101 and 154. By Jeremy Bagott. Moved 1-26.  TRAVEL-GREENBRIER-BOS (White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.) _ Imagining ourselves at the Greenbrier, we pictured a variety of leisurely activities the stately old resort is famous for. Serve and volley. Pull and shoot. Who would have thought we'd end up with duck and cover? By Anthony Flint. Moved 1-27.  BELLEVIEW-MIDO-COX (Undated) _ It was never the grandest of Florida's turn-of-the-century hotels. Not when you consider the fancy minarets of the nearby Tampa Bay Hotel or the real Tiffany windows of the Ponce de Leon Hotel in St. Augustine. No, the Belleview Hotel was never the real Belle of Florida's Gilded Age. But today, 100 years after it opened on Jan. 15, 1897, it is the most amazing of them all for one reason _ it survived. By Jan Tuckwood. Moved 1-30.  TRAVEL-LOUVRE-$ADV2-HNS (Paris) _ I have a confession to make. Although I've been to Paris three times, I have never set foot in the Louvre. I mention this not to impress upon you what an uncultured lout I am _ although one could reasonably draw that conclusion _ but to make a point: In travel, and particularly, I think, in European travel, we've each got to follow our own path. By John Flinn.Moved 1-29 for release 2-2.  SKIING  TRAVEL-COLORADO-SKI-NYT (Denver) _ Direct flights from Newark to Vail's Eagle County Airport, an $8 million air terminal that opened in November, and in-flight concierge service are all part of a wider vogue among vacationers to fly directly to the mountain resorts of Colorado, the nation's most popular skiing state. Feeding the trend are lower fares, new investments in mountain airports and the placement of Denver's new airport on Colorado's eastern plains. By James Brooke. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  TAHOE-HNS (South Lake Tahoe) _ Top tourism officials held a hasty summit meeting to plot their recovery from nature's second January sucker punch. Their surprising conclusion: Do nothing for now. Despite a second closure of U.S. 50, Tahoe's economic tether to the Bay Area and Sacramento, marketing directors of the top casinos and ski resorts said they didn't see disaster looming. Small hotel owners sing a sadder song. By Michael Dougan. Moved 1-28.  EXHIBITS AND ANNIVERSARIES  JEWELS-OF-THE-CZARS-NYT (Washington) _ Few blockbuster exhibitions have popped into view as suddenly as ``Jewels of the Romanovs: Treasures of the Russian Imperial Court,'' the jewel-studded display of art and artifacts that opens on Jan. 30 at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. By Roberta Smith. Moved 1-28.  BOTTICELLI-ART-NYT (Boston) _ ``Botticelli's Witness: Changing Style in a Changing Florence'' opened in the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum 10 days ago and runs through April 6. This elegant show of just 12 paintings and engravings that span Botticelli's life, 1445 to 1510, raises a big issue: the effect of politics and faith on an artist's work. By Deborah Weisgall. Moved 1-28.  TRAVEL-NOTES-BOS (Undated) _ Old Sturbridge Village, a re-created New England town of the 1830s, in Sturbridge, Mass., will hold a Washington's Birthday celebration Feb. 15-17 featuring song, dance and formal toasts to our first president. Moved 1-28.  CONSUMER NEWS  AIRLINE-PILOTS-REVIEW-NYT (Undated) _ Pilots' restiveness is about more than wages. Broad changes have occurred in the nature of the profession and the makeup of the pilot ranks, and those shifts help explain some of the current saber-rattling. Pilots, for example, do not command the respect they once did when air travel was glamorous and only for the well heeled. By Adam Bryant. Moved 1-25.  TRAVEL-CRUISESHIPS-ART-NYT (Undated) _ Heavy bookings for millennium cruises, including cruises whose price and itinerary are not yet established, promise to jump-start the cruise business for the year 2000. But right now the industry is perplexed about 1996, worried about 1997, and wondering whether any of those heady projections about the growing popularity of cruising will be realized before the next century. To ensure that popularity, the biggest ships (whose number _ and size _ are growing rapidly) have virtually become floating destinations, competing with resorts for vacationers' dollars. By Edwin McDowell. W/photo. Moved 1-29 for release 2-2.  OUTDOORS/ENVIRONMENT  OUTDOORS-DUCKS-TEX (Undated) _ If this year's waterfowl hunting season revealed anything, it is that duck hunting still is duck hunting. By Bob Hood. Moved 1-25.  WINTER-OUTDOORS-NYT (Undated) _ Another hunting season has come and gone. The deer trails and human footprints and fallen apples and acorns lie erased or buried under banks of new snow. By Peter Bodo. Moved 1-27.  KANSAS-PRAIRIE-PARK-ART-NYT (Lawrence) _ Creation of the new Tallgrass Prairie National Preserve in east-central Kansas did not end the debate between ranchers and environmentalists about how to manage what is left of the grassland that once stretched from Pennsylvania to Kansas and from Alberta to Texas. Rather, it left open the possibility of new confrontations, because Congress did not specify how the National Park Service should manage the new preserve. W/photo. Moved 1-26.  WILDERNESS-ROADS-ART-NYT (Arch Canyon, Utah) _ Some Utah environmentalists, when they want a dose of activism, hike into the remote red canyons in the southern part of the state to look at roads that they say are not really there. It is their itinerant tactic in a growing fight over millions of acres in the state, the latest battle in the decades-long struggle over control of federal lands in the West. By John Cushman. W/photo. Moved 1-28.  OUTDOORS-HIKING-NYT (Moshannon State Forest Pa.) _ Three-eighths of a mile doesn't go quickly,'' Ralph Seeley warned me as we hiked through the rugged ridgetop woods of central Pennsylvania. Seeley was not referring to walking three-eighths of a mile of trail. He was referring to creating it. By Charles Fergus. Moved 1-28.  COLUMNS/REGULAR FEATURES  BIZTRAVEL-COLUMN-BOS (Undated) _ Results are in for the annual ``guest satisfaction'' survey of hotel chains that cater primarily to business travel. Westin was the winner, but there was room for improvement across the board. By Jerry Ackerman. Moved 1-28.  TRAVEL-COLUMN-BOS (Undated) _ New York City is on sale from now through March 31, and Stephen Morello, president of the New York Convention &AMP; Visitors Bureau, says the ``New York for a Song'' promotion creates ``the best travel value in America.'' By Jerry Morris. Moved 1-28.  TRAVEL-BRIEFS-NYT (Undated) _ Travel news and notes. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  TRAVEL-Q&AMP;A-NYT (Undated) _ Travel questions and answers. By Janet Piorko. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER-NYT (Undated) _ The cruise industry, still looking for ways to sign on baby-boomers, is designing programs where children come along but parents get some time to themselves, with the knowledge that the children are safe and enjoying special activities. By Betsy Wade. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  TRAVEL-BARGAINS-NYT (Undated) _ British Airways has a London for Less package starting at $399, including round-trip air fare from New York and three nights' hotel accommodation with Continental breakfast. By Janet Piorko. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  The New York Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19970130.0195 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-TRAVEL-ADVISORY-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> (ATTN: Managing editors, travel editors, feature editors)  The New York Times News Service calls your attention to the following travel features and columns.  The articles, which moved within the last week, are from The New York Times (NYT), Boston Globe (BOS), Los Angeles Daily News (LADN), Hearst News Service (HNS), Fort Worth Star-Telegram (TEX) and Cox News Service (COX).  Photos, where indicated, have been sent to NYT photo clients. Graphics, where indicated, have been sent to NYT graphic clients. Nonsubscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204.  For retransmissions of these stories, please call 212-556-1927.  PLACES/DESTINATIONS  TRAVEL-COTSWOLD-$ADV02-HNS (Wortley, England) _ A traveling tour of the Cotswolds. By John Flinn. Moved 1-30 for release 2-2.  BABBIT-GRAND-CANYON-HNS (Berkeley, Calif.) _ At sunrise and sunset, tourists from around the world flock to the rims of the Grand Canyon to see the incredible colors on the layers of stones that rise thousands of feet above the Colorado River. It's a unique moment on Earth. By Carl Irving. Moved 1-28.  BORDER-TOUR-HNS (Tijuana) _ They paid $450 each to be ushered along a rocky, garbage-strewn path. And when they reached their destination _ the steel wall bisecting the border _ they joined a circle of men who regarded them with curiosity. Introductions began. But suddenly, a helicopter with a blinding spotlight burst out of the night. Were these desperate migrants hoping to cross the border? Not exactly. They were American tourists on a ``reality tour'' of the Mexico-California border sponsored by San Francisco's Global Exchange. By Susan Ferriss. Moved 1-27.  EXCLUSIVE-WOODSTOCK-LEGACY-ART-NYT (Bethel, N.Y.) _ Every summer, tens of thousands of pilgrims come to this Catskills town to gaze at what seems to be an ordinary cow pasture but to them is hallowed ground. Now Sullivan County officials have decided that rather than fight the invading hordes, they will acquire the 37-acre field and turn it into a shrine to Woodstock. By Joseph Berger. W/photo. Moved 1-26.  TRAVEL-TEXAS-NYT (Undated) _ There is perhaps no place in the continental United States where one can feel quite as blissfully small as one does in Big Bend National Park in West Texas. By Sam Howe Verhovek.Moved 1-24.  WINE-TRAVEL-LADN (Los Angeles) _ Forgetting to taste and encountering the occasional poseur is only a minor annoyance on the wine-tasting circuit in and around the rustic epicenter of California's Central Coast wine country, Los Olivos, a paltry 100 miles from Los Angeles up highways 101 and 154. By Jeremy Bagott. Moved 1-26.  TRAVEL-GREENBRIER-BOS (White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.) _ Imagining ourselves at the Greenbrier, we pictured a variety of leisurely activities the stately old resort is famous for. Serve and volley. Pull and shoot. Who would have thought we'd end up with duck and cover? By Anthony Flint. Moved 1-27.  BELLEVIEW-MIDO-COX (Undated) _ It was never the grandest of Florida's turn-of-the-century hotels. Not when you consider the fancy minarets of the nearby Tampa Bay Hotel or the real Tiffany windows of the Ponce de Leon Hotel in St. Augustine. No, the Belleview Hotel was never the real Belle of Florida's Gilded Age. But today, 100 years after it opened on Jan. 15, 1897, it is the most amazing of them all for one reason _ it survived. By Jan Tuckwood. Moved 1-30.  TRAVEL-LOUVRE-$ADV2-HNS (Paris) _ I have a confession to make. Although I've been to Paris three times, I have never set foot in the Louvre. I mention this not to impress upon you what an uncultured lout I am _ although one could reasonably draw that conclusion _ but to make a point: In travel, and particularly, I think, in European travel, we've each got to follow our own path. By John Flinn.Moved 1-29 for release 2-2.  SKIING  TRAVEL-COLORADO-SKI-NYT (Denver) _ Direct flights from Newark to Vail's Eagle County Airport, an $8 million air terminal that opened in November, and in-flight concierge service are all part of a wider vogue among vacationers to fly directly to the mountain resorts of Colorado, the nation's most popular skiing state. Feeding the trend are lower fares, new investments in mountain airports and the placement of Denver's new airport on Colorado's eastern plains. By James Brooke. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  TAHOE-HNS (South Lake Tahoe) _ Top tourism officials held a hasty summit meeting to plot their recovery from nature's second January sucker punch. Their surprising conclusion: Do nothing for now. Despite a second closure of U.S. 50, Tahoe's economic tether to the Bay Area and Sacramento, marketing directors of the top casinos and ski resorts said they didn't see disaster looming. Small hotel owners sing a sadder song. By Michael Dougan. Moved 1-28.  EXHIBITS AND ANNIVERSARIES  JEWELS-OF-THE-CZARS-NYT (Washington) _ Few blockbuster exhibitions have popped into view as suddenly as ``Jewels of the Romanovs: Treasures of the Russian Imperial Court,'' the jewel-studded display of art and artifacts that opens on Jan. 30 at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. By Roberta Smith. Moved 1-28.  BOTTICELLI-ART-NYT (Boston) _ ``Botticelli's Witness: Changing Style in a Changing Florence'' opened in the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum 10 days ago and runs through April 6. This elegant show of just 12 paintings and engravings that span Botticelli's life, 1445 to 1510, raises a big issue: the effect of politics and faith on an artist's work. By Deborah Weisgall. Moved 1-28.  TRAVEL-NOTES-BOS (Undated) _ Old Sturbridge Village, a re-created New England town of the 1830s, in Sturbridge, Mass., will hold a Washington's Birthday celebration Feb. 15-17 featuring song, dance and formal toasts to our first president. Moved 1-28.  CONSUMER NEWS  AIRLINE-PILOTS-REVIEW-NYT (Undated) _ Pilots' restiveness is about more than wages. Broad changes have occurred in the nature of the profession and the makeup of the pilot ranks, and those shifts help explain some of the current saber-rattling. Pilots, for example, do not command the respect they once did when air travel was glamorous and only for the well heeled. By Adam Bryant. Moved 1-25.  TRAVEL-CRUISESHIPS-ART-NYT (Undated) _ Heavy bookings for millennium cruises, including cruises whose price and itinerary are not yet established, promise to jump-start the cruise business for the year 2000. But right now the industry is perplexed about 1996, worried about 1997, and wondering whether any of those heady projections about the growing popularity of cruising will be realized before the next century. To ensure that popularity, the biggest ships (whose number _ and size _ are growing rapidly) have virtually become floating destinations, competing with resorts for vacationers' dollars. By Edwin McDowell. W/photo. Moved 1-29 for release 2-2. Despite a second closure of U.S. 50, Tahoe's economic tether to the Bay Area and Sacramento, marketing directors of the top casinos and ski resorts said they didn't see disaster looming. Small hotel owners sing a sadder song. By Michael Dougan. Moved 1-28.  EXHIBITS AND ANNIVERSARIES  JEWELS-OF-THE-CZARS-NYT (Washington) _ Few blockbuster exhibitions have popped into view as suddenly as ``Jewels of the Romanovs: Treasures of the Russian Imperial Court,'' the jewel-studded display of art and artifacts that opens on Jan. 30 at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. By Roberta Smith. Moved 1-28.  BOTTICELLI-ART-NYT (Boston) _ ``Botticelli's Witness: Changing Style in a Changing Florence'' opened in the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum 10 days ago and runs through April 6. This elegant show of just 12 paintings and engravings that span Botticelli's life, 1445 to 1510, raises a big issue: the effect of politics and faith on an artist's work. By Deborah Weisgall. Moved 1-28.  TRAVEL-NOTES-BOS (Undated) _ Old Sturbridge Village, a re-created New England town of the 1830s, in Sturbridge, Mass., will hold a Washington's Birthday celebration Feb. 15-17 featuring song, dance and formal toasts to our first president. Moved 1-28.  CONSUMER NEWS  AIRLINE-PILOTS-REVIEW-NYT (Undated) _ Pilots' restiveness is about more than wages. Broad changes have occurred in the nature of the profession and the makeup of the pilot ranks, and those shifts help explain some of the current saber-rattling. Pilots, for example, do not command the respect they once did when air travel was glamorous and only for the well heeled. By Adam Bryant. Moved 1-25.  TRAVEL-CRUISESHIPS-ART-NYT (Undated) _ Heavy bookings for millennium cruises, including cruises whose price and itinerary are not yet established, promise to jump-start the cruise business for the year 2000. But right now the industry is perplexed about 1996, worried about 1997, and wondering whether any of those heady projections about the growing popularity of cruising will be realized before the next century. To ensure that popularity, the biggest ships (whose number _ and size _ are growing rapidly) have virtually become floating destinations, competing with resorts for vacationers' dollars. By Edwin McDowell. W/photo. Moved 1-29 for release 2-2.  OUTDOORS/ENVIRONMENT  OUTDOORS-DUCKS-TEX (Undated) _ If this year's waterfowl hunting season revealed anything, it is that duck hunting still is duck hunting. By Bob Hood. Moved 1-25.  WINTER-OUTDOORS-NYT (Undated) _ Another hunting season has come and gone. The deer trails and human footprints and fallen apples and acorns lie erased or buried under banks of new snow. By Peter Bodo. Moved 1-27.  KANSAS-PRAIRIE-PARK-ART-NYT (Lawrence) _ Creation of the new Tallgrass Prairie National Preserve in east-central Kansas did not end the debate between ranchers and environmentalists about how to manage what is left of the grassland that once stretched from Pennsylvania to Kansas and from Alberta to Texas. Rather, it left open the possibility of new confrontations, because Congress did not specify how the National Park Service should manage the new preserve. W/photo. Moved 1-26.  WILDERNESS-ROADS-ART-NYT (Arch Canyon, Utah) _ Some Utah environmentalists, when they want a dose of activism, hike into the remote red canyons in the southern part of the state to look at roads that they say are not really there. It is their itinerant tactic in a growing fight over millions of acres in the state, the latest battle in the decades-long struggle over control of federal lands in the West. By John Cushman. W/photo. Moved 1-28.  OUTDOORS-HIKING-NYT (Moshannon State Forest Pa.) _ Three-eighths of a mile doesn't go quickly,'' Ralph Seeley warned me as we hiked through the rugged ridgetop woods of central Pennsylvania. Seeley was not referring to walking three-eighths of a mile of trail. He was referring to creating it. By Charles Fergus. Moved 1-28.  COLUMNS/REGULAR FEATURES  BIZTRAVEL-COLUMN-BOS (Undated) _ Results are in for the annual ``guest satisfaction'' survey of hotel chains that cater primarily to business travel. Westin was the winner, but there was room for improvement across the board. By Jerry Ackerman. Moved 1-28.  TRAVEL-COLUMN-BOS (Undated) _ New York City is on sale from now through March 31, and Stephen Morello, president of the New York Convention &AMP; Visitors Bureau, says the ``New York for a Song'' promotion creates ``the best travel value in America.'' By Jerry Morris. Moved 1-28.  TRAVEL-BRIEFS-NYT (Undated) _ Travel news and notes. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  TRAVEL-Q&AMP;A-NYT (Undated) _ Travel questions and answers. By Janet Piorko. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER-NYT (Undated) _ The cruise industry, still looking for ways to sign on baby-boomers, is designing programs where children come along but parents get some time to themselves, with the knowledge that the children are safe and enjoying special activities. By Betsy Wade. Moved 1-27 for 2-2.  TRAVEL-BARGAINS-NYT (Undated) _ British Airways has a London for Less package starting at $399, including round-trip air fare from New York and three nights' hotel accommodation with Continental breakfast. By Janet Piorko. Moved 1-27 for 2-2. Fat City, this barbecue capital is. (s)  Commentary  YOUNG-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ A group paraded before city council recently to protest a public library display that depicted worthwhile contributions by gays and lesbians in history. The all-too-common protest was that such an affirmative presentation ``promotes homosexuality.'' I've always wondered what ``promoting homosexuality'' entailed. (k)  NETHAWAY-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ True or false? Minority athletes should not be admitted to top universities based on their entertainment value. Most people, I think, would answer ``true.'' I would even if my answer hurt the chances of my alma mater, the University of Texas, to win another national championship in football. (k)  BORDERS-COLUMN _ HOUSTON _ Here there be giants. Of course, as one of my running buddies is ever fond of pointing out to me, I look up to most everybody, since I come from a long line of short people, including a midget uncle who repaired bicycles though he couldn't reach the pedals. Still, the folks shooting practice jumpers and routinely slamming the ball into the rim while barely getting off their feet look like giants, even from my seat 20 rows back or so in the Summit.
