(Visit the Star-Telegram's online services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com)  N A T I O N A L / T E X A S  RIO GRANDE CHOKED  BOCA CHICA BEACH, Texas _The Rio Grande normally flows into the Gulf of Mexico at Boca Chica Beach, but a sandbar has formed between the two bodies of water, blocking the already low flow of the river. By REBECA RODRIGUEZ. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  TEXAS-SCHOLARSHIPS  ARLINGTON _ The University of Texas at Arlington doesn't compete with UT-Austin or Texas A&AMP;M for football players, but it is poised to spend $65,000 to battle for some of Texas' best brains. This week, the university begins campaigning to persuade Texas' National Merit Scholarship semifinalists to consider UT-Arlington instead of UT-Austin, A&AMP;M, Rice University and other schools that typically scoop up large numbers of the state's sharpest test takers for their freshmen classes. Letters will invite about 1,300 semifinalists to campus for a National Merit Honors Day, scheduled for Saturday, Sept. 15. UT-Arlington's Honors College will spearhead the campaign. By JOHN AUSTIN. Story has moved in ``a'' general news category.  F I N A N C I A L  PRODUCE WOMAN  COLLEGE STATION, Texas _ For 39 years, Frieda Rapoport Caplan has worked to change what you eat. In the ``male-dominated and male-controlled'' produce business, the plucky 77-year-old Californian carved out and nurtured one specialty niche after another. Caplan became an industry legend _ the ``first woman of produce,'' according to one trade group _ for marketing the maladroitly named Chinese gooseberry from New Zealand. By BARRY SHLACHTER. Story has moved in ``f'' financial category.  E N T E R T A I N M E N T  MTV-HIP HOPERA  HOLLYWOOD _ On Tuesday, Destiny's Child's feature attraction, Beyonce Knowles, makes her acting debut on MTV's new ``Hip Hopera: Carmen,'' an adaptation of Bizet's opera. The leap from recording studio to sound stage seemed like only a matter of time for the 19-year-old Houston native, who's always at home at center stage. By MIKI TURNER. Story has moved in ``e'' entertainment category.  BOOK REVIEWS  UNDATED _ A selection of book reviews by books editor Jeff Guinn. By JEFF GUINN. Story has moved in ``e'' entertainment category.  C O M M E N T A R Y  SMITH-COLUMN  UNDATED _ The compelling emphasis that we placed on the space program is now needed in another field: energy. The United States, the most gluttonous energy consumer in the world, should launch an inspired, ambitious program to develop new energy sources and supplies while also dramatically improving energy efficiency and curbing pollution. By JACK Z. SMITH. Story has moved in ``k'' commentary category.  THOMPSON-COLUMN  UNDATED _ They weave. They wander. They swerve. They suddenly slow down for no apparent reason, and then accelerate as if roaring into the straightaway on a NASCAR track. They run red lights, stop on green, turn right on red without stopping first. They can easily violate three or four traffic laws in the space of a city block. You know who they are. You might be one of them. Any time I see someone driving erratically, I think, ``I'll bet a thousand bucks this idiot is talking on the phone.'' By BILL THOMPSON. "94510"	"I"	"think"	" The Flesh Fair, for instance, begins with the bizarre sight of mangled robots picking through junkyards, trying to piece together some semblance of a human form for themselves. Next we watch as other robots are shot from rocket launchers into a metal compactor, while a delirious carnival leader (Brendan Gleeson) stokes the bloodlust of the crowd. This is no doubt an echo of the cold-to-the-touch, bad-to-the-bone horror of Kubrick's ``A Clockwork Orange.'' But the enraged and mournful Spielberg of ``Schindler's List'' and ``Amistad'' is here also, taking in the grotesque and pitiful sight of man playing God. I saw ``A.I.'' two days after Timothy McVeigh was executed _ worth noting, I think, because the Flesh Fair may be the most forceful anti-death penalty statement ever put forth in a mainstream Hollywood film. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200106.gz"

"99885"	"you"	"think"	" Of course, some of the great surprises of life live in the pockets of  the self you thought you knew so well, and Munro's unearthing of those  secrets is a vein throughout her stories. In the quietly frightening  ``Post and Beam,'' where a young wife's ideas about love are far grander  than fact, she calmly realizes that her domineering husband provokes ``a  little hum of hate running along beside her love, nearly all the time.''  With the same chilling stillness evoked by Henry James's ``Beast in the  Jungle,'' the plot of this story veers precisely where you hope it  won't. The characters in ``Hateship, Friendship, Courtship'' take  chances and make changes and all kinds of choices, and yet, thinks the  fine, daring, ordinary woman of ``What Is Remembered,'' ``Maybe you  didn't find out so much, anyway.'' There's the truth of it, for better  or worse, and one takes an odd sort of solace from such realism. An  unconscious nod is the accompanying gesture through Munro's stories:  Yes, you think, faced with cruel compromise or a blush of hope, that's  right, that's the way it was; how could she know that? It is the sweet,  silent dialogue evoked only by a particular strain of empathic genius,  and in Munro's luxuriously long stories, it can wield the cumulative  power of a symphony. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200111.gz"

"100623"	"I"	"think"	" Jason Kidd continues to drive the Nets to improbable places (such as 4-1) and also tossed some bonbons at his former team last week. He was asked if he thought things would be easier for Suns boss Jerry Colangelo now that the Diamondbacks have won the World Series (Colangelo also owns the baseball team). ``I think it would make it easier in the fact that Jerry has won a championship in a major sport,'' Kidd said. ``It would be years before they win a championship in the NBA or decades.'' There you have it. Years or decades. He's probably right. The Suns again are perimeter-oriented _ they've started Jake Voskuhl at center, for goodness sakes _ and then there's the simple fact that Shaq and Kobe Bryant are still alive and kicking. ``You've got to look at those two guys in LA,'' Kidd said. ``It goes for the (whole) Western Conference, because the road goes through LA. It's not just the Suns _ it's everybody. You have to beat them. It's no way around it unless those two go on vacation during the playoffs.'' Sad, but true. The two went on vacation last year during the regular season and even then it didn't matter. Kidd also had this interesting tidbit about his new team. ``In a sense, I think, this team down the road would be the best team I probably have ever played on,'' he said. ``Athleticwise and talentwise I think this is the team that by far will be the best team I've ever played on. If we can keep everybody healthy, it would be the most fun team.'' . . . All hope is not lost for Paul Pierce getting selected to the United States team at next summer's world championships in Indianapolis. Seven players, including Kidd, already have been named. Five players will be added in March. On first glance, at least three of those five need to be big guys. As of now, the only size guys are Jermaine O'Neal and Antonio Davis. Selectors point to the size problem, although, truth be told, they could name 12 guys 6 feet 8 inches and under and still win the gold. Here's Pierce's problem: Two small forwards already have been chosen: Michael Finley and Shawn Marion. Among the missing so far are Kobe, Vince Carter, Tracy McGrady, Antawn Jamison, Chris Webber, Tim Duncan, and, well, you get the picture. Most of those just named won't play. There might be a surprise addition based on this year. But Pierce got some sentiment for the first seven and will likely get some more when the talk boils down to picking the rest of the team . . . The Toronto Raptors broke their own NBA record last Tuesday by blocking 24 shots in a win over Golden State. Well, most of them were blocks, anyway. Warriors beat writers were skeptical about some of the calls, and coach Dave Cowens added afterward, ``Maybe some of those layups we missed were just so bad that they made them blocked shots.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_200111.gz"

(Visit the Star-Telegram's online services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com)  N A T I O N A L / T E X A S  ATTACKS-AIRPORT SECURITY  UNDATED _ Thousands of airport luggage screeners will likely lose their jobs as the federal government takes over airport security. That is just one of the consequences expected as the federal government, airports and airlines grapple with the massive task of enacting the Aviation Security Act that Congress passed this month. By MIKE LEE. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  FARM-BILL  AUSTIN, Texas _ An official with the Texas Farm Bureau said that passage of the 10-year agriculture bill that is the subject of a snit between Senate Democrats and the Bush administration could mean ``life or death for Texas farmers.'' The state's agriculture industry is likely to received about 20 percent of the subsidies that Congress makes to farmers nationwide. By JOHN MORITZ. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  L I F E S T Y L E  DVD-PLAYERS  UNDATED _ By now, if you don't own a DVD player, chances are you know someone who does. It's also likely that your friend the DVD-player owner purchased his or her player recently, and is still building a DVD collection. So you have a built-in gift. The question is, which DVD to get? And what do you look for on a DVD? By ROBERT PHILPOT and TODD CAMP. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  ZEN-CLEANING  UNDATED _ Apparently, cleaning out the closets is not enough, and being able to park both cars in the garage is not sufficient either. To live a truly spiritual life, one must shed the flotsam and jetsam of acquisition and find joy in a trinket-free, spartan house. By GAILE ROBINSON. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  E N T E R T A I N M E N T  TV-`BEANSTALK'  UNDATED _ ``I'm ashamed to say we've been telling the story wrong for many years.'' By the time an exasperated Matthew Modine offers this declaration in ``Jim Henson's Jack and the Beanstalk: The Real Story,'' this enjoyable but long-winded CBS miniseries is already bursting with twists, turns and revisionist wonder. By KEN PARISH PERKINS. "102541"	"I"	"think"	" The creations of Walt Disney, the early ones especially, work at a level just short of the mythic. That, I think, is one of the reasons they were so successful. No allegory at all, and a kind of topical allusion that was unjaundiced and non-satiric. In fact, the most powerful myth at Disney was the one that attached to Walt himself, and it was powerful because it was true. It was the story of hard work, a certain genius, and a completely indomitable spirit, a story with rural roots but with an urban fulfillment, and with an ending not yet in sight. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011206.0046 type=story > <HEADLINE> DISPUTE ERUPTS OVER SEAT ON CIVIL RIGHTS PANEL </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> WASHINGTON (BC-CIVIL-RIGHTS-COMMISSION-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_200112.gz"

VIDEO-DISNEY (Los Angeles) -- Fueled by phenomenal DVD sales of ``Pearl Harbor'' and VHS sales of ``The Princess Diaries'' during the holiday season, Disney edged Warner Bros. for the home video crown with $8.5 billion in sales overall. By Greg Hernandez. (Will move on the ``f'' financial news wire.)  CAPSTONE-CLARK (Los Angeles) -- Capstone Turbine named Karen Clark as chief financial officer Wednesday, filling a major void as the company leaves behind a fiscal year riddled with imperfections. By Evan Pondel. (Will move on the ``f'' financial news wire.)  x x x </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020116.0208 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-LADN-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The Los Angeles Daily News plans to move the following general stories for use by NYTimes News Service clients, AMs and PMs of Thursday, Jan. 17, and thereafter. For questions, contact Carol Bidwell at the Daily News, (818) 713-3702.  QUAKE-ANNIVERSARY (Los Angeles) -- America's costliest urban natural disaster hit eight years ago Wednesday, and scientists are still a long way from being able to predict the next big earthquake. But in the years since the Jan. 17, 1994, 6.7-magnitude Northridge Earthquake, seismologists have made giant strides in computerized systems that identify within minutes the epicenter and maps the areas of the most intense shaking. By Troy Anderson. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.)  API-SCORES (Los Angeles) -- Los Angeles Unified schools continued to post gains on the annual Academic Performance Index, but still fell far short of the state's goals, according to new school rankings released Monday. By Sonia Giordani. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.)  BILL-BOARDS (Los Angeles) -- Frustrated and angry at the lack of action over the past six months, the Los Angeles City Council took steps Wednesday to crack down on illegal billboards by requiring the companies to provide an inventory and permits for all their signs. The issue of billboards has escalated in recent months with a study now under way of allowing the industry to break a 50-year ban and install signs adjacent to freeways in return for tearing down other signs. By Rick Orlov. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.)  WILD-ANIMALS (Los Angeles) -- Faced with a second temporary closure in less than two years, the Wildlife Waystation has suffered a significant loss of fund-raising revenue and will be forced to close if the issue isn't resolved within a year. On Thursday, the nonprofit animal rescue agency will hold its first meeting with county officials to negotiate the reopening of the wildlife santuary while it complies with county demands to build a water tank, upgrade its wastewater treatement system and widen roads. Meanwhile, waystation officials say hundreds of injured wild animals are dying without veterinary care. By Holly Edwards. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.)  DWP-MANAGER (Los Angeles) -- The Los Angeles City Council on Wednesday made David Wiggs the city's highest-paid general manager of a municipal department. As the new general manager of the Department of Water and Power, Wiggs will be paid $284,000 a year -- plus a $3,500 a month housing allowance. By Rick Orlov. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.) "104733"	"I"	"think"	" A: That's a complex issue. The first thing you should know _ and this is something that many people may be surprised about _ but there's quite a large reservoir of good will towards Americans among Philippine Muslims, including Philippine Muslim separatists. In general, Filipinos have generally positive attitudes toward the United States and fairly positive memories of the colonial period, the first 50 years of the 20th century. That goes just as strongly for Philippine Muslims. In fact, some older Philippine Muslims have even more positive feelings because they feel they were better treated under the Americans than they were under Philippine government. They consider themselves to still be colonized essentially by the Philippine government. They want to separate. But they say American colonialism was better for them, less exploitative than Philippine colonialism. That's an important point that should be brought out ... Given that, the mere fact of U.S. troops on the ground, theoretically as advisers, will not set Philippine Muslims off. ... For Philippines in general, there will be some nationalist sentiment that says, 'We don't want Americans here. They've got to get out.' Philippine Muslims, I think, ... will be a bit more nuanced: 'Well, let's wait and see what happens here. Gee, it might be better having American troops running after these guys than Philippine military troops.' </P> "	"nyt_eng_200201.gz"

"105492"	"I"	"think"	" (Miles Benson can be contacted at miles.benson(at)newhouse.com) </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020205.0138 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-BUDGET-FAIRYTALES-NNS ) </DATELINE> <TEXT> GOVERNMENT'S 10-YEAR ECONOMIC FORECASTS A `FANTASY,' BUT A USEFUL ONE  ATTENTION EDITORS: This article from the NEWHOUSE NEWS SERVICE report of TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 2002, is available as a ``separate buy.'' For information about purchasing the article, contact DEBRA WEYDERT of The New York Times Syndicate at 732-390-4480; fax, 732-390-4697; e-mail, weyded(at)nytimes.com  Art Advisory: With a graphic excerpting the White House Economic forecast For information about purchasing art call 202-383-7824  Also transmitting in ``f'' and ``w'' categories By MILES BENSON  c.2002 Newhouse News Service  WASHINGTON _ The fairy tales start on page 53 of the new Economic Report of the President, a 448-page document made public Tuesday.  That's where the Bush Administration offers up its 10-year forecast for the nation's economic growth rate, inflation, unemployment and interest rates. Similar projections about future spending levels, taxes and deficits are found throughout the budget that Bush sent to Congress on Monday.  Both Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill and OMB Director Mitchell Daniels use the word ``fantasy'' in referring to the so-called ``out-year'' calculations.  So why does the government insist on producing these notoriously unreliable projections and use them to shape major policy decisions?  Because predicting the future is difficult, and educated guesses _ even if wide of the mark _ are better than nothing, experts say.  ``Economists are not terribly good at forecasting and probably never will be,'' said Alice M. Rivlin, a former director of the White house Office of Management and Budget and the Congressional Budget Office. ``The situation is too complicated and too affected by all kinds of events. It doesn't mean we shouldn't try.''  Robert Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the Bush White House Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledged that economists are ``always stronger'' looking in the rearview mirror than looking forward, but said forecasting still helps guide policymakers.  ``One reason is that it gives us a chance to illustrate what different long-term scenarios mean both for our economy and for the budget,'' he said.  Hubbard also acknowledged a certain defensive political necessity facing the White House. Critics often use the 10-year forecast to attack White House budgets.  ``Given the attention paid in some quarters to 10-year numbers, we as an administration felt it important for us to produce our 10-year numbers as well,'' Hubbard said.  Although he said the council does its best to generate accurate projections, they remain imperfect.  ``We want to be very careful from a budget perspective of putting too much credence to 10-year numbers, because we know that just over the past year revisions in economics have changed the budget forecast a great deal,'' Hubbard said.  But the administration and Congress both continue to base long-term planning on these shaky numbers, and many experts with experience inside the government defend the practice of using them.  ``They are monstrously misleading,'' said former Rep. William Frenzel, R-Minn. But he quickly added, ``We need them, of course.''  Why? Because new programs are often ``seeded with future time bombs'' so that they expand in later years,'' and projections reveal those costs.  ``The question is whether you want no map or a rough map,'' said William G. Gale, who served as senior staff economist for the Council of Economic Advisers ``No map is better if you are interested in hiding the (long-term) costs of your programs.''  Still, the Bush White House said it intends to shift to shorter, five-year projections in future budgets.  ``We have no idea, of course, what's going to happen over 10 years,'' Budget director Mitchell Daniels said.  He pointed to last year's forecast of a $5.6 trillion, 10-year surplus that shrank to about $1 trillion this year. And even this year's projection may be an illusion, he said.  ``The fact is, we don't know. Next year the $5.6 trillion could be back if the economy is back roaring strong again,'' Daniels said. ``Let's get real. It's hard enough, as we learned last year, to be precise about how much money the federal government will take in one or two years out, let alone 10. And too much attention to these fantasy numbers, I think, sometimes leads us down some misleading, some unproductive, cul-de-sacs.''  LF END BENSON  (Miles Benson can be contacted at miles.benson(at)newhouse.com) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020205.0139 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-DANGEROUS-DISPLAYS-OF-COURAGE-DISCOVER-ADVISORY-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ``WHY WE TAKE RISKS''  ``CAN YOUR CHILD LEARN SOME OF MOZART'S MAGIC?''  These articles, described in greater detail below, constitute this week's transmission of The New York Times Syndicate's Discover News Service. The stories are available as ONESHOTS. For purchase information, see end of text.  ALL THE ART IS FREE OF CHARGE AND AVAILABLE ELECTRONICALLY.  WHY WE TAKE RISKS  RISK-TAKING-DISCOVER _ Why did Steve Fossett, a mild-mannered multimillionaire from the Midwestern United States who had no particular need for publicity, try to fly around the world by balloon? Why did another American businessman recently pay $20 million to get himself launched into space on a Russian rocket? Why do ordinary people climb Mount Everest? The handicap principle holds that humans make showy and sometimes dangerous displays of courage to increase their status and attract mates. A report. By Richard Conniff.  FREE ART:  _ Two color slides show people running ahead of a herd of bulls at the start of the first Running of the Bulls event held in the Oasis Ranch in Mesquite, Nev.  CAN YOUR CHILD LEARN SOME OF MOZART'S MAGIC?  PERFECT-PITCH-DISCOVER _ Only one in 10,000 Americans has perfect pitch, and even professional musicians tend to make do with relative pitch: They can name only the intervals between notes. To approximate perfect pitch, some musicians memorize just one note, usually middle C, and then use relative pitch to navigate to others. For decades, biologists thought that perfect pitch was a genetic anomaly, passed on from generation to generation. But research studies have shown that perfect pitch is far more common than it seems. It's a form of speech rather than a feature of music _ and like speech, it can be learned. A report. By Michael Abrams.  FREE ART: One color slide shows children participating in Camp Broadway, a theater camp for kids in New York City that teaches kids how to express themselves through song.  Both stories are also available in Spanish. "111742"	"I"	"think"	" Does a team really need a high-end player to do well? Well, the first question about the superstar guy, I think, if you look at the last number of Stanley Cups that have been won, the team that's won has basically been the best team throughout the playoffs, but they have also had a lot of talented players on their teams. Colorado has, especially if Peter Forsberg comes back, they have got two or three superstar guys, maybe even a half-dozen. Same with Detroit and New Jersey when they won the Cup. I think the team that wins in the end _ you know, you can have a very good team, hard-working, but you do need the top type of players to get over the hump in the end. That's not to say that this year a team that does not have a superstar won't win the Stanley Cup; I think it is possible. If you have any questions, please call John Yearwood, Tom Uhler, or Lou Hudson on the Star-Telegram's National/International desk at 817-390-7784/85. Also see BC-TEXBUDGET-FEATURES, moving separately.  (Visit the Star-Telegram's online services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com)  N A T I O N A L / T E X A S (''a'' category unless otherwise noted)  CHURCH-ABUSE  UNDATED: In a not so distant time in the Roman Catholic Church, parishioners believed that father knew best. A priest's commentary on theological issues was gospel truth to a much less educated laity. And if a priest's moral conduct was questionable, the faithful defined faithfulness as remaining silent. But now, as the largest denomination in Christendom is being rocked by sexual scandals involving priests and children, the culture clash between the church hierarchy and the often well-educated and more affluent American Catholic laity has been laid bare. The laity is pushing for the hierarchy, which is not used to giving answers, to do just that. Story has moved. By BRETT HOFFMAN  YOUTH-OBESITY  UNDATED: One in five children nationwide is overweight. Yet in many areas, programs to help them slim down are in short supply. From the classroom to the doctor's office, overweight children often are ignored. If society does not start taking childhood obesity seriously, the long-term effects will be devastating, said Dr. Roger Unger, an internist and professor at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas. ``There's a reason why you don't see any fat older people,'' Unger said. ``It's because they're all dead.'' By JAN JARVIS  US-ATTORNEY  DALLAS _ Jane Boyle was sworn in Monday as North Texas' top federal prosecutor and joined the war on terrorism with a strong sense of patriotism. Boyle, 47, is well-known in Dallas' legal community as a former state and federal prosecutor. She was appointed a federal magistrate judge in 1990. ``One of the biggest challenges of our task is to be involved in disrupting and preventing acts of terrorism before they occur,'' said Boyle, the first woman to serve as U.S. attorney for the 100-county Northern District of Texas. ``I'm doing everything I can to make our communities safe against these type of attacks.'' By TONI HEINZL  GREEK-CHURCH  FORT WORTH, Texas _ They didn't leave the past behind them. They carried bits and pieces of it with them, crosses and icons _ more than 80 years of memories and a thousand years of tradition. The pilgrims turned south when they left St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church on Sunday, walking in a ragged line down Fort Worth's Northwest 21st Street past the the modest houses, the middle school, the pickups parked at the curb.It is only a mile from the tiny brick sanctuary built in 1917 on Ross Avenue to the church's new home with the golden Byzantine dome overlooking Fort Worth's once-infamous Jacksboro Highway. But every step took the oldest Greek Orthodox parish in Texas into the future. By MARY ROGERS  CHAPMAN'S-TEXAS  PASADENA, Texas _ On a warm, overcast Saturday in the Houston area, thousands of people filled their ice chests, zipped up their fanny packs and headed to the San Jacinto Monument in nearby LaPorte to celebrate the 166th anniversary of one of the most important battles in our nation's history. But in Pasadena, a few miles west of the battleground, but still along the banks of Buffalo Bayou, there is hardly a stir of emotion. Back off the Pasadena Freeway, a couple of blocks behind the circular-shaped Ramada Inn, and among the army of railroad tank cars that feed off the petrochemical complex, there is a solitary granite marker that says this was an important site in the San Jacinto victory. Its faded message begins, ``Site of Vince's Bridge destroyed by military permission April 21, 1836.'' It goes on to list the men whom Gen. Sam Houston dispatched to destroy the bridge. Primary among them was Erastus ``Deaf'' Smith. By ART CHAPMAN  MOM-SON-SENTENCE  FORT WORTH, Texas _ A mother and her son who once faced the threat of the death penalty are sentenced to 22 and 20 years in prison for their roles in the execution-style killing of a Mexican drug dealer in Fort Worth. It was one of three murders tied to Julius Robinson, the leader of an Arlington-based drug-trafficking ring, who was sentenced to death in March. Edy Zamudio and Christian Morales were rewarded for helping authorities crack the unsolved murder of Rudolfo Resendez. By TONI HEINZL  LOCOS-POSSE  FORT WORTH, Texas _ The last of the Crazy Enough Posse members is sentenced to five years in prison after pleading guilty to aggravated perjury about killings in which other members were involved. By MELODY McDONALD  WILDFLOWER-CENTER  AUSTIN, TEXAS _ Two decades ago, Lady Bird Johnson provided the inspiration and seed money for a wildflower center that could help promote the kind of beauty Texans enjoy each spring: a landscape blanketed with vibrant color and hardy native vegetation. ``Ugliness is so grim,'' the former first lady said at the time. ``A little beauty, something that is lovely, I think, can help create harmony which will lessen tensions.'' The National Wildflower Research Center had a provincial beginning in 1982. It was established on a small parcel of Johnson-owned property in east Austin. Actress Helen Hayes, who died in 1993, helped found it, and it concentrated on the state's beloved bluebonnets and Indian paint brushes. Now, 20 years later, the center has moved to southwest Austin and a plush 179-acre site with more than 400 native plant species growing on the grounds. It has blossomed into a respected national research facility that has emerged as one of the country's leading advocates for native plant conservation. It has also branched out beyond bluebonnets to embrace landscape restoration, Hill Country culture and ecological education. By ART CHAPMAN  C O M M E N T A R Y  ALDAPE-COLUMN  UNDATED: On a continent where some countries go through multiple presidents in successive days, it's no surprise that a country's commitment to democracy can be rather fluid. Often a resolute voice is needed to remind the region that democracy is key to hemispheric development. Despite the adoption of democracy by almost all governments in the Americas, many countries are subject to interference by the military and weakened by populations that have yet to fully accept the challenges and limitations of a democratic system. The recent political turmoil in Venezuela merely exposed the tenuous hold that democracy has in the region. But what is striking is that unlike past periods of instability, this time Latin America stood with mostly one voice, defending democracy and rejecting the coup in Venezuela. The government that most soiled its reputation by welcoming both the coup and the fall of a freely elected government was the United States. By JAVIER J. Visit the Star-Telegram's online services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com) nn </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020610.0230 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-FATHERS-DAY-DRENNAN-ADVISORY-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> EDITORS: Just in time for Father's Day (June 16), columnist Beth Drennan has written two evocative essays that capture the spirit of the holiday.  In the first Drennan recounts the moving tale of her father, who was a member of the Mighty Eighth U.S. Army Air Force, and the Dutchman who rescued him after his B-17 was shot down by Germans in World War II.  In the second, she coins the phrase ``father love'' _ like mother love, only it comes from a man, and it's there every time a man spends a moment taking care of someone, especially someone who is not his child _ someone he doesn't have to care for, but does, just to be kind.  STORY DESCRIPTIONS:  FATHERS AND HEROES: A TIME TO REMEMBER  DRENNAN-HEROES-FATHERS-COLUMN _ If there is anything good to be said about a dark night, it's that when you are in the middle of it, you can see where the lights are. And from what I can tell, if there is anything good to be said about war, it's that when you are in the hell of it, you discover the heroes. Long after the war ends, however, a different kind of discovery begins: the process of measuring the ongoing effects heroes have on the lives they touch with their courage. And if you calculate the gratitude owed to such heroes, compounded year after year, the counting will take longer still. I know, because a man once risked his life to protect a soldier, and that soldier was my dad. I am here because of one man's courage. (MORE) By Beth Drennan. 800 words.  (ART ADV: Photos of the author's father, Staff Sgt. Harry Horton Jr., his crewmate, Sgt. Edward F. Sobolewski, a headshot of Theo Hennekens and a picture of Horton's fake French passport are available on Wieck, Newscom or by calling the Syndicate Photo Desk at 212-499-3339.)  FATHER LOVE  DRENNAN-FATHERS-DAY-COLUMN _ Sometimes, I think, we take the annual Father's Day ritual for granted. You know the one: it starts with, ``Oops!'' when we remember on Saturday that Father's Day is Sunday. Then comes the cross-town zoom for the three-buck card, questionable tie, soap on a rope and whichever cologne smells most like a pine forest when test-sprayed on our sleeve. Not that taking things for granted is bad; in fact, it can be a comfort. When we take a thing for granted, it means there is one less thing on our worry list. But every string has two ends. That's why I've come to appreciate ``father love.'' (MORE) By Beth Drennan. 700 words.  If you have any questions, please feel free to contact Tim Hilchey at (212) 499-3530. She can be reached by e-mail at nytsyn-drennan(at)nytimes.com.) </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020613.0272 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-FATHERS-DAY-DRENNAN-ADVISORY-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> EDITORS: Just in time for Father's Day (June 16), columnist Beth Drennan has written two evocative essays that capture the spirit of the holiday.  In the first Drennan recounts the moving tale of her father, who was a member of the Mighty Eighth U.S. Army Air Force, and the Dutchman who rescued him after his B-17 was shot down by Germans in World War II.  In the second, she coins the phrase ``father love'' _ like mother love, only it comes from a man, and it's there every time a man spends a moment taking care of someone, especially someone who is not his child _ someone he doesn't have to care for, but does, just to be kind.  STORY DESCRIPTIONS:  FATHERS AND HEROES: A TIME TO REMEMBER  DRENNAN-HEROES-FATHERS-COLUMN _ If there is anything good to be said about a dark night, it's that when you are in the middle of it, you can see where the lights are. And from what I can tell, if there is anything good to be said about war, it's that when you are in the hell of it, you discover the heroes. Long after the war ends, however, a different kind of discovery begins: the process of measuring the ongoing effects heroes have on the lives they touch with their courage. And if you calculate the gratitude owed to such heroes, compounded year after year, the counting will take longer still. I know, because a man once risked his life to protect a soldier, and that soldier was my dad. I am here because of one man's courage. (MORE) By Beth Drennan. 800 words.  (ART ADV: Photos of the author's father, Staff Sgt. Harry Horton Jr., his crewmate, Sgt. Edward F. Sobolewski, a headshot of Theo Hennekens and a picture of Horton's fake French passport are available on Wieck, Newscom or by calling the Syndicate Photo Desk at 212-499-3339.)  FATHER LOVE  DRENNAN-FATHERS-DAY-COLUMN _ Sometimes, I think, we take the annual Father's Day ritual for granted. You know the one: it starts with, ``Oops!'' when we remember on Saturday that Father's Day is Sunday. Then comes the cross-town zoom for the three-buck card, questionable tie, soap on a rope and whichever cologne smells most like a pine forest when test-sprayed on our sleeve. Not that taking things for granted is bad; in fact, it can be a comfort. When we take a thing for granted, it means there is one less thing on our worry list. But every string has two ends. That's why I've come to appreciate ``father love.'' (MORE) By Beth Drennan. 700 words.  If you have any questions, please feel free to contact Tim Hilchey at (212) 499-3530. The New York Times News Service night supervisor is Pat Ryan; phone: 888-346-9867; e-mail: patryan(at)nytimes.com.  INTERNATIONAL  (Will move in the ``i'' news file.)  TERROR-CHINA (Beijing) _ The Bush administration's decision to brand as terrorist the East Turkestan Islamic Movement, an obscure Muslim group with roots in western China has been greeted with skepticism by many Western diplomats and scholars, who say the Americans have offered little hard evidence and appear intent on softening Chinese opposition to an attack on Iraq by handing Beijing a propaganda coup. It has also caused dismay and anger among Uighur exiles, including the majority that reject indiscriminate violence in what they call a struggle against ethnic tyranny. By Erik Eckholm.  The story has moved.  CHINA-WORKERS (Beijing) _ Six months after angry workers massed in a northeastern city, accusing urban leaders of fraud and theft, several of the officials they named have been jailed or fired. The charges shouted by protesters in Liaoyang last March have been largely confirmed by anti-graft investigators from Beijing, who found that officials were indeed milking the assets of fading state companies, even as workers and retirees were denied their meager wages and pensions. By Erik Eckholm.  DELHI-STREET (Delhi, India) _ When the Moguls laid out a broad avenue linking the imperious glory of the Red Fort to the Fatehpuri Mosque, they saw it as a sweeping public space, a sedate counterpoint to the grandeur of their monuments. Little did they know what was to come. Four centuries later, Chandni Chowk remains one of Delhi's best known streets, but not for any reason the Moguls imagined. More than any other place in Delhi, and perhaps India, Chandni Chowk has become home to the chaos of humanity trying to sustain itself any way it can. By Amy Waldman.  The story has moved.  NATIONAL GENERAL  (Will move in ``a'' news file.)  CONGRESS-EDUC (Washington) _ Democrats won a rare victory on the floor of the House Thursday when Republican leaders withdrew a bill to provide a limited number of low-income parents with a tax break for education expenses for their children. The bill stands no chance of passing the Senate and therefore no chance of becoming law. So the wrangling today was almost entirely about election-year politics and not about getting legislation enacted. By David E. Rosenbaum.  The story has moved.  WIRETAP-COURT (Washington) _ The nation's most secret appeals court has agreed to be a little less secret. The court, the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review, announced in a letter to the Senate Judiciary Committee that it would provide the panel with a copy of what is expected to be a signal ruling on the Justice Department's request for broad new wiretap powers. By Philip Shenon.  The story has moved.  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. She plans a double-major in international relations and theater.  ACT 1: ``My first play was 'Romeo and Juliet.' I was in third grade, but I went to a junior high school and auditioned for their play. They gave me the part of the Apothecary, the druggist who gives Romeo the drugs to kill himself.''  AND, ACTION!: ``When 'Bring It On' (the cheerleading movie that starred Kirsten Dunst) came out, I went with my mom to watch it. I had so much fun. I was like, 'Mom, I have to be in a movie just like this.' The first movie I got was 'Got to Kick It,' a dancing movie. It was like a dream come true.''  AN ADMIRABLE LEADING LADY: ``Pop culture teaches us to give up our identity and try to mesh in with everybody else, and here was this girl loving herself despite it all. I thought her confidence was really attractive.''  FINDING HER INNER ANA: ``My mom really never encouraged my acting career, so I knew what it was like to pursue something I was really passionate about it without the support of my family. I drew from those experiences of knowing what it's like to stand on your own. I think it's something everyone can relate to.''  THAT'S LIFE: ``The one thing about this movie is that it is a very real portrayal of an immigrant family's life. Family is the essence of Latin culture, I think, because family is supposed to take care of family. And that's kind of the sense you get in the movie. The mother feels almost betrayed, like the daughter is giving up on her family. They need her help and she's being selfish in a way by giving up on them.''  FAT, WHAT FAT?: ``When I leave this movie, Ana's weight problem is the last thing on my mind because there's so much more to the story. It's ultimately about loving yourself. Obviously in our society where you turn on the TV and all you see is diet pills! And a new diet plan! And exercise stuff! And, oh, how to get down to a size 0 in two days! it's such an apparent thing. To make a movie about reality and not factor that in is almost impossible.''  A CONFIDENCE-BOOSTER: ``Yeah, I want to feel good, I want to look good, I'm a person. Everybody wants to feel good about who they are, and that's what this movie is saying.''  WHERE TO SEE HER: ``Real Women Have Curves'' opens Friday. "130794"	"I"	"think"	" UNDATED: In a beautifully illustrated book entitled ``The Texas Longhorns: Living Legend of the American West,'' the author writes: ``The mottled hide and the sharp, twisted, spreading, and often lyreshaped horns of the Texas Longhorn are emblematic of one of nature's unique creations.'' The story talks about the longhorn's development; how it can thrive in hostile country, and how it multiplied through the laws of survival of the fittest. And how it was the only cattle breed to ``evolve without human management.'' Those are romantic notions; traditional thoughts that were once true. But in today's harsh business environment, they no longer apply. Money trumps tradition. Saturday, in what longhorn breeders are calling a historic event, the first clone of a Texas longhorn will be sold at public auction. The image of the breed, I think, could suffer. If copies can be made _ identical copies _ then how unique will they be? By ART CHAPMAN   </P> "	"nyt_eng_200211.gz"

And to his credit, he made sure that he didn't waste a minute of preparation so that when the time did come, he was ready to go. , he explains,	 CARDOSO-PENSIONS _ Various countries around the world, both developed and less developed, have introduced important changes to their national pension Schumes over the last two decades. What's behind this trend, writes Fernando Henrique Cardoso, former president of Brazil, is that most of the world's pension systems were created during the 1930s and '40s. They were based on the principle of society's responsibility to support those no longer able to work _ due to advanced age or disability _ and are mostly organized on a pay-as-you-go basis. But the recent wave of pension reform, he explains, has a demographic, rather than ideological motivation. As the number of senior citizens expanded, on a par with diminishing birth rates and increased life expectancy, pension systems have begun to show ever-widening deficits. In Brazil, he adds, pension system reform faces particular challenges that reflect sensitive societal interests. </P> 	nyt_eng_200306.gz

CNS articles are transmitted courtesy of the New York Times Syndicate/New York Times News Service. Some articles have photos, which are downloadable from a Columbia University Web site whose address is on the story. There is no cost to News Service or Syndicate clients for the articles, photos or downloads.  The articles are slugged BC-CNS-KEYWORD and move in the ``l'' news category. They are written by master's degree candidates at the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University and edited by adjunct professors who work at The New York Times, The Daily News, Newsday and The New York Post, among other places.  All we ask is that you send us a tearsheet:  Columbia News Service  Graduate School of Journalism  Columbia University  2950 Broadway  New York, N.Y. 10027  Professor Stephen D. Isaacs  Columbia News Service  E-mail:sdi1(at)columbia.edu  This week's articles:  BC-CNS-CHINESE-BEER (New York Be75473192;226032909212::473:4296062:75973$7:9:77)7152:9127:29,07&amp;473;4668978264::760579860 299:0::947 the imported beer market. The makers of Tsingtao Beer, Yanjing's rival and the longtime best-selling Chinese lager in the United States, thinks low-key reinforcement of its Chinese identity is the best way to expand. By Chuck Bennett.  BC-CNS-TYPEWRITER-FANS (New York) _ Personal computers have largely displaced typewriters these days. But even as the sleek computers and other electronic gizmos have vastly surpassed what an office worker could accomplish with a typewriter, the ribbon-equipped typewriters of the past still have a place in typewriter collectors' hearts. By Gaston F. Ceron.  BC-CNS-TANGO (New York) _ The tango -- invented in Argentina in the 1880s -- still lives in big cities across the world. In the United States, New York is seen as the mecca, where devotees can dance all night long. By Holly Hickman.  With photo.  BC-CNS-SHIPWRECK-LOOT (New York) _ Submerged vessels are at the center of a controversy in today's underwater archaeological world that pits archaeologists against treasure hunters. Archaeologists come up from the deep with the idea that these artifacts belong to the public and should be preserved, while treasure hunters seek riches from artifacts taken from the open seas to the open market. With improvements in technology, the debate is growing. The seas are becoming easier to probe and tougher for authorities to police. By Erika J. Euler.  BC-CNS-INTERNET-PRIVACY (New York) _ The Internet has enabled Web surfers to locate lost loves, friends, relatives, classmates, military buddies and even biological parents. But for individuals who do not necessarily want to be found, Web sites offering their addresses and phone numbers pose a threat to maintaining privacy. By Jamie Francisco.  BC-CNS-PREPPY-IS-BACK (New York) _ Preppy fashion is making a comeback. Ribbon and whale belts, kelly green and hot pinks, Lacoste and Lilly Pulitzer. Walk into an Urban Outfitters or a vintage clothing store and take a walk back into the '80s -- leave the legwarmers at home, please. By Danielle Belopotosky.  With photo.  BC-CNS-TEACHING-TO-SAVE (New York) _ It's never too early to teach children about the value of money. A small company in Seattle created Moonjars to help parent broach the subject. The Moonjar teaches three principles: to save, to spend and to share. By Danielle Belopotosky.  With photo.  BC-CNS-COTTON-CANDY (New York) _ Far from carnivals and amusement parks, cotton candy is finding its way onto dessert menus of swank Manhattan restaurants and elsewhere around the nation as chefs spin their frou-frou food with a touch of childish fun. By Joe Sunnen.  BC-CNS-TEENS-ON-COFFEE (New York) _ At coffee outposts in Manhattan's wealthier neighborhoods, coffee is all about glamour for teenage girls, but a recent study shows an unexpected risk. By Cynthia Needham.  BC-CNS-BOOK-RECONSTRUCTION (New York) _ All books have a limited shelf life. How long a book lasts depends on what it's made of, the way it's held together, and how it's handled and stored. Librarians and book conservators struggle to protect their holdings while working within a limited budget. Some improvements, such as environmental controls, help preserve entire collections. Other remedies, which can be expensive and time-consuming, can be implemented only one book at a time. By John Arbucci.  With photo.  BC-CNS-WEIGHTLOSS-BRACELETS (New York) _ Two women found inventive ways to take the work out of keeping track of losing weight. Slimmer Beads and Balance Bands were designed as simple means of keeping track of what you eat. B}07 hobby, sidewalk astronomers do the unthinkable: They carry hundreds - and sometimes thousands - of dollars worth of equipment into New York City's streets and parks, and invite strangers to play with their toys. Like modern-day Galileos, they look at Jupiter's moons, track sunspots and explore the craters of the moon. There are sidewalk astronomers in many cities, including Chicago, Albuquerque, N.M., and San Francisco. They go out on the street, they say, because one of the greatest pleasures they know is sharing the beauty of the universe with others. By John Arbucci.  BC-CNS-MYSTICAL-ISLAM (New York) _ More than 20 Sufi orders are flourishing in the United States. From the classically Islamic Helveti Jerrahi order to the more peripheral Western Blaketashi Darwishes, who base their practices on the work of the 19th century poet William Blake, Sufism has a vibrant and diverse American following. Yet some Sufis would argue that the recasting of Sufism in a Western context has spawned some orders that retain little or no Islamic foundation. By Alexandra Alter.  With photo.  BC-CNS-KITE-FLYING (New York) _ Flying kites is not just a casual pastime. It's part hobby, part sport, and it attracts thousands of serious practitioners from all over the country. Many are affiliated with kite-flying clubs that span the nation from California to New York. Kite flyers also congregate at contests and festivals, where they can learn new techniques, take part in competitions and mingle with other fans. Every year, the American Kitefliers Association sponsors a five-day convention; this year, the event is being held in Dayton, Ohio, starting on Sept. 29. By Gaston F. Ceron.  BC-CNS-PAGAN-CULTURE (New York) _ Once a private, closed-door practice, neo-Paganism has been outed by an array of Pagan Web sites and TV shows with witchcraft themes such as ``Charmed'' and ``Buffy the Vampire Slayer.'' Neo-Pagans represent a cross-section of America; they even serve in the military. By Heather Burke.  With photo.  BC-CNS-NAZI-HUNTERS (New York) _ Simon Wiesenthal, the famed Nazi hunter, has decided at 94 to close his files and end his search. Elderly survivors, still searching for justice, saw him as their greatest defender. They now feel betrayed. By Gal Beckerman.  BC-CNS-PERSIAN-RUG-SLUMP (New York) _ The fine carpet business is a tricky one. Importers like Kashif Aslam must travel to Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iran, countries often torn apart by con/flict, several times a year, purchase as much as $1 million in carpets in a single trip, and send their shipment back to the United States. Carpet hunters often have long-standing business connections in the cotnpries where they find rugs, so safety and security is a important but minor conkeRj. Rug dealers say they worry most about most is selling their wares. By Ted Weihman.  BC-CNS-HUMMERS-IN-MANHATTAN (New York) _ Steven Ehr,icI doesn't often brook streams, topple statues, or advance across angry terrain in his Hummer H2. He drives it around New York City, rolling across the swarming urban grid to visit his son uptown or deliver his wife, Beverly, to one of the local hotels where she likes to swim and eat breakfast. The Ehrlichs could get around in another car, if they had one, but why take the risk? By Eric Gershon.  BC-CNS-THANKING-SAINTS-ONLINE (New York) _ Tucked between ads for call girls and notices for garage sales, a mysterious line of type can be found in hundreds of newspapers across America: Thanks to St. Jude for prayers received. Not required by the church, these tiny ads are an a both a manifestation of faith and a bit of advertising -- and the Internet is helping both along. "140710"	"I"	"think"	" The other trick is better, I think, but more work. Take out all that old caulk, then buy some 4 1/4-by-4 1/4-inch cap tiles, those with a curved top and used to top off a wall of tile. Attach these tiles to the bottom row of tiles around the tub, leaving a minimum gap beween tub and tile of 1/8 to 3/16 inch. Use a thin-set mortar to attach these tiles. After grouting them, fill that gap with a generous bead of adhesive caulk, smooth it off and press it in with your fingers. The caulk will ooze into the gap, making a secure bead. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200408.gz"

, they believed,	 In 1971, CBS pulled those classic shows from its schedule, and turned toward more urban-directed ones like The Mary Tyler Moore Show and All in the Family. That reconfiguration changed the prime-time landscape, said Ron Simon, television curator at the Museum of Television and Radio. Advertisers wanted to reach young, urban, sophisticated viewers, he said. The type of audience that shows like 'Hee Haw' reached was not what the networks and advertisers were looking for. "142822"	"I"	"think"	" The hostility Cassavetes inspired has always puzzled me. Like Orson Welles, he didn't always play well with others and he didn't make all that much money for the movie industry. The other reason for the discomfort, I think, is that he called himself an artist. Many critics prefer their art with subtitles or not at all. Cassavetes dared to believe that art and movies were not mutually exclusive, and he never gave up on the movies' capacity to move us, to make us feel, to connect us to the world and to other people. It says something about our age that it actually comes as a shock to hear him talk with such frank sincerity about his films as art, which he does in a French television interview included in the Criterion box set. Like a benevolent pedagogue, he draws dotted lines between his preoccupations, points in many directions, suggests various means of interpretation and delivers multiple references. But what he adamantly refuses to do, both in this film and elsewhere, is draw our conclusions for us, which may be the highest compliment a filmmaker can pay his audience. In a letter to a friend, Dante wrote of The Divine Comedy: The meaning of this work is not simple for we obtain one meaning from the letter of it and another from that which the letter signifies; and the first is called the literal, but the other allegorical or mystical. , it seems,	 Not that old times have been forgotten. Strolling around downtown Greenwood is like walking into one of those 1970s William Eggleston photographs that invoke a faded version of the 1940s Delta. Not a building has been built or torn down, it seems, since Greenwood's last heyday, the post-World War II years when cotton was still king. Not far from the grand Leflore County Courthouse, several blocks of sturdy early-20th-century red-brick commercial buildings, from modest to modestly magnificent, sit in various states of use. The night supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Lynn Hoogenboom; phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: lyhoognytimes.com.  TOP  Lede stories: 4-column hed  BUSH (Washington) -- President Bush vowed on Thursday to move quickly and aggressively to enact the plans he set out during the campaign, saying the people made it clear what they wanted. In a 40-minute news conference, Bush said he would begin working immediately on his proposal to overhaul Social Security, called for Congress to move speedily to limit lawsuit awards against doctors and signaled that he had settled on the broad outlines of his ideas for rewriting the tax code. Let me put it to you this way: I earned capital in the campaign, political capital, and now I intend to spend it, Bush said. He repeated that he wants to reach out across party lines after a campaign that emphasized partisan and ideological divisions and left raw feelings on both sides. But he left unclear how much, if at all, he would compromise to achieve some degree of partisan comity, especially after an election that gave him a convincing victory, strengthened conservative Republicans in Congress and left Democrats weaker. By Richard W. Stevenson.  With photos, NYT1-4, 8.  (An early lede has moved. The 1stld-writethru is scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in p news file.)  Top center:  MIDEAST-ARAFAT (Paris) -- Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was in serious condition in the intensive care unit of a French military hospital on Thursday after a sharp deterioration in his health and amid conflicting reports that he was fighting for his life. This was a day of rumor but little hard information about the health of Arafat, 75, who for 40 years personified his people's struggle for an independent state. After a report in the Israeli media and by Luxembourg's prime minister that Arafat was dead, the head of communications for French military health services was forced to issue a formal denial. By Elaine Sciolino.  With photo.  (An early lede has moved; the 1stld-writethru is scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in i news file.)  Off-lede:  IRAQ-EXPAT-VOTING (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Iraqi electoral officials said Thursday they would allow millions of Iraqis outside the country to vote in the coming election. The decision appeared certain to increase tensions with Iraq's Sunni minority, since many of the expatriate voters are Shiites. We've decided to allow Iraqis abroad to vote, and the mechanism will be worked out in the upcoming days, said Adel al-Lami, a supervisor for the Iraqi Independent Electoral Commission, which is charged with organizing the elections, scheduled for January. The voting will take place in those countries with a large number of Iraqis. The United Nations and the United States had recommended against allowing expatriate voting, fearing a political backlash from Sunnis as well as the potential for fraud, but leading Iraqi politicians, as well as Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, strongly supported the move. By Edward Wong.  SENATE-SPECTER (Washington) -- When Sen. Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican, faced the toughest primary race of his political career, President Bush came to his rescue, campaigning with Specter at every turn. But when both men were re-elected, Specter's first words to the president were a warning against nominating Supreme Court justices who would overturn the 1973 ruling legalizing abortion. On Thursday, as outraged conservatives tried to block Specter's rise to the chairmanship of the Senate Judiciary Committee, the Pennsylvania senator issued a statement clarifying his remarks, saying, I did not warn the president about anything, and I have never and would never apply any litmus test on the abortion issue. The controversy suggests that despite talk of a political mandate, the long-running battle over federal judgeships will be in full bloom when the new Congress convenes next year under strengthened Republican control. By Sheryl Gay Stolberg.  TAX-SHELTER (Undated) -- A federal judge has temporarily frozen more than $500 million in financial assets owned by thousands of doctors and dentists who bought what the government says are abusive tax shelters run by a San Diego investment company, xelan Inc., the Justice Department announced on Thursday. The unusual action is one of the largest of its kind and is a major effort by the Internal Revenue Service to clamp down on tax shelters it considers abusive. By Lynnley Browning.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in f news file.)  MEDICARE-TREATMENTS (Undated) -- For the first time in its history, Medicare is offering to systematically use its vast population of patients as research subjects to determine if new, expensive and complex treatments actually work and, if so, in whom. By Gina Kolata.  ELN-POLLS (Undated) -- For all the complaints about public polls this year, for the most part they predicted the election accurately -- often showing President Bush with a slight lead. But few showed him getting more than 50 percent of the national vote, or the overwhelming importance so many voters seemed to have placed on cultural issues. So while some pollsters were taking victory laps over their results, others were eating crow. By Jim Rutenberg.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in p news file.)  NY-ELECTION-BOARD (New York) -- Further details of the failures of the voting plans put in place by the New York City Board of Elections. The problems came as no surprise to the critics of the board and even some of its own members, and they presage what some officials say could be mass confusion in 2006, when the city is expected to begin voting with electronic machines. By Jennifer Steinhauer.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in p news file.)  EDWARDS-CANCER (Boston) -- Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of Sen. John Edwards, the former Democratic vice presidential candidate, received a diagnosis of breast cancer Wednesday, the day John Kerry conceded the presidential election, a spokesman announced Thursday. By Randal C. Archibold.  With photos NYT10, 41.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in a news file.)  ELN-ROVE (Washington) -- Victory may have a thousand fathers, but if President Bush's triumph this week had a Big Daddy it was indisputably Karl Rove -- the seer, strategist and serious student of politics and the presidency that a grateful Bush himself referred to as the architect of his winning campaign. By Todd S. Purdum and David D. Kirkpatrick.  With photo NYT 7.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in p news file.)  ELN-BUSH-RELIGION (Undated) -- For all the attention focused on evangelical Christians, President Bush's owed his victory to an impressively widespread swath of religious America. By Laurie Goodstein.  With photo and graphic.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in p news file.)  INCREDIBLES-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) -- A.O. Scott reviews The Incredibles, an animated film directed by Brad Bird with the voices of Craig T. Nelson, Holly Hunter, Wallace Shawn, John Ratzenberger and Jason Lee. , he argues,	 The new initiatives began this year when McClellan, who is both an internist and an economist, decided that evaluating treatments for elderly Americans falls under Medicare's purview to pay for whatever is medically necessary. If the treatment doesn't work, he argues, then it really isn't medically necessary. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, he said,	 With cancer drugs, he said, the tradition is that the new medications are tested in situations that their makers think are most likely to show benefit. That leads to approval by the FDA. Then the drugs often come into widespread use off-label -- doctors give them to patients with different cancers or in combination with other cancer drugs, trying the drugs out in new contexts. Medicare is required to pay for the original approved use and for uses that are listed in certain drug compendia. Other than that, Medicare payments for off-label uses are up to the discretion of local contractors to the agency. Some pay; others do not. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz

, he warned,	 . . Today, showpieces like Frank Gehry's Stata Center or Steven Holl's Simmons Hall, both at MIT, grandly lay claim to Boston's architectural vanguard. The Carpenter Center, on the other hand -- wedged between Harvard's Fogg Museum of Art and the Faculty Club, off the east end of the Yard on Quincy Street -- is familiar mostly to architects and architectural scholars. Not that it isn't arresting. It has been described as looking like two grand pianos copulating, with its two broadly curved wings resting on thin columns and meeting in a geometrical central structure of stacked concrete and glass boxes. A ramp rises from Quincy Street and runs through the building's open center before descending to Prescott Street behind it. When Harvard approached Le Corbusier in 1958, it had already embraced architectural modernism. Twenty years earlier the university had brought Walter Gropius, the father of the Bauhaus, over from Germany to head the GSD. His successor, Sert, was a close friend and collaborator with Le Corbusier. Gropius's Graduate Center and Sert's Holyoke Center and Peabody Terrace had already been built. When Harvard needed a building to house its newly created undergraduate visual arts program, it was Sert who suggested commissioning Le Corbusier. Having America's only building by Le Corbusier, he told Harvard's Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences McGeorge Bundy, would be like having the country's only Picasso. In Le Corbusier, Harvard met a man whose self-regard matched its own. Born Charles Edouard Jeanneret in Switzerland in 1887, he rechristened himself at the appropriate age of 33, conflating an ancestral name, Le Corbesier, with his nickname, 'Corbeau' (Crow). In his 1923 manifesto Toward a New Architecture he wrote rapturously of a supreme determinism under which a just and peaceful society would inevitably flourish. He wanted to raze cluttered neighborhoods like Paris's Marais and replace them with a Radiant City of ethereal skyscrapers and wide greenways. Only enlightened architecture, he warned, could prevent social unrest from boiling over into workers' revolution. But when Sert offered him the job, Le Corbusier was still angry at what he called American officialdom for his treatment during the design process for the United Nations headquarters, where he had been turned down for the commission only to see his ideas incorporated into the final complex. Ultimately, though, he couldn't turn down the chance to build in the United States, a country that early in his career had represented for him the possibility of the machine age. And the Carpenter Center's role in both housing and embodying Harvard's arts program coincided with his idea that architecture should synthesize all the arts, including painting, sculpture, and even music. As the architectural historian William Curtis has written, Le Corbusier wanted the building to be a manifesto. Le Corbusier only visited Harvard twice, but one of his most vivid impressions of the place was the overlapping tides of students that filled Harvard Yard as pealing bells signaled the break between classes. He was fascinated by that, Sekler recalled in a recent interview, how it suddenly came to life. As recounted in Le Corbusier at Work, Curtis and Sekler's definitive account of the building's creation, Le Corbusier was disappointed by the way his given site was closed off from the Yard, but he still sought to incorporate it into his plan, most dramatically with his S-shaped ramp, which he envisioned as an extension of the paths that crisscrossed the campus. In piercing the center of the building, the ramp would draw people in, both conceptually, by collapsing the distinction between internal and external space, and practically, by tantalizing them with a glimpse of the work going on in the glass-walled studios alongside the ramp. Electronic tones would issue from speakers along the ramp, echoing the choreography of bells and movement he had witnessed in the Yard. But the building didn't turn out exactly as Le Corbusier envisioned it. The electronic tones were dropped early on. More significantly, he was forced to abandon his plans to cover the building's external spaces with a garden, an extension of the greenery of the Yard. Unlike the manicured quads, he had wanted it to be a natural, untended garden -- seeded entirely by the wind and birds and insects, watered by the rain and allowed to run riot all over the building's several terraces. The idea didn't particularly appeal to the Harvard administration, and a lack of safety rails rendered most of the proposed space off-limits anyway. Today only the lower front terrace has a garden, and it's a rim of dirt thinly covered in summer with weeds. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, he says,	 Raised in the Midwest and upstate New York, Gabridge has a mild-mannered presence. He's not shy, he says, but says other playwrights can be. He knows how much easier it is to endlessly fine-tune a script than to send it out or take a director to lunch, the kind of networking that can be personally scary but is necessary for getting page to stage. Consequently a lot of plays end up languishing in drawers or on hard drives. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, I confess,	 Once upon a time, I was a little girl growing up in Dayton, Ohio, in a family that thought theater was a Good Thing in the abstract but never actually went to see a play. But I would listen to my mother's tales of Radio City and my father's memories of seeing Broadway shows with his cantankerous aunt (she hated everything, and dragged him away at the intermission of every musical from Oklahoma! to South Pacific), and I would dream of going to the theater myself. And what I dreamed of then, I confess, was not Shakespeare or Moliere or even Rodgers and Hammerstein. It was the Rockettes. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, he said,	 So did Kurt Cobain, who routinely claimed that the loud-soft dynamics of Nirvana's breakthrough hit Smells Like Teen Spirit was a blatant Pixies rip-off. Radiohead's Thom Yorke, another grateful fan, agreed to headline last spring's Coachella Festival, he said, because the Pixies would be there. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, they say,	 With work taking up so much time, they say, fewer employees are involved with the social structures, gatherings, and activities that, over time, shape families and communities. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, he said,	 So, when you retrieve your e-mail you can also go in, and with a headset attached to the computer, you can listen to all messages without even touching the telephone, said Lawrence. Even more advanced, he said, is the concept of presence communication. Through a collaboration portal, it allows you to reach a colleague, and see whether they are using e-mail, are in a meeting, or on the telephone. So, you can know if they are available before you contact them, Lawrence said. PENSION PLAN RETURNS BETTER THAN 401(K)S </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz

, she said,	 O'Loughlin said it was possible that more research could identify those at high risk for addiction. , he said,	 After they die, all those bodies decompose and they fertilize the forest, Yang said. This spike in nutrients, he said, may explain previous studies that showed an increase in tree growth in the first few years after a cicada emergence. Resource pulses like this are not uncommon; examples include synchronized heavy seeding by trees and mass deaths of salmon after spawning. Resource pulse dynamics are occurring in a lot of ecosystems, Yang said. Cicadas are just a very clear example. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, he said,	 In effect the bugs are responsible for two pulses: one in life, feeding animals and birds, another in death, feeding soil. Times Regional Newspaper Group. For use by member papers only.  We have news from Lakeland and Sarasota.  The goal of PHOTO-BUDGET is to be a forum for exchanging advice, equipment reviews and news about your photo department. Take issue if you disagree with an equipment review, but likewise let us -- and your counterparts at other papers -- know if you agree and have more to add. There's a lot of expertise out there and we are trying to help you share it.  Susan Kille and Stephen G. Reed are at the NYTRENG Wire Desk: (212) 556-1518.  ---  PHOTO EDITORS: Does everyone in your department see the PHOTO-BUDGET? We certainly want this weekly missive to reach photo editors, but any other shooter who sends his e-mail address to nytrengnytimes.com will be added to the list.  QUESTIONS, SUGGESTIONS: Call us at (212) 556-1518 or zap an e-mail message.  Part of this is repeated from last Tuesday's budget due to the Holiday week. I feel the subject is important and deserves more discussion. Some editors did respond, thanks.  How many NYTRNG papers ran the photo by AP Photographer John Moore in last Wednesday's papers? The image, which I bet is nominated for a Pulitzer, shows an Army Nurse as he tries to save the life of an American soldier by giving him CPR upon arrival at a military hospital in Baghdad, Iraq on Tuesday, Nov. 9, 2004. But the soldier died. The soldier was fatally wounded in a Baghdad firefight with insurgents. He lies on a stretcher and a wedding band is on his left hand that tells you he has a family. If you did run it then you know what I am talking about but the file should still be in your AP Server JBM107. I have archived it.  After being here for 20 years I can't ever remember running an image like this so big on 1A. When I found it in the AP server last Tuesday I made a proof and took it to Editor Skip Perez expecting to have a battle to get any ink on 1A. Skip agreed that the image was extremely powerful and illustrated the effects of war on our troops. We ran it six columns above the fold. Lots of other papers ran it about the same size, like the Tampa Tribune. The calls and the letters started coming in, about 20 calls the best I can figure. We have had Letters to the Editor about the image. At first it was ugly, how dare The Ledger show troops in this manner. How would you like it if it was your son? Then we started getting some positive letters. Skip Perez responded to some of them and his comments really help to explain things to the readers. The following is one of Skip's responses to a reader:  Dear Mr. Williams,  Ledger Publisher John Fitzwater passed along your e-mail critical of our front-page photo showing the dying soldier in Iraq. I respect your point of view.  I don't profess to always be right or certain about my judgments. I have been doing this job for 28 years and have made my share of mistakes. I do know a powerful, heart-grabbing photo when I see one. This was such a rare photo. That is why we used it and played it as we did.  I have also been around this business long enough to know that it's risky for anyone to make judgments about how someone's family might feel about us publishing a photo of a family member in crisis or death. I have spoken to family members about tragic photos we've published and some have thanked me.  We received about 20 phone calls or letters concerning the photo. Most were critical, but if you've been following our letters column, many praised our decision as well. Attached is a copy of one letter, from a military veteran, whose view differs from yours.  Again, thank you for being a longtime subscriber of The Ledger. We value your loyalty. Most days, I hope, you enjoy and are illuminated by what you see and read.  My name is John Carter. I'm retired U.S. Army. I was a first sergeant. I want to say that picture that I saw was not inappropriate. That picture represents what really happens in war. People must be aware that the cost of freedom is so soldiers and marines that are dying. So thank you. You'll get some flack over this, but I support you one hundred percent.  Responses from NYTRNG editors re. the photo:  We opted not to run the CPR photo.....being so close three area military bases, we thought it was a smattering too close to home for many family members.  We ran the photo, but on an inside page in color. I tried hard to get it on Page 1 but was resisted. I was asked if the soldier was already dead, which would have killed it's running here. Cheerios test and all. But the caption said he was still alive when the photo was taken. Our desk editors are pretty squeamish and harsh reality, especially when unpleasantly represented, is a tough sell. But at least we ran it. Kudos to Jim Osteen, our exec, who supported running it at all.  After looking at 75 portfolios over the last two months the following web page best explains my feelings. All of the NYTRNG Photo Editors/Chief Photographers have more experience than me with hiring....Because no shooter has left here in 18 years and I guess I am the closest one to the door because I have a foot in the casket and ride motorcycles. You're going to need high speed cable ... it's a quicktime movie.  http//www.sportsshooter.com/special_feature/2004_luau_video/port_rev  iews/ind ex.html  On the geek side:  I am just starting to use a Sprint Palm Treo650 Cell Phone with Bluetooth. Having all kinds of trouble using the Treo with the Powerbooks simply because Palm and Sprint have not released a real working Mac Desktop Software. So far, I can view Wieck and other Web pages from the phone, it's not real fast or easy but it can be done. I need to spend a little more time with it...  One gig Lexar 80X Compact Flash Cards as cheep as $75? ecost.com  On the photo front:  On Wednesday, Photographer Rick Runion and Business reporter Kevin Boufford are doing a story on the recovery of a local blueberry farmer after being hit by all three hurricanes this year.  On Friday night photographer Michael Wilson will cover Lt. Col. Hiram Mann who is a featured speaker at Sun 'N Fun's Aviation Expression lecture series. Mann is one of the original Tuskeegee airmen.  On Sunday the Tampa Bay Bucs and their worthless place kicker will play the Atlanta Falcons at Raymond James Stadium at 1PM. Photographer David Mills and one TBA will cover for deadline. All images will be posted to Wieck by 5PM.  The Herald-Tribune in Sarasota last month revived and expanded a photo feature called Life Through a Lens.  We have kicked around the idea for a photo column for quite a while and we finally made it happen, said MIKE LANG, director of photography.  A photo column, like a written column, has a point of view. While visual, photo columns usually include a narrative that pairs with images to express an idea. A photo column can have one image or several and a general goal is to convey an impression that readers haven't seen before.  Life Through a Lens is the name of a photo column that had run in one edition of the paper, but the new version runs prominently in all editions. It began its new life on Oct. 25 with a five-column spread of photos and text by CHIP LITHERLAND. Litherland captured the images after he finished an assignment at Mote Marine Laboratory in Sarasota and decided to play tourist for an hour.  Litherland wrote that Mote's aquariums provided an opportunity for instant nature photography but he did not take a conventional approach. His choice of black and white images added a sense of mystery to photos that include the fin of a tiger shark cutting through water, a moray eel showing his teeth, the silvery face of a lookdown and X-ray-like images of moon jellyfish.  The feature appears on the cover of the Florida West section every other Monday.  Since the relaunch, Life through a Lens has appeared three more times: THOMAS BENDER visited a group of Civil War re-enactors; PHIL DIEDERICH showed why he was sure a long election season was over; and Litherland looked for and found something different at a groundbreaking ceremony.  Space availability can vary greatly, so we will need to be flexible with the design, Lang said. One week, it might be several photos and a copy block written by the photographer. Another week, it might be a single image with a healthy cutline. Either way, it will be a great showcase for our staff photographers to publish photos that might not get in the paper anywhere else.  Doug Engle, senior photographer, (352) 671-6409; cell (352) 425-2476  Director of Photography Jim Matthews, (352) 374-5029: jim.matthewsgvillesun.com  Director of Photography John Metzger, (707) 526-8529, jmetzgerpressdemocrat.com  Deputy Director of Photography Chad Surmick, csurmickpressdemocrat.com  Picture of the week -- http://www.pressdemocrat.com/photos/gallery/  Matt McKean, photo editor, 256-740-5754 - cell: 256-436-2695 -Pager: 256-984-0886, matt.mckeantimesdaily.com  The above is not only one of the company's Rules of the Road, it is the specific goal of PHOTO-BUDGET.  To that end, please pass along news, advice, photo ideas, questions and anything else that will help connect NYTRENG photo departments by sharing information that will help us all do our jobs better. It doesn't take much time to share information and the benefit to others can be large.
