Yet Survivor not only survives, but thrives, even if co-workers no longer threaten to vote you off the island. And while The Apprentice has ceased to merit racks of magazine covers, it continues to tenuously hold a spot in the Top 10.Reality television is no passing fad ... but several of its hits are. Some of these shows arrive loud, noisy and demanding attention only to limp away after a season or two.Seriously: When was the last time you thought of Anne Robinson? I had to look up the name of the witchy Weakest Link host, even though her NBC show was white-hot for a spell in 2001.Now American Idol returns for Season 4, with a two-night premiere Tuesday and Wednesday. There's no doubt that future installments are in the offing in the years to come.(There will also be three special Monday episodes in February. In other words: With Fox's history of shifting programming, you're best advised to check weekly listings.)There's a simple reason why some reality shows last while others fade: simplicity.Take MTV's The Real World. The show has 15 seasons in the can, and just re-upped for five more. That longevity is the result of a basic concept ... take (predominantly) good-looking young people of different backgrounds and interests and make them live together.Rule No. 1, I think, is the more gimmicky these things are, the less shelf life they've got, said Robert Thompson, director of the Center for the Study of Popular Television at Syracuse University. In the end, it's the ones with the fewest bells and whistles ... that do the best. It certainly doesn't get any simpler than Idol. Sure, you can cite Simon and Paula and Randy and Ryan as contributing factors to the show's success. (OK, not Seacrest. But allow the point.) </P> "	"nyt_eng_200501.gz"

, he said,	 Recently, after a long, midstorm ski session at Mammoth Mountain, Calif., Dan Molnar glided home along a steep route that locals call the Condo Chute. From there, it's usually a short walk back to his two-story house. But there was so much snow, he said, that he was able to walk from the hill right onto the top of his roof -- and then skied off it, he said, right to the back of my house. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz
, he said,	 In mid-January, snow cleanup crews from Colorado to California were still uncovering buried cars and having trouble finding space to dump tons of freshly plowed snow. Brian O'Hara, a forecaster at the National Weather Service office in Reno, Nev., said that while the snowfall totals for these storms were impressive, they didn't set records for a single storm. But Molnar said that these storms outdumped even the deepest snows of California's '97-98 El Nino winter, when his dog could sit on the snow and chew on a branch in his yard that is 12 feet off the ground. Now, he said, that branch is buried. Even the locals who pride themselves on being kind of glib and nonchalant are saying that it's been a long time since they've seen this much snow, he said. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz
, she said,	 In the Wasatch Range, Park City, Utah, is flirting with record snow depth totals and is 100 percent open. The day after Christmas, up to this past week, it snowed two weeks without stopping, said the Park City spokeswoman Krista Rowles Parry. We've had 138 inches in that time. While main thoroughfares are now clear, she said, Park City has resorted to hauling away its snow and paying a company to melt it. Snowbanks are 20 to 25 feet high around town, she added. It's crazy, because it's like driving around in snow tunnels. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz

Five car bomb blasts rocked Baghdad Wednesday as suicide bombers hit targets that included the Australian Embassy, the latest attacks in an intensified campaign of violence apparently meant to disrupt nationwide elections planned for Jan. 30. (Staff byline TK)  An early lede has moved.  And  IRAQ-ELECT (Undated) -- A look at the mechanics of the Jan. 30 election. From training as many as 200,000 poll workers to tabulating the choices of approximately 14 million eligible voters, the logistical challenges of organizing the election has been lost in the wash of violence and political strife. By James Glanz.  IRAQ-BRITAIN (London) -- Folo on the release of graphic Iraqi prisoner abuse photos at the court martial of British soldiers, which has created an uproar in Britain and put renewed pressure on Prime Minister Tony Blair. By Alan Cowell.  MIDEAST (Gaza City, Gaza Strip) -- Developments. Palestinian security forces will fan out near Gaza's borders with Israel within days to enforce President Mahmoud Abbas' order to halt militant attacks on Israelis, their top commander says. Israel radio says the army has been given permission to launch an invasion of Gaza if rocket attacks by militants don't stop. By Greg Myre.  MEXICO-DRUGS (Mexico City) -- Prosecutors believe the police or possibly federal agents are behind the murder of the brother of former President Salinas Gotari, newspapers here have reported. Reports say the victim, Enrique Salinas, had hired federal agents or police to protect him from the demands of his ex-wife, who was seeking a part of the millions in cash that had been unfrozen in French bank accounts. By James C. McKinley.  PLAVIX-TEST (Undated) -- Plavix, an expensive and popular blood thinner, is no better than a much cheaper alternative, aspirin combined with the over-the-counter stomach protector Prilosec, a study suggests. By Gardiner Harris.  SMALL-STARS (Undated) -- The smallest star ever to be reliably weighed has tipped the scales at more than twice its expected weight, astronomers said today. The work casts doubt on much of what astronomers thought they knew about low-mass bits of cosmic litter, like so-called brown dwarfs, hovering on the edge of stardom, suggesting that astronomers have systematically misidentified these objects, which though faint far outnumber the more luminous stars, and have underestimated their masses. By Dennis Overbye.  BUSH INAUGURAL (w code)  INAUGURAL-POLL (Undated) -- When President Bush is sworn in on Thursday for his second term, he will lead a nation that is generally optimistic about his presidency, but doubtful that he will unite the country or make any real progress on the nation's most pressing problems -- including Iraq, terrorism, the economy, the budget deficit and the cost of prescription drugs, according to the finding of the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. By Adam Nagourney.  INQUGURAL-RELIGION (Washington) -- Incorporating religious elements into inaugural week and inaugural addresses has been the practice of many modern presidents. The visibility of religion and prayers in President Bush's festivities, and among some of his most prominent supporters, seems more conspicuous than in the past, they say, because society at large is more secular. On Inaugural Day, Bush attends a private church service; much of the music at the event will carry a religious theme. But the role of religion in inaugurations probably reached its apex with Eisenhower, who delivered his address in the form of a prayer. By David D. Kirkpatrick.  INAUGURAL-BUSH (Washington) -- President Bush's day as he attends pre-inaugural events and prepares to be sworn in at Noon on Thursday for his second term. By Richard W. Stevenson.  INAUGURAL-LAURA-BUSH (Washington) -- In an interview, Laura Bush talks about her agenda for a second-term and her family's relationships. She said she hoped to focus some on new efforts to pay attention to how boys are raised (pilot programs in Pittsburgh and elsewhere), as well as on other children's issues. Although she usually keeps much of herself hidden, she joked about being friskier than most people suspect. By Todd S. Purdum.  UNITED STATES -- National General (a code)  ELN-EXIT-POLLS (Undated) -- The exit poll consortium releases a report describing a number of problems with the presidential election exit polls that led to an overstatement of Sen. John Kerry's numbers. By Jacques Steinberg.  CALIF-EXECUTE (San Francisco) -- A possibly brain-damaged killer, Donald J. Beardslee, was executed by the state of California early Wednesday morning. Plus a look at the execution's import for the 600 inmates still awaiting execution here. By Dean E. Murphy.]  TIMES-LEAK (New York) -- A federal judge in New York hears arguments from two New York Times reporters seeking to stop subpoenas of their phone records in the case of a raid on Islamic charities in Chicago. By Adam Liptak.  UNITED STATES -- Other Washington (w code)  RICE-CONFIRM (Washington) -- WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Condoleezza Rice was overwhelmingly endorsed by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday to be the next secretary of state, but only after some spirited exchanges signaled that Iraq will be a divisive issue in President Bush's second term. The 16-2 vote by the panel cleared the way for Rice to be confirmed by the full Senate, in all probability in time for the inaugural celebrations on Friday. All 10 Republicans on the committee voted in favor, as had been expected. Six of the panel's eight Democrats also voted in favor, with only Sens. Barbara Boxer of California and John Kerry of Massachusetts in opposition. By Steven R. Weisman.  An early lede has moved.  GONZALES-CONFIRM (Washington) -- After tough questions are raised by Democrats who thought Alberto R. Gonzalez was too evasive in answering questions about torture policies, the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday morning put off the confirmation vote on his nomination to be attorney general. By Eric Lichtblau.  LEAVITT-CONFRIM (Washington) -- President Bush's nominee for secretary of health and human services, Michael Leavitt, gets tough questions on Medicaid at a confirmation hearing before the Senate Finance Committee. He will also be asked about FDA, drug safety, welfare and the new Medicare drug benefit. By Robert Pear.  FINANCIAL (f code)  ECON-FORUM (Undated) -- For a few days each January, Klaus Schwab, a German-born former business school teacher, throws the ultimate A-list party -- gathering chief executives, political leaders, activists, and the occasional rock star for a blend of high-flown talk and down-and-dirty networking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Schwab, 65, has built a thriving business around the conference, housed in a elegant hillside headquarters outside Geneva. But the World Economic Forum still lives and dies on the cachet of Davos. Two weeks before opening day, the planning here has reached a fever pitch. By Mark Landler.  MITSUBISHI-OUTLOOK (Tokyo) -- Mitsubishi Motors is scrambling to secure new financing and outline a strategy for reversing the huge losses it has incurred as a result of a series of management mistakes over the last several years. By Todd Zaun.  PHILIPPINES-ECON (Singapore) -- The Philippines said that the government posted a budget deficit in 2004 of 186.1 billion pesos ($3.35 billion), 7 percent less than its deficit in 2003 and 6 percent below the government's own target for last year. Economists attributed much of the improvement to higher tax receipts by the country's customs bureau, notably on imported oil and petroleum products. By Wayne Arnold.  EU-CHEMICALS-FINES (Brussels, Belgium) -- The European Union head office imposed fines totaling $283 million on the chemical giants Akzo Nobel, Atofina and Hoechst for carving up among themselves the European market for a chemical used to produce detergents, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics. By Paul Meller.  GM-EARNINGS (Detroit) -- General Motors reported that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 37 percent because of higher health care costs, losses in its European divisions and accounting charges. The company said earnings came in at $630 million, or $1.11 a share, down from $1 billion, or $2.13 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue was $51.34 billion, up 5.1 percent from $48.84 billion. By Jeremy W. Peters.  CHASE-EARNINGS (New York) -- J.P. Morgan Chase reported that its fourth-quarter profit declined 11 percent as charges related to its acquisition of Bank One ate into the bottom line. Net income came in at $1.67 billion, or 46 cents a share, compared with $1.86 billion, or 89 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Last year's results don't include the Bank One merger. By Timothy L. O'Brien.  LUCENT-EARNINGS (Undated) -- Lucent Technologies' profit fell 49 percent as higher expenses, gains in the year-earlier period, and struggles with its wireline business overshadowed revenue growth. By Ken Belson.  EBAY-EARNINGS (Undated) -- EBay will post fourth-quarter earnings after the market closes. By Gary Rivlin.  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) -- Short items on business news from around the world.  ECONSCENE (Undated) -- The weekly Economic Scene column. By Jeff Madrick.  GREER-BIG-BROTHER (London) -- Germaine Greer stirs up a fuss by agreeing to move into Britain's Celebrity Big Brother house and then moving out after one show. What does this tell us about the waning celebrity's traffic with the hot flame of fame? By Sarah Lyall.  BATH-THEATER-REVIEW (New York) -- As You Like It, a Theater Royal Bath production, at Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater. Reviewed by Ben Brantley.  SOCIETY-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) -- The Society of Others, by William Nicolson (Nan W. Talese/Doubleday). Reviewed by Janet Maslin.  FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION please contact Gary McCardell, News Service day editor; e-mail garymc@nytimes.com; 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. , they agree,	 Beyond their concerns about the legitimacy of the election lie a host of other disagreements with the president. They express pessimism about the upcoming election in Iraq, ask why no one has been held accountable for prewar intelligence errors, and voice fears that Bush's proposed changes to Social Security will lead to benefit cuts down the road. His educational and economic policies, they agree, are a disaster for the nonrich. This incredible skewing toward the haves, getting people to vote against their own interests: It is incredible, says Rothstein. The president's syntax also comes under fire: It is embarrassing to hear him speak, says Baughman. He can't put two sentences together. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz

For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.  INTERNATIONAL (i code)  IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Developments. Five car bomb blasts rocked Baghdad Wednesday as suicide bombers hit targets that included the Australian Embassy, the latest attacks in an intensified campaign of violence apparently meant to disrupt nationwide elections planned for Jan. 30. (Staff byline TK)  An early lede has moved.  And  IRAQ-ELECT (Undated) -- A look at the mechanics of the Jan. 30 election. From training as many as 200,000 poll workers to tabulating the choices of approximately 14 million eligible voters, the logistical challenges of organizing the election has been lost in the wash of violence and political strife. By James Glanz.  IRAQ-BRITAIN (London) -- Folo on the release of graphic Iraqi prisoner abuse photos at the court martial of British soldiers, which has created an uproar in Britain and put renewed pressure on Prime Minister Tony Blair. By Alan Cowell.  MIDEAST (Gaza City, Gaza Strip) -- Developments. Palestinian security forces will fan out near Gaza's borders with Israel within days to enforce President Mahmoud Abbas' order to halt militant attacks on Israelis, their top commander says. Israel radio says the army has been given permission to launch an invasion of Gaza if rocket attacks by militants don't stop. By Greg Myre.  MEXICO-DRUGS (Mexico City) -- Prosecutors believe the police or possibly federal agents are behind the murder of the brother of former President Salinas Gotari, newspapers here have reported. Reports say the victim, Enrique Salinas, had hired federal agents or police to protect him from the demands of his ex-wife, who was seeking a part of the millions in cash that had been unfrozen in French bank accounts. By James C. McKinley.  PLAVIX-TEST (Undated) -- Plavix, an expensive and popular blood thinner, is no better than a much cheaper alternative, aspirin combined with the over-the-counter stomach protector Prilosec, a study suggests. By Gardiner Harris.  SMALL-STARS (Undated) -- The smallest star ever to be reliably weighed has tipped the scales at more than twice its expected weight, astronomers said today. The work casts doubt on much of what astronomers thought they knew about low-mass bits of cosmic litter, like so-called brown dwarfs, hovering on the edge of stardom, suggesting that astronomers have systematically misidentified these objects, which though faint far outnumber the more luminous stars, and have underestimated their masses. By Dennis Overbye. SCOTUS-ELECT (Washington) -- The Supreme Court hears arguments in a political parties case in which the question is: Can a state limit a party's right to hold an open primary and let members of any party vote if they want to. In this Oklahoma case, the minor parties want the state's so-called closed primary opened. The state says it can't do this as a matter of state election law. But a federal court ruled that the state has to open the primary if the parties ask for it. By Linda Greenhouse. , he said,	 There are millions of containers in circulation, he said, any one of which could be used by terrorists as a Trojan horse. But if I knew a particular container had been tampered with, he said, I could intercept it without causing problems for everyone else. A suspect container could be identified and isolated for inspection without interrupting regular cargo operations. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz
, he said,	 Smart containers would also be important in the aftermath of an attack, he said, for forensic investigation. If we had an al-Qaida-style attack at two ports at the same time, he said, it would create uncertainty about all containers, possibly bringing trade to a standstill. But if you could go back into the data and find where the boxes came from, you could narrow down the set of problems, he said, without having to close down the whole system. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz

, she said,	 Greer explained that she had joined the show because she wanted money to help rehabilitate her 125 acres of Australian rain forest, as well as to strike a blow for old ladies. , he said,	 The claim may sound overly dramatic, because two or even three dishwashers together are only marginally louder than one, said Alan Fierstein of Acoustilog, an acoustical consultant in New York. Putting two units together doesn't make it twice as loud, he said. They could be playing on people who know a little but not enough about sound. Comparing the noise levels may be futile because competing manufacturers tend to measure sound differently, Fierstein said. They may measure sound at the front or from the sides, he said, or measure middle-range sounds only and not the lower-frequency hums or rumbles, which are a lot of the problem, Fierstein said. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz
, it seems,	 Consumers, it seems, will go to most any length to ensure greater peace in the home. They will spend 20 percent more on Jeld-Wen's ProCore Quiet Door (filled with particle board and costing $150 pre-hung) over hollow interior doors. The ProCore door, shown last week in a new five-panel Rockport style, is not soundproof but transmits only half as much sound as hollow models. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz
, she said,	 Yet the rub is that people don't want completely quiet exhaust fans, said Karen Collins, Broan's marketing manager. Because the bathroom is often in a public area of the house, she said, People want a certain level of noise as camouflage. Noise, it turns out, can be a plus when it helps give you a little privacy. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20050119.0144 type=story > <HEADLINE> STAR POWER FUELS L.A. , she said,	 Results of the consumer testing and other research should be ready by March, she said, and production would run into April. The ads would be ready for final commission approval in May and would air by the fall. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz
, she explained,	 Some of the proceeds, she explained, will go to the John Coltrane Foundation, a fund that has supported young jazz musicians for 18 years by giving them scholarships to music schools. Some will go to Jowcol, the Coltrane publishing company; some to her own charities, including churches and hospitals in Los Angeles and Detroit, the Red Cross, and a small school for orphans in Puttaparthi, India, near Madras. , I panicked,	 We bought digital cable service. We installed it. We juggled remote controls. We turned on the television set. The HD set seemed to make almost every channel look horrendous -- blotchy, jumpy, blurry, generally icky. I admit it, I panicked, thinking it was broken and realizing that I could not possibly lug the thing back downtown for a replacement if it did not work. I began surfing channels and discovered a few new stations, what I now call the 700 club, because they are where heaven resides on the cable dial. They are the high-definition channels. </P> 	nyt_eng_200501.gz

, he said,	 The Plavix study comes in the wake of several other trials that have shown unexpected safety problems with widely used drugs. The arthritis drug Vioxx, made by Merck, was withdrawn in September after it proved to double the risk of heart attack and stroke. Studies of Celebrex and Bextra, similar medicines made by Pfizer, also showed substantially increased risks. But Chan said he was not suggesting that Plavix should be withdrawn or that it is particularly dangerous. You need not hold the SC-X105 in your hands to catch the action as you fly down the piste or cling to the face of a cliff. A separate wide-angle lens module can be attached to a hat or a limb with the included straps, while the camera itself remains tucked away in a pocket or pack. , they say,	 Charles Stein is a Globe columnist. He can be reached at steinglobe.com. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20050207.0077 type=advis > <HEADLINE> SCIENCE-TIMES-BUDGET-NYT </HEADLINE> <TEXT> The New York Times News Service plans the following Science Times stories for papers of Tuesday, Feb. 8.  SCI-CRIME-EVIL (Undated) -- Many psychiatrists assiduously avoid the word evil, contending that its use would precipitate a dangerous slide from clinical to moral judgment that could put people on death row unnecessarily and obscure the understanding of violent criminals. In an effort to standardize what makes a crime particularly heinous, a group at New York University has been developing what it calls a depravity scale, which rates the horror of an act by the sum of its grim details. And a prominent personality expert at Columbia University has published a 22-level hierarchy of evil behavior, derived from detailed biographies of more than 500 violent criminals. He is now working on a book urging the profession not to shrink from thinking in terms of evil when appraising certain offenders, even if the E-word cannot be used as part of an official exam or diagnosis. By Benedict Carey.  SCI-MOLE (Undated) -- Researchers at Vanderbilt University have found that the star-nosed mole can eat 10 mouthful-size chunks of earthworm, one at a time, in 2.3 seconds, or 0.23 second a chunk. That is the fastest eating ever measured in any mammal. By Carl Zimmer.  SCI-HELIUM-WHISTLING (Undated) -- In the world of quantum physics, particles leap through impenetrable barriers or exist in two places at once, secret codes can't be broken, electrical currents pass through wires without resistance. Here's another quantum trick: liquid helium that whistles. By Kenneth Chang.  SCI-Q&amp;A (Undated) -- A science question answered: What is the nutritional difference between fresh fruit and the same fruit dried, for example between grapes and raisins and fresh and dried apricots? By C. Claiborne Ray.  SCI-MINI-SOLAR-SYSTEMS (Undated) -- Astronomers have found what they say may be a miniature solar system in the making. In the latest example of the apparent fecundity of nature, astronomers have determined a tiny starlike object too small to be a star is surrounded by a tiny disk of dust that could someday form planets, which could perhaps be able to support life for a short while -- a few million years of so. By Dennis Overbye.  SCI-SATURN-HOTSPOT (Undated) -- More than shimmering rings and a smoggy moon the size of a planet sets Saturn apart in the solar system. It also has an unusual hot spot at the tip of its south pole. By John Noble Wilford.  SCI-WATCH (Undated) -- News and notes on science: Using a 960-kilowatt transmitter, researchers beamed radio waves into the ionosphere during an auroral display and produced speckles of green light that were captured by a camera; role specialization in hunting has now been seen in bottlenose dolphins; Japanese researchers have found living things in sediments in the deepest place on Earth, a Pacific Ocean trench that is 35,750 feet deep. By Henry Fountain.  With  SCI-NAMING-MONKEYS (Undated) -- These days, if you're willing to pay the asking price, you can put your name on just about anything -- a basketball arena, a hospital wing, perhaps even a subway station. How humdrum. The Wildlife Conservation Society, on the other hand, is offering some true naming-rights excitement. The group will be auctioning off the chance to name a new species of monkey. A short by Henry Fountain.  SCI-ALZHEIMERS-DISTRESS (Undated) -- A Side Effects column. Something to worry about with Alzheimer's: researchers have found a clear correlation between the proneness to distress and the likelihood of developing Alzheimer's. By James Gorman.  SCI-MISCARRIAGES (Undated) -- The agony of infertility for thousands of women in the United States is not that they cannot conceive, but that they cannot hold on to their babies beyond the first few weeks of pregnancy -- and that no one can explain why. Doctors say that as many as 3 percent or 4 percent of couples who try to have a child suffer from recurrent pregnancy loss, in which women under 40 experience three or more consecutive miscarriages with the same partner. A quarter of those couples, the doctors say, will probably remain in the don't know why category. The Centers for Disease Control estimates that, of the 6.23 million pregnancies recorded in the United States 1999, a million ended in spontaneous abortion. A 25-year-old has about a 15 percent chance of miscarrying; by 42, that figure is above 50 per cent. Although miscarriages are common, they are often not talked about, nor are they much studied. By Emma Daly.  SCI-DOCTOR-YEARS (Undated) -- Does the practice of medicine have a natural lifespan? Every doctor, every patient (and every insurer) would probably answer differently. An essay by Abigail Zuger, M.D.  SCI-PATIENTS-LANGUAGES (Undated) -- What's a doctor to do when the patient doesn't speak her language, and she doesn't speak his. And, when the hospital translation service doesn't cover a language as basic as French. Then, it takes a little creativity. By Danielle Ofri, M.D.  SCI-REALLY (Undated) -- The Claim: Loud music can cause lasting hearing problems. The Facts: .... By Anahad O'Connor.  .SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) -- News and notes on health and medicine. By John O'Neil:  -- Treatments: Steroid injections are as effective as surgery in treating carpal tunnel syndrome, a new study concludes. The findings, published last week in the journal Arthritis &amp; Rheumatism, also note that the injections appeared to provide faster relief.  -- Behavior: Soothing music may help older people sleep, reseachers in Taiwan determine.  -- Therapies: A new rehabilitation technique has helped patients who lost some of their sight through strokes to recapture parts of their fields of vision, according to a study presented last week at the American Stroke Association's international conference in New Orleans.  -- Patterns: The injectable contraceptive sold under the name Depo-Provera is popular with adolescent girls and young women, but has been shown to reduce bone density during this crucial period of growth. A new study has found, however, that those who stop taking the drug catch up in about a year.  SCI-AUTISM (Undated) -- Within the last year, several laboratories have reported finding important new clues about autism, the mysterious syndrome that robs children of normal brain development. For the first time, they say, a coherent picture is emerging: in autism, subtle brain abnormalities are present from birth. Infants and toddlers move their bodies differently. Between the ages of 6 and 24 months, their heads grow much too fast. Parts of their brain have too many connections while other parts are underconnected. Moreover, their brains show signs of chronic inflammation in the same areas that show excessive growth. The inflammation appears to last a lifetime. By Sandra Blakeslee.  SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) -- The Personal Health column: Total knee replacement is now one of the nation's leading orthopedic operations, and it promises to become even more popular as the population ages (and grows heavier) and the body's most vulnerable joints fail to withstand the punishment of decades of use and abuse. Debilitating wear-and-tear arthritis is the major reason that knee bones are being replaced by two-pound pieces of metal in people who wish to remain mobile, pain-free and physically active in their later years. But the recovery, the writer confirms with personal experience, is prolonged and painful. By Jane E. Brody.  Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients. Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (212) 556-4204. , they say,	 The doctors who argue that evil has a place in forensics are well aware of these risks, but say that in some cases they are worth taking. "153750"	"I"	"think"	" Patriots receiver P.K. Sam faces a paradox. The harder he tries to forget 2004, the more he wants to remember it. The title-winning year for the Patriots proved quite forgettable for the rookie receiver. It began when Sam, acting on dubious advice, elected to leave Florida State after his junior year. The Patriots grabbed Sam with the 164th pick, a spot where riches are unlikely and a roster spot isn't even a certainty. A fifth-round pick - the last pick of the fifth round - is nowhere close to being financially secure, said Sam, who earned a little over $350,000 last year. Sam said the draft-day disappointment began a season-long funk that included being placed on injured reserve in the middle of the season, and low-lighted by a suspension from the team prior to the Super Bowl. Not only was that embarrassing, but it hurt, Sam said. I think that's finally when I hit that wall and I said, 'P.K. you got to turn this around. This league is going to move on without you, so you either turn around now or you're just going to be out of luck.' Sam has latched onto Deion Branch, picking his brain about the offense, and it has helped him relax. A couple of nice leaping catches at last week's minicamp could be a sign of things to come. Once you get more relaxed, it opens up opportunities, I think, Sam said. I still have a long way to go, but at least I have something to build on now. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200506.gz"

, he confesses,	 Alan Alda was born Alphonso D'Abruzzo, his mother was a schizophrenic, he contracted polio when he was in the second grade and as an adult he took Zoloft to combat depression. Who knew? This likable and seemingly untroubled man has long been an anomaly among actors: married to the same woman for nearly 50 years, a loving father and grandfather, politically outspoken, intellectually curious, morally steady and uncomplicated. Yet here we learn that when he was 3 the chorus girls at the nightclub where his father performed would take him to their dressing room and make him turn his back as they changed their costumes, and he would listen to the sound of their clothing sliding on an off their bodies, and smell the perfume and sweat in their clothes. It was, he confesses, far more interesting for a 3-year-old than you might imagine. So his book is an anomaly, too, a celebrity memoir of wit, substance and surprises. It reads like a series of stories rather than a record of his life, and while they never reveal more than you want to know, they're engaging and funny. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz

, she says,	 If Schulman works so hard to reach her students, perhaps that's in part because the world, as she sees it, has not always done as much for her. She has not, for instance, been as successful as she feels she deserves to be. Oh, she's been recognized; her seven published novels and two works of nonfiction have won many awards (she was a finalist for the Prix de Rome), while her playwriting has earned her most of the plum residencies and fellowships available. But there is still that sixth-floor walkup and that two-hour-each-way commute and the constant effort to get theaters to mount her work, while some writers she considers her peers struggle far less and have, she says, more personal choice about which of their plays will be produced. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz
, she said,	 Schulman feels there's a simple reason she isn't among them: She's a lesbian who writes openly about lesbians in an industry largely run by men. Often, works that reinforce dominant fantasies about oppressed people are inflated beyond their merit, she explained in an e-mail message, judiciously omitting the names of the works she meant. Whereas works like hers, she said, address oppression from a more authentic perspective and are therefore ruthlessly marginalized. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz
, she said,	 In that, I got off lightly. Though she won't discuss them, her feuds and pyrotechnic fallings-out are well known. No one I contacted would comment on the record, except to praise her as an artist. (I wish her nothing but success, she truly deserves it, the playwright Craig Lucas said.) It's hard to know how many of these relationships foundered on professional instead of personal shoals; in any case, Schulman laughed when I told her how much she is feared. Their fear, she said, is actually anger: the anger of privileged people being forced to question the source of their privilege. Anyway, she said, making an incredulous face, what can I do to these people? Apparently she meant what could she do beyond attacking them in public and alluding to them unflatteringly in her novels and plays. Two of the less likable characters in Manic Flight Reaction clearly allude to -- or are named for -- former friends. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz
, she said,	 But that effort, she said, has been worth it. Artistically, she has emerged from the process as a senior writer with a very wide palette who can handle, she added, pretty much anything. She now has nine plays in various stages of development; it is perhaps most telling that one of them, a 1920s farce called The Lady Hamlet, will have its first reading, starring Kate Burton, on Oct. 27 at the New York Theater Workshop -- where the reviled Rent originated. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz
, she said,	 If Schulman is trying to put her past behind her, it's a difficult past to dismiss. She has, she said, suffered from other people a lot. The outlines of an awful upbringing are easily discernible in some of her novels, and many of her friends died of AIDS. She does not like to discuss any of this, except through her work; as a typically pithy line in Manic Flight Reaction has it: When people find out that something truly horrible has happened to you, they show no mercy. Nevertheless, she feels optimistic, rather like her character Marge, struggling to settle into normalcy at the last minute. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz

The truth is, I was sort of a recluse. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200510.gz"

, they assert,	 Besides, they assert, these searches are useless. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
, he said,	 The randomness of the searches is their virtue, said David Cohen, the deputy police commissioner for intelligence. Unpredictability is the enemy of the terrorists, Cohen testified. They are not as sophisticated as some may think, he suggested. Bag inspections increase the risks for them, he said, and along with that the chances that they could just mess up. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
, he said,	 The attack was the worst in Basra, Iraq's second largest city, since early September, when a taxi exploded and killed 16 people, also outside a restaurant. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051101.0044 type=advis > <HEADLINE> DINING-NYT-BUDGET </HEADLINE> <TEXT> Food and dining stories from The New York Times News Service for Wednesday, Nov. 2.  MICHELIN-GUIDE-NY (New York) -- Michelin today announces the star ratings for its New York City guide to restaurants. This is Michelin's first guide outside of Europe. The book, which will go on sale on Friday, will include 500 restaurants in the five boroughs. By Florence Fabricant.  HINDU-MULSIM-HOLIDAYS (Undated) -- This week, in a rare coincidence of calendars, Hindus and Muslims from all over India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are celebrating their most joyous holidays of the year. Hindus observe Diwali and Muslims end Ramadan with Eid ul-Fitr. And both holidays are utterly soaked in sugar. Festive piles of pink, green, yellow, orange and white sweets, some shimmering with silver leaf, others snowy with shreds of coconut or crunchy with nuggets of pistachio, are integral to many religious celebrations and social rituals in South Asia. But these sweets, called mithai by Indians, have an almost religious significance in everyday life. By Julia Moskin.  With recipe.  NEW-ORLEANS-DINING (Oxford, Miss.) -- Officially, the theme of the eighth annual Southern Foodways Symposium that ended here at the University of Mississippi on Sunday, was the region's lasting love affair with sugar and sweets. But like other people in the American food world, the 250 people in attendance talked mostly about New Orleans and the Gulf Coast and their culinary future. John T. Edge, the director of the Southern Foodways Alliance, which runs the symposium, said he was confident that nearly all the nationally known New Orleans restaurants would eventually reopen. What troubles him, he said, is the po' boy shops, oyster bars, red-beans-and-rice joints and other mom-and-pop businesses that have given New Orleans dining so much of its zest. For every bit of cheerful news about a restaurant reopening, there were worried questions, especially about the small, often black-owned places in hard-hit parts of town. By R.W. Apple Jr.  SIMPLE-COOKING (Undated) -- The weekly feature: Easy polenta. By Mark Bittman.  With recipe.  MASTER-CHEF (Undated) -- Chef Dona Abramson, chef of Bright Food, makes autumn salsas. By Dana Bowen.  Last is a series of vegetarian chefs.  With recipes.  CHICKEN (Undated) -- Chicken remains the great international comfort food. But as the new world of flavor has evolved over the last 40 years, the simple chicken may have changed more than anything else on the American dinner table. There's now an infinite variety of recipes, thanks to immigration and ambitious chefs, and an increasing diversity of chicken itself, thanks to innovative farmers. By Joan Nathan.  With recipes.  WINE-TIMES (Undated) - The fortnightly feature: The Wines of the Times panel drinks California Rhone blends. This package includes an essay on tasters' impressions of the wines, a tabular report rating the wines and a recipe for a dish that goes with the wines. By Eric Asimov.  We expect to move all Dining Section stories by early evening with a d category code, unless otherwise indicated.  For information and repeats call the News Service at (888) 346-9867 or (212) 556-1927.  NEW YORK TIMES PARTNERS:  Please note that the New York Times News Service report includes news and features from The Arizona Republic, The Boston Globe, Cox News Service, The Denver Post, The Detroit News, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, Hearst Newspapers, The Houston Chronicle, The Kansas City Star, The Los Angeles Daily News, McClatchy News Service, The San Francisco Chronicle, The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, The St. Petersburg Times and the New York Times Regional Newspapers. Unauthorized use of budgets and advisories constitutes a violation of our contract terms. All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051101.0045 type=story > <HEADLINE> BC-LANGUAGE-COLUMN-BOS SHACK ATTACK </HEADLINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
, he said,	 He doesn't tell me when he goes on a mission until it's over, she said. I follow the news. I know soldiers are getting blown up on the road. He doesn't want to worry me more than I already am. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051101.0064 type=advis > <HEADLINE> NYT-WORLD-BUDGET </HEADLINE> <TEXT> Editors at publications outside the United States may find the following stories from The New York Times News Service for Wednesday, Nov. 2, of particular interest:  INTERNATIONAL (i code)  IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Developments, including a lottery conducted to determine the placement of parties on the ballot in the December parliamentary elections. By Edward Wong.  With photos, NYT1-3.  An early lede has moved.  OLY-KOREA (Dateline TK) -- In a step toward reconciliation, North and South Korea agree to form a joint team for the 2006 Asian Games and the 2008 Beijing Olympics.  MIDEAST (Jerusalem) -- An Israeli air strike near Gaza City today killed two wanted Palestinians, including one that Israel had singled out as a top priority. An Israeli missile destroyed the car carrying Hasan al-Madhoun, 32, a senior figure in the Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades who had organized a suicide bombing and several other deadly attacks against Israelis in the past two years, according to the military. For the past 10 days, the Palestinian factions and the Israeli military have clashed repeatedly, with the Palestinians firing rockets from Gaza into southern Israel and the Israelis staging airstrikes in the coastal territory. By Greg Myre.  KYRGYZSTAN-UNREST (Moldovanovka, Kyrgyzstan) -- Special forces soldiers stormed prisons in this Central Asian nation today, restoring at least the appearance of order to a federal penitentiary system that had partly slipped from government control last month. Four prisoners were killed, the authorities said. By Ethan Wilensky Lanford and C.J. Chivers.  U.N.-HOLOCAUST (United Nations) -- The U.N. General Assembly votes to make Jan. 27 the international day to commemorate the Holocaust. By Warren Hoge.  SCIENCE (a code)  BUSH-FLU (Washington) -- President Bush on Tuesday unveiled a plan to combat the threat of an avian flu pandemic, calling for $7.1 billion in emergency spending to stockpile reserves of medicines and to press ahead with the development of a new vaccine. While no cases of the H5N1 avian flu virus have been detected in the United States, more than 60 people have died from the virus, all of them in Asia, and 140 million birds have been killed worldwide to try to stop its spread. By Gardiner Harris.  With photo and graphic.  An early lede has moved.  GLOBAL-WARMING (Undated) -- If emissions of heat-trapping gases continue to accumulate in the atmosphere at the current rate, there may be many centuries of warming and a near-total loss of Arctic tundra, according to a new climate study. By Andrew C. Revkin.  CERVICAL-CANCER (Undated) -- A program for cervical cancer in which screening was coupled with quick treatment for high-risk women has very good results, a study in JAMA reports. By Denise Grady.  UNITED STATES -- National General (a code)  NEW-ORLEANS-SAINTS-DAY (New Orleans) -- The cemeteries of New Orleans, where many interred coffins were forced to the surface in the flood, drew thousands of Catholics on Tuesday observing the annual rite of All Saints Day. It was a day tinged with fresh mourning, when still-struggling residents cleaned the graves of loved ones, some of whom died in the storm, honoring lives lost this year and in the past. The confluence of All-Saints Day and Halloween is always keenly felt here, because more than any other American city, New Orleans is a place where the spiritual and secular worlds are spicily entwined. It's a place where the prevailing Catholic fervor lives with the mysticism of Voodoo in an atmosphere of neighborly tolerance, a place that reveres its ancestors, a place where food and music and sex and death are viewed as the fundamentals of existence. By Bruce Weber.  With photo.  DELAY-TRIAL (Austin, Texas) -- A judge here is to rule on a change of venue request by Rep. Tom Delay's defense team. By Ralph Blumenthal.  With photo.  NY-PRINCE (New York) -- Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, and his new wife visit New York. By Joyce Wadler.  ALIOTA-CONFRIM (Washington) -- Developments on the selection of Judge Samuel A. Aliota Jr. as he heads to Capitol Hill to begin meeting with senators. By Karl Hulse and David D. Kirkpatrick.  With photo, NYT4.  With  ALIOTA-ABORTION (Undated) -- A closer look at cases related to the issue of abortion that Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. handled. By Adam Liptak.  And  ALIOTA-IDEOLOGY (Washington) -- If everyone agrees that Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. is a good, smart, well-qualified candidate for the Supreme Court, is it legitimate for the Senate to reject him based purely on ideological issues? By Scott Shane.  SCOTUS (Washington) -- The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday in the hallucinogenic tea case, with the question being whether a church's need to import an illegal hallucinogenic substance for its sacred rituals trumps federal drug law. By Linda Greenhouse.  CHENEY-ADDINGTON (Washington) -- A profile of David S. Addington, the new counsel for Vice President Dick Cheney. By Douglas Jehl.  BUSH-TAXES (Washington) -- The Bush advisory commission on taxes issues its final report, recommending that many popular deductions be limited or abolished to generate enough money to allow the alternative minimum tax to be repealed. By David E. Rosenbaum.  ABRAMOFF-INQUIRY (Washington) -- The congressional and Justice Department investigations of lobbyist Jack Abramoff have broadened to include scrutiny of Abramoff's efforts to pressure senior officials at the Interior Department, including Secretary Gale Norton. On Wednesday, Sen. John McCain's Indian Affairs Committee holds the last of his public hearings. By Phillip Shenon.  FINANCIAL (f code)  FED-RATES (Washington) -- The Federal Reserve continues its series of 0.25 percent interest rate increases. By Edmund L. Andrews.  With graphic.  AUTO-SALES (Detroit) -- Auto makers report sales for October. By Micheline Maynard.  DYNEGY-FRAUD (Houston) -- Former Dynegy executive Jamie Olis' 24-year accounting fraud sentence was overturned by a federal appeals court, which found that the trial court overstated the loss caused by Olis's crimes. The decision upholds the conviction and sends the case back to a federal district court for re-sentencing. By Simon Romero.  BRITAIN-SHIPPER (London) -- It had been a sinew of empire, a shipping line that ferried soldiers and diplomats, even royalty, on the Victorian mail runs that tied Britain to its outposts far to the east and beyond. But when the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co. became the object of a likely bidding war on Monday after a takeover approach from Dubai Ports World, it seemed as if the 165-year-old company might be heading the same way as so many other onetime jewels in the British economic crown -- into foreign hands. And, as P&amp;O stock has soared on speculation that Danish and Hong Kong contenders might enter the bidding, pushing the price above $5 billion, the contest invited perhaps a more philosophical question: what makes Britain so relaxed about selling companies to outsiders in a way that many in continental Europe -- France, Italy and Germany in particular -- seem reluctant to emulate? By Alan Cowell and Heather Timmons.  UBS-EARNINGS (Undated) -- UBS reports record third-quarter profit, showing how institutions with large wealth management businesses are starting to reap the benefits from a boom in oil-related wealth in the Middle East and Asia. Unlike Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch, whose profit surged on rising global stock and bond markets, Swiss banks are making themselves less reliant on trading profits. By Tom Wright.  SUN-EARNINGS (Undated) -- Sun Microsystems will post first-quarter earnings after the market closes. By Laurie J. Flynn.  VIACOM-EARNINGS (New York) -- Viacom Inc. swung to a $708.5 million net profit in the third quarter amid strong performances at its cable and entertainment segments, bouncing back from a loss in the year-ago period when results were hit by a charge for the Blockbuster Inc. video-rental business. By Geraldine Fabrikant.  SMART-ELEVATORS (New York) -- Elevators of the future have started to arrive in New York. At the Marriott Marquis, for instance, riders will no longer have to cope with a widespread pet peeve: doors that open at floor after floor once the car is full. By Fred A. Bernstein.  Editors, the News Service will file these briefs, except when all items are from other news agencies:  In addition, many clients receive condensed versions of 15-20 major news stories, summarized in the TIMES-EXPRESS-BUDGET.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e unless otherwise indicated)  BANVILLE-BOOKER-PRIZE (Dublin, Ireland) -- Not everyone was thrilled by the decision last month to give the Man Booker Prize to The Sea, by the Irish novelist John Banville. For starters, two of the five Booker judges vehemently preferred another book, Kazuo Ishiguro's Never Let Me Go. But all this is grist for the mill to the author himself, who seems to relish a good literary dust-up, or at least not to mind being at the center of one. Frankly, I am gratified to see myself vilified and the jury being vilified, he said happily over lunch recently. It cheers me up. I must have done something right to annoy so many people. By Sarah Lyall.  HESSE-EXHIBIT (Undated) -- The Hesses, best known to Americans for supplying mercenaries to England's George III, have one of the best art troves in Germany. But unlike some German princely families, like the Hanovers who are selling things at Sotheby's this fall, they are striving to keep this collection together. On Saturday in Oregon, Americans will get a taste of these riches when the Portland Museum of Art opens Hesse: A Princely German Collection, presenting more than 400 paintings, decorative objects, an elaborate gilt bronze Schinkel centerpiece, a carriage, etc. The star of the show is Holbein's Madonna, which has never been seen on these shores and rarely outside Germany since at least the 19th century. By Judith H. Dobrzynski.  ART-AUCTION (New York) -- The art auctions season kicks off Tuesday night. By Carol Vogel.  TWO-LIVES-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) -- William Grimes reviews Two Lives by Vikram Seth.  DINING (d code)  MICHELIN-GUIDE-NY (New York) -- Michelin announces the star ratings for its New York City guide to restaurants. This is Michelin's first guide outside Europe. The book will include 500 restaurants. By Florence Fabricant. This package includes an essay on tasters' impressions of the wines, a tabular report rating the wines and a recipe for a dish that goes with the wines. By Eric Asimov.  SPORTS (s code)  RUN-MARATHON-TERGAT (New York) -- Profile of Paul Tergat, the world-record holder in the marathon who, at 36, is running Sunday's New York race for the first time. He's considered the father of Kenyan distance running, having won five cross country world championships before converting to the marathon. He set the world record in 2003 in Berlin, but he might not be in top form anymore; he dropped out of two marathons in England recently because of an injury. By John Eligon. ESSAY-EDUC (Undated) -- It is the bane of college admissions officers -- the highly polished, professionally edited personal essay that barely reflects the thinking or writing, let alone the personality, of a 17-year-old high school student. If it sounds like it was written by a 42-year-old attorney, chances are it was written by a 42-year-old attorney, said Lee Stetson, dean of admissions at the University of Pennsylvania. Now colleges have another tool to help them discern how much help students are getting on their applications -- the SAT. By Kate Stone Lombardi.  EDUCATION-COLUMN (Undated) -- A look at the lack of alignment between state and federal tests and the questions it raises about how accurate and useful all these testing and assessment systems are. For example, national test results say that fourth grade reading proficiency dropped in Florida, but the Florida state test show it going up substantially. The weekly column, by Michael Winerip. The decision upholds the conviction and sends the case back to a federal district court for re-sentencing. By Simon Romero.  BRITAIN-SHIPPER (London) -- It had been a sinew of empire, a shipping line that ferried soldiers and diplomats, even royalty, on the Victorian mail runs that tied Britain to its outposts far to the east and beyond. But when the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co. became the object of a likely bidding war on Monday after a takeover approach from Dubai Ports World, it seemed as if the 165-year-old company might be heading the same way as so many other onetime jewels in the British economic crown -- into foreign hands. And, as P&amp;O stock has soared on speculation that Danish and Hong Kong contenders might enter the bidding, pushing the price above $5 billion, the contest invited perhaps a more philosophical question: what makes Britain so relaxed about selling companies to outsiders in a way that many in continental Europe -- France, Italy and Germany in particular -- seem reluctant to emulate? By Alan Cowell and Heather Timmons.  UBS-EARNINGS (Undated) -- UBS reports record third-quarter profit, showing how institutions with large wealth management businesses are starting to reap the benefits from a boom in oil-related wealth in the Middle East and Asia. Unlike Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch, whose profit surged on rising global stock and bond markets, Swiss banks are making themselves less reliant on trading profits. By Tom Wright.  SUN-EARNINGS (Undated) -- Sun Microsystems will post first-quarter earnings after the market closes. By Laurie J. Flynn.  VIACOM-EARNINGS (New York) -- Viacom Inc. swung to a $708.5 million net profit in the third quarter amid strong performances at its cable and entertainment segments, bouncing back from a loss in the year-ago period when results were hit by a charge for the Blockbuster Inc. video-rental business. By Geraldine Fabrikant.  SMART-ELEVATORS (New York) -- Elevators of the future have started to arrive in New York. At the Marriott Marquis, for instance, riders will no longer have to cope with a widespread pet peeve: doors that open at floor after floor once the car is full. By Fred A. Bernstein. COVER STORIES  TV-TELEMUNDO (Undated) -- Eduardo Porter reports on how Telemundo's move toward producing its telenovelas in-house is fostering a whole new Spanish-language TV industry centered on Miami.  With:  TV-TELENOVELAS (Undated) -- Telenovelas are booming because their appeal crosses generational lines: young Hispanics who mostly watch English-language TV will still tune in for telenovelas. By Mireya Navarro.  THEATER  THEATER-JERSEY-BOYS (New York) -- Jesse McKinley talks with John Lloyd Young, who is starring as Frankie Valli in Jersey Boys. opening Dec. 6 at the August Wilson Theater on Broadway.  HOLIDAY MOVIES  FILM-DAWSON-RENT (Los Angeles) -- It has been nearly two months since Rosario Dawson, who plays Mimi in the film adaptation of the musical Rent, opening Nov. 23, left her native New York for Los Angeles, and already she is sounding like a changed woman. By Lola Ogunnaike.  FILM-MATCH-POINT (Undated) -- A Q&amp;A with Jonathan Rhys-Meyers, a standout in Woody Allen's Match Point. By Sharon Waxman.  FILM-GEISHA (Los Angeles) -- The challenge was daunting for any Hollywood studio: an $80 million-plus historical romance, a wartime saga with no special effects or bursting bombs, and nothing to put in the toy store to merchandise -- no small consideration for executives accustomed to the ancillary revenue streams of family-fun franchises like Spider-Man. Then there was the little matter of race. The film version of Arthur Golden's novel, Memoirs of a Geisha, would, after all, require an all-Asian cast, something that Hollywood has rarely ventured, and never in a big-budget, epic love story. Small wonder, then, that it took eight long years for this best-selling book to make it to the screen. By David Halbfinger.  FILM-PRODUCERS (Undated) -- It's a scheme so crazy it just might work. Make a movie about a pair of disreputable Broadway producers out to make a killing by opening a surefire flop and stealing their investors' money. Turn said movie into a musical and open it on the real Broadway. Turn around and make a film of the musical of the film, adding a couple of Hollywood names, about $50 million in production frills and a healthy dollop of faith in the power of old-school musical comedy. That, in sum, is the story of The Producers, Version 3.0, which will open in New York on Dec. 16 and nationwide on Christmas Day. By Jesse McKinley.  FILM-NARNIA (Undated) -- At the beginning of 2001, Perry Moore embarked on a forbidding quest. Moore, an executive with an untested movie company called Walden Media, dispatched an impassioned letter to the chief executive of the C.S. Lewis Co., seeking movie rights to the much-loved Chronicles of Narnia fantasy novels. He vowed that Walden would be able to accomplish what one of the most prolific and successful producing teams in Hollywood -- Kathleen Kennedy and Frank Marshall of Jurassic Park fame -- had already failed to do: turn The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, the first book published in the series, into a movie. Almost five years later, Moore's promise will be kept. By Lorne Manly.  FILM-PRIDE&amp;PREJUDICE (London) -- In Pride &amp; Prejudice, Matthew MacFadyen has a gentler take on Jane Austen's brooding romantic hero. By Sarah Lyall.  FILM-HANEKE-CACHE (Paris) --In photographs, Michael Haneke could easily pass for a taciturn philosophy professor weighed down by gloom and doom. Indeed, his movies are hardly more optimistic: Guilt and tension pervade the bleak stories he brings to the screen. It is something of a relief, then, to discover that this tall, bearded Austrian director, now 63, is talkative and can even be quite jolly. True, he is best known for dark tales like Funny Games and The Piano Teacher. And true, Haneke conceded, he could never make a comedy -- Don't ask a cobbler to make hats, he quipped. But, yes, he insisted, he does make movies to distract audiences and -- why not? -- to disturb them a little too. His latest movie, Cache (Hidden), the French-language psychological thriller that earned him the best director's prize at this year's Cannes Film Festival, does both. By Alan Riding.  Bestseller Lists  BESTSELLERS-HARD-L (Undated) -- Best-selling hardbacks, long-form list.  BESTSELLERS-HARD-S (Undated) -- Best-selling hardbacks, short-form list. By William Safire.  Editors, this column moves on the Monday or Tuesday before publication.  TRAVEL (t code)  TRAVEL-WILMA-MEXICO (Undated) -- In recovering from the devastation of Hurricane Wilma, hard-hit Mexican resorts like Cancun face two equally daunting challenges. The first, to physically restore and rebuild this part of Mexico's Caribbean coast, which was battered by torrential rains and winds of more than 110 mph for 60 hours, is expected to take at least several months. The second, to repair the public relations damage that was inflicted during the recovery process (or, according to some bitter vacationers, the lack thereof), could take much, much longer. By Elisabeth Malkin and James McKinley.  TRAVEL-ISRAEL-SPAS (Undated) -- Spas and Israel -- let alone relaxation and Israel -- might seem an unlikely pairing. Israelis are known for their aggressive driving, living and politics, in addition to the very real stress connected to terror and military maneuvers. But Israel has fully embraced the worldwide interest in spa vacations: Well beyond the famous Dead Sea mud, hotels across the country now offer spa services, and a number of full-service spas have opened or expanded over the last decade. By Sara Wildman.  TRAVEL-HOLYLAND (Undated) -- After the Palestinian intifada began in the fall of 2000, traveling to Israel became a statement of sorts. The Israeli tourism industry came to survive on a demographically narrowed but ideologically committed clientele: Christian pilgrims and American Jews. Leisure travel slowed to a trickle, with the overall number of visitors falling from a high of 2.8 million in 2000 to less than a million in 2002, according to the Israel Ministry of Tourism. But after half a decade of empty hotel rooms, Israel seems to be drawing diverse crowds once again. By Boris Fishman.  TRAVEL-SIERRA-LEONE (Undated) -- Sierra Leone is a stunningly beautiful place. But it is also a heartbreaking one. In Freetown, the capital, the signs of the 11-year civil war that ravaged this West African nation are everywhere. Children who had their limbs lopped off by rebel soldiers loiter on dusty trails. Garbage is piled high on the streets during the day, only to be set ablaze at night, providing the only light, as electricity is still rare. There is a reason this country has not yet found itself on the itinerary of even the most intrepid backpackers. Despite its beauty, it is very much on the edge of civilization. The civil war left at least 50,000 civilians dead. Children as young as 10 were forced into military conscription forming platoons called Small Boy Units, learning how to use an AK-47 before learning how to read. And most notoriously, during the later stages of the conflict, men, women and even children had their hands and legs amputated in a campaign of terror and violence. But it has been four years since the fighting ended and there is new hope within Sierra Leone. By Marc Santor.  Regular Features  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) -- When everyday chemicals cause illness during travel. By Fred A. Bernstein. And what people here routinely call the hunger season has barely begun. Malawi is the epicenter of Africa's second hunger crisis in five months, and the second in which the developed world has responded with painful slowness. More than 4.6 million of Malawi's 12 million citizens need donated food to fend off malnutrition until the next harvest begins in April. In Zimbabwe, at least 4 million more need emergency food aid. Zambia's government issued an urgent appeal for food on Wednesday, while 850,000 need food in Mozambique; 500,000 in Lesotho at least 300,000 in Swaziland. By Michael Wines.  With photo and map.  WASHINGTON  (Coded w)  ALIOTA-ABORTION (Undated) -- A closer look at cases related to the issue of abortion that Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. handled. By Adam Liptak.  CHENEY-ADDINGTON (Washington) -- A profile of David S. Addington, the new counsel for Vice President Dick Cheney. By Douglas Jehl.  ESSAY-EDUC (Undated) -- It is the bane of college admissions officers -- the highly polished, professionally edited personal essay that barely reflects the thinking or writing, let alone the personality, of a 17-year-old high school student. If it sounds like it was written by a 42-year-old attorney, chances are it was written by a 42-year-old attorney, said Lee Stetson, dean of admissions at the University of Pennsylvania. Now colleges have another tool to help them discern how much help students are getting on their applications -- the SAT. By Kate Stone Lombardi.  EDUCATION-COLUMN (Undated) -- A look at the lack of alignment between state and federal tests and the questions it raises about how accurate and useful all these testing and assessment systems are. For example, national test results say that fourth grade reading proficiency dropped in Florida, but the Florida state test show it going up substantially. The weekly column, by Michael Winerip.  FINANCIAL  (Coded f)  HYDROGEN-CAR (Los Angeles) -- You would never guess that Jon Spallino drives what is probably the most expensive car in this city known for automotive excess. Or that he is the world's most technologically advanced commuter. He was at the wheel of his silver Honda FCX, a car worth about $1 million that looks like a cross between a compact -- say, a Volkswagen Golf -- and a cinder block. The FCX is powered by hydrogen fuel cells, the futuristic technology that many automakers see as an eventual solution to the world's energy woes, though their viability is a subject of vigorous debate inside and outside the auto industry. By Danny Hakim  BRITAIN-CAPITALISM (London) -- It had been a sinew of empire, a shipping line that ferried soldiers and diplomats, even royalty, on the Victorian mail runs that tied Britain to its outposts far to the east and beyond. But when the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co. became the object of a likely bidding war on Monday after a takeover approach from Dubai Ports World, it seemed as if the 165-year-old company might be heading the same way as so many other onetime jewels in the British economic crown -- into foreign hands. And, as P&amp;O stock has soared on speculation that Danish and Hong Kong contenders might enter the bidding, pushing the price above $5 billion, the contest invited perhaps a more philosophical question: what makes Britain so relaxed about selling companies to outsiders in a way that many in continental Europe -- France, Italy and Germany in particular -- seem reluctant to emulate? By Alan Cowell and Heather Timmons.  SMART-ELEVATORS (New York) -- Elevators of the future have started to arrive in New York. At the Marriott Marquis, for instance, riders will no longer have to cope with a widespread pet peeve: doors that open at floor after floor once the car is full. By Fred A. Bernstein.  COPPER-MARKETPLACE (London) -- For much of the year, copper prices climbed steadily, driven by a housing boom in the United States and demand from the rapidly industrializing economies of India and China. Supply disruptions further fed the price gains. If that sounds similar to the story of crude oil futures this year, it should. Like oil, copper has attracted a wave of new money from hedge funds and other big investors seeking to ride the rally. But with the copper rally stuttering in recent weeks, and prices down as much as 3 percent from their October highs, some analysts and investors say they see signs that a bubble is about to burst. By Heather Timmons.  With graphic.  PANASONIC-AD-COLUMN (New York) -- Panasonic is betting that offbeat characters called Oxymites can help pull off a mighty feat: persuade younger consumers to buy a new brand of battery. To introduce the battery, Oxyride, which promises to deliver more power than alkaline batteries in devices like digital cameras, the North American unit of the Panasonic Corp. is rolling out a campaign featuring several nontraditional elements. The campaign, which began last week, has a budget estimated at $5 million to $10 million. By Stuart Elliott.  SPORTS  (Coded s)  OLY-ROBERTS-COLUMN (Undated) -- A Sports of the Times column by Selena Roberts on what she sees as the hypocrisy of the IOC insisting that Italy relax its drug rules during the Olympics after being so critical of the United States for its handling of drugs.  BBO-JACKIE-ROBINSON (New York) -- Outside the Mets' minor league stadium in Coney Island, a statue is unveiled depicting the moment when Brooklyn Dodger shortstop Pee Wee Reese put his arm around teammate Jackie Robinson -- Major League Baseball's first black player -- in a gesture designed to silence racist heckling. By Ira Berkow.  RUN-MARATHON-TERGAT (New York) -- Profile of Paul Tergat, the world-record holder in the marathon who, at 36, is running Sunday's New York race for the first time. He's considered the father of Kenyan distance running, having won five cross country world championships before converting to the marathon. He set the world record in 2003 in Berlin, but he might not be in top form anymore; he dropped out of two marathons in England recently because of an injury. By John Eligon.  LEFT-BEHIND-DVD (Los Angeles) -- Checking in on Sony's Left Behind, which screened for free to thousands of churches last week in a bid to sell millions of DVDs. By Sharon Waxman.  BANVILLE-BOOKER-PRIZE (Dublin, Ireland) -- Not everyone was thrilled by the decision last month to give the Man Booker Prize to The Sea, by the Irish novelist John Banville. For starters, two of the five Booker judges vehemently preferred another book, Kazuo Ishiguro's Never Let Me Go. But all this is grist for the mill to the author himself, who seems to relish a good literary dust-up, or at least not to mind being at the center of one. Frankly, I am gratified to see myself vilified and the jury being vilified, he said happily over lunch recently. It cheers me up. I must have done something right to annoy so many people. By Sarah Lyall.  HESSE-EXHIBIT (Undated) -- The Hesses, best known to Americans for supplying mercenaries to England's George III, have one of the best art troves in Germany. But unlike some German princely families, like the Hanovers who are selling things at Sotheby's this fall, they are striving to keep this collection together. On Saturday in Oregon, Americans will get a taste of these riches when the Portland Museum of Art opens Hesse: A Princely German Collection, presenting more than 400 paintings, decorative objects, an elaborate gilt bronze Schinkel centerpiece, a carriage, etc. The star of the show is Holbein's Madonna, which has never been seen on these shores and rarely outside Germany since at least the 19th century. By Judith H. Dobrzynski.  PET-RADIO (Undated) -- His Master's Download: All about the new Internet radio station for home-alone pets. By Dinitia Smith.  ART-AUCTION (New York) -- The art auctions season kicks off Tuesday night. By Carol Vogel.  TWO-LIVES-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) -- William Grimes reviews Two Lives by Vikram Seth.  TV-BANKS (Undated) -- A Critic's Notebook on Tyra Banks -- her new daytime talk show and the current edition of America's Top Model, on UPN. By Ned Martel.  ARTS-BRIEFLY (Undated) -- News and notes on culture and entertainment.  DINING  (Coded d)  MICHELIN-GUIDE-NY (New York) -- Michelin today announces the star ratings for its New York City guide to restaurants. This is Michelin's first guide outside of Europe. The book, which will go on sale on Friday, will include 500 restaurants in the five boroughs. By Florence Fabricant.  HINDU-MULSIM-HOLIDAYS (Undated) -- This week, in a rare coincidence of calendars, Hindus and Muslims from all over India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are celebrating their most joyous holidays of the year. Hindus observe Diwali and Muslims end Ramadan with Eid ul-Fitr. And both holidays are utterly soaked in sugar. Festive piles of pink, green, yellow, orange and white sweets, some shimmering with silver leaf, others snowy with shreds of coconut or crunchy with nuggets of pistachio, are integral to many religious celebrations and social rituals in South Asia. But these sweets, called mithai by Indians, have an almost religious significance in everyday life. By Julia Moskin.  With recipe.  NEW-ORLEANS-DINING (Oxford, Miss.) -- Officially, the theme of the eighth annual Southern Foodways Symposium that ended here at the University of Mississippi on Sunday, was the region's lasting love affair with sugar and sweets. But like other people in the American food world, the 250 people in attendance talked mostly about New Orleans and the Gulf Coast and their culinary future. John T. Edge, the director of the Southern Foodways Alliance, which runs the symposium, said he was confident that nearly all the nationally known New Orleans restaurants would eventually reopen. What troubles him, he said, is the po' boy shops, oyster bars, red-beans-and-rice joints and other mom-and-pop businesses that have given New Orleans dining so much of its zest. For every bit of cheerful news about a restaurant reopening, there were worried questions, especially about the small, often black-owned places in hard-hit parts of town. By R.W. Apple Jr.  SIMPLE-COOKING (Undated) -- The weekly feature: Easy polenta. By Mark Bittman.  With recipe.  MASTER-CHEF (Undated) -- Chef Dona Abramson, chef of Bright Food, makes autumn salsas. By Dana Bowen.  Last is a series of vegetarian chefs.  With recipes.  CHICKEN (Undated) -- Chicken remains the great international comfort food. But as the new world of flavor has evolved over the last 40 years, the simple chicken may have changed more than anything else on the American dinner table. There's now an infinite variety of recipes, thanks to immigration and ambitious chefs, and an increasing diversity of chicken itself, thanks to innovative farmers. By Joan Nathan.  With recipes.  WINE-TIMES (Undated) - The fortnightly feature: The Wines of the Times panel drinks California Rhone blends. This package includes an essay on tasters' impressions of the wines, a tabular report rating the wines and a recipe for a dish that goes with the wines. By Eric Asimov. "159757"	"I"	"think"	" And that is because of the light. The Pantheon is defined by its oculus, a bright opening in the center of the dome. It renders the space an inside-out sundial: the shaft of light that shines through the oculus slowly moves across the dome over the course of the day. A well-trained eye can tell the month and the hour by the slant of light -- but not, I think, the year. Time collapses inside the Pantheon. While most Roman architectural achievements are meant to communicate the civilization's mastery over nature, the Pantheon maintains a deep connection to it, to the essential elements of light and sky. Rain pours through the oculus and collects in a drain in the center of the floor, as does snow, on the rare and wonderful occasions when it snows in Rome. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200511.gz"

, she says,	 Lisa Bleyaert, the audience coordinator for Late Night, compares loading an audience to mixing a cocktail. Just after 5 p.m., she directs about 40 fans to the first rows of the 189-seat auditorium. Then, two dozen VIPs -- people who obtained tickets through industry connections -- enter. Because they tend to be a bit blase, she says, she seats them just outside the zone of audience interaction. She tries to save room for some standbys, because they raise the energy level of the studio overall. On a recent day, the first standbys were so keen to see O'Brien's show that they had arrived at 4:30 a.m. to secure their spots. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
