For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.  INTERNATIONAL (i code)  IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- A car bomb exploded Thursday outside the main hospital in the town of Mahmudiya, killing at least 30 people and wounding at least 23. Another car bomb left at least two dead and scattered attacks in Baghdad and elsewhere killed at least eight other Iraqis and five American soldiers. By Edward Wong.  An early lede has moved.  And  IRAQ-SEARCH (Baghdad, Iraq) -- In the midst of a rapid expansion of Iraqi detention facilities, which operate virtually unchecked, the story of a woman's harrowing search for her detained husband. By Sabrina Tavernise.  SKOREA-CLONE (Seoul, South Korea) -- South Korea's pioneering stem cell scientist apologized on Thursday that two members of his team had donated their egg cells for research, saying his rush to advance science may have clouded his ethical judgment. Hwang Woo-suk, who became a hero in South Korea after major developments in cloning research, has been caught in a swirl of allegations over his work after a U.S. collaborator left the group, saying Hwang unethically procured human eggs. Hwang also said he was stepping down as the head of a global stem cell hub, established last month in South Korea. (Summary from wires) By Choe Sang-Hun.  VATICAN-GAYS-POPE (Rome) -- A look at the Vatican's newly strengthened ban on gay applicants to the priesthood, and what, if any, connection it has to the seven month-old tenure of the conservative Pope Benedict XVI. By Ian Fisher.  CHINA-WATER (Harbin, China) -- The Chinese government on Thursday blamed the country's biggest oil company for a pollution spill that allowed a 50-mile slick of toxic benzene to reach this northern city of almost 4 million people. In an increasingly unwashed and unflushed city, residents continued to stockpile bottled drinking water on the second day after authorities shut down the municipal water system and stopped pumping from the Songhua River to minimize the risk of poisoning. Officials said that the slick was expected to have passed the city by Saturday and that normal water supplies could resume by Sunday. By David Lague and Jim Yardley.  An early lede has moved.  RUSSIA-NGOS (Moscow) -- President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday defended Russia's right to scrutinize any political activity by foreign and domestic charities and nongovernmental organizations, even as he promised that civil society in Russia should not suffer. Putin said he would consult with parliamentary leaders on new legislation that would place all private organizations under strict state control and threaten others with closure. The continuing financing of the political activity from abroad should be, I think, in the state's field of vision, he said in remarks broadcast on state television, especially if this financing is carried out through the state channels of other countries and these or those organizations functioning in our country and involved in the political activity are, in fact, used as a tool of the foreign policy of other states. By Steven Lee Myers.  An early lede has moved.  ICE-GREENHOUSE-GAS (Undated) -- Shafts of ancient ice pulled from Antarctica's frozen depths show that for at least 650,000 years atmospheric concentrations of three important heat-trapping greenhouse gases never matched levels reached recently because of emissions from human activities, scientists report. By Andrew C. Revkin.  JAPAN-CONSTRUCTION (Tokyo) -- Developments in an unfolding scandal involving defective construction and falsified certification of many buildings that could fall in an earthquake. By James Brooke.  NATIONAL GENERAL (a code)  LA-THANKSGIVING (Slidel, La.) -- An eclectic gathering of Katrina refugees dines in the tent that has been their home since the great hurricane of 2005 blew away life as they once knew it. By Jere Longman.  THANKSGIVING-PARADE (New York) -- Two people were injured Thursday at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade as it traveled through Times Square after a gust of wind sent a giant balloon crashing into a lamppost along the crowded parade route, knocking the lamp onto spectators below. One of the injured, a 26-year-old woman who witnesses said was struck on the back of the head and the shoulder by a falling lamp, was taken to Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. Her 11-year-old sister, who was watching the parade from a wheel chair, appeared to have less serious injuries, the police and witnesses said. In 1997, high winds caused the Cat in the Hat balloon to smash into a lamppost on Central Park West. The light post fell, striking a woman, who fell into a coma. By Marc Santora and Jeffrey Gettleman.  An early lede has moved.  STATES-FISCAL (Los Angeles) -- After four years of tight budgets and deepening state debt, many states suddenly find themselves awash in unexpected revenue that will allow them to build up fiscal reserves and painlessly balance their budgets next year. By John M. Broder.  BALTIMORE-POLES (Baltimore) -- In a new twist on the theft by addicts of copper wire for its resale value, thieves in Baltimore have cut down and stolen 100 metal utility poles to sell as scrap metal. By Gary Gately.  FINANCIAL (f code)  EURO-ECON (Frankfurt, Germany) -- The European Central Bank has settled the debate over when it plans to tighten credit in Europe, signaling a rate increase next week. The debate over whether it should do so rages on. On Thursday, an influential survey of German businesses reported a larger-than-expected decline in confidence in November, suggesting that Europe's biggest economy, while growing, remains fragile. That followed two other troubling economic reports on the Continent - one showing a decline in consumer spending in France last month, the other a drop in business confidence in Belgium. Taken together, these indicators seem to challenge one of the European Central Bank's key justifications for its first interest-rate increase in five years: that Europe is finally on a sustainable growth path. By Mark Landler.  TRADE-TALKS-LAMY (Hong Kong) -- The new director general of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, faces global trade talks that are deadlocked. Lamy does not even plan to propose a comprehensive agreement before trade ministers from 149 nations and customs territories gather here on Dec. 13. Instead, he intends to issue a fairly broad outline of where the different sides stand on a range of issues. By Keith Bradsher.  FRANCE-NORRIS-COLUMN (Undated) -- The weekly column: French investors take hope. Maybe the Socialists will bail you out of your folly and buy back the shares you so eagerly purchased. The largest initial public offering in Europe this year, Electricite de France, raised 7 billion euros, or $8.2 billion. It reinforced stereotypes of French workers and disappointed the buyers of shares in France's dominant electric utility. French capitalism is, of course, a little different from the Anglo-Saxon variety. In the United States, employees celebrate when their companies sell shares to the public, hoping that will make them rich. In France, the workers stage protests. By Floyd Norris.  RUSSIA-OIL (Moscow) -- The Russian state-owned oil company Rosneft on Thursday reported a huge jump in profit of about 600 percent for the first half of 2005, reflecting its takeover last year of the largest production unit of the private Yukos company. By Andrew Kramer.  COMMENTARY (k code)  An Op-Ed column by Paul Krugman. Thomas L. Friedman is on vacation. GRAND-CAYMAN-REBUILD (Undated) -- The worst of this year's horrific crop of Atlantic storms brought only heavy rain and some wind gusts to the island of Grand Cayman. But in 2004 Ivan damaged or destroyed 74 percent of the homes and left $3 billion in damage and losses. While this year's hurricane victims are still mopping up, Grand Cayman is a study in the recovery process on a resort island heavily dependent on its beauty and tourist allure. By Michelle Higgins. FEATURES  NUTCRACKER-BALLET (New York) -- The Nutcracker, a ritual of the holiday season, is still handsomely sustained by the New York City Ballet. The little girls of our childhood are there (or their children or maybe even grandchildren), dressed up and bright-eyed and eagerly expectant. A few years ago one of those little girls was mine. There are beautiful children on the stage, too, part of the horde of youngsters that George Balanchine -- recalling his own childhood in St. Petersburg in the late 19th century -- choreographed into the production. Year after year, in town after town, that twinkling Christmas tree rising to gigantic heights, or the dizzying onslaught of snow at the end of the first act, or the elegance of the Sugar Plum Fairy and her Cavalier and the Dewdrop -- and all the charming dancers of the delicious treats (hot chocolate, coffee, tea, candy cane, marzipan, ginger) -- awaken wonder in children and their parents alike. An essay by John Rockwell.  AFRICAN-ART-EXHIBITS (Undated) -- Holland Cotter reviews shows of African art including African Art Now at the Smithsonian; West African Gold at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston; Power Dressing: Men's Fashion and Prestige in Africa at the Newark Museum; Lasting Foundations: The Art of Architecture in Africa at the World Financial Center; and the Nigerian artist El Anatsui at Skoto.  XBOX (Undated) -- There is a saying in technology circles, often delivered with rueful respect, that if you give the folks at Microsoft enough chances, they will eventually deliver a compelling result. They did it with spreadsheets. They did it with Web browsers. And now, with the new Xbox 360, the Bill Gates team has delivered a legitimately excellent gaming and home media system. Certainly, the graphics are incredibly detailed, lifelike and vivid, far beyond anything on the current generation of game consoles. Playing an Xbox 360 game can be almost like controlling a Pixar animated film. And that's on a regular old television. On a high-definition set, get ready for your eyes to weep. By Seth Schiesel.  KELLEY-EXHIBIT (New York) -- Michael Kimmelman reviews Mike Kelley at Gagosian in Chelsea.  HENRY-JAMES-NY (New York) -- An essay about Henry James's New York, pegged to the release of Henry James New York Stories, edited by Colm Toibin (author of The Master). By Dinitia Smith.  MOVIES  BONE-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) -- Down to the Bone: Debra Granik, director; with Vera Farmiga, Hugh Dillon. By Dana Stevens.  LIBERTINE-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) -- The Libertine: Laurence Dunmore, director; with Johnny Depp, Samantha Morton, John Malkovich. Reviewed by Manohla Dargis.  PALFREY-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) -- Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont: Dan Ireland, director; with Joan Plowright, Rupert Friend. Reviewed by Stephen Holden.  BIG-FAT-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) -- My Big Fat Independent Movie: Philip Zlotorynski, director. Reviewed by Jeannette Catsoulis.  SEAMLESS-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) -- Seamless: Douglas Keeve, director; a documentary. Reviewed by Nathan Lee.  OTHER ENTERTAINMENT  IVY-LEAGUE-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) -- The Chosen: Hidden History of Admissions at Harvard, Yale, Princeton by Jerome Karabel (Houghton Mifflin). Reviewed by Michiko Kakutani.  TV-READING-REVIEW (Undated) -- Ginia Bellafante reviews The Reading Room, Saturday on the Hallmark Channel.  ANTIQUES-COLUMN (New York) -- The Antiques Column. By Wendy Moonan. , he argues,	 This all changed after World War I, he argues, as it became clear that a system of selection focused solely on scholastic performance would lead to the admission of increasing numbers of Jewish students, most of them of eastern European background. This development, he notes, occurred in the midst of one of the most reactionary moments in American history, when the nationwide movement to restrict immigration was gaining momentum and anti-Semitism was on the rise, and the Big Three administrators began to worry that the presence of 'too many' Jews would in fact lead to the departure of Gentiles. Their conclusion, in Karabel's words: given the dependence of the Big Three on the Protestant upper class for both material resources and social prestige, the 'Jewish problem' was genuine, and the defense of institutional interests required a solution that would prevent 'WASP flight.' </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
, he notes,	 Karabel reports that on the eve of President John F. Kennedy's election, the three schools were still de facto segregated institutions -- less than 1 percent black and, in the case of Princeton, enrolling just 1 African-American freshman in a class of 826. And while anti-Semitism was officially taboo, he notes, Harvard rejected three-quarters of the applicants from the Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant that year (compared to just 31 percent from Exeter and Andover) while Yale limited the Jewish presence in the freshman class to one student in eight. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz

NY-SLAVERY (New York) -- What New Yorkers are saying about New York's role in slavery, once they've seen the New-York Historical Society's exhibition on slavery. By Felicia R. Lee.  RUSSIA-ARTISTIC-FREEDOM (Moscow) -- Marat Guelman, owner of Russia's first post-Soviet art gallery, unveiled his project, Russia 2 with an exhibition of paintings and other works intended to parallel Moscow's first biennial of contemporary art in January and February. The exhibition's tone was irreverent, subversive and piercingly critical of President Vladimir Putin, the Kremlin and, significantly, the Russian Orthodox Church. But a group of nine artists has filed a civil suit, seeking compensation for the moral injury caused by four of the works, by some of Russia's most prominent contemporary artists. The complaint cited provisions in Russia's Constitution protecting human rights and religious freedom and an article in the criminal code against inciting ethnic and religious hatred. By Steven Lee Myers.  BRITAIN-CELLPHONES (London) -- Britain goes mad over cell phones ringing in theaters. By Sarah Lyall.  DURANG-THEATER (Bucks County, Pa.) -- The evolution of Chris Durang's view of faith and religion in his plays, the latest of which, Miss Witherspoon, opens Dec. 6. By Dinitia Smith.  WALCOTT-WATERCOLORS (New York) -- A review of Derek Walcott's watercolors at the June Kelly Gallery. By Ken Johnson.  AXA-IMAGES (New York) -- In 1515 the German artist Albrecht Deurer made a woodcut of a rhinoceros, an ominous-looking creature with a sharply pointed horn on its snout. Duerer had never seen the real thing; neither had most other Europeans. But his widely distributed image, conjured up from descriptions of an actual beast, served as definitive in Europe for more than 200 years. The Duerer distortion is one example of the power of printed illustrations, fantastical or not, in forming public concepts. It is among nearly 90 works by artists and other image-makers, from William Blake to the Flash Gordon comic strip artist Alex Raymond to NASA, that appear at the AXA Gallery in Imagined Worlds: Willful Invention and the Printed Image 1470-2005. Reviewed by Grace Glueck.  ALBANIA-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) -- The Successor, by Ismail Kadare (Arcade): In 1981 Mehmet Shehu, the presumed successor to Albania's terrifying dictator Enver Hoxha, was found dead. Suicide was the official verdict, but in that least-known and most isolated Balkan nation the real verdict was death by mystery. Reviewed by Richard Eder. She also has a cerebral side: She plays competitive chess. She is not on the World Chess Federation's list of the world's top female players. In fact, she is ranked 47,694th among both men and women. A Web site called World Chess Beauty Contest ranks her as the world's most beautiful woman in the game. By Dylan Loeb McClain. For information, phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. INTERNATIONAL (Will move in the i news file.) BOLIVIA-COCA (Chipiriri, Bolivia) -- In nearly 50 years of growing coca, Jose Torrico has seen army soldiers swarm across his fields to pull up his plants and heard threats from successive Bolivian governments determined to destroy his crop. And like thousands of other coca farmers Torrico has refused to stop growing coca, the main ingredient in cocaine. Now, after years of persistence, he and his fellow farmers say they are eagerly anticipating the advent of a new era, one in which growing coca will finally be made legal again. That is, they say, if Evo Morales is elected president on Dec. 18. Morales, a one-time leader of the coca-growers federation, is revered by the left around Latin American as an unbending opponent of globalization. That is worrisome enough to the Bush administration. But more alarming is that a man American officials accuse of promoting coca farming -- annation.  IRAN-FILMMAKER (Tehran, Iran) -- For years, Massoud Dehnamaki was known widely as the feared enforcer of conservative rules that restricted freedom for women and society. In recent years, however, he has emerged as Iran's Michael Moore, having directed a documentary on the taboo issue of prostitution and another forthcoming film on soccer as a metaphor of political struggle. Reformists and conservatives alike harshly criticized Dehnamaki for making the first movie, Poverty and Prostitution. Conservatives were furious that one of their own had not only highlighted an un-Islamic social pathology but seemed to sympathize with the prostitutes. Reformists believed he deliberately exaggerated the problem to make a case against easing Islamic law. In an interview, Dehnamaki said both camps had gotten it wrong, and denied that his views had undergone a radical transformation. The Saturday profile, by Nazila Fathi.  NATIONAL GENERAL  (Will move in a news file.)  CIRCUIT-RABBI (Atlanta) -- The weekly religion column. When Rabbi Debra Kassoff shows up to lead Friday night shabbat services in McGehee, Ark., she is a bit of a star. People have been known to drive 90 miles to hear the slight 33-year-old read from the Torah and lead prayers. That Kassoff is so popular is less a testament to her wisdom and insight -- though her congregants agree she has both -- than it is to her availability. This year, Kassoff will travel to 28 temples in 12 states throughout the South to provide leadership to small-town congregations, some with fewer than a dozen members. Although visiting rabbis are not uncommon, Kassoff is believed to be the only full-time circuit rabbi in the United States. By Brenda Goodman.  RESEARCH-IMMIG (Washington) -- American universities are concerned that rules proposed by the Defense Department and expected shortly from the Commerce Department could hurt research by limiting the ability of foreign citizens to work with sensitive technology in laboratories. By Scott C. Shane.  CALIF-WILLIAMS-HOUSE (Los Angeles) -- In 1936, Paul Revere Williams, one of Southern California's preeminent architects, designed the Morris Landau house in Holmby Hills, a neighborhood where he, as an African American, would not have been permitted to live. The Landau house, named after the South African merchant who commissioned it, passed from owner to owner, among them the former Los Angeles Kings impresario Bruce McNall, and Revlon's chairman, Ronald O. Perelman. When it became clear that the house would be an impediment to the expansion plans of its current owner, the elite prep school Harvard-Westlake, preservationists and neighborhood residents joined forces with school officials to find a buyer willing to move the 10,000 square-foot structure to a location in Pasadena. By Cindy Chang.  (Editors: Budgets and advisories are internal documents not for publication or redistribution outside of client news organizations. If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For questions about photos, call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  THEATER-SHUBERT (New York) -- Somewhere inside the offices of the Shubert there's an 81-year-old man who may know the answer to the biggest question on Broadway. His name is Gerald Schoenfeld and he is by most accounts the most powerful person in American theater. Schoenfeld is the chairman of the Shubert Organization, the largest Broadway theater chain. He took over sole leadership of the organization in 1996, when Bernard B. Jacobs, its president, died. Now that Schoenfeld is in his 10th year in that role and his ninth decade on the planet, his succession and what it means for Broadway remains a dominant mystery in an industry famed for its uncertainties. By Jesse McKinley.  HIPHOP-PROTEGE (Undated) -- Imagine, for a moment, that you're a promising young R&amp;B singer. You have a work ethic that drives you to compose and record three songs in a single day. But no one has ever even heard of you. Meanwhile the music industry is cranking out thousands of new CD's each year and only the luckiest new artists will manage to score a spot on a radio playlist. What you might need is someone to open doors. A trusted ally who could put his arm around you and introduce you to his friends. Say, a million or so of them. Acting on that theory, record labels in recent years have made a point of introducing new, little-known acts as proteges of established stars. By Jeff Leeds.  CHAPPELLE-RETURN (Undated) -- Dave Chappelle is alive and well and playing In Las Vegas. Dave Itzkoff reports on the comedian's re-emergence.  FEATURES  FILM-POCOHONTAS (Los Angeles) --Steve Chagollan reports on the historical Pocahontas, a figure so elusive her name is never once mentioned in New Line's tough new film all about her.  FILM-IRVING-HOAX (Undated) -- On the heels of Capote and Good Night, and Good Luck, yet another chapter in the twisted history of New York news media thus heads for the screen with fair warning, and more than a little tension among some of the principals. The Hoax, directed by Lasse Hallstrom, with a permed and sideburned Richard Gere as the 70's-era Clifford Irving, also stars Alfred Molina as Irving's co-writer and sidekick, Richard Suskind, and Marcia Gay Harden as Irving's wife Edith. Filmed over 49 days, mostly in and around New York City, the movie about a faked autobiography of Howard Hughes is set for release next year. By Pat H. Broeske.  With:  HOAX-DUMMAR (Undated) -- Sidebar on whatever happened to Melvin Dummar? (He's selling fish in the desert.) Strawberry Saroyan reports on the suddenly seamless transition from child star to superstar: a shift in the culture of celebrity.  TV-AUDIENCES (Undated) -- Getting just the right talk-show audience may not be science, but it's never left to chance. By Eve Gerber. TRAVEL-PHILADELPHIA (Undated) -- The Northern Liberties neighborhood stretching from near the Delaware River west to Sixth Street and from Spring Garden Street north to Girard Avenue, the Northern Liberties neighborhood isn't a place of Ye Olde ambiance. Its gritty urban aesthetic is part of its charm, and the influx of new condos is raising both its real estate prices and its profile. By Jeff Schlegel.  TRAVEL-CARACAS (Undated) -- The truth is that, as with many other big cities with questionable reputations, a visitor to Caracas can with a little luck and patience find hidden gems amid the frenzy. By Juan Forero. With photo.  CHESS-WOMEN (Undated) -- Vaness Reid runs cross-country, plays touch football, enjoys in-line skating, swims and goes bodyboarding. She also has a cerebral side: She plays competitive chess. She is not on the World Chess Federation's list of the world's top female players. In fact, she is ranked 47,694th among both men and women. But Reid is arguably the top player in the world based on a more subjective criterion: her looks. A Web site called World Chess Beauty Contest ranks her as the world's most beautiful woman in the game. By Dylan Loeb McClain.  MIZRAHI-TV (Undated) -- Since he shuttered his faltering ready-to-wear business nearly seven years ago, Isaac Mizrahi has tried everything from theater to mass market design. Now he is heavily focused on television, readying Isaac, his daily hourlong talk show, for a Dec. 5 premiere on the Style cable channel. By Lola Ogunnaike.  HOME-AIDS-TEST (Washington) -- The two young single women were sitting at the bar when they were asked how a relatively quick do-it-yourself HIV test might affect their dating life. One of them, Julie Powers, 23, laughed. I would definitely make someone take it, she said, hopefully before the sex. And she would not be embarrassed, she said, to insist that a man submit to the test. I really think we've got what they want, she explained. And if they want it, they can have it on our terms. By Gardiner Harris.  MODERN-LOVE (Undated) -- Breaking up, 2005-Style: Point 1: We had fun. Point 2: It's over. Point 3: Get lost. By Raya Kuzyk. , he said,	 Sox pitching coach Dave Wallace worked with Mota in the Los Angeles organization. It's always great to acquire depth in your bullpen, said Wallace. He set up for Eric Gagne for us and he did a great job with us for a couple of years. We had Mota, Paul Quantrill, and Gagne, and we had one of the best bullpens in the National League. I know he had elbow inflammation last year in Florida, so hopefully that's behind him. He's a good setup man and if your closer has gone three or four days, he can close for you. He's a quiet guy on a team, a converted infielder, so he doesn't have the wear and tear on his arm that guys his age would normally have. Wallace has had experience with pitchers like Beckett who have had recurring blisters. I had Ismael Valdes in Los Angeles and he got them all the time, said Wallace. It's one of those situations you have to manage. I don't know that there's a dermatologist around who has a cure or else the problem would have been solved. Maybe it's the humidity in Florida. I don't know if pitching up here will help that situation. But we're happy to have Josh, who's a quality young pitcher. EXP-CASPIAN-STURGEON (Nardaran, Azerbaijan) -- No resource is more richly associated with the Caspian basin than the sturgeon -- its briny eggs are among the most valuable wildlife commodities on earth. International and domestic regulations are in place to protect the surviving stock, but the region's manifest lawlessness and graft undermine rules to the point of uselessness. By C.J. Chivers  EXP-CHINA-JUDGE (Luoyang, China) -- Faced with a conflict between national and provincial law in a mundane case about seed prices, Judge Li Huijuan declared the provincial law invalid. In doing so, she unwittingly made legal history, setting in motion a national debate about judicial independence in China's closed political system. By Jim Yardley.  EXP-IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Developments. By John F. Burns  EXP-GAZA-GREENHOUSES (Gadid, Gaza Strip) -- Less than three months after the Israelis departed, Palestinians have repaired scores of greenhouses left by the settlers, planted a fall crop, and are preparing to harvest an estimated $20 million worth of strawberries, cherry tomatoes, sweet peppers and herbs and spices. By Greg Myre.  EXP-EGYPT-POLITICS (Cairo, Egypt) -- The Muslim Brotherhood, an organization outlawed by Egyptian law, has demonstrated in recent parliamentary elections that it is by far the strongest opposition party in the country. By Michael Slackman.  EXP-SPAIN-SUMMIT (Barcelona, Spain) -- The Euro-Mediterranean summit meeting, hosted by Spain, is one of the few forums where Israel, Syria, Lebanon and the Palestinian Authority all meet. E-mail: mrossajc.com </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051128.0031 type=advis > <HEADLINE> SCIENCE-TIMES-BUDGET-NYT </HEADLINE> <TEXT> The New York Times News Service plans the following Science Times stories for papers of Tuesday, Nov. 29.  SCI-MOUNT-ST-HELENS (Undated) -- Mount St. Helens is quietly erupting, and for the scientists at the volcano observatory there, the past year has been an unexpected bonanza, one that is giving them new insight into Mount St. Helens, the youngest and most active of the volcanoes in the Cascades Mountains, and perhaps into the 60 other volcanoes on the United States mainland that have erupted in the past 10,000 years and are thus presumed to have the potential to erupt again. By Kenneth Chang.  With photo and graphic.  SCI-CANCER-STRESS (Undated) -- The question of whether there is a link between stress and cancer has puzzled and intrigued researchers as well as patients. Study after study has asked whether people who developed cancer had more stress in the years before the diagnosis, and conversely, whether people who experienced extreme stress were more likely to develop cancer. What has emerged is a tenuous connection between stress, the immune system and cancer, with a surprising new insight that is changing the direction of research: It now appears that cancer cells make proteins that actually tell the immune system to let them alone and even to help them grow. By Gina Kolata.  Second in a series, Preventing Cancer. The first article discussed whether diet matters in prevention. Later ones will look at the effects of stress and the roles of genetics and the immune system.  With photo and graphic.  SCI-ATHLETES (Undated) -- Athletes on a hot streak often describe warps in space-time that even Einstein did not anticipate: basketball hoops appearing as wide as hula-hoops, tennis balls that seem to move in slow motion, golf outings in which the cups seem as easy to hit as open manholes. Now an experiment at the University of Virginia suggests that the changes in perception are apparently real, if sometimes exaggerated. A short, by Benedict Carey.  SCI-ANSETH-TISSUE (Undated) -- A Conversation With feature on Kristi S. Anseth, professor of chemical and biological engineering at the University of Colorado. She discusses the barriers she is breaking in tissue engineering. In terms of progress, she says, products for tissue in the cartilage, bones and skin are likely to be available within 5 to 10 years. Major progress, like treatments for Parkinson's disease and diabetes, will be available within her lifetime. By Claudia Dreifus.  With photo.  SCI-Q&amp;A (Undated) -- A science question answered: How long does it take for a fractured skull to heal? By C. Claiborne Ray.  SCI-INSECTS (Undated) -- In the annals of life, insects are one of the great success stories. A little over 400 million years ago, their six-legged ancestors came out of the water onto dry land. They have evolved into an estimated 5 million living species -- dwarfing the diversity of all other animals combined. Even if you throw in all the known species of plants, fungi and protozoans, insects still win. And that path to progress began when they started sprouting wings. By Carl Zimmer.  With photo.  SCI-WATCH (Undated) -- News and notes on science: Ants lay down chemical do not enter cues to keep other ants off paths that don't lead to food; removal of selection pressure causes adaptation in African village weaverbirds; 11 migratory species added to endangered list. By Henry Fountain.  With  SCI-MOON-FORMATION (Undated) -- Using a new technique, scientists have obtained a more precise date for the formation of the moon after the earth was struck by an object the size of Mars. The impact and ensuing crystallization of the moon occurred from 4.517 billion to 4.537 billion years ago, which is 30 million to 50 million years after the solar system was formed. A short, by Henry Fountain.  SCI-NANOTECH-RISK (Undated) -- As nanotechnology research explodes, the much smaller field that investigates the technology's possible risks is also growing. The primary worry about the potential health and safety risks of nanotechnology is simply that far too little is known about the behavior of the tiny nanoscale materials in various environments. A short, by Barnaby J. Feder.  With photo.  SCI-TYLENOL-RISK (Undated) -- A consumer column: Despite more than a decade of research showing that taking too much of a popular pain reliever can ruin the liver, the number of severe, unintentional poisonings from the drug is on the rise, a new study indicates. The drug, acetaminophen, is best known under the brand name Tylenol. But many consumers don't realize that the medicine is also found in widely varying doses in several hundred other common cold remedies and combination pain relievers. By Deborah Franklin.  SCI-REALLY (Undated) -- The claim: Green tea helps prevent cancer. The facts: .... By Anahad O'Connor.  SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) -- News and notes on health and medicine. By Nicholas Bakalar:  -- Progression: Drugs for high cholesterol may slow the progression of Alzheimer's.  -- Patterns: Extended breast-feeding appears to lower the risk of Type 2 diabetes for the mother.  -- Testing: Drinking decaffeinated coffee can raise the level of LDL, the bad cholesterol associated with cardiovascular disease risk, new research suggests.  -- Twins: Researchers in Scotland have found that twins have substantially lower IQ's than their singleton siblings, based on a sampling of more than 10,000 Scottish children born in the 1950s.  SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) -- The Personal Health column: Unless there is a drastic change in the way research is organized, the only hope for people with rare disorders is that one of the few researchers exploring a disease will stumble on a way help. The plight of a young woman with a fatal lung disease known as LAM, for lymphangioleiomyomatosis, illustrates the point. By Jane E. Brody.  SCI-FEELING-THIN (Undated) -- Within seconds, people could actually feel their waists begin to shrink. It would have been a great advance in the world of weight loss -- if only it had been real. But the shrinking feeling was just an illusion, created by scientists who wanted to study how the brain creates body image, people's perceptions of their own size and shape. The British researchers fooled 17 people into feeling as if they were getting skinnier by outfitting them with gadgets that stimulated a tendon in each wrist to create the false sensation that both hands were moving inward. By Denise Grady.  Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients. Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (212) 556-4204.  Some ScienceTimes stories are available to international clients only by special arrangement, and are so marked. Asian and European points: contact Philippe Hertzberg in Paris for details and prices, phone: 47-42-17-11; Fax: 47-42-80-44; e-mail phertzbergnytimes.com. We may be getting to the point, Moreno says, where you could actually administer a drug with a protein that helps to stimulate a certain neural center, and that might create an attitude of confidence and trust and low stress in the person being interrogated. , he said,	 The hafnium-tungsten method is a chronometer that is very well suited to date planetary accretion, said the lead author of the paper, Thorsten Kleine of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich. Until now, he said, using the technique on lunar rocks has been a problem. That's because cosmic radiation bombarding the airless moon converts another element in the rocks, tantalum, into the same tungsten isotope. So it's impossible to tell how much tungsten came from the hafnium. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
, he added,	 Kleine said that it was still unclear exactly how long it took the magma to solidify. We can only say that it's less than 20 million years, he said. The work, he added, supports the Giant Impact hypothesis. It shows that the moon formed relatively late, he said. If it formed by a more normal process, it should have formed earlier. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051128.0112 type=advis > <HEADLINE> TIMES-EXPRESS-BUDGET-NYT </HEADLINE> <TEXT> FOR Tuesday, Nov. 29. The supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Mitch Keller; phone: 212-556-1927 or 888-346-9867; e-mail:mikell @nytimes.com.  EXP-IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Saddam Hussein returned to court on Monday and quickly seized the floor for a verbal assault on the American military guards who he said had manhandled him on his way to the courtroom, calling them occupiers and invaders and demanding that the chief judge in the trial reprove them. By John F. Burns.  EXP- IRAQ-DEATH-SQUADS (Baghdad, Iraq) -- As the American military steps back from front-line duty and pushes the Shiite-dominated Iraqi security services into a larger role in combating the insurgency, the result has been a plethora of Sunni civilian deaths. By Dexter Filkins.  EXP-NIGERIA-CORRUPTION (Yenagoa, Nigeria) -- Nigeria's crooked leaders have, in the past four decades, stolen or misspent $400 billion in government money, most of it the profits from Nigeria's vast oil reserves. By Lydia Polgreen.  EXP-MIDEAST (Jerusalem) -- Palestinian gunmen, shooting into the air, pushed their way into polling stations in Gaza on Monday and forced the postponement of primary elections for the main Palestinian party, Fatah, led by president Mahmoud Abbas.. By Steven Erlanger.  TERROR-FUNDING (Washington) -- A look at U.S. efforts to curb funding for terrorism abroad. By Eric Lichtblau.  EXP-NEW-ORLEANS-FLOODS (New Orleans) -- The one article of faith in the city -- the one thing everyone agrees must be done -- is to build flood protection that will withstand a Category 5 hurricane, unlike the old Category 3 protection. But that is turning out to be an astronomically expensive and complex notion. By John Schwartz.  EXP-SCOTUS-ABORTION (Washington) -- The Supreme Court is about to take up its first abortion case in five years. By Linda Greenhouse.  EXP-BUSH (Tucson, Ariz.) -- President Bush restarts his push for an overhaul of the nation's immigration laws, focusing on border security, rather than the initial centerpiece of his plan, his proposal for a guest worker program that would temporarily legalize many workers who are in the United States illegally. By Richard W. Stevenson.  EXP-NEW-ORLEANS-SCHOOL (New Orleans) -- The first public school opens in New Orleans -- an elementary school where about 100 kids showed up from all over the city. By Adam Nossiter.  EXP-SCOTUS (Washington) -- The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear a case brought by a Justice Department whistleblower, who was dismissed after claiming fellow translators were deliberately misinterpreting Middle Eastern translations on terrorism fronts. By Linda Greenhouse.  EXP-MERCK-CUTBACK (Undated) -- Merck said Monday that it would close five manufacturing plants by 2008 and lay off 7,000 employees, about 11 percent of its work force, as it struggles with falling sales and profits. By Alex Berenson.  EXP-CHINA-CURRENCY (Washington) -- China's trade surplus with the United States has continued to balloon and is expected to approach a record of $200 billion this year. By Edmund L. Andrews.  EXP-ELECTRONICS-GIFTS (Undated) -- The two most-desired consumer electronics items this holiday season are the Apple iPod music player and the Xbox 360 game console, according to the Consumer Electronics Association, which puts out an annual list of the most-coveted electronics gifts. By Eric Taub.  EXP-DELPHI-BANKRUPTCY (Detroit) -- Delphi, which filed for Chapter 11 protection in October, said General Motors would suspend previously agreed-upon 2006 price reductions on components provided by Delphi as a way of providing interim financial support. By Micheline Maynard.  EXP-ECON-REPORT (Washington) -- Sales of previously owned homes fell by 2.7 percent in October as the housing market continued to signal that the boom of the last five years may be slowing. By Vikas Bajaj.  EXP-SCI-MOUNT-ST-HELENS (Undated) -- Mount St. Helens is quietly erupting, and for the scientists at the volcano observatory there, the past year has been an unexpected bonanza. By Kenneth Chang.  EXP-SCI-CANCER-STRESS (Undated) -- The question of whether there is a link between stress and cancer has puzzled and intrigued researchers as well as patients. What has emerged is a tenuous connection between stress, the immune system and cancer, with a surprising new insight that is changing the direction of research: By Gina Kolata.  (Editors: Budgets and advisories are internal documents not for publication or redistribution outside of client news organizations. FOREIGN  With story BC-TEEN-REPELLENT-NYT  In Wales, merchants find innovative ways to keep surly teenagers from hanging out, including the use of a high-pitched whistle that older folks usually can't hear but that drives young people nuts. The Imam's supporters say they voted him in because they want jobs and clean water, not because they embrace the Muslim Brotherhood's militant Islamist ideology.  Precisely where in the rogue's gallery of corrupt Nigerian leaders Diepreye Alamieyeseigha will fall is a matter for history to judge.  Despite a growing number of men helping aging relatives, women account for 71 percent of those devoting 40 or more hours a week to the task. Among those with the greatest burden of care, regardless of gender, 88 percent either take leaves of absence, quit or retire. Stewart died at Kings County Hospital after undergoing surgery. It was the first fatal shooting of a New York City police officer this year  We plan NY--Police Vests -- 2 x 4  Annotated photo of the bullet-proof vests worn by the NYPD  We plan BESTSELLERS--Weekly 1204 -- Various files of Besteller Lists  About 150,000 Americans annually undergo such surgery, whose risks include strokes, heart attacks and infections. Until recently, the only alternate was a combination of blood-thinning drugs and blood-pressure medications, and watchful waiting. But Linda Packer, a 64-year-old social worker in Manhattan, sought a relatively new, less-invasive alternative called carotid stenting, which has been used on more than 10,000 patients since federal regulators approved it last year.  Across rural America, entrepreneurs, lawmakers and Internet company executives say they are frustrated with a loan program created by Congress in 2002 to help extend high-speed Internet service to rural areas  Mount St. Helens is quietly erupting, and for the scientists at the volcano observatory there, the past year has been an unexpected bonanza, one that is giving them new insight into Mount St. Helens, the youngest and most active of the volcanoes in the Cascades Mountains, and perhaps into the 60 other volcanoes on the United States mainland that have erupted in the past 10,000 years and are thus presumed to have the potential to erupt again.  The question of whether there is a link between stress and cancer has puzzled and intrigued researchers as well as patients. What has emerged is a tenuous connection between stress, the immune system and cancer, with a surprising new insight that is changing the direction of research: It now appears that cancer cells make proteins that actually tell the immune system to let them alone and even to help them grow. CANADA-POLITICS (Toronto) -- Developments as Canada's three opposition parties prepared on Monday night to bring down the Liberal government of Prime Minister Paul Martin, contending that the governing party is corrupt. The no-confidence vote had been expected for the last month. By Clifford Krauss.  EGYPT-POLITICS (Mazghouna, Egypt) -- A visit to a town where the local Imam, a member of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, has won a parliamentary seat, defeating the incumbent member of President Hosni Mubarak's party. The Imam's supporters say they voted him in because they want jobs and clean water, not because they embrace the Muslim Brotherhood's militant Islamist ideology. By Michael Slackman.  TEEN-REPELLENT (Barry, Wales) -- When Howard Stapleton was 12 and visiting a factory with his father, they came to a room where workers were using high-frequency welding equipment, and he found he could not bear to go inside. The noise! he complained. What noise? the grownups asked. Now 39, Stapleton has taken the lesson he learned that day -- that children can hear sounds at higher frequencies than adults can -- to fashion a novel device that he hopes will provide a solution to the eternal problem of obstreperous teenagers who hang around outside stores and cause trouble. The device, called the Mosquito, emits a high-frequency pulsing sound that, he says, can be heard by most people younger than 20 and almost no one older than 30. A journal by Sarah Lyall.  WASHINGTON  (Will move in the w news file.)  ALITO-CONFIRM (Washington) -- About 450 pages of documents are released by the Justice Department related to the tenure of Samuel A. Alito Jr. at the Office of Legal Counsel. By David D. Kirkpatrick.  NATIONAL GENERAL  (Will move in a news file.)  PLAINS-STORMS (Undated) -- Blizzard conditions closed hundreds of miles of major highways across the Plains states Monday, part of a treacherous system that also sent tornadoes ripping through Arkansas and Kansas. Six-foot snowdrifts were common in eastern Colorado and western Kansas, the National Weather Service said. Wind up to 60 mph piled drifts 3 feet high in Pierre, S.D., where state government offices were closed. Snow fell as far south as the Texas Panhandle. By Gretchen Ruethling.  CULTURE  (Will move in e news file.)  MAGAZINE-EDITOR (Undated) -- A national magazine is expected to name a new editor. By David Carr.  SCIENCE  (Will move in s news file.)  SCI-AIDS-WHO (Undated) -- The World Health Organization's failure to meet a goal of treating 3 million HIV-infected people by the end of this year can be blamed on inadequate international coordination and lack of national leadership, a group of leading advocates for AIDS patients said on Monday. Although the health agency has said it cannot meet the goal, an advocacy group, the International Treatment Preparedness Coalition, credited it with bold efforts. WHO, a Geneva-based U.N. agency, helped show that antiretroviral treatment can be delivered effectively, extending the lives of hundreds of thousands of people, even in the poorest settings, the coalition said. By Lawrence K. Altman Jr.  (Editors: Budgets and advisories are internal documents not for publication or redistribution outside of client news organizations. , he said,	 Using his children as guinea pigs, he tried a number of different noise and frequency levels, testing a single-toned unit before settling on a pulsating tone which, he said, is more unbearable, and which can be broadcast at 75 decibels, within government auditory-safety limits. I didn't want to make it hurt, Stapleton said. It just has to nag at them. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz

, he said,	 The prairie pothole region has been described as a duck factory and is considered to be one of the most productive habitats for waterfowl in the world. The reason, according to study co-author Glenn Guntenspergen, is that it contains different types of wetlands that birds need at different times. Temporary wetlands that hold water only in early spring are critical for ducks as they migrate north because they harbor insects and other food while deeper wetlands remain frozen, he said. After the ducks pair, mate and nest, he said, they and their ducklings need deeper wetlands for food and protection in late spring and summer. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
, he said,	 The area would still have occasional wet years, he said, but they would be much less frequent. The net effect would be lower water levels, longer dry periods and no water for years in many shallow wetlands. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz
, it said,	 The effect on birds would be dramatic, and the research paper cited mallards as an example. Whereas the number of mallards during the past century has ranged from 2 million to 7 million birds a year during droughts and wet periods, it said, the outlook for the coming decades is that mallard populations will drop below historical lows and remain there. </P> 	nyt_eng_200511.gz

, it shouldn't,	 If this sounds paradoxical, it shouldn't, Stark argues. Despite the prejudiced arguments of anticlerical Enlightenment thinkers, free inquiry and faith in human reason were intrinsic to Christian thought. Christianity, alone among the world's religions, conceived of God as a supremely rational being who created a coherent world whose inner workings could be discovered through the application of reason and logic. Consequently, it was only in the West, rather than in Asia or the Middle East, that alchemy evolved into chemistry, astrology into astronomy. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz
, he writes,	 Stark sneaks in one of his most intriguing theories late in the book. He notes that soon after the Roman emperor Constantine embraced Christianity in 312, he began showering the church with money and privileges, making it an attractive career for the upper classes. The church of piety, run by dedicated, poorly paid and ascetic clergy, gave way to the church of power, which was far less likely to impede the growth of commerce. Had the church of piety prevailed, he writes, Christianity probably would have continued to denounce usury and to oppose profit and materialism in general, just as Islam still does. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz

, he wrote,	 People, he's discovered, tip for a variety of reasons, ranging from obligation to gratitude to guilt. , she says,	 On July 30, 1960, Larsen (The White) sat in a taxi outside an Iowa convent and smoked one last cigarette before going inside to begin the process of becoming a nun. She was 19. She and other postulants were welcomed, then assigned beds, places at the table, seats in chapel. It seemed, she says, like summer camp. Five years later, she decided not to take her final vows, but her time in the convent had transformed her into a woman who was strong enough to leave it. This lovely and affectionate memoir reflects the allure of religious life in an era when girls read Kathryn Hulme's novel The Nun's Story and saw themselves in it. Writing in short sections with headings (Black Becomes Us, Custody of the Eyes, A Grapefruit Incident), Larsen creates a vivid picture of those years, from the clothes she wore to her longing for cigarettes (she gave the last of hers to the cabbie) to the comforting presence of her fellow postulants. We fairly pulsed with idealism and purpose, she writes. We had all come to give our lives to God. We did not think that what we were doing was one bit odd. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz

If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or With photos.  Theater  GUNN-THEATER (Undated) -- By any measure, this is a breakout season for the American baritone Nathan Gunn at the Metropolitan Opera. On Dec. 28, he finished a demanding run of performances in An American Tragedy, by Tobias Picker. On Jan. 21, Gunn gives his first Met performance as Papageno, in Mozart's Zauberflote, in a revival of the 2004 production by Julie Taymor. Some of his many fans in the New York area tossed makeshift confetti of ripped-up programs from the balconies during his curtain calls for An American Tragedy. But is it possible that Gunn's appearance has drawn attention away from his fine vocal artistry? By Anthony Tommasini.  Movies  BRAZIL-FILM (Rio de Janeiro) -- Over the years, Zeze di Camargo and Luciano, the brothers who are a leading country music duo in Brazil, had grown accustomed to people saying that their life story would make an inspiring movie. Theirs is a classic rags-to-riches tale. But nothing in their experience in the music business prepared them for what happened after just such a film based on a true story was made and was released here in August. Two Sons of Francisco (2 Filhos de Francisco) has not only won new respect for an often overlooked musical genre, it has also gone on to break box office records and become Brazil's Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film. By Larry Rohter.  BUJALSKI-FILM (Undated) -- At 28, Andrew Bujalski has already made two homespun, micro-budget features, both set deep within the befuddling gray zone of post-collegiate life. In his first, Funny Ha Ha, Marnie, a 23-year-old recent graduate, floats between dead-end temp jobs while nursing an unrequited crush and fending off an unwelcome suitor. His latest, Mutual Appreciation, centers on a more ambitious but equally restless protagonist: Alan, an indie rocker who arrives in Brooklyn with a gig but no band mates. Though still an industry outsider, Bujalski is emerging as a critics' favorite. By Dennis Lim.  Television  LEE-TV (Undated) -- Four months into his run as the title character on NBC's My Name Is Earl, Jason Lee understands that the boundary between his on-screen alter ego -- a likable loser determined to make amends to everyone he's ever wronged -- and his own identity has been obliterated. Fans of the sitcom who don't know Lee's name now feel perfectly comfortable addressing this 35-year-old actor in public as Hey, Earl! And now NBC has moved My Name Is Earl (on which Lee also serves as a producer) into the 9 p.m. Thursday time slot that has traditionally served as the cornerstone of the network's prime-time lineup. By Dave Itzkoff.  Pop Music  ANGEL-MUSIC (Undated) -- Do you have any skills? A likable guy with shaggy blond hair is sitting in a cafe with his girlfriend, and she wants to know. MTV is betting that a few hundred thousand viewers will want to know, too. The blond is Ashley Parker Angel, once a minor pop star and now, well, a former minor pop star. He was featured on the semisuccessful reality show Making the Band, on which he was recruited into the boy band O-Town. The group managed a few small hits before the boy-band bubble burst, destroying the market for synchronized shamelessness. And now Angel is the star of Ashley Parker Angel: There and Back, a new series on MTV. By Kelefa Sanneh.  Bestseller Lists  BESTSELLERS-HARD-L (Undated) -- Best-selling hardbacks, long-form list.  BESTSELLERS-HARD-S (Undated) -- Best-selling hardbacks, short-form list.  BESTSELLERS-PAPER-L (Undated) -- Best-selling paperbacks, long-form list.  BESTSELLERS-PAPER-S (Undated) -- Best-selling paperbacks, short-form list.  BESTSELLERS-CHILDREN (Undated) -- Best-selling children's books.  NOTEWORTHY-PAPERBACKS (Undated) -- Short summaries of other paperbacks.  On Language  ON-LANGUAGE (Undated) -- The weekly language column. By William Safire.  Editors, this column moves on the Monday or Tuesday before publication.  TRAVEL-GALAPOGOS (Undated) -- It can be tough deciding which wildlife encounters are worthy of pause after only a few days in the Galapagos. Nearly any tour that cruises this isolated yet popular chain, 600 miles west of Ecuador, comes packaged with extreme close-ups of washer-size tortoises, swimming lizards and crabs the color of rainbows. But this is not one of those tours. It's late November, and Peter Grubb is leading a small group of guides, naturalists and reporters on a weeklong exploratory sea kayaking trip. When Grubb's Galapagos sea kayaking trips open to the public in February, a dozen adventurous clients at a time will experience these islands and wildlife in an enticing new way: by paddling to deserted beaches and camping overnight in sand that bears few five-toe footprints. By Tim Neville.  TRAVEL-MEXICO (Undated) -- A Cancun in the making? Once dotted by cabanas, the nearby Mayan Riviera is sprouting family-friendly megaresorts. By Marek Fuchs.  TRAVEL-PUERTO-RICO (Undated) -- A new youthful beat pulses through Puerto Rico as reggaeton, a kind of salsa-flavored hip-hop, gyrates San Juan and the hills beyond. By Julia Chaplin.  TRAVEL-THE-HAGUE (Undated) -- Time was if you mentioned The Hague to someone from Amsterdam, the most likely comment you would have received would have been stately, followed closely by boring (if not the reverse). The Hague, site of the 13th century Binnenhof, where the Dutch parliament meets, has long labored in the shadows of its supposedly hipper sister city. Now thanks to a recent cultural and culinary renaissance in the area of the Denneweg and the Lange Voorhout, The Hague, which remains as stately as it ever was, has cast off its boring reputation. By Gordon F. Sander.  Regular Features  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) -- Hyatt is one of several hotel chains that are upgrading their exercise facilities and programs. Most of the renovations feature new workout equipment. But some are going a step further, adding personal trainers or exercise classes, or building entirely new facilities to accommodate guests who are reluctant to take a day off from their exercise schedule. By Christopher S. Elliott. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20060103.0180 type=story > <HEADLINE> WEATHERING THE STORM IN LONDON, WHICH HAS CREATIVITY TO KEEP IT WARM </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> LONDON </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_200601.gz"

, they roll,	 Using a short wooden pin, Wang stretches the dough with her thumb and rolls the piece into an oval. Across the table, Ming is doing the same thing. Then Yun Wei Wang spreads each oval with a teaspoon of pork and Chinese leek filling before pressing the two narrow edges of the oval together and crimping the remaining edges. To tighten the seal, she points both index fingers together and holds the dumpling against the fingers with her thumbs. Over and over, they roll, stretch, fill, and crimp until the baking sheet at the edge of the table is lined with 150 perfectly-formed 1 1/2-inch-long dumplings. They'll fill 10 sheets. The dumplings are steamed and served in the restaurant or sold uncooked and frozen, 50 to a bag. </P> 	nyt_eng_200601.gz
, she explains,	 Wang's dumplings contain light, subtly seasoned fillings. The wrappers are thicker than the commercial variety found in Asian markets (those are usually wonton wrappers). Homemade wrappers, says Yi Wang, should have lots of texture. The dough is shaped into ovals, she explains, because that makes them easier to form into identical dumplings. </P> 	nyt_eng_200601.gz

, he says,	 The problem with a book like this is finding a way to describe it without persuading you not to read it at all. Here are some assurances: Gallego's novel - - it's actually a series of autobiographical vignettes - - is not depressing. It's not horrifying, despite the appalling conditions it reveals. It's stunning, but not for the reasons you'd expect. Gallego was born with cerebral palsy in Moscow in 1968. When he was 1, for reasons too twisted to relate here, Soviet authorities separated him from his mother (she was told he had died) and placed him in an institution, and then another and another. That is how he grew up, severely handicapped, often in squalor, with little tenderness or regard. It was, he says, cruel and terrible, yet he writes of those years with a clarity that is almost clinical, and in a voice so matter-of-fact that it seems nonchalant. Today, he has been reunited with his mother and has a life in the world. But his point of view was born of heroic survival, and he raises questions, not by asking them, but by making us ask ourselves: What is luck? What is hope? What is pity? What is joy? </P> 	nyt_eng_200601.gz

When they asked the owner who had freed them to re-enslave them, he refused, and they responded by killing him and his family, moving back to their old quarters, and resuming their old ways -- the point being that institutionalized oppression and self-loathing, instilled over generations, form habits not easily broken. </P> 	nyt_eng_200601.gz

, he explains,	 The fruits of Brendel's empiricism may be observed, to choose only one example, in his treatment of the famous four-voiced staccato chords that begin Beethoven's sonata in C major, Op. 53, the Waldstein. How to balance the voices in these pianissimo eruptions? Arthur Schnabel's recommendation was to stress the extremes, the soprano and the bass, and leave the middle voices in the background -- but this, Brendel quarrelsomely insists, will get a great deal of clarity but a totally wrong atmosphere. , it seems,	 Prions exist in normal form in mammals, and become disease agents when they are misfolded. Darfur is a battlefield in the conventional sense, and an increasingly violent one where rebels intent on toppling the government square off against Sudanese troops. But it is also a giant crime scene littered with shell casings and full of suspects on the run. There are assaults and homicides and rapes and larcenies across Darfur, but there is hardly anyone, it seems, seriously trying to solve the crimes. (Michael Kamber/The New York Times)  (NYT39) NEAR KALMA REFUGEE CAMP, Sudan -- Feb. 4, 2006 -- SUDAN-VIOLENCE-4 -- Women and children from the Kalma refugee camp in Darfur, Sudan, Feb. 1, 2006 wait at sunrise for handouts from soldiers. Livni is seen as willing to confront tough issues. Livni, 47, is the first woman to serve as Israel's foreign minister since Golda Meir did so half a century ago. Some think she may be the first since Meir to be prime minister. Tall, neat and unadorned, she is a most unusual Israeli politician, a lawyer respected for integrity and her willingness to engage on difficult issues and to confront ideology with pragmatism. But she is also a deeply Israeli figure, the daughter of Zionist guerrillas -- terrorists in some eyes -- who met in the Irgun, the underground organization that fought the British and the Arabs, and that blew up the British headquarters in the King David Hotel in 1946, killing 91 people. SCI-LOW-FAT-DIET (Undated) -- Shock, disbelief, cynicism and criticism have greeted a report that a low fat diet may not prevent breast cancer, colon cancer, or heart disease, after all. And it's shattering an American canon that vice gets punished and virtue gets rewarded: if you eat or drink or inhale the wrong things you get sick. If not, you get healthy. By Gina Kolata.  With photo.  SCI-ROBOTS-WILSON (Undated) -- In his new book, How to Survive a Robot Uprising, Daniel Wilson, a robotics expert, offers detailed -- and hilariously deadpan -- advice on evading hostile swarms of robot insects (don't try to fight -- loss of an individual robot is inconsequential to the swarm); outsmarting your smart house (be suspicious if the house suggests you test the microwave by putting your head in it); escaping unmanned ground vehicles (drive in circles -- they'll have a harder time tracking you); and surviving hand-to-hand combat with a humanoid (smear yourself with mud to disguise your distinctive human thermal signature and go for the eyes -- its cameras). By Cornelia Dean.  With photo.  And  SCI-ROBOTS-TIPS (Undated) -- Tips for fighting off a robot. By Cornelia Dean.  SCI-PRESIDENTS-MENTAL-HEALTH (Undated) -- All told, almost half of American presidents between 1789 and 1974 had at least one mental illness in their lifetime, according to a recent analysis of biographical sources by psychiatrists at Duke University Medical Center. A short by Benedict Carey.  SCI-TANNEN-LINGUISTICS A Conversation With feature on Deborah Tannen: A trailblazing linguist who helped expand the field to include aspects of everyday conversation is back on the best-seller list with You're Wearing That? Understanding Mothers and Daughters in Conversation. Those difficult family chasms can be mended, she says, with a better understanding of communications. By Claudia Dreifus.  With photo.  SCI-Q&amp;A (Undated) -- A science question answered: What will happen later to the trees around New York that seemed to be about to burst into bloom or sprout leaves after an unusually warm stretch? By C. Claiborne Ray.  SCI-LEVEES (Vicksburg, Miss.) -- Engineers are building giant model of New Orleans, one-50th of actual size, to help determine what happened in Hurricane Katrina. But these efforts and others, some critics say, may simply be means to deflect blame. By John Schwartz.  NASA-EARTHS-FATE (Undated) -- Billions of years from now, the sun will burn out and the world will end. Science books have told us this for years. But NASA, not wanting to scare anyone, has such a reference removed from a press release. By Dennis Overbye.  SCI-WATCH (Undated) -- News and notes on science: The eruptions of Krakatoa had effects on ocean temperatures and sea level that persisted for decades; Augustine, a volcano 170 miles southwest of Anchorage, has something Krakatoa never had, monitoring over the Internet; the chemical TTX, found naturally in the potentially deadly pufferfish, is used as an offensive weapon in other animals, including a flatworm. By Henry Fountain.  With  SCI-SYMPATHETIC-MATES (Undated) -- Scientists find weight gains among male marmosets and tamarins when their mates are pregnant. A short by Henry Fountain.  SCI-RATS-MAZES (Undated) -- When rats pause in running through a maze, they play back their memory of points along their route, but in reverse order. The discovery may provide a deep insight into how memory works in humans, as well as rats. The reverse rewind capability seems to be part of a neural editing process in which memories are selected, combined and stored as a set of edited movies, as it were, of important experiences in a rat's -- or a person's -- life. By Nicholas Wade.  SCI-PARKINSONS-DRUG (Undated) -- A drug for Parkinson's disease can bring on illusions, in this case auditory ones. A first-person account by Mark Derr.  SCI-COGNITIVE-THERAPY (Undated) -- For most of the 20th century, therapists in America agreed on a single truth. To cure patients, it was necessary to explore and talk through the origins of their problems. In other words, they had to come to terms with the past to move forward in the present. But returning to the past has fallen out of fashion among mental health professionals over the last 15 years. Over the last 20 years, psychotherapeutic techniques like psychoanalysis and psychodynamic therapy, have been eclipsed by cognitive behavioral approaches. That relatively new school holds that reviewing the past is not only unnecessary to healing, but can be counterproductive. By Alix Spiegel.  SCI-ADDICTION-PILL (Undated) -- Patients with addiction problems -- including gambling -- want a pill that will wipe away their problems. Though medicine may help, it will never be a cure-all. By Sally Satel, M.D.  SCI-REALLY (Undated) -- The claim: High intake of sodas increases the risk of esophageal cancer. The facts: .... By Anahad O'Connor.  SCI-WOMEN-HORMONES (Undated) -- A new report suggests that for women who have had hysterectomies, taking estrogen does not increase the risk of heart disease and may even protect the heart in those who are younger, from 50 to 59. By Denise Grady.  SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) -- News and notes on health and medicine. By Eric Nagourney:  -- At the Pharmacy: Pharmacies are often unable to provide labels in Spanish, even when the pharmacy is a neighborhood where the language is spoken heavily, a new study finds.  -- Testing: Doctors are increasingly being asked to give drug tests to teenagers, but a new study suggests that they are not necessarily well qualified to do so, and that they often fail to carry out the tests property.  -- Alternatives: The fruit of the saw palmetto plant is widely used as a dietary supplement to reduce swollen prostate glands. But a new study finds that it is no better than a placebo.  -- Patterns: Pregnant women with asthma are likely to experience worse symptoms if they are carrying a girl, a new study has found.  SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) -- The Personal Health column: It is time to make changes in what planners call the built environment, to give more people the opportunity to become physically active and remain so. By Jane E. Brody.  SCI-MUSIC-TASTE (Undated) -- Frank Sinatra or Tony Bennett, classical or baroque, early Los Lobos or late: Taste in music seems a deeply personal matter, guided by an internal compass all one's own. Yet two new studies reveal how social considerations influence not only the music a person buys but the recordings he or she calls favorites. By Benedict Carey. For information, phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. INTERNATIONAL (Will move in the i news file.) LOVE-POEM (Istanbul, Turkey) -- It is as tiny as the sleekest mobile phones that fit in the palm of the hand, but its message is anything but modern. A small tablet in a special display this month in the Istanbul Museum of the Ancient Orient is thought to be the oldest love poem ever found, the words of a lover from more than 4,000 years ago. The ancient Sumerian tablet was unearthed in the late 1880s in Nippur, a region in what is now Iraq, and had been resting quietly in a modest corner of the museum until it was brought back to the limelight this year by a company that made it part of a Valentine's Day promotion.part of a Valentine's Day promotion. With photo.  TURKEY-FILM (Istanbul, Turkey) -- The crowd cheered, clapped and whistled as the Turkish agent plunged the knife into the chest of the enemy commander. Valley of the Wolves -- Iraq, which opened last week in movie theaters in Turkey, Austria and Germany, is a Rambo-like action story involving Turkish gunmen who seek revenge against a tyrannical occupying army. In this version, however, the enemy is no oppressive Third World dictatorship. The commander's name is Sam -- as in uncle -- and the opposing forces are the Americans, who are being punished for offenses against Turkish as well as Iraqi pride and honor. The commander, Sam William Marshall, played by an American actor, Billy Zane, is a sociopath, killing people without a second's thought and claiming that he is doing God's will. While fictional, some of the movie is based in part on real events, and many of the scenes elicit knowing looks from the audience. A journal by Sebnem Arsu.  With photo.  ITALY-BERLUSCONI (Turin, Italy) -- Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, wanted to set the record straight: He was joking when he compared himself to Napoleon the day before. I am the Jesus Christ of politics, he corrected himself in a speech on Saturday. I am a patient victim; I bear everything; I sacrifice myself for everyone. This came the same day that Berlusconi put himself in Churchill's league and not long after he made a vow to a priest not to have sex until the end of his already strenuous exertions to be re-elected in April. By Ian Fisher.  WASHINGTON  (Will move in the w news file.)  IRAQ-DETAIN (Washington) -- A federal judge here ruled on Monday that the Bush administration cannot transfer a U.S. citizen held by the military in Iraq to Iraqi civilian custody. In his ruling, Judge Ricardo M. Urbina rejected arguments made last week by Justice Department lawyers that the courts had no jurisdiction because the man, Shawqi Ahmad Omar, was not technically in U.S. custody. In his 16-page ruling, Urbina minimized as legalistic the government's argument that Omar was actually in the custody of the 27-nation Multi-National Force in Iraq, which the United States did not control. Omar, 44, a naturalized American citizen, was arrested in Baghdad over a year ago by military authorities. He has not been charged or allowed to consult with a lawyer. By Neil A. Lewis.  NATIONAL GENERAL  (Will move in a news file.)  HARVARD-SUMMERS (Cambridge, Mass.) -- A year after weathering a no-confidence vote by the faculty, Harvard University's president, Lawrence H. Summers, is facing another showdown with dissident faculty members. By Alan Finder. , it seems,	 So, to hell in a handbasket, in other words, but fortunately for the plot of the novel, the trains are still running on time to a place called the city - a painless, mostly pleasant realm on the other side of a desert that all the dead must cross. Their crossings are as varied and elaborate as their ten billion lives: One woman is turned into snow on her journey, another remembers swimming through a heartbeat surrounded by shoals of brilliant fish. Once they arrive in the city, they set up shop: A former journalism professor finds whatever news is fit to print and publishes a free broadsheet. A blind man finds his way around by means of his enhanced other senses. One fellow achieves his lifelong dream of opening a little cafe, where lots of city inhabitants linger. All of them are here, it seems, not as a final destination but rather to inhabit a way station of memory. So long as they are tethered to the earth by a living person's archives, they will stay in the city. As long as, say, your grocer remembers you, or your spouse, or the child who beat you up in fifth grade, you'll hang around this quiet zone, wrapped in the corporeal cloak of human consciousness. But once you've been forgotten - well, that finality is what The Brief History of the Dead is all about. </P> 	nyt_eng_200602.gz

, he said,	 Ted Turner stayed on as a director at Time Warner years longer than necessary though he disapproved of many changes and his influence started to wane. Turner stuck it out, he said, to help usher the company through a host of challenges, including an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and, most recently, an assault by investor Carl Icahn. I didn't want to leave them in the lurch, he said in an interview Monday at Emory University, just three days after Time Warner announced Turner wouldn't stand for re-election to the company's board. Turner, 67, is a legendary entrepreneur and businessman, from his purchase of the once-moribund Braves to the founding of CNN as a pioneering experiment in news. However, he sold his Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System to Time Warner in 1996 and, over the years, has steadily lost clout. They're doing a good job of operating the company, said Turner, who in stepping down offered kind words for Time Warner Chairman and CEO Richard Parsons. But it has been heart-wrenching, Turner said, to see Time Warner dismantle some of the things at his former company. He didn't like the just-announced sale of cable network Turner South to News Corp., and he hates seeing his beloved Atlanta Braves on the auction block. He still regrets the demise of the Goodwill Games, too. To see so many things that I worked my whole business life to put together, to see them broken apart, sold off, it is very hard for me, he said. Turner's not interested in buying the Braves, though. Been there, done that, he said. What would I do for an encore? The main thing is that I couldn't afford it. While Turner is preparing to drop off the Time Warner board as of May, he looks back on a proud history at Turner Broadcasting. I'm still the founder, and that's not going to change, he said. My heart will always be there. Turner, who was at Emory to accept the school's inaugural Global Innovation Award, said Turner Broadcasting was a special place for him. I like to think of it as kind of a little Camelot, Turner said. Ever the center of attention, he broke into a recitation of Camelot. Time Warner, however, hasn't been such a good place. Turner, during a question-and-answer session at Emory, said the company has been selling everything, divesting everything that was the least bit difficult to manage. He cited examples including the Braves, Turner South and Time Warner's music division and book publishing units. You need to be taking some risks, he said. I was always buying and expanding. In 2003, he stepped down as vice chairman of the Time Warner board. It has been just a matter of time before he would decide to depart all together despite his trove of shares. It's not like this came as a surprise to anyone, Turner said. Turner wanted to stay on the board, he said, while Time Warner resolved several major problems, including an SEC investigation of accounting for online advertising revenue at the company's America Online unit. Time Warner paid $300 million in early 2005 to settle civil fraud charges lodged by the agency. (The company also paid $210 million a few months prior to resolve Justice Department charges of criminal securities fraud that also involved AOL.) Then came Icahn, who lobbied in favor of breaking up Time Warner, owner of such huge properties as AOL and Time Warner Cable. Icahn lobbied hard, only to reach a deal that fell far short of his most ambitious goals. You notice I stayed until the Icahn thing was behind us, Turner said. Turner, who has a fortune estimated at $2 billion, continues with his devotion to a long list of philanthropic causes. He's a supporter of Emory's Global Perspectives Program, for example. But as Time Warner and Turner Broadcasting change, including in ways he doesn't like, Turner knows he's experiencing something many other successful businesspeople have already faced. I'm 67 years old, he said. It's true of everybody that gets old -- entrepreneurs, founders, always feel like the new guys are messing it up. </P> 	nyt_eng_200602.gz
