If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For questions about photos, call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  TRAVEL-WINTER-SKI (Undated) -- From Colorado to British Columbia, a look at the best places for late-season skiing this year. By Michelle Higgins.  TRAVEL-SKI-TAOS (Undated) -- The 20-mile drive from the town of Taos to Taos Ski Valley in northeastern New Mexico is a stunning geographical contradiction. The road travels through vast red desert, past adobe houses and prickly pear cactuses, upward through the dense evergreens of the Carson National Forest, finally reaching a Bavarianlike village with the Sangre de Cristo Mountains -- blood-red at sunset -- rising to 13,000 feet overhead. The road ends where the lift line to Al's Run begins, a harrowing-looking bump run that must, in part, account for Taos's reputation as one of skiing's most daunting challenges. On this journey, the psychic distance is just as great as the physical one. In Taos, the spirituality is New Age; here in Taos Ski Valley village, it's all about the skiing. By Lisa Reed.  TRAVEL-SKI-CHAMONIX (Undated) -- Chamonix, a small resort town nestled 3,396 feet high in the Alps, has a long-standing, well-earned reputation as a center for hard-edged sports. After all, it was the birthplace of mountaineering in the late 1700s, and the site of the first Winter Olympics, in 1924. In 1988, a band of skiers that included Glen Plake, the mohawked bad boy of American skiing, upped the ante, creating the sport of extreme skiing by launching themselves (on skis, naturally) off the slopes, cliffs and even tramways around Chamonix, often while upside down and spiraling like a helicopter in a movie that has become a cult skiing classic, The Blizzard of Aahhhs. For skiers of much less than professional ability who don't have any desire to be upside down at any point whatsoever, Chamonix still provides plenty of opportunities to get the adrenaline flowing. By Heather Timmons.  TRAVEL-BUDGET-JACKSON (Undated) -- A budget weekend in Jackson Hole, Wyo., on $500. Matt Gross shows how it can be done.  TRAVEL-LAOS (Undated) -- Just four years ago, a stop in this tranquil town was de rigueur for drug-touring trekkers. Local weed and Burmese speed were sold openly on the street, and by some accounts the opium dens outnumbered the guesthouses. The backpackers flocked, and haughty fans of the writer Paul Theroux, whose travels are held up by purists as the right way to do it, announced that Vang Vieng was over. Then something interesting happened. Guesthouses began posting signs saying No Drugs and Please Keep Yourself Clean. Enough of the town's 45,000 residents, it seemed, refused to choke under the hazy smoke exhaled by scruffy budget travelers. The modest economy has since gone straight, attracting well-heeled tourists to counteract the dreadlock dudes. With development moving ahead -- six new guesthouses are opening this year, bringing the total to nearly 70 -- hotel operators and tour guides see a brighter future in inner-tube rentals than in opium dens. By Jeff Koyen.  Regular Features  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) -- Don't get lost. A guide to GPS devices. By David R. Kelly.  TRAVEL-BRIEFS (Undated) -- News and notes on travel.  TRAVEL-Q&amp;A (Undated) -- Travel question answered. By Roger Collis. , he concedes,	 Add another credit to Robert Osborne's growing list: official celebrity greeter at the 78th annual Academy Awards. Already Oscar's official historian, the Hollywood Reporter columnist and genial longtime host of Turner Classic Movies will be the red carpet king on Sunday. He'll announce the stars as they arrive outside the Kodak Theatre. Offering equal welcome to nominees doesn't mean he doesn't have his own Oscar faves. But certainly not [ones] that I'll be talking about on the carpet, he says by phone from New York. If I had a vote, I'd certainly vote for 'Brokeback Mountain,' he continues. And I'm delighted that 'Crash' got nominated, since it was [released] so early in the year. For best actor, he's betting on Philip Seymour Hoffman. He's a seamless actor, and he does daring things, Osborne says. He's kind of the Spencer Tracy of today. As for the competition: I think Heath Ledger is really brilliant in 'Brokeback Mountain,' but just as an Oscar observer, it might be to his advantage not to win, Osborne says. For a young person, it can actually stifle a career. Call it the too-much-too-young syndrome. (Think Mira Sorvino and Marisa Tomei.) Best actress? Reese [Witherspoon] will very likely win, but she does have tough competition from Felicity Huffman. In all, he assesses it as a particularly competitive Oscar year, in terms of nominees' overall quality. Well, with one big exception. Personally I'm not sure that 'Munich' deserves to be an Oscar nominee, he says, focusing on the otherwise strong best picture category. Steven Spielberg is a great director, but I'm not sure this is his best work. (He would've liked to see either Cinderella Man or Walk the Line in that fifth slot.) As author of 75 Years of the Oscar: The Official History of the Academy Awards, Osborne knows the big night inside and out. For all the event's pomp and designer-gown elegance, his favorite years are the ones when something upsets the apple cart, like the streaker. That was in 1974. On the opposite end of things, great Oscar moments came from, well, the greats. Like Charlie Chaplin's 1972 honorary Oscar, which brought the silent-film genius back to the States after years of living in European obscurity. He'd kind of been exiled from this country for so many years, and was considered a communist who raped young girls, Osborne recalls, alluding to Chaplin's marriage to Oona O'Neill when she was 17. But he came out onstage by himself at the end of the show, this lonely, wonderful little old man who was not a danger to anybody. It's a revelation he likens to the 1966 ceremony when Fred Astaire, then in his mid-60s, and Ginger Rogers, then in her mid-50s, presented an Oscar. As they came on, they did an impromptu kind of swing, a dance step, he says. And you thought, 'Oh my God, this is Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers!' Moments like that are thrilling. These days, Oscar night isn't what it once was. Fewer viewers tune in. One reason? All these other awards shows are trying to copy Oscar, Osborne says. Indeed, who wants to see Witherspoon give another acceptance speech when she's done it already at the Golden Globes, the Screen Actors Guild Awards, and even the UK's Baftas? But at least people know who she is, whereas Osborne feels that 13 or 14 of the 20 actors on the list for Oscar this year are basically unknown to the public. Even that, though, can be seen as an offshoot of one of Oscar's big pluses: They call attention to more obscure movies that otherwise would not get booked in the multiplex. So Oscar matters -- at least to those who win, knowing when they die their obituaries will begin with those magic words: Academy Award-winner so-and-so died today.? Though he's new to this celeb-greeting gig -- replacing Variety columnist Army Archerd, who served for more than four decades -- Osborne is looking to have fun on Sunday. If he's bad at it, well, like host Jon Stewart, he's not too worried about its affect on his future. I'll really do my best, but it isn't exactly my main job. For the record, neither is acting in horrible movies -- even though his entry on the Internet Movie Database erroneously claims he played Farmer .2 in Tom (as in, Whatever Happened to ? ) Green's Freddy Got Fingered. This is my snobbish side, but I wouldn't go see that movie, much less be in it, Osborne says. He has no idea how to get that false credit erased from the Internet. With a laugh, he concedes, That's probably gonna be on my obituary. </P> 	nyt_eng_200602.gz

They are available to all NYT graphic clients via satellite on Associated Press GraphicsNet, and will be posted at nytimages.com and on Newscom. For retransmission of graphics from the AP, call the AP Service Desk at 212-621-7983.  Non-subscribers may make individual graphics purchases or get additional information by calling the NYT Photo/Graphics desk at (212) 556-4204 or (888) 603-1036 between noon and 10 p.m. ET.  ATTENTION EDITORS: Please check the Graphic Budget section on our Web site - nytimages.com - where you can find continuous updates of planned graphics.  FOREIGN  With story BC-BIRD-FLU-FRANCE-NYT  The deadly strain of bird flu has been found in a cat in Germany, officials said Tuesday, the first time the virus has been identified in an animal other than a bird in central Europe.  Two months after the Central American Free Trade Agreement was supposed to go into effect, only El Salvador is ready to join, frustrating a hard-won victory for Washington in its push toward free trade. Four other countries have yet to change a host of laws to bring them into line with the agreement, which requires them to open up their economies to American trade and investment, dismantle protections for many local industries and crack down on counterfeit movies and CDs. A fifth country, Costa Rica, has yet to ratify it. While the delay is in part a sign of how complex negotiations have been when so many countries are involved, it also reflects the extent of the concerns about the agreement in the tiny economies it will affect.  We plan KATRINA--Fuel -- size to be determined  How much natural gas and oil is still shut-in in the Gulf of Mexico  vacant area near the Passaic River. A waterfront park, a new light rail line and the refurbishment of McCarter Highway along the river and the Amtrak bridge over the Passaic are in various stages of completion, and all of the public investment is attracting private investment as well. The first phase of a major mixed-use commercial development on an eight-acre waterfront site is expected to start this year.  In the airline industry's battle to survive and maybe even eke out a profit, the weapon of choice is shifting from cutting costs to raising prices.  Shares of Google dropped 10 percent after its chief financial officer, George Reyes, said growth was slowing and the company needed to find new ways to bolster sales.  The 20-mile drive from the town of Taos to Taos Ski Valley in northeastern New Mexico is a stunning geographical contradiction. The road travels through vast red desert, past adobe houses and prickly pear cactuses, upward through the dense evergreens of the Carson National Forest, finally reaching a Bavarianlike village with the Sangre de Cristo Mountains - blood-red at sunset - rising to 13,000 feet overhead. The road ends where the lift line to Al's Run begins, a harrowing-looking bump run that must, in part, account for Taos's reputation as one of skiing's most daunting challenges. On this journey, the psychic distance is just as great as the physical one. In Taos, the spirituality is New Age; here in Taos Ski Valley village, it's all about the skiing.  Chamonix, a small resort town nestled 3,396 feet high in the Alps, has a long-standing, well-earned reputation as a center for hard-edged sports. After all, it was the birthplace of mountaineering in the late 1700s, and the site of the first Winter Olympics, in 1924. In 1988, a band of skiers that included Glen Plake, the mohawked bad boy of American skiing, upped the ante, creating the sport of extreme skiing by launching themselves (on skis, naturally) off the slopes, cliffs and even tramways around Chamonix, often while upside down and spiraling like a helicopter in a movie that has become a cult skiing classic, The Blizzard of Aahhhs. For skiers of much less than professional ability who don't have any desire to be upside down at any point whatsoever, Chamonix still provides plenty of opportunities to get the adrenaline flowing.  Just four years ago, a stop in this tranquil town was de rigueur for drug-touring trekkers. Local weed and Burmese speed were sold openly on the street, and by some accounts the opium dens outnumbered the guesthouses. The backpackers flocked, and haughty fans of the writer Paul Theroux, whose travels are held up by purists as the right way to do it, announced that Vang Vieng was over. Then something interesting happened. Guesthouses began posting signs saying No Drugs and Please Keep Yourself Clean. Enough of the town's 45,000 residents, it seemed, refused to choke under the hazy smoke exhaled by scruffy budget travelers. The modest economy has since gone straight, attracting well-heeled tourists to counteract the dreadlock dudes. With development moving ahead - six new guesthouses are opening this year, bringing the total to nearly 70 - hotel operators and tour guides see a brighter future in inner-tube rentals than in opium dens. , he added,	 Cox News Service LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. - If the Braves have a figurative torch for their pitching ace, it was passed Tuesday from John Smoltz to Tim Hudson. Manager Bobby Cox confirmed Hudson is scheduled to start the April 3 season opener at the Los Angeles Dodgers. Smoltz, last year's opening-day starter, would pitch the second game at Dodger Stadium. If everything works out, that's right, [Hudson] will open, said Cox, who would be using his sixth different opening day starter in six seasons after three in the previous 11 years. The manager had yet to talk to his pitchers about the plan, but Smoltz, 38, said it made perfect sense. Two weeks ago, the veteran with the surgically repaired (four times) elbow and shoulder that throbbed in September and October, announced he would reduce his workload in hopes of staying healthy this year. It's a no-brainer, to me, Smoltz said of Hudson starting the opener. I don't say that to be submissive. It makes sense because of everything - stats, everything. He's the guy that's going to carry the club. I don't want to put pressure on him, but that's the truth. The way the rotation breaks down, the No. 3 starter - likely Horacio Ramirez - will pitch the home opener on April 10th against Philadelphia. Hudson, 30, went 14-9 with a 3.52 ERA in 192 innings during his first season with the Braves, modest for a pitcher who led the American League with 81 wins and 1,104 innings in the previous five seasons. He fell short of his expectations, and Hudson is eager to improve on it and be the pitcher the Braves expected when he got a four-year, $47 million contract extension last spring, before he'd thrown a pitch for Atlanta. Until something's official, I don't really have anything to say about [starting opening day], said Hudson, who pitched several openers for Oakland. I just go out and work when they tell me to work. But, he added, Obviously, pitching any opening day is an honor. Especially with the staff we have. Smoltz was 14-7 with a 3.06 ERA in 33 starts, silencing those who questioned the decision to move the former All-Star closer back to his starting role after 3 1/2 seasons in the bullpen. After allowing six earned runs in 1 2/3 innings in the opener at Florida and losing his first three starts, Smoltz went 14-4 with a 2.86 ERA in 30 starts despite nagging neck, back and shoulder injuries. When the Braves had injuries to starters Mike Hampton, John Thomson and Hudson, Smoltz ground out 79 innings while going 8-0 with a 2.05 ERA over 10 games June 11 to July 31. He later conceded he pushed himself too hard over that stretch, which included three complete games and consecutive games June 21-26 in which he totaled 241 pitches in 18 innings with one run allowed. One thing I want to do is [help] lessen his workload, said Hudson, who spent a month on the disabled list last summer with a strained intercostal muscle in his left side. I want to be able to pitch every [fifth] day, stay healthy, go deep into games so he doesn't have to do what he had to do last year. Last year, all parties agreed it made sense to start Smoltz in the opener, since so much was made of his return to the starting rotation and him being the only remaining pitcher from the Braves' great rotations of the '90s. Also, the Braves wanted to take some pressure off Hudson, a Georgia-born, Alabama-raised pitcher who starred at Auburn and was the talk of baseball after being traded to Atlanta following the 2004 winter meetings. There was a lot of stuff going on for me last year, Hudson said. New team, the contract, new baby ... it was a whirlwind last year. Things really seem a lot more settled now. Meanwhile, the reality of his own mortality seems to have struck Smoltz, a former Cy Young Award winner who overcome four elbow surgeries and became the first elite pitcher to move from starter to closer and back to starter. He wants to keep going, at least long enough for another shot at the World Series, and Smoltz seems to be acknowledging that will require some concessions to his advancing age and medical history. Besides, he's started three times on opening day. Been there, done that, he said, then smiled and added, I don't care where I'm at [in the rotation], I just want to win my first start. I haven't done that very often. </P> 	nyt_eng_200602.gz
, he said,	 But, he said, I realized it was better to make them available to the world rather than to keep them under the mattress. He said he hoped the donation would not only inspire students and aid scholars but also help push more works hidden in dusty archives toward the light of day. </P> 	nyt_eng_200602.gz

, she said,	 Cox News Service DAYTON, Ohio -- For a scary moment there, it felt like 2004 all over again. USA Today listed Ohio among 16 states introducing legislation to ban gays and lesbians from adopting children -- part of a second front in the culture wars that began during the 2004 elections over same-sex marriage. Now that we've defined what marriage is, we need to take that further and say children deserve to be in that relationship, Greg Quinlan of Ohio's Pro-Family Network, a conservative Christian group, told USA Today. Well, gosh darn it, he's right. With such an overabundance of loving families waiting to adopt kids, shouldn't we make it as restrictive as possible? In a nation with more than 6,000 children waiting to be adopted, the notion is as absurd as it is hateful. House Bill 515, introduced Feb. 9 by Rep. Ron Hood, R-Ashville, would prohibit foster and adoptive children from being placed in the home of any gay, bisexual or transgender person. Fortunately, House Speaker Jon Husted, R-Kettering, stood up to the bullies in his party and said enough is enough. He killed the bill, refusing to refer it to committee. If other states try to capitalize on the issue, as they did with same-sex marriage in 2004, Husted believes the strategy will fail. This doesn't have the same legs, he said. Voters perceived that as being for traditional marriage; they'll see this as being against the child. The issue hit close to home, since Husted himself was adopted. I know how many children never get adopted, he said. They need people to love them and to nurture them. I don't want to restrict those opportunities, I want to expand them. Judy and Jim Husted adopted Jon as an infant and raised him on a 4,000-acre farm in Montpelier, Ohio. You can't pick your parents but I couldn't be more fortunate that they picked me, Husted said of his parents, now retired and living in South Carolina. And then my sister came along and I got to pick her -- or at least that's what my parents told me. Husted said he has received relatively little flak for his position and many supportive e-mails. Husted speaks from first-hand knowledge what it is like to be in that position, said Lori Richmond of Columbus, a gay mother raising her 1-year-old son with her partner, Elizabeth Hollenbaugh. Richmond said she was shocked and hurt when she learned about the bill. Adoptive parents prove themselves worthy of parenting over and over -- first to the social worker, then to prospective birth parents, then every month to the social worker again, before finally having a judge decide if they are suitable, she said. I believe that all of these people who know the person or people trying to adopt are much more qualified to determine if that person is suitable to adopt than a blanket ban on a select group of people. It is one thing to not like gays or lesbians, she said, but it is something entirely different to punish children because of it. Fortunately for Ohio's children, Jon Husted sees it the same way. </P> 	nyt_eng_200602.gz
, it seemed,	 It's a message about how we are using up our resources at an alarming rate. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20060228.0204 type=advis > <HEADLINE> SUNDAY-EARLY-BUDGET-NYT </HEADLINE> <TEXT> The New York Times News Service plans the following articles from its Arts &amp; Leisure and Travel sections for use Sunday, March 5, and thereafter.  If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For questions about photos, call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204. Sunday Financial articles are budgeted separately on Thursday, then incorporated, with updates, into Friday's final budget.  Arts &amp; Leisure articles move with an e code; Travel articles, t.  ARTS &amp; LEISURE  HUSBAND-WIFE-MUSICIANS (Undated) -- When the blues-rock singer and guitarist Susan Tedeschi considers her itinerary for a coming tour, she worries about more than venue size, motel rooms and the other things that might concern the average musician on the road. She also reads up on museums, zoos, aquariums and anything else that might appeal to the most important members of her entourage: her son, Charlie, who is almost 4, and daughter, Sophia, 1. And if the vagaries of scheduling and travel permit, somewhere along the way she might even work in a few days with the fourth member of the household: her husband, the guitarist Derek Trucks. There have been musical couples before them, from George Jones and Tammy Wynette to Bruce Springsteen and Patti Scialfa. But the most long-lived have tended to be professional partners, and often unequal ones. Trucks and Tedeschi are striving for a different model, maintaining separate careers with occasional intersections. By Jesse Fox Mayshark.  OSCARS (Undated) -- Sunday night, an expected 41 million Americans will tune into the 78th annual Academy Awards to watch a spectacle largely honoring films they have not seen and may never get around to watching. Much has been made about the smallness of most of the nominees for best picture, which usually refers to their modest budgets and absence of stars, but also rightly suggests an economy of ambition and scale. The received wisdom about the awards, especially outside Los Angeles, is that they are nothing but an orgy of self-love and self-advertisement, which of course they are. But they are also a useful barometer of mainstream American film culture, and they tell us something about how the movie industry sees itself and sees us, its increasingly fickle consumers. By Mahohla Dargis.  ARTIST-COLLECTIVES (Undated) -- Contemporary art is a multibillion-dollar global industry. But why does such a big deal look so small, so slight? There has to be another way to go, an alternative to a used-up alternative. By far the most interesting option so far, one that began to be news a few years ago and has increased its visibility since, is the work of miniature subcultures known as collectives. One way or another, joint production among parties of equal standing scrambles existing aesthetic formulas. It may undermine the cult of the artist as media star, dislodge the supremacy of the precious object and unsettle the economic structures that make the art world a mirror image of the inequities of American culture at large. In short, it confuses how we think about art and assign value to it. This can only be good. By Holland Cotter.  THEATER-ALBA (Undated) -- Bernarda Alba is the latest salvo in Michael John LaChiusa's campaign to repopulate musical theater. Jesse Green talks with LaChiusa.  TV-LOST (Undated) -- There is a grown-up love story unfolding on Lost, but it's often overshadowed by flashier hook-ups. Sure, Kate and Sawyer are hot. But for the teary-eyed pleasure of watching two characters in love falling apart and coming together again, it's hard to beat the South Korean husband-and-wife castaways, Sun and Jin Kwon. By Joyce Millman.  TV-SONS&amp;DAUGHTERS (Undated) -- Sons &amp; Daughters, which has its premiere on March 7, is no typical sitcom -- the performances and dialogue are largely improvised by the actors. The improvised format also makes for some intensive sessions in the editing room. That really is the final rewrite, director and star Fred Goss said. Basically the show is a puzzle: There are a lot of different ways to assemble it, and there is no one right way. By Neil Genzlinger. TRAVEL (t code)  TRAVEL-WINTER-SKI (Undated) -- From Colorado to British Columbia, a look at the best places for late-season skiing this year. By Michelle Higgins.  TRAVEL-SKI-TAOS (Undated) -- The 20-mile drive from the town of Taos to Taos Ski Valley in northeastern New Mexico is a stunning geographical contradiction. The road travels through vast red desert, past adobe houses and prickly pear cactuses, upward through the dense evergreens of the Carson National Forest, finally reaching a Bavarian-like village with the Sangre de Cristo Mountains -- blood-red at sunset -- rising to 13,000 feet overhead. The road ends where the lift line to Al's Run begins, a harrowing-looking bump run that must, in part, account for Taos's reputation as one of skiing's most daunting challenges. On this journey, the psychic distance is just as great as the physical one. In Taos, the spirituality is New Age; here in Taos Ski Valley village, it's all about the skiing. By Lisa Reed.  TRAVEL-SKI-CHAMONIX (Undated) -- Chamonix, a small resort town nestled 3,396 feet high in the Alps, has a long-standing, well-earned reputation as a center for hard-edged sports. After all, it was the birthplace of mountaineering in the late 1700s, and the site of the first Winter Olympics, in 1924. In 1988, a band of skiers that included Glen Plake, the mohawked bad boy of American skiing, upped the ante, creating the sport of extreme skiing by launching themselves (on skis, naturally) off the slopes, cliffs and even tramways around Chamonix, often while upside down and spiraling like a helicopter in a movie that has become a cult skiing classic, The Blizzard of Aahhhs. For skiers of much less than professional ability who don't have any desire to be upside down at any point whatsoever, Chamonix still provides plenty of opportunities to get the adrenaline flowing. By Heather Timmons.  TRAVEL-BUDGET-JACKSON (Undated) -- A budget weekend in Jackson Hole, Wyo., on $500. Matt Gross shows how it can be done.  TRAVEL-LAOS (Undated) -- Just four years ago, a stop in this tranquil town was de rigueur for drug-touring trekkers. Local weed and Burmese speed were sold openly on the street, and by some accounts the opium dens outnumbered the guesthouses. The backpackers flocked, and haughty fans of the writer Paul Theroux, whose travels are held up by purists as the right way to do it, announced that Vang Vieng was over. Then something interesting happened. Guesthouses began posting signs saying No Drugs and Please Keep Yourself Clean. Enough of the town's 45,000 residents, it seemed, refused to choke under the hazy smoke exhaled by scruffy budget travelers. The modest economy has since gone straight, attracting well-heeled tourists to counteract the dreadlock dudes. With development moving ahead -- six new guesthouses are opening this year, bringing the total to nearly 70 -- hotel operators and tour guides see a brighter future in inner-tube rentals than in opium dens. By Jeff Koyen.  Regular Features  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) -- Don't get lost. A guide to GPS devices. By David R. Kelly.  TRAVEL-BRIEFS (Undated) -- News and notes on travel.  TRAVEL-Q&amp;A (Undated) -- Travel question answered. By Roger Collis. SCI-FLA-PANTHERS (Ochopee, Fla.) -- A new federal report has announced the obvious: The Florida panther population must grow to survive -- ideally, to three separate populations of at least 240 each. But it is ever more desperate for space. The report, by the Fish and Wildlife Service, suggested moving some to Central Florida and on to Georgia and Arkansas. But there are no firm plans, and with the panther population still endangered but healthier than it has been in decades, South Florida is facing an equally thorny new question: what to do when panthers get too comfortable on human turf? By Abby Goodnough.  With photo and map.  SCI-PREGNANCY (Undated) -- A Harvard evolutionary biologist argues that a mother and her unborn child engage in an unconscious struggle over the nutrients she will provide it. His theory has been gaining support in recent years, as scientists examine the various ways pregnancy can go wrong. His theory also explains a baffling feature of developing fetuses: The copies of some genes are shut down, depending on which parent they come from. By Carl Zimmer.  With photo.  SCI-HAIRY-LOBSTERS (Undated) -- As lobsters go, this one is not very appetizing -- it's white, it's covered with hair, and if you ate it, it would probably taste like rotten eggs. But for the scientists who found it and named it, Kiwa hirsuta was a sweet discovery: It represents not just a new species or even a new genus, they say, but a family of animals previously unknown to science. A short by Cornelia Dean.  With photo.  SCI-Q&amp;A (Undated) -- A science question answered: Do any animals (besides humans) season or otherwise alter their food to make it taste better? By C. Claiborne Ray.  SCI-MUTTER-EARTH (Undated) -- A Conversation With feature on John Mutter, deputy director of Columbia's Earth Institute. He explores the idea that the hard sciences should be connected more closely with soft science, and perhaps solve the problems of global poverty. In most parts of the world, people depend on the earth for their livelihoods. If we can understand more how the earth functions, Mutter said, we can learn how it interacts with human well-being. By Claudia Dreifus.  With photo.  SCI-FRANKLIN-PRINCESS (Philadelphia) -- During the 300th anniversary of the birth of Ben Franklin, a Russian princess whom he met once is sharing his spotlight in an exhibit here. Both were scientific innovators, and she was the first woman to head an academy of science. The princess took over directorship of the decrepit Imperial Academy of Sciences in Russia and, though not a scientist herself, restored it to prominence and intellectual respectability. This came at a critical time in the history of science, its transformation from what was called natural philosophy, often practiced by gifted amateurs, to a professional enterprise. By John Noble Wilford.  SCI-MYSTIC-PHYSICS (Undated) -- When people start turning to physics for salvation, you can bet that either something very good or very bad is happening. Two years ago, the movie What the .$!%.. Do We Know!? argued that reality is just a mental construct that we can rearrange and improve, if we are enlightened or determined enough. Science and spirituality have tied the knot, and the world is your infinitely deformable apple. Now, its sequel is out. These films and the quantum mysticism industry behind them raise a disturbing question about the muddled intersection between science and culture. Do we have to indulge in bad physics to feel good? An essay by Dennis Overbye.  SCI-WATCH (Undated) -- News and notes on science. By Henry Fountain:  -- New analysis places new dates on the settlement of Easter Island, answering questions about why it took so long for Polynesian settlers to deforest it.  -- Deforestation of Sumatra and Borneo has led to a sharp decrease in populations of orangutans, the only great apes found outside Africa, new research shows.  -- The Magdalenian Girl, a 15,000-year-old nearly intact skeleton found in a rock shelter in southwestern France, has a secret: She's not a girl -- she's a woman. New research suggests she about 25 years old or 30, not 15. The newest findings are based on the discovery that her wisdom teeth were impacted.  With  SCI-YELLOWSTONE-GEYSERS (Undated) -- Scientists believe they have found an explanation for what happened in Yellowstone in 2002 and 2003. The Norris Geyser Basin, the hottest of the park's hot spots, grew hotter still. Several geysers erupted after having been quiet for years. Others erupted more frequently. Some grew so hot that the water boiled off and they became steam vents. Satellite photos suggest that an area near the basin rose up about an inch a year over five years. The uplift probably caused increased fracturing near the surface that would account for the unrest. A short by Henry Fountain.  With photo.  SCI-WANTING-TO-LIVE (Undated) -- A cases column: A psychiatric patient prone to leaving astonishing messages overnight on his psychiatrist's answering machine has an epiphany that may save his life. It's not evidence-based, but it may help him get his ominous cholesterol down to a tolerable level. By Elissa Ely, M.D.  SCI-NASAL-SPRAY (Undated) -- Relief provided by nasal spray decongestants like Afrin and Neo-Synephrine comes at a price: the risk of rebound congestion caused by overuse and, for some people, a vicious cycle of overuse and dependence that feels like an addiction. By Richard Saltus.  SCI-MED-STUDENTS (Undated) -- Does grilling medical students with questions make them into better doctors? For years, many professors routinely peppered students with relevant and arcane queries, often embarrassing them. Things may be gentler today, but the practice, referred to as the pimping of students, still has its advocates. By Barron H. Lerner, M.D.  SCI-REALLY (Undated) -- The claim: Heart attacks are more common on Monday. The facts: .... by Anahad O'Connor.  SCI-NORMAL-SLEEP (Undated) -- Disturbed sleep has to be one of the most common complaints in medicine. Not only patients but the general public seems to have a cherished notion of what constitutes a normal night's sleep: seven to eight blissful hours of uninterrupted slumber. The problem, it seems, is not so much with their sleep as it is with a common and mistaken notion about what constitutes a normal night's sleep. Research suggests that sleeping and waking patterns are normal and evolutionary. By Richard A. Friedman, M.D.  SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) -- News and notes on health and medicine. By Eric Nagourney:  -- Safety: Injuries from infant walkers have gone down significantly but are still enough of a problem that researchers say they should be banned.  -- Reactions: Is there such a thing as too much coffee? A new study suggests there may be. Volunteers asked to perform challenging mathematical problems while placed under stress did better when they drank the equivalent of two cups of coffee, but worse when they had four.  -- Aging: It is natural that many people slow down with age, and need to work harder to do the same things they did when they were younger. But it is not just a matter of aging, a new study suggests. Researchers have found that when many older people walk, for example, they do so less efficiently than younger people, using about a fifth more oxygen.  -- Practices: A new study of medical reporting on local television news programs, a major source of health information for Americans, has found much of the coverage wanting at best, and downright misleading at worst.  SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) -- The Personal Health column: The latest research findings won't change the healthful regimen of this columnist. She looks closely at the latest finding on nonfat diets and other regimens and concludes there's every reason to stay her course. By Jane E. Brody.  SCI-DEATH-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) -- Chasing Daylight: How My Forthcoming Death Transformed My Life, by Eugene O'Kelly. A chief executive learns of his imminent death and makes the most of his last 100 days. Reviewed by Cornelia Dean.  Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients. Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (212) 556-4204. , she says,	 Paglia (Sexual Personae) says she is restive with the current state of poetry - - I find too much work by the most acclaimed poets labored, affected, and verbose, intended not to communicate with the general audience but to impress their fellow poets. It's why she wrote this book, which was published last year and is new in paperback. It contains short essays on individual poems of her choice, by such writers as Walt Whitman, Emily Dickinson, William Butler Yeats, Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams, Theodore Roethke, Sylvia Plath, Robert Lowell, Gary Snyder and a few contemporary surprises. The latter include Joni Mitchell, whose Woodstock was the rousing anthem for the hippie counterculture, Paglia says, but is also an important modern poem. Critics found her comments fresh, challenging and accessible. Reading and rereading a poem, she says, should be an emotional experience. We feel (to quote singer Stevie Nicks) the hauntingly familiar, she writes. It's akin to addiction or to the euphoria of being in love. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20060313.0174 type=story > <HEADLINE> GOVERNMENT, INSURANCE COMPANIES SQUEEZING SMALL PHARMACIES </HEADLINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200603.gz
, she said,	 Cox News Service ATLANTA -- A jury begins deliberating today whether to impose the death sentence on convicted murderer James Sullivan or give him life in prison, with or without the possibility of parole. Sullivan, 64, was convicted Friday of paying a hit man $25,000 to kill his estranged wife, Lita McClinton Sullivan, 35, at her Buckhead townhouse 19 years ago. After arguments and testimony from prosecution and defense witnesses in the sentencing phase of the trial, the case went to the sequestered jury around 5 p.m. Monday, but the panel chose to defer deliberations until this morning. I have looked forward to this day for many years, the victim's mother, JoAnn McClinton, choking back tears, said in a series of victim impact statements by Lita Sullivan's relatives allowed under Georgia law. Should I forgive him? I cannot. Will I forgive him? I will not. Sullivan's younger brother, Frank Sullivan, was to court Monday prepared to testify, not for the defense, but for the prosecution. He was not allowed to take the witness stand, but outside the courtroom, Frank Sullivan read the statement he had prepared. It is a great shame I have to admit that James Sullivan is my brother, Frank Sullivan read. James' behavior is not a reflection of the household we came from. My parents lived for their children and created a comfortable, nurturing, happy home. He offered his sympathy to JoAnn and Emory McClinton and told reporters he would like to tell his older brother: For the first time in your life, stand up and tell the truth. Admit to the McClinton family what you did to their daughter. Do you have any idea the pain and suffering you brought to our parents and your children? James Sullivan's children are all young adults and do not speak to their father, his younger brother said. Defense attorney Josh Moore of the Capital Defender group tried to convince jurors that James Sullivan does not deserve the death penalty. This is not a death penalty case, Moore said. Lita Sullivan was a good person robbed of her life at an early time. She died of a single gunshot wound to the head. This is not a case where she was tortured or brutalized over days. ? This is not the worst of the worst. If he goes to prison, life for Jim Sullivan is concrete, razor wire and clanging steel bars, Moore said. Assistant District Attorney Kellie Hill said the facts of the murder fit all the aggravating circumstance required for imposition of the death penalty, including depravity of mind. You take a total stranger from the street and you pay him to put a bullet in her head. Now how depraved, how horrible, how inhuman can that be? Hill said Lita Sullivan lived for almost an hour after being shot. For agonizing minutes, She lay on the floor, bullets in her brain, gurgling and gasping for breath. She argued that the death penalty is the only appropriate option. [Defense attorneys] have asked you to give this defendant hope, at least the possibility of life with parole. ? This defendant has lived his parole for 19 years, Hill said. She said James Sullivan's day planner for nine days after Lita Sullivan was killed noted he was having champagne and caviar with Suki, the woman who became his third wife. He went on with his life for 19 years. ? He has lived in exotic places and luxurious surroundings. The McClintons, she said, have lived, enduring holidays and birthdays, without their beloved Lita. Defense attorney Don Samuel appealed to jurors for his client's life. The prosecution is appealing to your mind-set for retribution and revenge. I appeal to a different part of your being: the more noble part that involves mercy, Samuel said. Justice includes mercy and compassion and preservation at all costs of human life. Ed Garland, also representing James Sullivan, said, Whatever sentence you choose, he will die in one of the state prisons of Georgia. It is not necessary that you put poison into this man's veins. </P> 	nyt_eng_200603.gz
, he said,	 In 2003, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention , 31.6 percent of African-Americans had excessively high blood pressure, compared to 20.5 percent of whites; 3.5 percent had suffered a stroke, compared to 2.3 percent of whites; and 10.1 percent had diabetes, compared to 6.2 percent of whites. On Friday, the association opened a new $10 million headquarters and research center, named for the late Atlanta Mayor Maynard H. Jackson, on a 127-acre plot south of Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport, as part of a weekend science symposium designed to coincide with the American College of Cardiology meeting in downtown Atlanta. But in contrast to that 30,000-attendee meeting -- which focuses on treatment and through today will be releasing results of new drug trials -- the black cardiologists' group divides its attention between treating heart disease and the much more elusive goal of preventing it. Our people suffer so much from the ravages of cardiovascular disease, said Dr. B. Waine Kong, a psychologist and attorney who has been the association's chief executive officer since 1985. We could have the best doctors, the best hospitals, but they are never going to be as good as preventing the problem in the first place. Pursuing prevention, the association has brought its concern for African-Americans' high rates of heart disease, stroke, diabetes, obesity and kidney failure out of laboratories and doctors' offices and into the community. It pioneered a program, CHOICES (Changing Health Outcomes by Improving Cardiovascular Education &amp; Screenings ) that combines blood pressure, cholesterol and blood-sugar testing with a Bible-based health curriculum run out of churches in Phoenix, Chicago, Philadelphia, New York and southwest Mississippi. It supports a Center for Women's Health and created an anti-secondhand smoke campaign, active in Georgia, called Not in Mama's Kitchen. And it fields the REACH campaign, which supports 10 volunteers including Fuller on funds from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Fulton County Department of Health and Wellness. At lunchtime Monday, men trickled through the door of the Silver Star as Fuller unwound her blood-pressure cuff . Collier fretted that his customers -- her patients -- wouldn't find her. His barbershop, which occupied 181 Auburn Ave. for almost 60 years, was forced up the street a few weeks ago by the start of a $45 million redevelopment project, spearheaded by Big Bethel AME Church, that will rebuild his former block. Now it sits at the corner of Auburn and Jackson, across from Ebenezer Baptist Church and the Martin Luther King Jr. National Historic Site, under a small sign that says Grand Opening Coming Soon. At the old shop, we'd get quite a few guys waiting for her when she came, he said. But at least one of Fuller's patients tracked her down: Paul Thomas, the lone barber at the La Sisters' parlor next door. When he met Fuller a year ago in the Silver Star's old location, his blood pressure was 170/90, well into the danger zone. He had a prescription for medications, but he kept forgetting to take them. He felt fine. Fuller, he said, explained that he wasn't fine -- and coaxed and pleaded with him to do better. On Monday, her meter showed the results: 120/80, solidly normal. Fuller hugged him. Thomas grinned. I knew I was supposed to do better, but I didn't, he said. She set me straight. </P> 	nyt_eng_200603.gz
, he said,	 Cox News Service ATLANTA -- Toting around a crackling scanner might look positively archaic at the Atlanta Motor Speedway this weekend . Since January, NASCAR fans have been immersing themselves in up-to-date statistics and a variety of minutiae thanks to a nifty new handheld device. The black-and-yellow NASCAR Nextel FanView has become the must-have -- actually, must-rent -- gadget for fans attending a race. We've sold out of these each weekend, said Michael Robichaud, director of sponsorships for Sprint Nextel. Between video and audio replays and rich data, it's just a great combination. FanView rented out 3,500 units, which weigh less than a pound, at the recent Daytona 500. The upcoming Golden Corral 500 promises to offer almost 5,500. Among its capabilities: -- Eight video feeds, including seven in-car cameras. -- Real-time statistics on each driver. -- An audio replay feature that allows users to listen to the last three minutes of communications between a specific driver and crew (for instance, one can listen to the build-up to a crash). Make sure to budget for the privilege. The FanView rents for $50 a day or $70 for a race weekend and comes with a battery that lasts approximately five hours. Those who rent for the entire race weekend get a second battery, plus a charger to refuel for another day's action. For years and years the scanners would provide inside-the-helmet audio, said Andrew Giangola, director of business communications for NASCAR in New York. This is a next-generation scanner. You can watch the race in the grandstands at what the in-car camera views. NASCAR has always used technology to bring the sport closer to fans. Drivers, he said, are open and accessible to this intimate view. For rabid fans drooling at the chance to purchase one, Sprint Nextel is working toward making a consumer model available. So, do the applications of the FanView have promise for other sporting events? Eagle-eyed views of calls at tennis tournaments? Cameras sewn into baseball caps for up-close thrills from the mound? We're just launching and we don't want to get too far ahead of ourselves, Robichaud said. But we're open to thinking about it. </P> 	nyt_eng_200603.gz

, she said,	 The play opened on Broadway in March 1957 and drew mixed reviews, but Stapleton won raves in the lead role of Lady Torrance, Williams's gritty, sex-starved heroine. In 1959, she and Allentuck were divorced, and she began a relationship with the playwright David Rayfiel, whom she eventually married. , he explained,	 In addition, the organ exchanges are done at exactly the same time, requiring four surgical teams at two hospitals to simultaneously carry out a surgery that lasts more than four hours. For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.  INTERNATIONAL (i code)  IRAQ-MURDER (Dateline TK) -- Developments in the investigation of the rape-murder in Iraq and of the American who has been charged. (Byline TK)  IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Civilian deaths in June were about double the rate of a year ago, new figures from the Baghdad morgue show. Other developments, including the kidnapping of the Iraqi deputy electricity minister and 19 bodyguards. By Sabrina Tavernise.  MIDEAST (Gaza City, Gaza Strip) -- A deadline announced by Palestinian militants holding an Israeli soldier captive passes with no word on his fate. The Hamas prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Ismael Haniyeh, urges the captors not to kill him. By Greg Myre.  MEXICO-ELECT (Mexico City) -- Developments in tally of Mexico's presidential vote. The final results, expected Wednesday, may still take a few days to compute. The No. 3 candidate Roberto Madrazo of the once-dominant PRI, formally conceded on Tuesday. By James C. McKinley and Ginger Thompson.  WASHINGTON (w code)  IMMIG-CONGRESS (Washington) -- On the eve of nationwide hearings that could determine the fate of his immigration bill on Capitol Hill, President Bush is signaling a new willingness to negotiate with House Republicans in an attempt to revive the stalled legislation before Election Day. By Sheryl Gay Stolberg.  NATIONAL GENERAL (a code)  SHUTTLE (Cape Canaveral, Fla.) -- The space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to launch at 2:37 pm EDT, foam crack or not. By John Schwartz.  BUSH (Fort Bragg, N.C.) -- In a speech marking Independence Day, President Bush thanked American troops for their service in Iraq and elsewhere, saying that they were winning the war, but warning them that it was far from over. By Sheryl Gay Stolberg.  An early lede has moved.  NJ-FISCAL (Trenton, N.J.) -- Hoping to break a budget stalemate that has paralyzed New Jersey's state government, Gov. Jon S. Corzine told legislators summoned to a rare holiday session that they must accept a sales tax increase this year or face fiscal crises for years to come. But the Democrats who have opposed his plan in the Assembly appeared unmoved by his appeal during a rare joint-session of the legislature, and left the Statehouse without any plans to vote on a budget. The state's budget was due on Friday. On Saturday, Corzine began a phased shutdown of state government services that will take full effect on Wednesday, when state parks and Atlantic City's casinos will be forced to close, along with all non-essential government offices. By Richard G. Jones and Laura Mansnerus.  EDUCATION (a code)  EDUCATION-COLUMN (Lynchburg, Va.) -- Alone together, Matea Osti and Marwa Abdel Latif shared a piano bench at the Steinway grand, gift of the Class of 1940. It was a summer morning on a campus without a summer session, and the entry lobby of Main Hall at Randolph-Macon Woman's College sat nearly deserted. As the two young women put hands to keyboard for Fur Elise, a sole janitor passed behind them, vacuuming the Persian rugs. The two, both from lands torn by war, have become best friends on a campus that encourages foreign students. The weekly column, by Samuel G. Freedman.  FINANCIAL (f code)  COAL-FUEL (East Dubuque, Ill.) -- The coal in the ground in Illinois alone has more energy than all the oil in Saudi Arabia. The technology to turn that coal into fuel for cars, homes and factories is proven. And at current prices, that process could be at the vanguard of a big, new industry. Such promise has attracted entrepreneurs and government officials who want domestic substitutes for foreign oil. But there is one big catch. Producing such fuel from coal generates far more carbon dioxide, which contributes to global warming, than producing vehicle fuel from oil, or using ordinary natural gas. And the projects now moving forward have no incentive to reduce the CO2 emissions beyond the limited amount that can currently be sold for industrial use. By Matthew L. Wald.  SMILEY-FACE-WAR (Undated) -- In the battle of the smiley face, it's not just who smiled first that counts, but also where and how. Frown-inducing accusations have been flying in a trademark dispute between Wal-Mart Stores and a company owned by a French family over American commercial rights to the ubiquitous yellow symbol for happiness. Both parties say they expect victory when the Patent and Trademark Office rules on the case this summer. 28  LEONHARDT-COLUMN (Undated) -- David Leonhardt's weekly column. A few years back, a technology writer named John Battelle began talking about how the Internet had made it possible to predict the future. When people went to the home page of Google or Yahoo and entered a few words into a search engine, what they were really doing, he realized, was announcing their intentions. If somebody were to add up all this information, it would produce a pretty good notion of where the world was headed, of what was about to get hot and what was going out of style. It was a nice idea, but for most of us it was just an abstraction. A few weeks ago, Google took a big step toward changing this -- toward making the database of intentions visible to the world -- by creating a product called Google Trends. It allows you to check the relative popularity of absolutely any search term, to look at how it has changed over the last couple years and to see the cities where the term is most popular. And it's totally addictive.  ARABIC-MEDIA (undated) -- A media competition for minds and market share in the Middle East is evolving as a crowd of Western news organizations prepares to deliver headlines -- and geopolitical views -- in the language of the Koran. By Doreen Carvajal.  MICROSOFT-CAMPUS (Undated) -- In the midst of its biggest expansion in nearly a decade, Microsoft, the world's largest software company, has suddenly found itself with a major obstacle: not enough room to grow. The company, which houses more than 30,000 people on its sprawling campus in Redmond, Wash., wants to make room for up to 12,000 new bodies. It will spend $1 billion to expand its headquarters by more than one-third, or 3.1 million square feet, over the next three years. For a modest-sized real estate market like Seattle, those are staggering numbers. By Kristina Shevory. The Frisky Kitty's hang-up is basic real estate: location, location, location. Stripper clubs, which are prohibited from selling alcohol, cannot operate within 500 feet of many things, including residences. Within or beyond that distance -- depending on how it's measured -- are the Tarzana Courtyard Apartments, where a few dozen seniors live. It might seem odd that in the San Fernando Valley -- known to some as Porn Valley since it is home to most of the nation's pornography industry -- a politician would care so much about a nude club. , he says,	 As elaborate as Indian-American weddings can be, says Sorabh Kapoor, they're relatively modest compared to weddings in India, where ceremonies can go on for a week. The Kapoors are first-generation Indians who came to the area from New Delhi about 25 years ago. The Kapoor family returns often to India to visit, look for new dishes, and sometimes attend family weddings. My niece had 18 ceremonies, says the elder Kapoor. Here, he says, because of the number of weddings, the Hyatt is discussing putting in a tandoor so that the portable ones won't have to be rolled in under the hotel kitchen's exhaust fans. Last year, Bombay catered about 80 weddings, and the father and son expect to do more than 100 this year. They keep their prices below those of many other caterers - about $24 per guest for a casual buffet to $34 for a sit-down dinner. The events are also good advertisements for his restaurants, says Kapoor, who is thinking about buying a hotel in the western suburbs with his son. </P> 	nyt_eng_200607.gz

They are available to all NYT graphic clients via satellite on Associated Press GraphicsNet, and will be posted at nytimages.com and on Newscom. For retransmission of graphics from the AP, call the AP Service Desk at 212-621-7983.  Non-subscribers may make individual graphics purchases or get additional information by calling the NYT Photo/Graphics desk at (212) 556-4204 or (888) 603-1036 between noon and 10 p.m. ET.  ATTENTION EDITORS: Please check the Graphic Budget section on our Web site - nytimages.com - where you can find continuous updates of planned graphics.  FOREIGN  With story BC-MIDEAST-NYT  Israel on Wednesday suffered its worst casualties in southern Lebanon since the current conflict with Hezbollah started, as thousands of Israeli troops there fought house to house, and village to village, in an attempt to create a buffer zone that Israel hoped would be filled by a multinational peacekeeping force. Israeli officers on the border said there were thousands of soldiers in the south of the country engaged in very heavy fighting.  We plan MIDEAST--Update map 0727 -- 3 x size to be determined  Detailed look at border area where Israeli soldeirs killed. Inset of daily developments  With story BC-GEORGIA-UNREST-NYT  Georgian special forces pressed their attacks through the mountainous Kodori Gorge on Wednesday, trying to put down a rebellious militia whose leader had said he would no longer recognize the central government. , he continued,	 For further proof, read the address Rumsfeld gave to Pentagon workers on Sept. 10, 2001 -- a policy manifesto he regarded as sufficiently important, James Bamford reminds us in his book A Pretext to War, that it was disseminated to the press. , I think,	 Other Democrats said they think religion has permeated the political discussion like never before and accused Republicans of exploiting it as a political tool. I see it more now, I think, in the last election cycle and with some of the issues that are coming up in the Congress that are being supported by the evangelicals, said Hilda Solis, D-El Monte. I think Republicans spend a lot more funding and they manage to really target that population much more effectively than we have, she said. Political scientists said both views hold some truth. </P> 	nyt_eng_200609.gz
, he said,	 Most of what's been said in this area is based on quick observation and not long-term content analysis, said Jim Guth, a political science professor at Furman University in South Carolina who studies religion in politics. He noted there were no court challenges in 1954, when Congress inserted under God into the Pledge of Allegiance. And while President Bush's faith-based rhetoric is the subject of lengthy analysis, former President Franklin D. Roosevelt engaged in far more religious discussion. We tend to think that we noticed it, and this was yesterday, and so it must be a change from the past. That's not always the case, Guth said. Green agreed, noting the intense religious involvement against slavery leading up to the Civil War, the fierce debates over Darwinism during the Scopes trial of the 1920s and the fear that when John F. Kennedy ran for president he would take orders from the pope. The current political era, he said, isn't the most intense, but is more intense than many times. What's new is a division based on religiosity rather than affiliation, Green said. As European ethnic groups have assimilated into American society, many of the religious divisions that once defined them -- and by extension, their political identities -- also have dissolved, Green said. In its place, analysts agreed, is a division between two larger groups: those of Judeo-Christian denominations who are religious, and those who are not. At the same time, social and cultural issues that cut to the core of many religious beliefs -- such as abortion and gay marriage -- have soared to the top of the political agenda. Instead of having a division between religious traditions, what you tend to have is a difference between people who have a more traditional religiosity, whether they are Catholics or Protestants or Jews, and people who have less religiosity, Green said. As best as we can tell, this division between religiosity and secularity has never happened (before), he said. Mark Silk, head of the Leonard E. Greenberg Center for the Study of Religion at Trinity College, called it a pluralism of people of faith. When it comes to faith-based outreach, Silk said, the George W. Bush view of the world is 'us against them,' -- but the 'us' is fairly inclusive. While the impact the issue will have at the polls this fall remains to be seen, some are predicting that its influence will eventually wane. This intensity will continue, certainly through 2008, Green said. But if history is any guide, it will (go away) eventually. And it could just be because people are tired of fighting. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20060902.0216 type=story > <HEADLINE> AN ISLAND WHERE EVEN MILLIONS AREN'T ENOUGH </HEADLINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200609.gz

, it seems,	 Liberty faces enormous hurdles, chief among them the lingering doubts about the viability of large stretches of the drowned-out, predominantly black eastern half of the city, where Liberty's customers were concentrated and which is still largely in ruin. Liberty's success in helping black professionals and others settle the east established a large African-American homeownership class for the first time in the city's history. But that legacy, combined with the bank's backing of the city's small but growing ranks of black entrepreneurs, prompts concern among experts contemplating how well Liberty will fare if its carefully cultivated customers never return. Liberty's very success, it seems, presents the bank with its greatest challenge. </P> 	nyt_eng_200609.gz

, he tried,	 He might have been confident about the bank's prospects, but a large portion of his customer base still had no idea when they would move home, if ever. , he said,	 Yet Liberty's buffed-up bottom line can be deceiving. A widespread lack of housing in New Orleans, McDonald acknowledged, has meant that the bank has fewer employees than it needs. FOREIGN  With story BC-AFGHAN-NYT  When the Taliban fell, a southern provincial capital seemed like fertile ground for the United States-led effort to stabilize the country. For 30 years during the cold war, Americans carried out the largest development project in Afghanistan's history there. Afghans called this city Little America. Today, Little America is at the epicenter of a Taliban resurgence and explosion in drug cultivation.  We moved AFGHAN--Lashkar Gah map -- 21p6 x 3  Locator map. With story BC-BRAZIL-POLITICS-NYT  On the campaign trail with the leftist presidential candidate challenging Brazil's president, contending that he has abandoned his leftist roots. She has no chance of winning but is causing a major stir that could influence the outcome.  Of all the aristocratic white families who settled in this country, one is more famous than them all, the Delameres. But Thomas Cholmondeley, the scion of the family, is no longer here. He's in Kamiti maximum security prison awaiting trial in a murder case that is dividing Kenya -- his second killing in a year of a black Kenyan.  Last week, the California legislature decided that a statue of Thomas Starr King should be replaced in the National Hall of Statuary on Capitol Hill by one of a more modern Republican who shared a similar gift of gab: Ronald Reagan. The vote, which passed nearly unanimously just before the end of the state's legislative session on Thursday night, was hailed by state Senator Dennis Hollingsworth, its author, as a fitting nod to the Great Communicator.  Five years after the World Trade Center towers collapsed in a vortex of dust and ash, government officials have only recently begun to take a role in the care of many of the 40,000 responders and recovery workers who were made sick by toxins(as in mercury and asbestos) at ground zero. FINANCIAL  With story BC-AMERICAN-EAGLE-NYT  Fifteen years ago, as the head of men's and women's fashion at Abercrombie &amp; Fitch, husband and wife team Michele and Charles Martin decreed a new dress code for American teenagers, filled with baggy cargo pants, weather-beaten rugby jerseys and frayed, athletic T-shirts. Today, however, the Martins have a very different mission: to wean 30 year-olds off those clothes.  Soon after Specialist Michael Potocki was shot and killed in June, the soldiers in his platoon agreed on their goal for the months ahead: to survive and make it home alive. Survival may be the only thing the troops here agree on. The first death of a comrade in battle is always an emotional shock, and the views from the foxhole here are probably as varied as the 34 soldiers. Still, in this hostile stretch of western Iraq, some of the troops have begun to wonder if the presence of United States forces here is worth the cost in American lives. , he said,	 Which of the God models you follow is an accurate predictor of a number of factors, including race, political stances, even where you live, said Paul Froese, a Baylor sociologist who worked on the BISR project headed by Rodney Stark and Byron Johnson. For example, there is a strong gender differential in belief in God. Women, he said, tend toward the more engaged versions (types A and B), while men tend toward the less engaged and are more likely to be atheist. More than half the blacks in the study said they believe in the Authoritarian God. None surveyed said they were atheist. Lower-income and less-educated folk were more likely to worship god types A or B, while those with college degrees or earning more than $100,000 were more likely to believe in the Distant God or be atheists, the Baylor study concluded. Froese noted that the geography also seemed to correlate: Easterners disproportionately seem to believe in a Critical God; Southerners tend toward the Authoritarian God; Midwesterners worship the Benevolent God; and West Coast residents contemplate the Distant God. American Piety found also that God's anger alone (such as type C) does little to inspire religious participation. The authors suggest religion may most successfully motivate individuals through what it can offer them in spiritual intimacy and congregational connectivity rather than through demands backed by threats of divine punishment. Believers in an angry God tend to reject the idea that church and state are or can be separate, and are more likely to feel that one's religious faith is exclusively the correct path of righteousness. The belief that God is engaged in the world also is associated with higher expressions of religious involvement and commitment, the study found. Other findings in the expansive, newly released Baylor study: </P> 	nyt_eng_200609.gz
, he said,	 Executed in conjunction with the Gallup Organization, the national, random sampling of more than 1,700 English-speaking adults was conducted from October to December last year. The margin of error is plus or minus four percentage points. Through telephone surveys, or a 16-page form, participants answered almost 400 questions on spiritual beliefs and practices. Baylor researchers say it's the most comprehensive study of its kind in more than 40 years. Byron Johnson, professor of sociology and director of the Baylor Institute for Studies of Religion, says American Piety will change the way religion is studied in this country. This nation's beliefs and practices have not been probed in such detail since a 1960s study by Rodney Stark, then with the University of California at Berkeley. Stark now works for Baylor as BISR co-director with Johnson Johnson said analysis of the responses will offer a snapshot of American religious life in the early 21st century. Specifically, we examined the religious identities claimed by Americans, their experiences, activities, images of God, beliefs about heaven, views about the role of religion in politics, and even the consumption of religious goods, he said. Survey areas covered are tantalizing, including the war on terror; whether God truly favors one political party over another; the viewpoints of the faithful when it comes to paranormal matters such as horoscopes; and the impact of the bestselling novel The Da Vinci Code on believers. Getting agnostic and even atheist participation on Baylor's religion survey didn't seem to be a problem, he added. Although 10.8 percent did not claim any affiliation with any faith family or house of worship, only 5.2 percent of those surveyed declared themselves to be atheists. Bader said Baylor is only just beginning to mine the data for more insights into the American religious spectrum. When the next phase of the study is conducted in 2007, he said, he hopes not only to see how images of God have changed in the two-year interim, he also hopes to add other study modules as well. For example, he wants to probe racial and ethnic diversity, and gather more data on nondenominational worship. </P> 	nyt_eng_200609.gz

, he said,	 Tom Oyen, who is president of the Chimney Sweep Online (chimneysweeponline.com), a retailer of hearth products, said one option is a fireplace insert. With an insert, he said, the firebox sits inside the fireplace opening, with the front extending several inches out past the opening. To keep the insert's heat from being absorbed by the walls of the fireplace and eventually lost, the firebox is encased in a larger metal box (called a plenum) that is vented to the room. </P> 	nyt_eng_200611.gz
, he said,	 In most cases, he said, when installing an insert, it is also necessary to install a chimney liner. The standard fireplace chimney is going to be way too big to properly vent a wood stove, he said, adding that the liner is a flexible stainless steel tube about 6 inches in diameter. The liner is routed down the chimney and connected directly to the stove. A sealer plate at the top of the chimney covers the space between the liner and the chimney walls, thereby allowing for removal of the damper. </P> 	nyt_eng_200611.gz

, it appeared,	 Our waiter -- my notes are unclear, but I think his name was Luis -- had sad but kindly eyes, a pencil-thin moustache and a comb-over that consisted of three thin strands of hair and, it appeared, half a tube of Brylcream. He spoke not a word of English, and my attempt at Spanish was typically pathetic, so we communicated mostly by sign language. I pantomimed drawing a beer from a tap, and he brought me a large draft beer. It was trickier to request lime wedges to drizzle on my carne asada -- apparently this is not commonly done in Chile -- but when he finally deciphered my gestures he dashed off to the kitchen and brought back a bowl of them. </P> 	nyt_eng_200611.gz
, I nodded,	 It was a pleasant but hardly memorable evening. Yet when we walked in the next night, Luis spotted us from across the restaurant and hurried over to make sure we got a good table. He motioned as if he were pouring a draft beer, I nodded, and seconds later a frosty mug showed up at our table. Without my even asking, my carne asada arrived with a bowl of lime wedges. As he moved around the restaurant, Luis made eye contact with us every couple of minutes. All I had to do was raise an eyebrow and he was at our table. A glass of Sauvignon Blanc for Jeri, a little more of the Chilean equivalent of chimichurri sauce, another draft beer, the check -- I merely had to think it and Luis had it covered. </P> 	nyt_eng_200611.gz

The desk supervisor for the New York Times News Service is Mitch Keller, followed by Jesse Mayshark; phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: mikell@nytimes.com or mayshark@nytimes.com.  TOP  Lede story (1-col. hed):  IRAQ-BUSH (Washington) -- President Bush delivered a vote of confidence to Iraq's prime minister on Thursday and rejected calls to begin a drawdown of American forces in Iraq, pushing back on a decision by an independent bipartisan panel to call for a gradual withdrawal. But Bush may find that his firm insistence that he will not accept any timetable for withdrawing American troops will come up against a competing view taking hold here: that it is in the interests of both the United States and Iraq to reduce the American military presence there starting no later than the middle of next year. By John M. Broder and Sheryl Gay Stolberg.  With photos NYT 1-8.  (An early lede has moved. A writethru is scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in i news file.)  With a weave to:  IRAQ-BUSH-ASSESS (Washington) -- In the cacophony of competing plans about how to deal with Iraq, one reality now appears clear: Despite the Democrats' victory this month in an election viewed as a referendum on the war, the idea of a rapid American troop withdrawal is fast receding as a viable option. By David E. Sanger.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in i news file.)  Top right center (1-col. hed):  WVA-MEDICAID (Hamlin, W. Va.) -- No question, John Johnson is a doctor's nightmare. Speaking from the easy chair where he spends his days in a small wood house, his left trouser leg folded by a safety pin where a limb was lost to diabetes, Johnson lighted another cigarette. Johnson, 61, a former garbage man, goes to a clinic once a month for diabetes checkups and takes insulin. His bills are paid by taxpayers through Medicaid. When doctors urged him to mind his diet, he recalled, I told 'em I eat what I want to eat and the hell with 'em. But ignoring doctors' orders may exact a new price among West Virginia's Medicaid recipients, as the state begins a plan to reward responsible patients with significant extra benefits and -- as critics describe it-- to punish poor people who do not join weight-loss or anti-smoking programs by taking away important services. By Erik Eckholm.  AFRICA-SEX-ABUSE (Sambava, Madagascar) -- Even as Sub-Saharan Africa races to adopt many of the developed world's norms for children, from universal education to improved nutrition to limits on child labor, one taboo -- child sexual abuse -- remains stubbornly resistant to change. In much of the continent, child advocates say, perpetrators are shielded by the traditionally low status of girls, and a lingering view among many that sex with children, particularly by relatives, does not constitute a criminal offense. By Sharon LaFraniere.  REPUBS-GOVS-MCCAIN (Doral, Fla.) -- Sen. John McCain of Arizona turned up here on Thursday for a surprise stop at the Republican Governors Association -- the group headed by Mitt Romney, the Massachusetts governor who happens to be McCain's main rival for the Republican Party nomination in 2008. McCain's appearance here -- which included eight hours of nonstop meetings -- gave Romney a reminder that he cannot take the support of his fellow governors for granted. By Adam Nagourney.  PROSTATE-CANCER-TREAT (Undated) -- The nearly 240,000 men in the United States who will be diagnosed with prostate cancer this year have one more thing to worry about: Do their doctors have a big financial stake in choosing their treatments? Among several widely used treatments for prostate cancer, one stands out for its profit potential. The approach, a radiation therapy known as IMRT, can mean reimbursement of $47,000 or more a patient. Critics see a potential conflict of interest on the part of urologists, the specialists who typically help prostate patients choose a course of treatment. The critics say that urologists who can profit from IMRT may be less likely to recommend other proven approaches. Part of a series. By Stephanie Saul.  SPY-POISON (London) -- In the latest turn in the mystery surrounding Alexander Litvinenko, the former Russian spy who died of radiation poisoning here a week ago, the British government said on Thursday that radiation had been detected in 12 locations around London, and that it was likely to be found in more. By Sarah Lyall and Steven Lee Myers.  (Story has moved in i news file.)  CIVIL-DEFENSE-LOGO (Undated) -- The stark insignia of civil defense -- a C and D forming a red circle in a white triangle on a blue disk -- died on Thursday after a long eclipse. It was 67 years old and lived in the mind's eye of anyone who remembers air-raid drills, fallout shelters and metal drums filled with what had to be the stalest biscuits in the world. By David W. Dunlap.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in i news file.)  PARIS-FOR-SALE (Paris) -- For sale: history, with a view. France is selling dozens of historic properties in Paris and the provinces, using the proceeds to move government bureaucrats into less expensive properties and to help pay off the national debt. So far it has unloaded dozens of chateaux, villas and hotels particuliers, the stone mansions of the golden age of Paris. By Craig S. Smith.  (Story has moved in f news file.)  INSIDER-TRADING (Undated) -- Developments in an investigation of suspicious trading activity. By Gretchen Morgenson.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in i news file.)  ALVIN-AILEY (New York) -- The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is on a roll: a new building, lots of touring, more great dancers than ever and interesting new choreographic premieres this season. By John Rockwell.  (Story has moved in e news file.)  (Editors: Budgets and advisories are internal documents not for publication or redistribution outside of client news organizations. "174532"	"I"	"think"	" Ford's presidency marked a turning point away from the enormous economic and military strength the United States enjoyed after World War II, said Ellen Fitzpatrick, a University of New Hampshire historian, citing the limiting effects of the Vietnam War, Watergate, the first oil crisis, and more. The nation still struggles with redefining itself and its mission in the face of these realities. It's a very sobering set of problems that, I think, can really be traced to that period in history. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200612.gz"
